HEADLINE: For the Poles, Brimming Baskets and a Vote Too

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The new abundance in Poland is evident everywhere in the supermarket parking lot here.
Smoked salmon and delicate pastries are among the goodies Kristina Ostap, a 50-year-old dentist, tosses onto the back seat of her car. 
 As Kasha Ostojska heads for the store, her year-old daughter, Karolina, is looking cute in her imported fake crocodile shoes and faded denim overalls.
All around, shopping carts are being wheeled out of the Geant supermarket -- a French chain -- stuffed with fresh fish and meat, vegetables and brand-name mineral water.
Poland will hold parliamentary elections on Sunday, and as middle-class shoppers in the Warsaw suburb of Ursynow load their trunks for the weekend, they find it hard to deny the almost giddy rise in their living standards during the last four years under a Government of former Communists.
Nevertheless, surprisingly few of them will vote for the Democratic Left Alliance, as the revamped former Communists call themselves, even though the Alliance promises an even rosier future.
The fault lines in the election, which many consider a landmark, will be ideological, according to politicians, pollsters and ordinary voters. Whether you were or were not a Communist is a question that continues to haunt the Poles eight years after the collapse of the Berlin wall.
And because the question still dominates the political environment, the former Communists, despite the added advantage of a popular and youthful President, Aleksander Kwasniewski, are unlikely to command much more than one-quarter of the vote, according to recent polls.
A right-of-center populist coalition, grouped around the anti-Communist Solidarity trade union movement founded by Lech Walesa and now known as Solidarity Election Action, is also likely to command about one-quarter of the vote.
This will most probably leave as kingmaker Leszek Balcerowicz, the ascetic-looking architect of Poland's shock-therapy economic reforms and now the leader of the centrist free-market party, Freedom Union.
Mr. Balcerowicz is likely to be courted by both major parties as they struggle after Sunday's vote to form a government.
Mr. Balcerowicz's program, calling for faster privatization and completion of the economic reforms he started, is actually closer to that of the former Communists than to that of Solidarity, which is not anxious to complete the reform program it began five years ago.
But given Poland's current ideological divide, Mr. Balcerowicz cannot say so.
"We have to take into account the emotions of our voters," he said, as he completed a radio debate in Warsaw and headed by car to his election district in the coal mining area of Silesia.
Poland's foreign investors, many of them big American companies, say they hope that the former Communists, whom they see as more progressive on the economy, come in ahead of Solidarity.
Whatever the shape of the new Government, it will be taking over a Poland that in many ways looks far more like a country on the move than the much richer members of the European Union it hopes to join.
Poland is heading for its third year of about 6 percent economic growth. Unemployment, at slightly below 12 percent, has been steadily declining, and real incomes are rising. Car sales have grown at such a phenomenal rate that international manufacturers are racing to build plants.
Some of this success is expected to rub off on the former Communists, who in 1993 won 20 percent of the vote and formed a Government with the Peasant Party. This time the former Communists are likely to increase their vote by 6 or 7 percent, polls suggest, but not by enough to insure a place in the new Government.
"The public is happy with the economic growth but unhappy with the method of governing," said Wojciech Pawlak, the president of OBOP, a leading polling organization. "They feel there is political corruption."
For example, he said, voters look askance at the Alliance's appointments of party faithful to lead important public institutions, like television and radio. They object to state-run industries being run by former Communist apparatchiks. And they feel that the ballooning deficit in foreign trade is getting out of hand.
Back at the supermarket parking lot, Anna Cegiela, 44, a language professor at Warsaw University, said she could not trust the former Communists.
"I'm old enough to remember what they were like," she said. "And they want to appoint all their people to top posts."
As for Kasha Ostojska, she said her life was good; her husband runs a car-leasing company and they can afford what they want.
"But other people at state institutions are doing very poorly -- their standard of living went down," she added, nosing her shopping cart toward the supermarket entrance, with her daughter perched atop. "I'm not a Communist. I've never voted for the Democratic Alliance and never will."
But as Mrs. Ostap, the dentist, threw the last of her delicacies into the car, she said that she worries that there is too much discussion about the past.
"We have to go forward," she said.
In the last four years, she bought a new and better apartment and rented out her old one. Her daughter, Katarzyna, 24, recently graduated from business school and was hired by Philip Morris.
Mrs. Ostap said she would vote for the former Communists. "I've never been a supporter of the left wing, but I'm becoming one," she said as she drove off.
Whatever the outcome, many in Poland see the election as a final leg in the maturing of the democratic process here. It will be the third national election -- after a parliamentary election in 1993 and a presidential election in 1995 -- in which standard methods of Western electioneering have been used.
Television advertising, tracking polls, scrappy radio and television debates and exit polls are all routine now. And most important, the count is considered sound and the results are adhered to.
"This campaign has been much more civilized," said Mr. Pawlak, the pollster. "The debates are serious, there's no sign of the furious politics. You can even complain that it is too quiet in Poland."
This is the first election since 1989 in which Mr. Walesa, President from 1990 to 1995, is not a major player. Mr. Walesa has promised to launch a new political party after Sunday's vote.
But in another sign of Poland's new political maturity, it seems likely that Mr. Walesa -- the patron of Polish democracy, but unpredictable and hot-headed -- will be looking on from the sidelines.

Former Communists, revamped as the Democratic Left Alliance, have led the country to new prosperity and promised an even rosier future, but they were behind in polls before the vote. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh at Progress Crossroads

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
This is no ordinary mining machine and no ordinary building where scientists are tinkering with it.
The 25-foot-long machine, which can churn loose several tons of soft coal a day, is being rigged with a computer system so a single operator can drive it from above ground rather than a team of workers down below, reducing workers' exposure to the danger of the mines. 
 The building housing the machine, once a pipe and valve plant, was vacant for decades before the city bought it in 1994. Now renovated and leased to Carnegie Mellon University, it serves as a center for scientists developing robotic systems to operate vehicles and machinery.
"We can make any machine intelligent, from a car to a lawn mower," said R. Craig Coulter, a project scientist. Pointing to a harvester, he said, "We can run that with a cell phone." Oh, and by the way, Mr. Coulter predicted that robotic systems would generate annual sales of $40 billion within five years for the growing number of companies developing them.
Welcome to Pittsburgh as the 21st century approaches.
Long past its prime as the nation's leading steel producer, Pittsburgh is blooming all along the three rivers that converge at its heart. High technology, health services and banking have become the anchors of a steadily diversifying economy. Crime rates and real estate costs are among the lowest of any big city in the country, and the vacant lots and hulking shells of long-abandoned steel mills are being turned into parks, residential developments, manufacturing plants and technology centers.
Yet for all the progress of the post-industrial years, Pittsburgh is at a crossroads. The city and the surrounding 10 counties face a November referendum to finance several major projects that officials say could determine whether the city continues its path of improvement.
Despite the recent growth, the city's population has fallen to 360,000, a mighty drop from its peak of 676,000 in 1950. Allegheny County, which includes Pittsburgh and 129 smaller municipalities, dropped to 1.33 million in 1990 from 1.45 million in 1980.
Many graduates of Carnegie Mellon, the University of Pittsburgh and Duquesne University have sought careers elsewhere. And the outward flow of young brain power is fueling a common perception among the remaining residents that Pittsburgh has become a second-tier American city, too parochial to challenge more sophisticated places like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago at anything. The city's older population, especially, tends to view change suspiciously, even fearfully.
"Sometimes people here just don't have much confidence in themselves," said Frank Cahouet, chairman and chief executive of Mellon Bank, and that view is shared by many in the city's power structure. "They find it easier to say no than yes."
In November, voters in Pittsburgh, Allegheny County and nine surrounding counties will have their next chance to say yes or no on a new sales tax to finance development. Business and civic leaders say the choice could determine whether the city leaps or limps into the 21st century, while others warn that the tax would drive out still more residents while primarily benefiting the city's sports teams.
The referendum, known as the Regional Renaissance Initiative, proposes a half-cent sales tax increase that could generate as much as $700 million by the time it ends in seven years. Most of the money would be used in Pittsburgh for two downtown stadiums for the city's professional baseball and football teams, the Pirates and the Steelers; a major expansion of the convention center, and completion of the Cultural District of theaters and galleries.
Counties in which voters approve the measure would receive money for their own economic development projects. And only those in which the measure passed would share the revenue. Economists here predict that the tax would cost each working family member $35 to $45 a year and lead to $1 billion or more in new private investment for the region, if all 10 counties approved the measure.
But that appears unlikely. Public sentiment is running strongly against the measure, even in Allegheny County, despite the fact that the Pirates, a beloved team with a rich history of success, is threatening to leave Pittsburgh by 2001 if a new baseball stadium is not built. Since 1971, both of the city's professional teams have played in Three Rivers Stadium.
"This is critical," said Pittsburgh's Mayor, Tom Murphy, an ardent supporter of the referendum and a Democrat who is expected to breeze to re-election in November. "This would put us in a position to compete with many other cities. Tangibly, it could lead to several billion dollars of investment commitments. Intangibly, it takes Pittsburgh to another level of how we think about ourselves."
A $3 million advertising campaign to sell the referendum is aimed principally at voters who oppose a tax increase and those who say the measure would benefit only Pittsburgh, wealthy team owners and high-salaried athletes.
Larry Dunn, a Republican member of the Allegheny County Commission and its chairman until he was ousted last month, has led the opposition to the measure, arguing that Allegheny's sales tax of 7 percent, compared with the surrounding counties' 6 percent, is already helping to drive people out of the city.
But supporters of the referendum contend that such a narrow view not only threatens the economic base of the entire region, stanching job growth, but also reflects a "mill mentality" that lingers from the days of Big Steel, when paternalistic plant owners played major roles in solving the city's problems.
Many of Pittsburgh's older neighborhoods are still populated by the grown children of steelworkers who have followed family tradition by seeking work in the scores of smaller manufacturing plants, which have become the region's third-largest employer, after business services, which include the high-tech companies, and retail.
"There is no longer an industrialist climate here of Big Daddy or Momma taking care of you -- those days are over," said George L. Miles Jr., president and chief executive of WQED, the city's public television station. "If the tax doesn't go through, the region could start to go adrift."
Rick Stafford, executive director of the Allegheny Conference on Community Development, an organization of corporate executives that favors the referendum, put it more bluntly, saying: "There is no Plan B. Those who say there is one don't know what they're talking about."
Mayor Murphy and other leaders disagree with that assessment, saying that alternative financing for the sports stadiums and other downtown construction could be found if the tax measure failed. But they say the failure of the referendum would be a psychological blow to the region.
"It would not be a total disaster, but it would slow down momentum," said Thomas H. O'Brien, chairman and chief executive of PNC Bank, the largest financial services company in the city. "We would still grow but at a slower rate."
The downtown projects that would be financed by the new sales tax are viewed by supporters as important magnets to stem the loss of young people and attract new residents and businesses throughout the region.
For all the economic growth in the city, the downtown triangle, bordered by the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, is struggling to catch up with redeveloped neighborhoods as a place people want to go after 7 P.M. Referendum supporters say an expanded convention center, in particular, would attract new hotels, bars and restaurants, enhancing Pittsburgh's ability to compete for events that now go to cities of comparable size that have larger convention centers and more amenities.
That kind of growth would also complement the modernization occurring beyond downtown, much of it in Mr. Murphy's first term. Since 1994, the city has spent more than $200 million to buy unused properties, then leased or sold them to developers who have turned them into new businesses, housing and manufacturing plants.
Prominent examples include Washington's Landing, a small island in the Allegheny that was once home to the city's slaughterhouses but is now a 90-unit residential community and the Pittsburgh Technology Center, an office complex on the Monongahela built on the site of a former steel mill.
"The No. 1 problem we have," Mr. Murphy said, "is building a sense of confidence in ourselves that we can do anything. In that sense, the referendum is a metaphor for whether we believe in ourselves and whether we can take Pittsburgh to another level."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 145 words

HEADLINE: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students;
Bold Change at Chicago

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 17 Education page article on the closing of the University of Chicago's department of education effectively captures the different views of that decision and how it grew out of past developments in educational research here and elsewhere. 
 There is also a forward-looking perspective. The faculty at Chicago voted to close the department because they believed that it was not working well and alternatives had to be sought. It was not a decision to abandon educational research but to refocus it in the departments of sociology, economics, psychology and anthropology, where the most challenging and rigorous social science studies of education will be produced, as they have been here at Chicago over the past two decades.
 
RICHARD P. SALLER
Dean, Social Sciences Division
University of Chicago
Chicago, Sept. 18, 1997

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Cone Puts Yankees' Minds at Ease

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
Cito Gaston didn't intend the double meaning. He merely meant to deliver the highest of compliments.
"David Cone is a manager's off day," said Gaston, who managed Cone on the Toronto Blue Jays' 1992 world championship team. He meant that Cone is so low maintenance, he practically assures a manager a one-day-a-week vacation. If everything is right. 
 Yet Joe Torre -- Gaston's counterpart with the Yankees and Cone's present manager -- knows that things haven't been right for a while. Not since Cone was felled by shoulder tendinitis in a game against the Texas Rangers on Aug. 17.
Now Torre and the Yankees need for everything to be perfect again, with Cone leading the rotation, or else the entire organization is headed for a bunch of unwanted off days come October -- because the Yankees look so vulnerable in the rotation, because Andy Pettitte, the only other reliable starter, can't start every post-season game.
Which is why yesterday's game at Yankee Stadium was so important, not only for Cone's mental health but for that of the Yankees. After an agonizing absence of more than a month, Cone pitched again, so well that you could almost hear a whole organization exhale.
Cone didn't win; he was gone long before the Yankees stopped Gaston's Jays, 4-3, in 11 innings to clinch the American League wild-card berth at last.
But the fact that Cone, for a second straight season, battled back from injuries to be in position to pitch a game of such import was even more medicinal than the clincher.
Now he will have only one more start to tune up before possibly taking the ball in the first playoff game, which will probably be against Cleveland here on Sept. 30. And because the 34-year-old Cone is set to help along the Yankees' dream of a repeat world championship, Torre couldn't hide his delight.
"I couldn't be happier," said Torre, who fielded more questions about his star pitcher than about the second straight post-season he will enter with the club.
Such a post-season assignment for Cone was far from a given only a week ago. "I wasn't ready to give up, but I was worried, no doubt about it," Cone said after the relief of his 80-pitch effort.
The Blue Jays did pick at Cone for three runs, two of them earned, in five innings. And Cone allowed six hits, including two triples by the leadoff hitter, Shannon Stewart.
But he gave up no walks and had five strikeouts. More important, there were no obvious tweaks, twinges or looks of concern. Cone, obviously at ease physically, settled into a routine, with decreasing anxiety and increasing economy of effort. He opened with a 19-pitch first inning, followed by innings of 18, 15, 16 and 12.
Cone's final pitch, a slider, was good enough to strike out Carlos Garcia to end the fifth after Stewart's second triple. "Probably the best slider I threw," Cone said. "I was a little shaky early, but in the fourth and fifth I was much closer to normal. And the way I threw in the fourth and fifth, that was the most encouraging part about the game, not only for me but for my teammates."
Indeed, as Cone settled into his recognizable cruise control, one could just imagine Torre doing the same.
"He's just one of those guys you don't have to worry about every inning," said Gaston, a manager who has had the opportunity to compare Cone, Dave Stewart, Roger Clemens and Jimmy Key. "He's one of those guys who really knows what he is doing out there. Cone has so many different pitches, so many different ways to get you out. He's so professional, you just kind of sit back and relax when he's out there, because you know he's going to get the job done for you most of the time."
Torre, the lead tenor in the Yankee chorus that has sung Cone's praises for two seasons, can attest to everything Gaston said. He watched Cone overcome surgery for an aneurysm last season, almost single-handedly elevating the Yankees' level of intensity when he came back after missing four months to pitch a near no-hitter at Oakland. And he saw Cone get the victory in the division-clinching game against Milwaukee last Sept. 25.
The pitcher showed the Yankees what was needed to hold off the charging Baltimore Orioles in the American League East, going 3-1 last September. But he saved his most inspirational performance for the World Series, once again resuscitating the Yankees after they had lost the first two games at home against the Atlanta Braves. Cone was brilliant in Game 3, limiting the Braves to one run in six innings and sparking the first of four straight Yankee victories.
Now, Cone has fought another battle, pitting his guile and talent against an enemy not as frightening as an aneurysm but nonetheless potentially devastating to the Yankees' hope of repeating as world champions. The outcome may not be final; Cone says how his shoulder feels today will say a lot about his October.
Should Cone come all the way back, Gaston, for one, is convinced the pitcher who just keeps getting better will have more than a few big moments left.
"Believe me, he's still in charge out there," Gaston said. "It still burns brightly. You don't see it as much as you do with Roger; it's a quiet thing. But it's definitely there."
That's what Joe Torre must count on if he wants to take his off days one at a time next month, on days when David Cone has taken the ball.

HEADLINE: Rubin Warns of Asia Trade Backlash

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 20

 BODY:
With economic troubles in Southeast Asia and Japan and China's exports booming, Administration officials meeting with finance ministers from around the world said today that they feared the United States was headed toward a revival of huge trade deficits with Asia that could provoke a backlash in Congress.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin met with his Japanese counterpart, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, in a session that one Japanese official described as "quiet but very tense." Mr. Rubin urged him to make sure that Japan did not attempt to crawl out of its recession by boosting exports to the United States. 
 Yet Japanese executives concede that is already happening, and they say they have little choice now that their biggest market -- Southeast Asia -- is reeling from a summer-long currency crisis that is spreading to other nations.
"No one wants to admit it out loud," said one senior Japanese executive here for the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. "But now there is no place else that still has strong demand for Japanese goods except the U.S."
According to many estimates circulating here, Japan's surplus with the United States will exceed $65 billion this year, roughly a 20 percent increase from last year.
The sudden revival of trade deficits -- an issue on which President Clinton focused intently for the first three years of his presidency, then scarcely mentioned -- comes at a politically inopportune time for the White House. Mr. Clinton is battling in Congress for a renewal of his power to strike new trade accords around the world.
But he is running into strong opposition on both the Democratic left and the Republican right, much of it rooted in suspicions that American workers have gained far less from from the Administration's embrace of global competition than Mr. Clinton contends.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton is about to welcome China's President, Jiang Zimen, to the United States for the first state visit of a Chinese leader since before the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. With little progress to boast about on the human rights front, Mr. Clinton's aides had hoped to emphasize the foreign policy benefits of an expanding trade relationship with China.
That will now be difficult. Most American estimates now suggest that China's trade deficit with the United States will exceed $50 billion for the first time this year, making it nearly the size of Japan's.
Moreover, efforts to speed along negotiations to get China into the World Trade Organization -- which would require it to adopt rules that would further open the Chinese market -- have bogged down. Administration officials are now playing down the potential discussion of that subject at the Washington summit meeting.
"Wherever you look in Asia, America's trade numbers are about to go bonkers," said Kenneth Courtis, the global economist at Deutsche Bank in Tokyo. "And we are just beginning to see the political fallout."
Large trade deficits themselves are not necessarily bad news for the American economy. A steady stream of competitive imports helps keep inflation in check. America's soaring trade deficit numbers also reflect the fact that the United States has one of the healthiest economies in the world, while its trading partners are not growing fast enough to attract more imports.
But trade politics and trade economics are often two very different things. So today in his meeting with Mr. Mitsuzuka -- a longtime leader of the Liberal Democratic Party and a veteran of many trade disputes -- Mr. Rubin took the unusual step of inviting the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, to join him in arguing that Japan must act now to revive its economy.
Japan's usual response has been to launch major public works programs, but at one American official said recently, "There are only so many roads and train tracks you can build to nowhere. And they've built them.'
Mr. Rubin said later that he thought that his message had gotten through. "It is fair to say that they, too, are concerned about domestic demand and sustainable, solid growth," he said. But he stopped short of saying that he had urged Japan to cut taxes.
The trade problem has been exacerbated by the currency crisis in Southeast Asia. Those emerging markets have been a major customer for American exports. But Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia are now canceling major projects, including dams and airports, to trim their own large deficits.
They also have been forced to devalue their currencies, making their goods more competitive on world markets and American goods, priced in dollars, sharply more expensive. Equally important, Southeast Asia accounts for slightly less than half of Japan's exports, and some of those goods will undoubtedly be redirected to the United States.
In the currency markets, this has led to some speculation that the United States would attempt to weaken the dollar, to make American goods more attractive abroad.
But Mr. Rubin has given no hint of that and today at a meeting of finance ministers of the Group of Seven top industrial nations, there was a veiled warning to Japan not to try to drive down the yen to boost its own exports.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Here's One Way You Can Beat the Bursar

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Timothy Radle entered Ohio State University in 1994, his parents were not concerned about college tuition or how much it might climb while he was there.
For three years, they had been contributing money to Ohio's prepaid tuition plan, which helped them save for college and locked in the price of tuition even before their son became a freshman. 
 "This took much of the guesswork out of college tuition," said Donald Radle, Timothy's father. "For us this has worked out very well."
More and more states -- with New York, New Jersey and Connecticut among the most recent -- are joining Ohio in encouraging people to save for a college education. The New York plan was signed into law this month, but the details of how it will operate are still being worked out, state officials say. And when New York and other states finish devising their plans, they will market them aggressively.
One of the main types of state college savings programs is the prepaid tuition plan, which allows families to put up money before a child is ready for college, and to lock in the tuition in effect when they invest their money.
If tuition rises by the time the child goes to college, the money invested in the prepaid plans will rise a comparable amount.
If, for example, tuition costs $1,000 a semester when a family puts its money into a prepaid plan, but rises to $1,500 a semester when a student begins college, the prepaid plan will cover the full amount. If the family prepays less than the full amount, it may have to pay some tuition at the rate in effect when the student is in college.
Although the specifics vary, most states base their rates on the cost of tuition at public colleges or universities within those states, although they may allow families to spend the money at any college anywhere.
The other main type of program is a college savings plan, which allows families to invest their money in state-sponsored accounts whose earnings are sheltered from Federal taxes until used for college and are typically not subject to state taxes. In most of these programs, families are subject to the vagaries of the markets the money is invested in, which means that families have no guarantee that their money will grow as fast as tuition -- or at all, although it may also grow faster.
In both types of programs, the beneficiary college student typically is not expected to pay any taxes on the gain in value until the money is used for college, and then at the student's rate rather than the donor's.
Most states forgive the state taxes altogether. Most, but not all, specify that the beneficiary be a resident of the state, although the contributors do not need to be. And most states welcome contributions from anyone willing to make them, but some limit the size of contributions per beneficiary.
Before this year, fewer than a dozen states offered either plan, according to the College Savings Plans Network. Twenty-eight states, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Wisconsin and Indiana, have started programs this year or expect to have them running by next year.
"We've seen a huge surge of interest by states," said Katherine Tyson, a researcher for the National Association of State Treasurers.
Financial experts say these plans can be a bargain for families planning to send someone to college.
"With the escalating cost of college, this is the way to be able to afford it," said H. Carl McCall, the Comptroller of New York State. "Every person who thinks about being able to afford a college education for his or her child should think about it."
But some experts give the programs more mixed reviews as public policy because the tax breaks that make the savings plans attractive are likely to be less useful to lower-income families than to people in the upper tax brackets and because states with prepaid tuition plans could be forced to pay big bills if tuition prices shoot up.
"It could bring families some peace of mind," said Arthur Hauptman, a higher-education finance consultant in Washington. "But the fact that families can prepay tuition now and not face the risk of rising tuition suggests that states could have problems later."
IT is small wonder that states are leaping to start college savings programs. States pay a big portion of the cost of higher education, through direct subsidies to state colleges and financial aid. If families can pay more tuition themselves, the pressure on state treasuries may be reduced.
Paying for college is a big concern for many families, too. Although the average tuition for state residents at public four-year colleges and universities was only $2,681 a year in 1995 -- well below the $20,000-plus price tag at the Ivy League and many other private colleges -- that is still a burden for many families.
"I don't care whose poll you look at, it seems like this is on families' minds," said Barbara M. Jennings, executive director of the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority and chairwoman of the College Savings Plans Network, an affiliate of the National Association of State Treasurers.
A national survey in 1996 of 1,938 registered voters by Princeton Survey Research Associates for the Pew Research Center, for example, found that nearly two-thirds said they were very concerned or somewhat concerned about being unable to save enough money to put a child through college.
To deal with these concerns -- and with the growing number of state tuition plans -- Congress enacted rules governing state plans last year and expanded them this year. The new Federal regulations specifically allow for accounts to be used to pay for room and board as well as tuition and books. If the money in the account is used for anything other than higher education, it will be subject to a penalty. But the state tuition plans typically allow the money to be used for graduate school as well as college, and to be shifted from the intended beneficiary to relatives.
Separately this summer, Congress also created a new "education I.R.A.," which starts in 1998 and is modeled after the traditional I.R.A. While the money that is invested is not deductible for income-tax purposes, the earnings on the investments will not be taxed until the money is withdrawn to pay for college.
No more than $500 a year can be placed in the I.R.A. There are also income limitations on who may invest in an education I.R.A.; the program phases out for families earning $150,000 or more a year.
The new Federal legislation prompted many states without college savings plans to establish them. Each state is free to develop its own guidelines, subject to these Federal rules. The states can set limits on contributions, the penalties for using the money for something other than higher education, fees for managing these accounts and rules on who can contribute and whether the money can be used out of state or at private colleges.
The College Plan Savings Network offers information about tuition savings programs, what individual states do, and how to find more information at a clearinghouse on the Internet at www.collegesavings.org. The group can be reached by phone at (606) 244-8175. Other sources of information include the state treasurers' offices and financial advisers.
The newer programs tend to offer more flexibility than some older ones. Mr. McCall, the New York Comptroller, said the aim in designing the New York program was flexibility; while many of the specifics are not yet established by the state, he said he hoped to have the program in operation by next year.
Contributions of up to $5,000 a year will be allowed (though the state has not yet decided whether to apply the limit to each beneficiary or to each person contributing to such an account), up to a maximum of $100,000. Withdrawal for college will be allowed after three years.
Connecticut, which is starting a College Savings Program this fall, will allow people to invest as much money as they think college might cost and set up a college fund through local banks. Contributors will be allowed to choose the investment strategy they want, though the money will be managed for them, said Patrick O'Neil, communications director for Treasurer Paul J. Silvester.
Indiana, which is starting its savings plan program this week, is allowing people to contribute money through payroll deductions, automatic withdrawals from bank accounts, or through deposits by mail or in person. People will be allowed to deposit up to $9,100 each year, since that is currently the average tuition in Indiana. But the state is also allowing one-time lump-sum deposits of up to $25,000 for each account.
Joyce Brinkman, the Indiana Treasurer, acknowledges that the accounts, which will be in a balanced portfolio run by professional money managers, carry some risk if financial markets fall.
But, she said: "There is absolutely nothing you do that doesn't include risk. If you just go with a passbook savings account, the sure thing is that you are going to lose money because of inflation."
FINANCIAL advisers say parents and grandparents and others who are thinking of using the college accounts should look carefully at the rules within their states.
Whether the programs make sense for them may depend partly on their incomes. Tax advantages -- the deferral of Federal taxes and the deferral or forgiveness of state taxes on the earnings on the accounts -- are more valuable to people in higher tax brackets. People with lower incomes may be less able to save money and more concerned about being able to reach the money in a financial pinch.
Families should also determine whether the state rules are broad enough to accommodate a choice of college. Some programs, especially some of the earlier ones, are more restrictive, though many of the new ones allow the money to be used anywhere. New Jersey, which adopted legislation this month for college savings trust accounts, offers participants broad portability, but also provides $500 bonuses to state residents if they attend college in the state.
"The more flexible they are, the more people will participate," said Michael A. Olivas, a professor of law at the University of Houston, who has studied these plans.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 28, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about state plans for saving for college tuition misstated a rule governing the new Federal education I.R.A.'s. Provided the money is used for college expenses, earnings on these accounts will not be subject to Federal taxes when withdrawn.

Chart: "How a Plan Worked for One Family"
The Radle family decided in 1990 to use the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority's prepayment plan to save for their son Timothy's education at Ohio State University. Under the plan, the Radles bought credits periodically from 1990 to 1992 as their budget permitted.
 
Paying In
Timothy would need 400 credits for a four-year degree at Ohio State. His parents bought the credits over three school years, paying a price per credit based on the current tuition at Ohio State each year.
 
Drawing Out
Timothy enrolled in 1994 and used the prepaid credits to cover the costs of classes he took. Thanks to a scholarship, he will have some credits left over when he graduates next spring, which can be used for other family members' schooling or refunded. (A refund would be taxable.)
 
If the Radles had instead put the money in a taxable investment earning 8 percent a year on the same schedule, it would have yielded only $16,800 to spend on Timothy's schooling when he enrolled. (Source: National Association of State Treasurers (states' plans))

HEADLINE: The Lobbyist;
Is Richard Lipsky Battling for the Little Guy? Or Is He Just Gumming Up the Works

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
THE hallelujahs from City Hall and the State Capitol were almost audible. After years of bitter contention over whether to build a new Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, Mayor Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki were scheduled to break ground at the 125th Street site in late August.
But just days before the scheduled ceremony, a memo arrived in the Governor's office, warning that the East Harlem mid-sized supermarket owners who had fought the megastore were considering protesting at the groundbreaking. 
 With the potential for embarrassment looming, the Governor's people scrambled. They hastily arranged a meeting between some of the supermarket owners; Joseph Del Sindaco, the chief operating officer of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic arm; and the East Harlem merchants' longtime lobbyist, Richard J. Lipsky. Mr. Lipsky had made a name, and quite a few enemies, fighting Pathmark like a pit bull. He had also written the memo.
In the meeting, according to several participants, the store owners reiterated demands that they be given equal access to low-interest capital and to proposed megastore sites. Mr. Del Sindaco asked for more specific proposals and made assurances they would be taken seriously. The results were perhaps symbolic -- a place at the table when future developments particularly a site at 145th Street, are discussed -- but that was enough. "The store owners were satisfied that the Governor was making a commitment to help them," Mr. Lipsky said.
A few days later, the Pathmark groundbreaking was held -- without protests. The maneuver -- a friendly heads-up hinting at hardball -- was classic Lipsky: bring the fear of God into politicians by demonstrating the reality, or creating the illusion, of community opposition. In a political culture saturated with paid advocates, that tactic sets Mr. Lipsky apart: while he does traditional lobbying in City Hall, and while he greases palms -- legally -- with campaign contributions, much of his work involves bringing the people into the process. It is an approach getting a frequent workout, to judge by how often the lobbyist is surfacing, Zelig-like, in neighborhood development battles across the city.
In Mr. Lipsky, Howard J. Rubenstein, the public relations executive, meets the late Saul Alinsky, the radical community organizer. "Elected officials talk about the democratic process, and make a big deal about people participating," he said. "But they would rather people just participate by voting and leave the serious business of governing to elected officials."
But Mr. Lipsky's critics say he is more demagogue than democrat, that he churns tensions by distorting facts and appealing to ethnic rivalries. They say he fans the fires of fear to create smoke that obscures the issue at hand. That issue, they say, is always open to negotiation. "He'll work for whoever pays him," said Kathy Goldman, the founder of the Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit group that supported the Pathmark. "I don't know where principle ends and expedience starts when you do that."
This is the conundrum of Richard Lipsky: As a hired gun with a grass-roots bent, is he giving a voice to those ignored by a system that favors the monied and powerful -- or is he gumming up the works?
That question will keep arising, because Pathmark redux is playing in neighborhoods across New York. Arguing that suburban superstores are draining city dollars, Mayor Giuliani has made plain his affinity for megastore developers. The number of such stores is growing, despite the city's labrynthine zoning laws and protracted approval processes. The Mayor wants to change the scale of the city, but many residents and small businessmen do not. The merchants fear the competition; the residents fear traffic, pollution and the corrosion of their neighborhoods' characters. So the heat in local politics is increasingly generated by clashes between communities, developers and politicians over Pathmarks, Home Depots and other large chains. Enter Mr. Lipsky, who pays many of his bills with that heat.
Mr. Lipsky has become the champion of small merchants threatened by the spread of "mega" -- megastores, megamalls, pro-mega zoning. His record in stopping megastore developments is mixed, but no one denies his skill at delaying them.
 
The Profitable Niche of a Gadfly
 Given lobbyists' reputations as the handmaidens of the powerful, the notion of a populist lobbyist may seem a contradiction in terms. But in some ways, that is just what Mr. Lipsky is: he harnesses community sentiment to champion the interests of small businesses and homeowners -- New York's middle class -- against corporate and political power.
"What comes out of the 1960's for me is skepticism concerning government," said Mr. Lipsky, 50, who grew up in a liberal Upper West Side home. "Government needs gadflies."
Being a gadfly has become a profitable niche for the former political science professor, who made the transition from studying the system to maneuvering it in 1981, when he was hired to head a labor-industry coalition fighting a bottle bill. (He lost.) Last year he took home over $200,000 in lobbying fees, plus more for public relations work.
Mr. Lipsky has not built his career on charisma. He looks unremarkable: flat brown hair; a graying mustache; plain, well-pressed dark suits and white shirts; undistinguished features.
But when he opens his mouth, it becomes apparent that Mr. Lipsky, the son of a theatrical press agent, has the gift of gab, and it keeps on giving. To spend time with him is to alternately endure and enjoy a virtually uninterrupted stream of strategy, spin, political theory, moral and legal argument, and analysis -- of self and others -- spiced with the occasional Yiddish phrase. He will segue from a sports analogy -- "The people get emotionally invested in who wins and loses, but at the end of the game, someone else is counting the receipts" -- to arguing that Machiavelli was misunderstood, too: "He wrote 'The Prince' to educate people how policy works, and it got him a bad rap."
Mr. Lipsky's verbosity occasionally misfires. The City Planning Commissioner, Joseph B. Rose, hasn't spoken to the lobbyist since he told a newspaper columnist that Mr. Rose shouldn't oversee city planning because his father is a major New York City developer -- a major faux pas, since so much of Mr. Lipsky's work is in Mr. Rose's orbit.
But more often, Mr. Lipsky's way with words works well. Whether in public meetings or political or press tete-a-tetes, he is persuasive -- "articulate" is the adjective used second most often to describe him. ("Persistent" is the first.)
Mr. Lipsky opens doors the traditional way: he occasionally gives contributions, but more often bundles them for his clients. He estimates that the small businesses he represents gave anywhere from $150,000 to $200,000 to the City Council over the four-year rezoning fight, helping to insure his access to the Council. The Governor returns his calls because Mr. Lipsky supported his underdog campaign for State Senate in 1992. (The Mayor most definitely does not take his calls: the two are on opposite sides of almost every issue.)
But a good lobbyist has something to offer, as well as something he wants, when he gets inside. Mr. Lipsky offers information -- a lot of it.
"He has more expertise on the zoning system than I do and I'm a lawyer and he's not," said Howard Tisch, president of the Metropolitan Food Council, an association of 800 independent supermarkets.
June Eisland, the chairwoman of the council's Land Use Committee, a key figure in megastore fights, said, "He backs up conversations with a paper trail, so there's something you can read and remember."
Mr. Lipsky takes a similar approach with the news media. The press is his megaphone, and he understands the importance of being useful to reporters. "He is always filled with facts, figures, numbers" and story ideas and angles, said Philip Lentz, the editor of The Crain's Insider, a daily faxed newsletter on "government action of importance to business" that is watched closely by political and business people.
Over the last few years, Mr. Lipsky has begun taking his knowledge, his sophistication, to a novel audience, offering it free to grass-roots groups and neighborhood associations around the city. Midway through the four-year fight against the Mayor's plan to rezone the city to allow megastores up to 200,000 square feet in manufacturing zones, for example, Mr. Lipsky began contacting community groups opposed to the legislation and offering to help.
"He had information we needed when we needed it," recalled Patricia Dolan, the vice-president of the Queens Civic Congress, a grass-roots group. He would, for example, provide her group with environmental information he had extracted from a recalcitrant City Planning Commission. He would advise community groups when to speak out, and get them press coverage when they did.
To say Mr. Lipsky was motivated by altruism would be a stretch. He openly concedes that he shifted to rallying community opposition to the proposal when he realized that the concerns of his patrons -- small businesses -- were no longer moving policy makers. Allying with grass-roots advocates allows him to make his clients' private cause a matter of the public's interest. "For small businesses," he said, "the only way to get political and press attention is to get the community involved."
Mr. Lipsky cannot be credited with stopping the rezoning proposal; it died last December, when the Mayor and the Council failed to agree on what new powers to give the Council in return for those it would abdicate under the Mayor's plan.
But in the final weeks of the fight, Mr. Lipsky seemed omnipresent at City Hall, reminding Council members that they would lose one of the few powers granted to them by the City Charter if they gave up the right to approve megastores. And just as community opposition gave him cover, he said, it gave the Council a less self-interested reason to vote down the proposal.
Now he is using the same strategy for the city's small garbage haulers, who feel threatened by the Mayor's war against the mobsters among them and by his affection for garbage-hauling giants. Mr. Lipsky has graciously offered his assistance to a Brooklyn community group, Neighbors Against Garbage, which is fighting an attempt by USA Waste to expand a waste transfer station in Williamsburg. His hope, he said, is to inspire the group to pressure public officials to give "the big guys" like USA Waste and Waste Management of New York the same scrutiny his clients have received.
Mr. Lipsky's supporters say he is giving communities the courage and know-how to take on the fat cats and the politicos who genuflect before them. But those who have been on the opposing side of Mr. Lipsky's community work describe it as disingenuous and polarizing. Mr. Lipksy is definitely a graduate of the "you can't make an omelet without breaking eggs" school of lobbying, and on occasion, he seems to have poorly chosen which eggs to break.
In the East Harlem battle, he has been charged with using race as an issue. "He was particularly skillful in recognizing that the developers were African-American and the principal store owners were Hispanic," said Karen Phillips, the chief executive of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, a partner in the Pathmark project. "He used that very wisely as a divisive tool and a scare tactic. He made them think we were invading the neighborhood and putting them out of business."
In fact, much of the focus on race came from Councilman Antonio Pagan, who vociferously opposed the East Harlem Pathmark, although it is not in his district. But Mr. Pagan and Mr. Lipsky are close allies, and Mr. Lipsky, who is white, has trafficked in ethnic politics before: when he was representing independent beer distributors against Anheuser-Busch, he accused the beer behemoth of being anti-Hispanic, because many of his clients were Puerto Rican.
Mr. Lipsky's tactics in East Harlem helped cost him at least one client, Krasdale Foods, the large wholesaler that supplies many small stores and covertly financed Mr. Lipsky's campaign against the megastore proposal. "To make it into African-American versus Hispanic -- we wanted no part of that," said Krasdale's general counsel, Raymond Thek, who also cited Mr. Lipsky's reputation as an obstructionist as a reason for the parting of ways.
While saying charges that he is a racial polarizer sting, Mr. Lipsky continued to invoke notions of ethnic solidarity this summer as he tried to defeat Councilman Guillermo Linares of Washington Heights, whose last-minute switch to support the Pathmark project enabled its advancement and earned Mr. Lipsky's undying enmity.
"I do not think an African-American would do that to his own people," the lobbyist said of Mr. Linares, New York City's first Dominican-American elected official. "If we can defeat him, it sends a powerful message that there is a price to be paid for going against your own people."
Mr. Lipsky spared no chance to deride Mr. Linares to anyone who would listen. Just before the Sept. 9 Democratic primary, he publicized and joined a rally by Hispanic merchants outside the Councilman's Bronx office. "It was fun," he gloated afterward. "We boxed him into his office."
Six days later, Guillermo Linares won re-election resoundingly, beating Mr. Lipsky's candidate, Roberto Lizardo, by a margin of 64 percent of the vote to 27 percent, and leaving Mr. Lipsky with a powerful, entrenched enemy on the Council. Mr. Linares called Mr. Lipsky a "paid hack, paid by interests that have little respect and regard for the common interest of our community" and "the epitome of the worst kind of lobbyist you can hope to encounter."
Mr. Linares's victory suggests that East Harlem seemed to want to reward, not rebuke, the Councilman for supporting Pathmark, which in turn suggests that perhaps Mr. Lipsky was wrong when he said the community did not need a new supermarket. That, critics say, is the danger when a paid protagonist pretends to represent a community's interests.
But even his electoral defeat by proxy has not slowed Mr. Lipsky's ethnic politicking. In the ever-changing constellation of organizations and associations that Mr. Lipsky represents and heads, there is now the Puerto Rican-Asian-Hispanic Development Corporation, an economic development initiative aimed at mid-sized supermarket owners and the food industry. Mr. Lipsky is president and executive director.
The corporation's name already has raised eyebrows. Some state economic development officials call it a poor choice, showing Mr. Lipsky's insensitivity.
But if state officials find Mr. Lipsky's approachrepugnant, they have an odd way of showing it: they have agreed to give the corporation $150,000 for training and a study on the needs of mid-sized supermarkets.
The grant shows that persistence pays off. Indeed, critics, clients, community organizers and politicians agree that he is a formidable lobbyist. "I think Richard Lipsky is one of the best lobbyists in the city of New York," Ms. Phillips of the Abyssinian Development Corporation said.
 
A Storeowner Watches A Dream Die
 But even Mr. Lipsky's tenaciousness may not be able to halt the inexorable march of mega. The City Council is now readying a modified version of the Mayor's rezoning proposal and residents may dislike the prospect of megastores, but they do not seem to dislike shopping at them.
On McDonald Avenue in Borough Park, shoppers are streaming to a new 65,000-square-foot Shop Rite, while down the street, Edward Young Lee is watching his dream drain away. In the three weeks since Shop Rite opened, the Korean immigrant's much smaller Met Food store, built on 20 years of saving, has lost 75 percent of its business. "Shop Rite are murderers without a gun," he said, his eyes filling with tears.
Mr. Lipsky argues he does not want to protect store owners like Mr. Lee from competition: he simply wants to level the playing field. He said Shop Rite had bypassed community review, then obtained a temporary certificate of occupancy despite a Department of Buildings ruling that it was violating zoning regulations. Mr. Lipsky claims Councilman Noach Dear intervened with the Department of Buildings, to which Mr. Dear responds: "I've been a big advocate for that Shop Rite. All I did is show my support; whatever the city interprets that support to mean is their decision."
What it means for Mr. Lipsky is an uphill battle. He has organized protests by merchants outside the Shop Rite, and called for Council hearings about the store, but neither politicians nor residents are biting. Shop Rite, it appears, is there to stay.
The coming weeks will tell whether Mr. Lee hangs on, but it seems certain Mr. Lipsky will, continuing the often lonely, troll for business that the lobbying life demands. Mr. Lipsky is well aware that his relationships are built not on love and loyalty, but on usefulness. "No one is going to pay just for the pleasure of watching me irritate everybody," he said.
And so while Mr. Lipsky believes in defending little against big, the underdog against the insider, he is, first, a businessman. If the ship of small sinks in New York, it is unlikely he will go down with it. Would he work for a megachain like Pathmark (as he once offered to do for Fairway Market)?
"I'll remain pure until I face that moral dilemma," the lobbyist answered. "They haven't asked."

"PRESSURE AND POLITICS -- A Lobbyist and His Battles"
A Partial List of Mr. Lipsky's Lobbying and Public Relations Clients
 
CLIENT: Small Business Congress
ISSUES: Besides fighting megastores, such as the Shop-Rite on McDonald Avenue, Mr. Lipsky works on regulatory reform for the Congress, a coalition of small business associations. That includes issues such as challenging the tobacco advertising ban, which he argues affects small stores disproportionately, and fighting for fairness in the levying of fines on small businesses.
 
CLIENT: Neighborhood Small Business Association:
ISSUES: Mr. Lipsky is the executive director of this 70-member group, which is devoted exclusively to megastore policy and specific megastore fights. Under its auspices, Mr. Lipsky is helping community groups fight the 17-megastore Brooklyn Junction mall that the developer Charles Katz wants to build in Bay Ridge.
 
CLIENT: United Food and Commercial Workers
ISSUE: The union hired Mr. Lipsky to increase its political profile, and to help it fight -- or at least water down -- City Council legislation to curb mob influence at the city's public markets. At Mr. Lipsky's advice, the union secured the support -- and political clout -- of the AFL-CIO's Central Labor Council to fight the bill, and got union members to make their presence known in council members' districts. The bill was modified, but now Mr. Lipsky is helping the union fight regulations for the markets that it claims are more punitive than the legislation agreed to.
 
CLIENT: Sanitation and Recycling Industry
ISSUE: Mr. Lipsky is doing public relations work for this association of small garbage haulers, who feel that the Mayor is trying to squeeze them out of the industry to make way for national corporations such as Waste Management Inc. Mr. Lipsky's task is to try to get "more balanced press coverage on trade waste issues."
 
CLIENT: Ambassador Ambulance Co.
ISSUE: Mr. Lipsky went to the governor and the media to pressure the Regional Emergency Medical Services Council to grant a license to Ambassador, after it had been twice denied. He also helped the company get a New York City license to operate.
 
CLIENT: Jetro Cash & Carry
ISSUE: Among other things, this food wholesaler hired Mr. Lipsky to protest a provision in the changeover to electronic food stamps. As first proposed, the state plans would have required the mom-and-pop stores and bodegas to purchase the equipment needed for electronic benefits transfers. Arguing that that would be unduly burdensome, Mr. Lipsky succeeded in getting the equipment provided as a right; the plan is now being challenged in court for other reasons. (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
'You Can't Take It With You,' Featuring Hippies

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

CALIFORNIA'S OVER
By Louis B. Jones
329 pages. Pantheon. $24.
 "All this was 1973," reports the narrator of Louis B. Jones's psychedelically tragicomic new novel, "California's Over," about the disintegration of a hippie family living at the Pacific edge of Marin County.
The narrator, a 17-year-old idealist who has taken the peculiar name of Baelthon "in a literary impulse," is recalling a brief interval when he hired himself out to help dismantle everything in the incredibly cluttered house belonging to the Farmicans. 
 "Everything?" Baelthon asks Julia, the sexy mother of the house, whose husband, the poet James Farmican, author of "The Green Conquistador," "Anabasis" and "Begin Here," has recently shot himself.
"Everything," replies Julia, "the whole house, all four stories. Seven days from now, there will be absolutely nothing. We're moving to Oregon."
"You're moving?"
"Everybody knows California's over."
The Farmicans are like the characters in the play "You Can't Take It With You" gone to pot and other mind-bending substances. Nineteen-year-old Peter, determined to match the supposed fame of his father, is writing an opera about the cannibalism at Donner Pass. ("And the members of the Donner Family would stagger over the set in bloody rags, delivering his poetry as songs, while swinging a severed leg or an elbow joint.")
Sixteen-year-old Wendy is obsessed with burying the ashes of her father, which she has found in a box labeled "McGuffin," the name of the funeral parlor, and switched to an empty Tang jar for safekeeping. Their mother, Julia, has taken up with Faro Ness, a rich Ivy League-educated psychotherapist who plans to start a community in Oregon that transcends materialism.
"This was a time, and a place, when people's motives for doing things weren't economic," remarks Baelthon, whose real name turns out to be Steve and who is trying to overcome his origins as an ordinary person from Kaseburg, Wisc.
Except that it isn't such a time at all. Once again, as he did in his highly entertaining two previous novels, "Ordinary Money" and "Particles and Luck," Mr. Jones is exploring the paradoxes of American culture, where commercialism so often underlies idealism and vice versa.
On the same day that Baelthon shows up at the Farmican house, so does a 24-year-old man formerly named Ed Pease who has recently learned he is really a Farmican. "It's you," says Julia, his mother, when Ed arrives. "How marvelous, I can't believe it." As she explains to Peter about his long-lost older brother: "Your father and I abandoned him back in the bad old days, when I was just too self-centered and wild and I would have made a terrible mother anyway I was such a slut. But now he's forgiven us! He's come back to us! This is Edward! Edward, Male, Live birth!"
The reason Ed has returned is that he has received a letter from a lawyer promising him that he has inherited one-third of a Nevada gambling casino called the Cornucopia that the late James Farmican won in a poker game. Ed is determined to find the Cornucopia and get it running again. He wants Peter and Wendy to join him. Faro, Julia's lover, opposes this plan because he would prefer them all to help him pull off the tax scam that underlies his Oregon commune.
Mr. Jones is good at painting these characters with his looping prose. Of Faro Ness he writes: "His huge complex of family businesses, and the meshing of its gears with other gears, which in turn meshed with the distant machinery of an axiomatic foreign war, was operated and lubricated by lawyers, so he remained obviously free to lead the life of an intellectual, hands in pockets, his benign teacherly stoop, fern-like, defining the base-curve of a greater arc of protectiveness. He was decently ashamed of all his wealth, and then even subversive of it."
Yet it's often hard to tell whether the author is affectionately kidding his characters or savagely skewering them. Whatever his intentions, the people in the novel come off varyingly repugnant. Julia is a parody of permissiveness. Faro tries to seduce Wendy with her tacit encouragement. Peter becomes a cocaine and gambling addict. And Baelthon winds up a cynical failure correcting papers for a living. There is no one among them with whom to feel the slightest identity, with the possible exception of Ed, who succeeds in business despite the failure of his Cornucopia mission and is rebuilt "as a permanently happy, generous man."
More puzzlingly, Mr. Jones unfolds his plot in a way that seems self-defeating. We know from almost the start that Baelthon and the three Farmican children will travel to Nevada and learn that their casino is all but nonexistent. In the story's only compelling episode, Wendy gets pregnant by Baelthon and falls into the clutches of a Christian card shark who saves her from the sin of an abortion by forcing her into prostitution.
But these scenes turn out to be a flash-forward, and the story returns to the Farmican home to debate questions to which we already know the book's answers.
"There are various realities," says the radical-chic Faro, trying to talk Ed out of going to Nevada. "There isn't just one over-arching reality. A lot of our economic reality is truly based on war and racism and sexism and injustice and a class system. That's what you're going out into. That's what you'll be cooperating with."
"Yup," says Ed.
Yup, echoes the reader, trying to suppress a yawn.

HEADLINE: Treasury Offerings Tentatively Set for This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and on Wednesday.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.91 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 5.05 percent. 
 In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.78 percent, and the five-year note at 5.98 percent.

HEADLINE: Gore in Russia, Hoping to Be Cast in a Different Light

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 21

 BODY:
If Vice President Al Gore thought he would get away from questions about campaign finance once he had landed in Russia, he soon found out otherwise.
No sooner had Mr. Gore arrived at the Vnukovo airport in Moscow tonight than a Russian reporter asked him if the fund-raising allegations that had dogged him at home would hamper his effectiveness here. 
 Mr. Gore said with a smile that he was glad to see that Russia had a strong and free press. His official Russian hosts were less amused. They abruptly shut down the impromptu news conference.
Wrapping himself in the mantle of a diplomat, Mr. Gore began three days of meetings with Russia's top leaders on a lengthy list of issues ranging from plutonium production to oil agreements to religious freedom.
If Mr. Gore's aides are successful, it will also be a week of high-profile meetings and carefully scripted photo-ops, all intended to direct the spotlight away from the Vice President's political troubles and toward his role as a world statesman.
To be sure, Mr. Gore and the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, have been holding these biannual sessions for years -- so many years that the talks are denoted with Roman numerals, like Hollywood sequels or Superbowl games. (This week's meeting is officially known as Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission IX, though the cognoscenti simply call it G.C.C.)
But this time the public relations team is pulling out all the stops.
There is, for example, "the walk in the woods." On Monday, Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin will be driven to a lunch spot near a leafy sanitorium for the former Communist and present-day post-Communist elite. They will then stroll through the woods together before a "prepositioned pool" of photographers and television cameramen.
Mr. Gore will be the host of an unusual "media roundtable" with American reporters to discuss the intricacies of American-Russian relations. No Russian reporters are invited to this made-for-America event, which his aides hope will give the Vice President a chance to display his policy expertise.
Mr. Gore's team is also exploring a visit to a Moscow jazz club. That could help overcome the Vice President's wooden image, though it is not yet clear when it would be sandwiched into his crowded schedule.
American reporters complained earlier this year that they were locked out of a speech Mr. Gore gave to the American Chamber of Commerce in Tokyo. But under the new policy of maximum exposure, the news organizations have been invited to Mr. Gore's opening remarks to the American Chamber of Commerce here.
Mr. Gore's wife, Tipper, also has a busy public schedule. She will be meeting with characters from the Russian version of Sesame Street and visiting a Russian school that stresses teaching about the environment.
It would be wrong to think, however, that G.C.C. is all public relations. Each commission session is, in fact, a series of meetings involving American Cabinet-level officials, Russian ministers and seemingly hundreds of aides from both sides. The many issues that Mr. Gore and the Russians will discuss are complicated and often nettlesome.
The two sides, for example, plan to seal an accord requiring the Russians to alter nuclear reactors in Tomsk and Krasnoyarsk so that they no longer produce weapons-grade plutonium. The Russians had earlier promised to shut down the reactors, only to backtrack after concluding that they needed them to heat the Siberian cities.
The Americans also want the Russians to return to the Atomic Energy Ministry several American supercomputers acquired for Russia's nuclear program in circumvention of American export restrictions.
Mr. Gore plans to press the Russians to stop their scientists from helping Iran to develop new surface-to-surface missiles and to curtail nuclear cooperation.
The Russian Atomic Energy Minister, Viktor Mikhailov, proposed tonight that the United States and Russia jointly monitor the nuclear reactor that Russia is selling to the Iranians. But such a step would not address American concerns that the project would help Iran to develop its nuclear expertise and to acquire nuclear technology.
On the economic front, Mr. Gore is expected to try to help American companies that have become increasingly frustrated over breakdowns in their multi-billion dollar oil-production agreements with the Russians.
The Vice President will also press the Russian leadership to reject a bill that the Russian Parliament passed on Friday to protect the Russian Orthodox Church from competition with other Christian faiths. Persuading President Boris N. Yeltsin to block the law will be a herculean chore, since it closely resembles his own draft.
And that is not to mention discussions on space cooperation, a new tax code, the sale of Russian uranium, environmental issues, and the prospects for Russian ratification of the START II treaty reducing strategic nuclear arms and the international accord banning chemical weapons.
After the three days of talks, a meeting with Mr. Yeltsin and a news conference, Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin are to leave on Wednesday for Samara, a Volga River city that is under the sway of economic reformers and that welcomes foreign investment.
For all of the time invested, previous Gore-Cheronomyrdin meetings have rarely produced dramatic results. Mr. Chernomyrdin is more of a status-quo figure than the dynamic free-market advocates in the Russian Government like Anatoly B. Chubais and Boris Nemtsov.
Nor have the meetings always enabled Mr. Gore to put his best foot forward. Mr. Gore had a awkward moment in 1994 when his meetings coincided with the Russian onslaught on Chechnya. Trying to avoid offending the Russian Government, Mr. Gore described the fighting as an internal Russian problem -- a stance that was soon superseded by Washington's anxiety over the brutal nature of the Russian attacks and the fate of civilians.
Still, United States officials say the meetings help keep communication channels open and provide a venue for hammering out agreements. Mr. Gore is also practiced in dealing with the Russians, which should enable him to avoid the tentative approach he was criticized for during his trip to China in March.
And while the Russians may not make many concessions, they seem willing to help Mr. Gore achieve a public relations success. "Our friendship on the personal level is very important," Mr. Chernomyrdin said.

HEADLINE: George Champion, 93, Head Of Chase Manhattan in 1960's

 BODY:
George Champion, a former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 93.
Mr. Champion joined the Chase National Bank in New York as a second vice president in 1933, and he remained with the company until he retired in 1969. He was promoted to senior vice president in 1949 and chairman of the general loan committee in 1954. 
 In 1953, Mr. Champion was appointed head of Chase's domestic corporate banking division. When Chase merged with the Bank of the Manhattan Company in 1955, he was named an executive vice president of the new company.
Mr. Champion became president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1957 and chairman in 1961. According to a spokeswoman for Chase, the company's assets grew from $9.3 billion to $19.3 billion and its deposits from $8.1 billion to $16.7 billion while Mr. Champion was chairman.
After he retired, Mr. Champion served as chairman and president of the Economic Development Council of New York City, a private nonprofit organization, and as the chairman and chief executive of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, formed in 1974 with the merger of the council and the chamber.
Mr. Champion was graduated from Dartmouth College in 1926 and worked at the National Bank of Commerce in New York before joining the Equitable Trust Company in 1929. He became assistant cashier when Equitable merged with Chase National Bank in 1930. After two years with the Canal Bank and Trust Company in New Orleans, Mr. Champion returned to the Chase National Bank in 1933.
He is survived by his wife, Eleanor, of Greenwich; a son, George Jr. of Key Largo, Fla.; a daughter, Emily Jean Knobloch of Atlanta; a sister, Sara C. Andrews of Urbana, Ill.; seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
