HEADLINE: Stamford Would Like to Turn A Successful Mall Inside Out

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 21

 BODY:
When the Stamford Town Center opened here 15 years ago, it was seen as a marvel of urban renewal, the marble and concrete happy ending to a hard-fought battle against the decay and flight that had destroyed so many downtowns in cities across the country.
There is little question that the economic success of the mall has played an important role in the remarkable revival of Stamford's core. But as the city redefines itself for boom times, the hulking vertical mall is emerging as an impediment to Stamford's new vision of its downtown as a miniature Manhattan, full of color and street life day and night. 
 In many respects, it is the quintessential suburban mall set down in the middle of a city. It was used in "Scenes From a Mall," a 1991 dark comedy starring Woody Allen that takes place almost entirely in an enclosed world meant to resemble the Beverly Center on the west side of Los Angeles.
Constructed at the end of what is sometimes called the "urban fortress" era of downtown design, the Stamford mall is a windowless, self-contained world built largely above street level and with little connection to anything around it. Seemingly impenetrable to pedestrians, it is meant to be entered by car.
"Their challenge is to take that fortress and open it up to the street," said Sandy Goldstein, the executive director of the Stamford Downtown Special Services District. "It's a very separate, fortresslike entity."
Such monolithic structures, built in reaction to the urban decay of the 1960's, provided a feeling of personal safety, said Christopher P. Bruhl, the president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut. "But it's a mall from a different era," he added. "People's tastes have changed."
Where safety had once been an overriding concern, a growing number of people are now seeking a feeling of community and a sense of place that the generic design of most malls cannot provide, planners said. And a lesson pounded home by several decades of vast urban renewal projects is that no downtown can survive without buoyant street life. "I'm sure Stamford would like to see more of a streetscape look," Mr. Bruhl said. "A question for the mall is, is there a reason to create more street-level ambience or not?"
The 900,000-square-foot mall has been a substantial success, weathering the recession of the 1980's and holding its own against its most formidable competition, the Westchester mall in White Plains, which opened in 1994. Both malls focus on affluent customers, Westchester with Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom as anchor stores, and Stamford with Saks Fifth Avenue, Macy's and, most recently, Filene's.
"We took our lumps," said Al Messer, the manager of the Stamford Town Center. Sales dropped about 10 to 15 percent for a brief time, he said, but most of the people came back.
Filene's, which replaced J. C. Penney three years ago, pushed the mall up another notch in its quest for upscale shoppers. And the management is constantly tinkering with the mix of smaller boutiques and chain stores to weed out those that fail to draw enough customers or generate sufficient sales.
"You really have to do well here or you're not going to make it," Mr. Messer said. The average lease for all but the anchor stores is seven years, he said, and many stores have three- or four-year leases with clauses that require remodeling halfway through to insure against shabbiness.
Mr. Messer said he is pleased with the current mix of stores, but acknowledged that one problem has bedeviled the management for years: the mall has no restaurant. On the top level, a number of fast-food outlets form a version of a food court, but none offer the table service that the mall's target clientele might expect.
Restaurant owners are reluctant to move in because there is no access to the outside when the mall is closed, he said. The mall was built so that only the anchor stores have entrances at the street level.
Recently, some tough competition has emerged from the retail districts in Greenwich, just to the southwest, and Westport, several towns to the northeast. Each has a district designed to be inviting to pedestrians, with restaurants, cafes, expensive shops and branches of national chain stores like the Gap and Williams Sonoma, all at street level.
"On a nice day, they have the ambience we don't have," Mr. Messer conceded. "But on a rainy day, we rub their noses in it."
Weather notwithstanding, Stamford's planners believe that the possibility of a leisurely stroll through town is the sort of thing that appeals to the professionals who are moving into several thousand luxury rental apartments under construction or recently completed in the downtown area. One such building completed this year, Avalon Grove, has a large landscaped courtyard, outdoor swimming pool, health club and rents that rival Manhattan's. Three-bedroom apartments begin at more than $3,000 a month. The complex has filled quickly, mostly with young professionals who are attracted to the budding street life and restaurants downtown.
But the building is less than a block from a corner of the mall that, to pedestrians, is one of the least inviting. It is Macy's 266,000-square-foot, three-level store, squatting like an airplane hangar over Broad Street, a main avenue on which planners have pinned much of their hope for pedestrian revival.
Macy's does have a pedestrian entrance on Broad Street, but it is hidden behind a concrete wall whose message seems to be "move along."
If the mall is to become more inviting to pedestrians, Macy's holds the key, said Ms. Goldstein, the director of the downtown district. It is unclear whether there is a practical way to alter the building to make it more inviting, she said, but removing the concrete wall would be a first step. "Macy's is going to have to come to the realization that it is in Macy's best interest," Ms. Goldstein said. The mall needs a vibrant downtown as much as the town needs the mall, she said.
Macy's has not been contacted about the matter by the Stamford officials and has not yet begun to consider alterations, said Mary Ann Shannon, a spokeswoman for Federated Department Stores, Macy's parent company. It is the prerogative of Macy's, not mall managers, to make structural changes to the Macy's building, mall officials said.
For several years, the mall managers have been working closely on community art programs and special events that tie the mall more closely to shops and restaurants in the rest of downtown.
"We know we cannot break down these walls," Ms. Goldstein said, "so we have to break down the walls metaphorically."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 900,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center mall, built 15 years ago during the "urban fortress" era of downtown design, is windowless and self-contained. Only the anchor stores have entrances at street level. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)(pg. B7)

HEADLINE: MEDIA: BROADCASTING;
A new TV season, and executives fret about more than the latest cop show.

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

 BODY:
FOR the network executives who program the prime-time schedules, the new television season that starts tonight is D-Day of sorts: A long-planned invasion whose coming is marked by feelings of giddy excitement and abject fear.
This year, the fear inside the landing boats is at an all-time high. Programmers always enter a season worried about the future of specific programs; but never before have so many of them entered a season so worried about the future of the entire business. 
 The list of concerns is almost as long as the list of situation comedies; in fact, the number of sitcoms is one of the concerns: 62 and counting. (The programmers acknowledge there are nowhere near enough funny people in television to go around.)
At the top of the list is the biggest issue of all: What is the economic future of network television? Is it destined to be a business continually diminishing inward from the edge, with viewers defecting to cable, syndicated shows and the Internet?
At a recent industry luncheon in Los Angeles, attended by the presidents of every network entertainment division, the question of viewer erosion haunted the room like a badly dressed, unwanted guest.
The looks over shoulders for that apparition will continue until the programmers arrive in their offices tomorrow morning and check the overnight ratings. They hope they see viewers, lots and lots of viewers. Tonight is the first night since May when viewers can see a full complement of new programming after the grim summer diet of repeats.
Summer viewers in larger numbers than ever are imitating Oliver Twist ("Please, networks, we want some more!"), prodding the network executives to recognize an issue that demands attention, though few have any answers for it.
Peter Roth, president of Fox Entertainment, has been the most vocal in saying the networks can no longer afford to take the summer off, counting on viewers to return in September like good little schoolchildren.
Fox tried a few new shows this summer, with modest success. Over all, however, the four networks' share of the summer audience fell to an all-time low.
"The thing to look at early this season is: Do the shows get sampled?" asked Ted Harbert, now an executive with the Dreamworks studio, but a longtime ABC programmer before that. "Each network has a couple of pretty good new shows. But will they be seen?"
Increasingly, putting on new shows that stick amounts to a survival test for the networks. According to industry trade publications, the advertising rates for television's biggest hit shows, like "Seinfeld" and "Frasier," are either down or just slightly up, while the rates for second-year shows considered incipient hits, like "King of the Hill" on Fox and "Everybody Loves Raymond" on CBS, had the biggest increases in average price for each commercial.
For example, according to Advertising Age magazine, the price of advertising for 30 seconds on "Everyone Loves Raymond" jumped to $215,000 from $110,000 the year before. On the other hand, some hits like ABC's "Home Improvement," whose ratings tumbled, saw their average advertising prices plummet -- in the case of "Home Improvement," to about $350,000 a half-minute from about $455,000.
So far, the overall commitment of the advertising industry to network television has not waned, but nobody at the networks wants to talk about what might happen if the national economy goes into a downturn.
Not that they have not thought about it. NBC's competitors see in that leading network's strategy a kind of Darwinian approach intended to insure NBC's survival even if its competitors slide toward extinction.
Defying previous network wisdom, which counseled avoiding direct challenges to hits, NBC has begun to pit successful shows against successful shows on other networks, looking to steal viewers rather than pull in alternative viewers.
Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment, said the old network concept of counter-programming -- going in the opposite direction from an existing hit -- is, as he put it, "a dead idea."
Instead, NBC put four female-oriented comedies on Monday night, directly opposite a similar lineup on CBS. NBC also put the growing hit "Third Rock From the Sun" on Wednesday opposite another growing hit comedy, "The Drew Carey Show" on ABC.
Mr. Littlefield says networks have to present a consistent identity to viewers. For NBC, that means acres of "young adult comedies," whether other networks are doing the same thing or not. He calls this "doing what's best for NBC."
His competitors call it, as one put it, "scorching the earth," and wonder if it is a disservice to viewers that will further drive them from network television.
But Steve Sternberg, a senior partner with BJK & E Media, a service that buys commercial time for advertising clients, said the landscape of television had changed so much that networks simply do not see their marketplace in the same terms as they once did.
"Networks have their own cable interests now; they see things in terms of how well all their assets are doing," he said. For example, NBC regularly promotes its cable networks, MSNBC and CNBC, on its NBC programs.
And Fox does not worry so much that repeats of its own hit, "The X-Files" is running every weeknight at 8, pulling away viewers that might otherwise be watching network television because the cable channel it is going to, F/X, is also owned by Fox.
Still Mr. Sternberg wondered how viewers were helped when five networks placed high-profile shows head-to-head, as is the case now on Wednesday night, when "Third Rock" and "Drew Carey" are joined at 9 P.M. by Fox's youth hit "Party of Five," the new CBS news magazine "Private Eye" with Bryant Gumbel' and "Star Trek Voyager" on UPN.
It is hard to see how all those programs, each vital to its network, can thrive trying to live in the same place.
"Nobody has that many VCR's," Mr. Sternberg said.

HEADLINE: Low-End PC's Take Growing Share of Home Market

BYLINE: BY LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
When the price of a personal computer fell below $1,000 earlier this year, consumers began flocking to stores in search of the ultimate deal. For the first time, they are discovering that $999 can buy the latest technology -- or something close to it -- rather than a closed-out model the manufacturer had long ago replaced with something bigger, faster and better.
As a result, sales of these low-priced workhorses have been skyrocketing lately. While surveys from two companies that track such sales showed slightly different results -- in part because they used different methodologies -- both indicated that new, low-priced machines were having a profound affect on the industry. 
 One survey, from Computer Intelligence Corporation showed that personal computers costing less than $1,000 accounted for nearly 23 percent of all retail PC sales in July, up from only 7.2 percent in January. Figures from Dataquest Inc. were lower, showing that PC's priced below $1,000 accounted for 16 to 18 percent of consumer PC sales in the second quarter. In both cases, it is important to note that the under-$1,000 figure usually does not include a monitor, which typically adds a minimum of $200 to the price.
The first under-$1,000 Pentium PC from a major manufacturer arrived in January, when Packard Bell NEC introduced its D141 model. Since then, the company, which is based in Sacramento, Calif., has rolled out two more lines, and leads the category with about 28 percent market share, followed closely by Compaq with roughly 25 percent of the market. And I.B.M., Acer America and AST have also brought out models priced below $1,000 since.
But even before that, tiny start-up Monorail Inc. jump-started the low-end market last year with an odd-looking but functional system that includes a built-in notebook-style L.C.D. screen.
Just who is buying these systems is still a matter of debate. Fred Kern, vice president of product marketing for Packard Bell NEC, said the company's research showed that 70 percent of those who purchased its under-$1,000 PC's were either first-time buyers or people who had owned a computer in the past but stopped using it once it had become outdated. That was compared with the 50 percent of all Packard Bell systems that are bought by first-time buyers.
But the big question is whether the surge in sales of low-priced systems is leading to an overall expansion of the home PC market, whose reach into American households has inched up from 38 to 41 percent in the past year. At Packard Bell, the answer is a hesitant "yes."
"We think the market is expanding because of this phenomenon but we don't have any firm data yet," Mr. Kern said. But industry analysts, who generally concur that it is too early to tell, say a surprisingly high number of these systems are being bought as replacement systems by experienced PC users, and by small businesses and corporations looking to equip low-end users inexpensively.
What market researchers have discovered about the fickle consumer market could be disturbing for the makers of these personal computers.
Surveys of the more than 60 percent of homes that don't own a personal computer show that price is not what keeps many of these people out of the computer store. Rather, it is the perception that they have no use for a computer.
"The majority of home users who don't have a PC don't think they need it," said James Staten, a PC analyst at Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif.
But that, too, appears to be changing, driven to a large extent by the extensive hype about the Internet, Mr. Kern said. Add to that some major improvements that are expected shortly in graphics technology, along with the imminent arrival of D.V.D., a new video standard that delivers higher quality full-motion video than CD-ROM disks, and personal computer makers have reason to hope that the die-hards will come around soon.
These new low-priced systems have a significant advantage over low-end PC's that went on the market before them. Their most noteworthy feature is that they are able to run the latest software programs.
"The sub-$1,000 market used to be close-out computers, typically a few generations old," said Matt Sargent, an analyst at Computer Intelligence. "Now we have Packard Bell, Compaq and others announcing systems that were actually new technology."
But that's not to say the low-end personal computer is for everyone. While sales of these PC's may be surging, the volume is still small in comparison with higher priced systems, and the $1,500 to $2,000 PC remains the best seller. According to Dataquest, more than a million PC's priced in that range were sold to homeowners during the second quarter, compared with roughly 200,000 PC's priced below $1,000.
The reason? At the lower end, customers may be getting current technology, but they are most likely getting a bare-bones configuration. Most home PC's in that range, for example, typically have only 16 megabytes of memory, hardly enough to run more than one program at a time, a feature more experienced users would want. And such computers typically have the slowest of the current Pentium processors, easily fast enough for most users, but perceived as insufficient for heavy number crunching or for some demanding graphics applications.
Likewise, a sub-$1,000 system isn't likely to have the fastest CD-ROM drive or the fastest modem, both features many customers would prefer to pay extra to have.
But as analysts point out, home consumers typically do not need the fastest processor and largest drive, as long as they can do what they need to: write letters, track home finances and perhaps browse the World Wide Web. For those things, $1,000 could be money well spent.

HEADLINE: Still Running With the Cows;
For Now, the Founder of Gateway Sticks to His Roots

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Drop out of college, start a company, work endless hours and, against all odds, your fledgling personal-computer marketer becomes a success. You watch with pride and some awe as the company, started in a tiny office on the family cattle farm in Iowa, grows astronomically in size and value, into the millions of dollars, and then billions.
It seems only human to occasionally consider stepping back a bit from the workload and responsibility, cashing in and spending more time with your children. Ted Waitt, the Midwest's computer-industry billionaire, who is the chairman of Gateway 2000 Inc. -- a direct-from-the-factory marketer of personal computers, known for its quirky advertising and cowhide-patterned boxes -- acknowledges that he has had some second thoughts over the years. 
 One proposal, Mr. Waitt recalled, came a few years after Gateway was founded in 1985 and he was offered about $10 million for the company. He called his uncle David, a commodities broker, a man attuned to the punishing swings of the agricultural business. His uncle's advice: sell the business while it was hot. "He said, 'Don't walk away from it, run,' " Mr. Waitt said.
The 34-year-old Mr. Waitt also apparently entertained some second thoughts about his future and Gateway's earlier this year, when he talked to executives of the Compaq Computer Corporation about acquiring Gateway for roughly $7 billion. The merger talks collapsed in mid-April. But those reports, word that Mr. Waitt paid $14 million in July for a seaside mansion near San Diego (far indeed from Gateway's headquarters) and a surprising drop in Gateway's earnings raise the issue of whether Mr. Waitt's focus has strayed from the business recently.
"I'd be lying to you if I said I had not done some soul searching," Mr. Waitt said in an interview recently in his suite at the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan.
"But that is also something I've done at various stages in my career," he added. "Every time, I've come back and recommitted myself to the business. And that's where I am now."
He has not commented on reports of the talks with Compaq, and he would not do so directly earlier this month. "But I will say that I never looked at a transaction with the intention of getting out of the business," said Mr. Waitt, who was in New York to introduce new Gateway products and meet with analysts.
The Compaq-Gateway deal that was considered, according to one person close to Compaq, would have made Mr. Waitt, who owns 46 percent of Gateway, the largest single shareholder in Compaq and a member of the Compaq board. In short, Mr. Waitt would have stayed in the business, but as a high-level underling at Compaq, the world's largest PC maker.
Mr. Waitt also had qualms about Gateway being controlled by a faraway corporation, this person said. He may have some ambivalent feelings about his hometown community of Sioux City, Iowa, but his roots there are deep and loyal. "Both Gateway and I are products of Sioux City," Mr. Waitt observed.
His period of personal reflection behind him, Mr. Waitt must now lead Gateway through a tricky corporate transition. Gateway is trying to move aggressively beyond its consumer business into the lucrative corporate market. In the early going, that corporate campaign has faltered.
On Sept. 3, Gateway warned that its operating profits for the third quarter would fall sharply -- not much above the break-even point. The reason: an overly optimistic forecast of how quickly it could make inroads in the corporate market has left Gateway saddled with a costly inventory of chips and other PC components.
The company overreached, Gateway executives say, not because its forecasting model went awry but because sales targets were set above the level in the forecast. Gateway, to be sure, is growing at a rate of some 30 percent a year, well ahead of the PC industry as a whole. Yet its mirror-image rival as a direct marketer of PC's, the Dell Computer Corporation, which focuses mainly on the corporate market, is growing at twice the rate of Gateway.
"I pushed the forecast because I felt that we had become complacent, that we weren't growing fast enough," Mr. Waitt explained. "After all, you've got Dell clipping along at a 60 percent growth rate."
Indeed, the Dell-Gateway competition is one of the most intriguing rivalries in the computer business. Both companies are led by college dropouts -- now both billionaires in their early 30's -- who recognized the power of the direct-sales approach, bypassing retail middlemen to offer customers more powerful PC's for less money and enabling producers to build direct marketing relationships with buyers.
Yet the two men at the top seem a study in contrasts. Lanky and informal, his receding hair pulled back in a ponytail, Mr. Waitt drapes himself over a chair and lights a cigarette after retrieving an ash holder. ("I've used soap dishes as ashtrays in the best hotels in the world.")
His manner is welcoming, he looks people in the eye, and he speaks with a voice that suggests sincerity, even to the hotel staff. ("Hey, that's great; thanks a lot.") By temperament and instinct, he is a consumer marketer.
Michael Dell, Dell's 32-year-old chairman, is heavier set and more formal in manner and appearance. A no-nonsense businessman, he also has a lively, acerbic sense of humor, with his jokes usually cutting remarks about rivals. He comes from a professional family -- his father an orthodontist, his mother a stockbroker -- and is very much at home in dealing with buttoned-down corporate types.
Small wonder, then, that Mr. Waitt focused on the consumer PC market, while Mr. Dell favored the corporate market. Today, it seems, Mr. Dell made the better choice. Dell Computer's growth rate has been faster, its profits higher and its stock is the Wall Street darling among PC companies.
Gateway has begun pushing hard in the business market, doubling its corporate sales force in the last year. Earlier this month it introduced a full line of powerful work stations and servers, the machines that distribute data to desktops in computer networks.
The focus on corporate business, though, does not mean Gateway is pulling back from its consumer business. Its research suggests that the penetration of PC's in American households will move from 40 percent to 65 percent in the next three years, as lower-income families and the elderly join the computer age.
The company's greatest asset, Mr. Waitt insists, is its relationship with millions of consumers -- a third of American households with incomes of $75,000 or more own a Gateway machine -- whose preferences and purchasing patterns are stored, sorted and studied on the company's massive data bases.
"The corporate business is very important to us," he said, "but my biggest priority is to not lose the home."
Gateway is going to face increasing competition in the home market, notably from Dell, which announced last month a consumer marketing drive. "By concentrating on the corporate business for the better part of the last decade, we allowed Gateway to grow underneath the Dell umbrella," Mr. Dell said. "Now, we're attacking on both fronts."
Still, most analysts and industry executives agree that the challenges facing Gateway are mainly those of prudently managing new growth as it expands into new markets. Dell stumbled a couple of years ago, for example, and has since recovered with a vengeance.
And given Mr. Waitt's track record, industry executives say, he should be up to guiding Gateway through its current problems.
"Look at what the man has done," said Andrew Grove, the chairman of the Intel Corporation. "If anybody had walked into my office and described his business plan -- location-wise, look-and-feel wise -- I would have thrown him out."
Gateway's unlikely locale is perhaps the most remarkable thing about the company. And Mr. Waitt's relationship with the local community is complicated -- and it accounts, he suggests, for some of his self-described soul-searching recently.
Gateway's rise to become a $7 billion-a-year company has made it the engine of the local economy -- a community of about 130,000 people, where Iowa, South Dakota and Nebraska meet. At the borders, three cities meld together in what is called Siouxland -- Sioux City, Iowa; South Sioux City, Neb., and North Sioux City, S.D., where Gateway has its headquarters.
Son of a fourth-generation cattle broker, Mr. Waitt grew up in a longtime Sioux City family. When he started Gateway in the mid-1980's, the economy was moribund, a series of abandoned slaughterhouses as the local meatpacking business waned.
Gateway now employs 5,000 people locally, and it has led a resurgence in the local economy. A construction boom is under way, with new homes, bridges and streets. The police cars are new. Sioux City built a baseball stadium and has its own minor league team, the Explorers.
Mr. Waitt is the local boy-turned-tycoon in what has become a kind of high-technology company town. (His personal assistant is Jim Wharton, the former Mayor of Sioux City.) His success and personal wealth of $2.3 billion bring a burden of responsibility and loss of privacy, especially in a community with an agricultural tradition and long memories of painful reverses in fortunes. "There is a certain sense that this bubble could burst," observed James Taylor, senior vice president for marketing, who is a transplanted New Yorker. "Rightly or wrongly, that bubble is seen to rest on Ted's shoulders."
For Mr. Waitt and his wife, Joan, it means being more famous than they ever imagined. They walk into a restaurant, and every head turns. "There is no such thing as anonymity in Sioux City for us," Mr. Waitt said.
He extols the virtues of Sioux City life -- a five-minute drive to work, the extended family nearby, the Midwest work ethic of Gateway's workers. Still, as much as he has made up his mind to remain deeply immersed at Gateway, he hints that he is weighing the possibility of someday becoming a very long-distance commuter, working four 16- or 18-hour days at Gateway's headquarters and then departing on his private jet.
Mr. Waitt owns a vacation home in Colorado as well as the new house in Southern California. The $14 million property rests atop Mount Soledad in La Jolla, Calif., and includes a 16,000 square-foot house, pool and tennis courts. "We've had a house in San Diego for five years," he explained. "I just bought a bigger place."
Why San Diego? "I look at the ocean and think," he said, adding "and my wife loves the place."
The eldest of his four children is 7, and Mr. Waitt is intent on spending time with them, in the setting he deems best. "I'll end up living where I feel is the best place to raise my kids," he said. "But regardless of how much time I spend in Sioux City going forward, it will always be home for me."

HEADLINE: Rural Opposition to Hog Farms Grows

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GRUVER, Tex., Sept. 18

 BODY:
In the latest skirmish between rural counties in the South and West and corporate hog farms, voters in Seward County, Kan., have voted by more than 2 to 1 to keep out new manifestations of big pork.
Concerned about pollution that has been linked to hog farms, which can have up to 250,000 pigs, farmers and environmentalists in several states are working to slow or prevent the expansion of the pork industry into their areas. Spokesmen for hog-farm operations, however, say the companies are aware of environmental concerns and are seeking to reduce pollution. 
 With Seward County's vote against corporate hog farms in a nonbinding referendum on Tuesday, it became the 20th county in Kansas to vote on the issue. The Kansas Rural Center, an organization in Whiting, Kan., that says it promotes sustainable agriculture and family farming, said all but 2 of the 20 counties had voted against new corporate hog farms, also in nonbinding referendums.
Recent votes elsewhere have also gone against hog farms. On Sept. 8, officials in Hopkins County, Ky., asked Vall Inc., a pork producer from Spain, not to build a $7 million hog farm in their county. On Sept. 10, officials in Holt County, Neb., approved a moratorium on construction or expanding any feedlots, including chicken and turkey houses, for two years or until zoning regulations can be enacted.
Nancy Thompson, a consultant for the Center for Rural Affairs, a group in Walthill, Neb., that studies rural communities, said the votes reflected a widely held sentiment. "Any time you go to the people and ask them what they want," Ms. Thompson said, "in every instance they say they don't want corporate farming. It says people understand better than a lot of policy makers what kind of impacts corporate farming has on the community, independent producers and the quality of life in the area."
The Seward County vote was a blow to Seaboard Farms, which opened a $110 million slaughterhouse in Guymon, the biggest city in Texas County, Okla., south of Seward County, last year. The company produces 2 million hogs a year in this region and had been planning to produce up to 400,000 additional hogs a year in Seward County.
Mark Campbell, a vice president for development at Seaboard, based in Shawnee Mission, Kan., refused to comment directly on the Seward County vote. The final decision on building the farm is up to the county commissioners, who have indicated that they will follow the referendum.
"Seaboard is concerned about the environment and how it interacts with communities," Mr. Campbell said. "We are cognizant of our responsibilities, and we want to be sure that clean water and clean air can be balanced in the equation of animal production and economic development."
In the last five years, Seaboard and other companies have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the region, which the wheat and cattle industries have long dominated. Dozens of new barns, each with up to 1,000 hogs, have become as common as irrigation equipment along the roads that connect the Panhandle regions of Texas and Oklahoma with southern Kansas.
Although the industry has created several thousand jobs, it has also created opposition. Farmers in Texas are suing the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission to block permits that have been issued to hog farms in Ochiltree County, saying they are concerned about odors and water pollution.
Kathy Bloom, vice president of Citizens for a Healthy Environment, the Seward County citizens' group that led the fight against the pork industry, said that her county already had 80,000 hogs and that voters did not want to add 400,000. "A pig excretes two to five times the waste of a human," said Mrs. Bloom, who, along with her husband, Fred, grows wheat, corn and milo. "That translates into a city of two million with no sewage treatment. That was appalling to us. Who would want that in their backyard?"
But Jim Shantz, a spokesman for Murphy Family Farms, a company based in North Carolina that is the nation's largest pork producer and is expanding operations into Texas and Oklahoma, said his industry was working to reduce odors and the potential for water contamination. Mr. Shantz said the Seward County vote would not have long-term effects on the industry. "It's an isolated case," he said. "There are other communities where corporate farming is being welcomed."

HEADLINE: In the Balance, the Future of a Lake;
Arizona Town Battles Environmentalists Over Drainage Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: PAGE, Ariz., Sept. 19

 BODY:
To Sierra Club directors, their proposal to drain Lake Powell, the nation's second-largest artificial lake, is breathtaking in its boldness.
To residents and recreationists here, the idea of destroying the nation's second most popular camping area is breathtaking in its arrogance. 
 "I tend to vote green, but this makes them look like absolute fools," Tony Randall, a Flagstaff resident, said on Thursday as he and his wife prepared their motor boat for a four-day fishing and camping trip among the lake's redrock canyons. Referring to the Sierra Club, he said: "If you support something ludicrous, it undermines your credibility."
Page, a prosperous town of 8,200 people, was built in 1957 by workers who created the Glen Canyon dam, and with it, Lake Powell. People here seem to be universally opposed to draining the lake and recovering the canyon. And with Congressional hearings on the plan set to begin on Tuesday, the lineup of forces would seem to be in their favor. Four million electricity users, 2.5 million recreationists, a $500 million tourist economy, volumes of regional water compacts and the Navajo nation are lined up against two environmental groups and a few species of fish.
"But the environmentalists closed down the forest industry to save the spotted owl," warned Verna M. Stoddard, who runs the Lake Powell Yacht Club. "They are pretty powerful people."
The environmentalists say the lake is wasting water through evaporation, covering up a beautiful red rock canyon and irreversibly changing the ecosystem of the Grand Canyon. People opposed to the plan say that Page needs the lake to survive and that after so many years, the canyon has been lost forever.
Four decades ago, engineers built a massive convex dam here, blocking the Colorado River at a narrow gorge of Navajo sandstone. Swelling to nearly the size of Lake Meade, the nation's largest manmade lake, Lake Powell has served for the last 20 years as a massive water bank for flood control, for hydroelectric power and for guaranteeing steady water supplies to Phoenix, Las Vegas, Nev., and Los Angeles.
Surprising planners, Lake Powell has also become a runaway recreational success story. Last year, 2.5 million people visited this remote lake five hours north of Phoenix. Of these visitors to Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, most of which is in Utah, almost 1.8 million camped overnight, just under the 2.1 million who stayed at Yosemite National Park, the nation's most popular camping area.
The lake fuels an annual local tourist economy of half a billion dollars.
Lulled by these numbers, few people took it seriously last year when David Brower, the founder of the Sierra Club, proposed that the lake be drained. If that were done, he said, the flooded scenery of Glen Canyon would be recovered and a wild river habitat would be restored for endangered fish in the Grand Canyon, 40 miles downstream from here.
To many people's surprise, the plan has gained momentum. Last November, the executive board of the Sierra Club, an organization with 600,000 members, unanimously endorsed the plan. The Glen Canyon Institute, a Utah group whose main goal is to see the lake drained, last year tripled attendance at its annual convention, to 1,500 people.
Organized opposition to the plan has formed only recently.
"People are only now beginning to wake up to this threat," said Larry E. Tarp, a retiree here who two months ago organized Friends of Lake Powell. "If they get rid of this dam, they would go for the next one, and then the next one."
On Tuesday, Mr. Tarp is to testify in Washington at hearings on the lake-drainage proposal called by Representative James V. Hansen, Republican of Utah.
Mr. Brower, 84, who has spent half a century battling the Government over environmental issues, plans to testify about the lost beauty of Glen Canyon.
"That dam destroyed one of the most magnificent places on earth, in order to have flatwater recreation," he said in a telephone interview from his home in Berkeley, Calif.
For 40 years, Mr. Brower said, he has felt guilty about dropping opposition to the Glen Canyon dam in the mid-1950's as part of a tradeoff that prevented construction of a dam that would have flooded the Dinosaur National Monument in Colorado.
"I was in a position to stop it," said Mr. Brower, who was the Sierra Club's executive director at the time. "But we softened, and Glen Canyon dam was built."
Critics say that Mr. Brower has personalized the battle, his ego obscuring the fact that the dam was built after a vote by Congress and cost $272 million and the lives of 17 workers.
"David Brower's ego problem is such that he believes he was solely responsible for the dam," Mr. Tarp said from his home in Greenehaven, a residential development overlooking the lake's southern end here.
Undaunted by such criticism, Mr. Brower contends that the lake is filling with silt and that each year it loses to evaporation 1.5 million acre feet of water -- enough to supply 1.5 million homes a year.
Bill Duncan, the Bureau of Reclamation engineer who manages the 710-foot-high dam, said that the sedimentation of the lake is very slow. At current rates, he predicted, dredging will be needed to clear turbine intake pipes in about 500 years.
Evaporation, in a lake that covers 252 square miles, amounts to about four percent of annual inflow.
"Evaporation is not elimination," said Mr. Tarp. Water that evaporates under the desert sun in Lake Powell returns to the ground in the form of fog or rain, most likely in the Colorado River watershed, he said.
The Glen Canyon dam, one of the last to be built on the Colorado River, has long been anathema to hardline environmentalists. In the novel "The Monkey Wrench Gang," Edward Abbey discussed blowing it up. In 1981, Earth First, a confrontational group, made its political debut by unfurling a 300-foot-long piece of plastic down the dam's wall to simulate a massive crack.
The loss of Glen Canyon, a kind of submerged Atlantis to some environmentalists, is expected to be a theme at Tuesday's hearings.
"The primary reason is recovering Glen Canyon," said Adam Werbach, who is the Sierra's Club president and who plans to testify. "At my age, 24, I have never had the chance to see Glen Canyon, but I hope my children will."
But people here say that the canyon is lost forever. Draining the lake, they say, would create a massive environmental mess -- the odor of millions of rotting fish, a white "bathtub ring" of dried salt stretching for 2,000 miles around the redrock shoreline, and an air pollution problem from fine sand blowing off the old lake bottom.
"You'd have silt, debris, the smell, the bathtub ring around the edge," said Michael A. Woods, a son of one of the dam's builders and Mayor of Page. "And Page would become a ghost town."
Mr. Werbach countered that there would be plenty of cleanup jobs for people in Page, adding: "We are talking about the largest, most important restoration project in human history."
With 400,000 boats launched on Lake Powell every year, local people also argue that draining the lake would destroy the recreational economy.
Mr. Werbach says river rafting, hiking and mountain biking could take the place of flatwater boating.
But the old landscape and ecosystem were not big tourist draws.
Before the lake was formed, Rainbow Bridge National Monument was visited by only several hundred people a year, who arrived on foot or on mule. With a boat dock now only a few away, 325,000 people visited the 290-foot-high natural arch last year.
Another group that fears the Sierra Club's proposal is the Navajo, the largest American Indian tribe. About 1,200 Navajos work at a coal-fired electricity plant and at a coal mine that feeds the plant, both of which might have to close if the lake were drained.
"The Navajo Generating Station would be out of water -- the intake pipes are 250 feet from the river level," said Mr. Woods, the Mayor, who is also superintendent of engineering at the plant. Designed to use a constant supply of clear lake water for steam and for cooling, the plant could not run on erratic supplies of muddy Colorado River water, he said.
With the dam and the plant, Page supplies power to about 4 million people. Sierra Club officials say that the power plant could be re-engineered to run on river water and that a regional conservation program could make up for the shortfall from the hydroelectric turbines.
There is some official support for the opposition. A regional environmental impact statement concluded recently: "Removal of Glen Canyon Dam is considered unreasonable." Undaunted, Richard Ingebretsen, president of Glen Canyon Institute, plans to hold in coming months a series of public meetings to foster debate over draining Lake Powell.
A popular line of attack on the dam is that it has disrupted the eco-system of the Grand Canyon.
"I don't want to be known as part of the generation that killed the Grand Canyon," said Mr. Werbach, the Sierra Club leader. "There is the destruction of the beaches, and the dieoff of the fish from the cold water coming out of the dam."
This water, which flows out of the middle of the 500-foot-deep lake at 47 degrees, has pushed to the edge of extinction several warm-water species of fish that are unique to the Grand Canyon. On the other hand, the new lake ecosystem has become a popular wintering ground for bald eagles, a threatened species, and home to the largest population in the lower 48 states of peregrine falcons, an endangered species.
The endangered species argument cuts both ways, people here say. Referring to one of the endangered fish species, Mrs. Stoddard said, "Why choose a humpback chub over an eagle?"

HEADLINE: Virginia's Race for Governor Turns on Education and a Tax

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: VINTON, Va., Sept. 19

 BODY:
As the governor's race in Virginia heats up through the final weeks of the campaign, the messages get louder if not clearer: Both candidates to succeed George F. Allen, a popular Republican, are selling comprehensive programs to improve education, their highest priority.
Donald S. Beyer, the Democrat who is Mr. Allen's Lieutenant Governor, wants to raise the salaries of public school teachers and reduce the size of classes by hiring a thousand teachers. James S. Gilmore 3d, a Republican who served as Attorney General until he resigned in June, wants to hire 4,000 new elementary school teachers and provide tax credits for private school tuition. 
 But with most statewide polls still showing large numbers of undecided voters, as many as 1 in 4 in some surveys, and the rest almost equally split, the outcome could well turn on abortion and on a pocketbook issue: an unpopular tax on cars and trucks, which both candidates have proposed eliminating in some form.
As one of only two statewide elections in the country this year, along with the governor's race in New Jersey, the Beyer-Gilmore contest is drawing wider attention than campaigns for governor normally attract. It is already notable for its spending, about $12 million so far, topping the previous record for total spending in a Virginia gubernatorial campaign.
But the two races also bear watching because they are taking place at a time when both major parties are struggling to redefine themselves and when public regard for politics is sagging.
In Virginia, where a governor cannot succeed himself and candidates for governor and lieutenant governor run independently, party unity often fractures.
A United States Senate race three years ago included two candidates who ran temporarily as independents -- L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat who preceded Mr. Allen as the first black ever elected governor in the United States, and a moderate Republican, J. Marshall Coleman -- as well as the Republican nominee, Oliver L. North, and the eventual winner, Charles S. Robb, the incumbent Democrat.
In the current campaign, Mr. Beyer has been mildly criticized by Mr. Wilder for the patronizing tone of some of his advertisements, a rebuke that could hold down Mr. Beyer's advantage, as a Democrat, among black voters, and by Mr. Robb for elements of his tax-relief plan.
But campaign waters are calm for now, leaving Mr. Gilmore and Mr. Beyer the freedom to stick with their messages.
For both, the major thrust has been the need to improve state public schools and expand access to college at a time when Virginia's economy is growing at a fairly robust pace. Though their solutions differ, they agree that a growing number of job opportunities in Virginia await the properly educated.
In recent years, state officials have succeeded in attracting major new businesses to the state, like a Motorola microchip plant outside Richmond and a branch of the Gateway 2000 computer company in Hampton Roads. Also, the highway from the Capitol Beltway to Dulles International Airport in northern Virginia has become a corridor of major high-tech companies.
"To me, the most pressing issue is education; it's my passion," said Mr. Beyer, who says his background in business, as the owner of a Volvo dealership in Fairfax, would bring a new approach to problem solving. "For the last 40 years, Virginia's governors have been lawyers."
Mr. Gilmore, a strong supporter of Mr. Allen's push to eliminate parole and implement tough welfare-to-work requirements, said he wanted to be known as the next "education governor," an image he tried to bolster by having Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor who made education the centerpiece of his Presidential campaign last year, join him today at a handful of stops.
Yet neither candidate can shake too many hands before questions arise about his plans for tax relief.
As the first to announce an initiative, Mr. Gilmore said he would phase out part of the annual tax Virginians pay on their cars and trucks, eliminating the tax on the first $20,000 of the vehicle's value. Under the current system, some residents pay $1,000 a year or more. The tax generates more than $1 billion a year in revenue.
Mr. Gilmore contends that the loss in tax revenue would be more than offset by $5.5 billion in economic growth projected by some economists for the next four years.
Mr. Beyer initially derided the plan as "the worst in modern political life," only to propose a similar measure that would offer vehicle owners up to $250 a year in state income tax credit.
That would cut tax revenue by $1.2 billion, an amount that he also said would be offset by the growth projected by other economists for the state's economy. Mr. Gilmore characterized the Beyer plan as an effort to blur the lines between them.
Robert S. Holsworth, a professor of political science at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, said that unless Mr. Beyer could draw a sharper distinction on education, exploiting an issue that typically serves Democrats well, he might be unable to overcome Mr. Gilmore's natural advantage as a Republican who favors tax cuts.
But Mr. Gilmore might face a similar challenge on abortion, Mr. Holsworth said, because he has moved beyond his call for requiring teen-agers to notify their parents before they could get abortions to now advocating that they get parental consent. Also, Mr. Gilmore favors abortion only when the life of the mother is at risk.
Those positions might play well among conservative Republicans and members of the Christian Coalition, which began in Virginia. Mr. Beyer favors abortion rights.
For now, it remains unclear whether any aspect of the Virginia race might influence politics outside the state.
Mr. Beyer said he did not believe it would. But Mr. Gilmore disagreed, calling the two statehouse races this year especially critical in preventing Democrats from gathering momentum as they try to regain control of Congress in 1998 and hold the White House in 2000.
That concern has been reflected by the parade of nationally prominent Republicans who have come into the state to campaign with Mr. Gilmore, a list that includes Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader; Speaker Newt Gingrich, and former President George Bush, as well as some with their own agenda, like the Presidential hopefuls Dan Quayle and Steve Forbes. Colin L. Powell and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas are scheduled for future events.

HEADLINE: A New On-Line Publisher Promotes Nonfiction on a Pay-Per-Read Basis

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN 

DATELINE: PHILOMATH, Ore.

 BODY:
Jon Franklin has had it with the New York publishing industry. The journalist, who has twice won a Pulitzer Prize, has written four acclaimed medical science books. But they are all out of print.
Mr. Franklin teaches creative writing at the University of Oregon and his book, "Writing for Story" (NAL/Plume, 1986), a how-to guide for "stalking and writing true stories," has made Mr. Franklin a mentor of sorts for thousands of aspiring writers of literary nonfiction nationwide. It still sells steadily and has been kept in print. 
 But like an increasing number of his students and colleagues, Mr. Franklin is finding it harder to get his modest-selling "midlist" books published, let alone keep them in print. "New York is no longer backing midlevel books," Mr. Franklin said. "A lot of quality books are not given a chance."
So Mr. Franklin is turning to the World Wide Web to sell his own work and other "good writing" directly to readers. In late August, Mr. Franklin opened Bylines, a pay-per-read Web site (http://www.bylines.org), where readers can choose from "a gallery of fine writing" -- including original work by a variety of writers as well as his own out-of-print books -- and charge it to their credit cards.
The site began with 13 offerings, ranging from nonfiction "short stories" for 29 cents to full-length books for $2.50. It also includes essays on writing literary nonfiction, and Mr. Franklin has plans to add poetry and fiction.
Mr. Franklin is a traditionalist when it comes to the storytelling craft of writing and Bylines reflects his style. At The Baltimore Evening Sun, Mr. Franklin won the first Pulitzer Prize given for feature writing in 1979 and the first for explanatory journalism in 1985 for articles that broke with newspaper style and used the dramatic techniques of fiction to report on experimental brain surgery and neuroscience.
Because the focus is on writing, the Bylines site includes only text. It is simple and speedy. There are no graphics to slow it down. A visitor to the site can read the catalogue of offerings and browse through some samples of writing, but must provide a credit card number before downloading any of the pieces. The pieces can then be read on the screen or printed out, a step that Mr. Franklin acknowledged was still a weak link.
"I think people would rather read a book," he said. "But we're not competing with a book on the shelf. We're competing with a book that isn't there. You can't get it."
Bylines also aims to compete with book publishers for good writing by offering writers a 60 percent royalty. At that rate, a book sold on Bylines for $2.50 will earn the author roughly the same amount as a royalty on a hardback book, while costing the reader just one-tenth the price.
"What we're trying to do is tie the writer with the reader directly with an economic exchange," he said. "The idea is to cut out publishers, printers, advertisers and glitz. We believe significant content coupled with insignificant prices should yield very significant audiences."
Mr. Franklin said it was too early to tell whether his hunch is right. "Traffic is a whole lot higher than sales," he said. "People are looking and sniffing it over, like they do new things. One person came back three times before finally buying something. This is so very new, it takes people some time to digest it. The critical thing is whether after they read the first thing they buy they'll come back for a second thing."
Bylines is a collaboration between Mr. Franklin, his wife Lynn, who wrote a nonfiction "novella" for the site on reviving old, little-grown varieties of apples, and George Rodgers, who was projects editor at The Baltimore Evening Sun when Mr. Franklin won his Pulitzers there.
The Bylines Web site is sponsored by the journalism organization Investigative Reporters and Editors at the University of Missouri, and was designed by George Landau, president of News Engin Inc., a company that programs computer systems for newsrooms. Both have donated their time and equipment to support Mr. Franklin's quest to find out whether good writing will sell on the Web.
Brant Houston, the director of Investigative Reporters and Editors, said the project "is more of a mission to help writers and journalists than a business" at this point. The organization invested about $3,000 to set up the site, in addition to "hundreds of hours of staff time." It will collect 10 percent of sales. Credit card fees will take 2.5 percent, and the rest will go to capitalize Bylines, which Mr. Houston said would eventually become a commercial site.
Others, including The Utne Reader, have tried and failed to sell writing on a pay-per-read basis. And Idealab was developing a similar model for selling all kinds of intellectual property on its Ideamarket site last year, but has since pared its offerings to advice about computers and business.
"Pay-per-read has its place," said Paul Saffo, director of the Institute for the Future in Silicon Valley. "This is innovation in the grand tradition of innovation in publishing. By reducing distribution costs to zero, one can have a direct relationship to the reader. But people are still getting used to buying items over the Internet. It will take time."
Still, there are plenty of skeptics.
"I think this is a dead end," said Holly Brady, director of the Stanford Professional Publishing Course, which is offering a class on publishing on the Web this fall. "I don't think this is the way books are ultimately going to be sold." The course teaches business models for magazine, book and newspaper publishing based on subscription revenue and advertising revenue, but not pay-per-read.
The Franklins live and work in a quiet secluded home off a gravel road in the Oregon Coast Range rain forest west of Corvallis. But with computer keyboards in their laps, they are sitting at the nerve center of a buzzing literary world that Ms. Franklin compares to "Paris in the 1920's." Mr. Franklin moderates and Ms. Franklin edits an Internet literary nonfiction discussion group called WriterL that has grown to 300 professional writers and journalists since it began three years ago.
Most initial offerings on Bylines were written by participants in WriterL. The Franklins believe their network will help spread the word about Bylines and that their first market will be other writers.
John Higgins, one of Mr. Franklin's students at the University of Oregon, wrote "The Test," a nonfiction short story on Bylines about a young street-fighter who learns self-control through Kung Fu. He now writes the "Our Town" column for The Akron Beacon Journal.
He was also one of the site's first buyers. "I just downloaded a whole library for less than $16," he said.
Mr. Higgins said he was surprised to find himself reading books on his computer. "I like holding books, reading them, having them in bed," he said. "But if the writing is powerful enough, you forget you're reading on the screen."
Mr. Higgins said he had "faith in the medium." But, he added, "I'm not quitting my day job yet."

HEADLINE: Vast Worker Database to Track Deadbeat Parents

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Enforcement of child support obligations enters a new era on Oct. 1, when the Federal Government will start operating a computerized directory showing every person newly hired by every employer in the country so Federal and state investigators can track down parents who owe money to their children.
States will be able to use the directory to locate parents and dun them, typically by securing court orders to employers to deduct child support from wages and salaries. 
 Keeping track of parents who move from state to state is one of the most difficult tasks in collecting child support, officials say. More than 30 percent of the 19 million child support cases involve parents who do not live in the same state as their children.
President Clinton will soon announce the National Directory of New Hires, which is required by the 1996 welfare law. But the directory is not just for welfare recipients. It will record basic information, including names, addresses, Social Security numbers and wages, for everyone hired after Oct. 1 for a full- or part-time job by an employer of any size.
It will be one of the largest, most up-to-date files of personal information kept by the Government. Michael Kharfen, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said the Government expected to receive data on 60 million newly hired employees a year. Wages must be reported every three months; the Government expects to receive 160 million wage reports each quarter.
The size and scope of the database have raised concerns about the potential for intrusions on privacy.
Federal and state officials predict that the new Federal directory, combined with similar directories in all states, will produce billions of dollars in new child support payments. States like New York, Virginia, Texas and Missouri, which have required the reporting of newly hired workers in the last few years, say the procedure has been extremely helpful in locating absent parents.
In New York, Daniel D. Hogan, a spokesman for the state's Department of Family Assistance, said that three million people had been hired in the last year and that more than 5 percent of them had been found, through matching of computer files, to owe child support.
When people change jobs, Mr. Hogan said, New York officials inform the new employers of any child support obligations so the money can immediately be withheld from wages.
"We don't give them an opportunity to become deadbeats," Mr. Hogan said. "The biggest problem facing us in child support enforcement is people who move out of state. The best part of the Federal reform is that it will allow us to break down barriers state to state."
Health and Human Services will maintain a separate register listing everyone who owes or is owed child support. It will check each new employee against the list of child support orders to see if the worker owes any money.
Thomas D. Neal, a child support specialist in the Texas Attorney General's office, said: "The national directory will tremendously enhance our ability to locate absent parents and collect child support. Before now, we did not have a good mechanism to know that another state was looking for an individual who might be working in Texas."
Virginia has required the reporting of all newly hired employees since 1993. Patricia Addison, manager of operations for the state's child support program, said, "We've found it an invaluable tool."
The State of Virginia is routinely informed whenever a person takes a new job. By contrast, Ms. Addison said, in the past, "the only way we found out that the father had changed jobs is that the child support payments stopped."
Despite the enthusiasm of state officials, Robert M. Gellman, an expert on privacy and information policy, expressed concern that the new data would be misused.
"The Government is creating a gigantic new database with very broad uses and very little attention paid to the protection of personal privacy," he said. "Private detectives will find a friend in the police department or a child welfare office to give them access to information in the directory of new hires. That already happens with criminal, medical and credit records."
Mr. Gellman predicted that Congress would increase the number of people authorized to use the new directory, just as it has expanded the list of officials with access to Federal tax return information over the years.
Under Federal law, state welfare and child support officials will have access to the new national directory. The Internal Revenue Service, the Social Security Administration and the Justice Department will also have access for some purposes.
A parent living with a child will be able to use the directory to get information about an absent parent who owes child support. For example, a mother with custody of a child will be able to ascertain the father's home address, the name and address of his employer and the amount of the father's income, assets and debts. Using such information, the mother may ask a local court to modify the child's support order if the father's earnings have increased.
In Missouri, child support collections rose 17 percent, to $279 million, in 1996 after the state required reporting of newly hired workers. Teresa L. Kaiser, director of the Missouri program, said, "We had a big increase in collections from 'job jumpers,' parents who would work in one place for a few months, then move to another job before we could get a wage-withholding order."
States say the reporting of new employees not only increases child support collections, but also saves money in other programs. State officials can often reduce or eliminate payments for welfare, food stamps, unemployment insurance and Medicaid after learning that the recipients of such aid have been hired.
Under Federal law, the hiring of a new employee must be reported within 20 days to state authorities, who then have 8 days to send the data to Washington. States may establish tighter deadlines for employers, and many have done so.
Collections through the Federal child support program increased last year by 50 percent, to $12 billion, from $8 billion in 1992. But nationwide, only half of the families with child support orders receive the full amount due, and millions get nothing.
Here is how the new program will work:
*Employers may file information by mail or magnetic tape. States may also take the information over the telephone, by fax or through the Internet.
*An employer who fails to report new employees may be fined $25 for each newly hired worker. An employer who conspires with an employee to flout the reporting requirements may be fined $500.
*A multistate employer may file a report with one state listing all of its hiring across the country. Or, it may file a separate report for each new employee in the state where the person works.
The Federal Government will require only six items of information: the name, address and Social Security number of each newly hired employee, the employer's name and address and the identification number assigned to the employer by the Government.
But many states are requiring employers to file additional information, like telephone numbers, dates of birth, driver's license number and details of health insurance coverage provided to new employees.

HEADLINE: Arab Countries Vote to Defy U.N. Sanctions Against Libya

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Arab countries voted today to defy United Nations sanctions by permitting airplanes carrying Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to land on their territory and to permit other flights for religious and humanitarian purposes.
The resolution approved by the Arab League is an explicit rejection of the sanctions imposed on Libya since 1992 over its refusal to surrender suspects wanted in the United States and Britain in connection with the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am plane over Lockerbie, Scotland, which killed 270 people. 
 Colonel Qaddafi and his Government have flouted the sanctions at least four times in the last three years, including a trip that the Libyan leader made to Cairo 15 months ago at the time of an Arab summit meeting.
But the decision, approved by some 18 Arab foreign ministers, underscores the sense of solidarity felt within the Arab world with Colonel Qaddafi. It also reflected some of the rekindled animosity felt in recent months toward the West -- and the United States in particular -- for what is widely regarded as support for Israel in the latest crisis in the quest for a broader Middle East peace.
Together with Britain, the United States has been the prime proponent of an unyielding line toward Libya, demanding that Libya hand over the suspects for trial in the United States or Britain. Libya has proposed that the two men be tried in a third country or at the International Court of Justice at The Hague. Britain and the United States have rejected that proposal.
The Libyan Government first violated the travel ban in 1994, when a plane carrying Muslim pilgrims flew from Libya to Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. It has done so at least three times since, including the journey that Colonel Qaddafi took in 1996 when he flew to Cairo to join other Arab leaders in a regional summit meeting.
Egypt insisted at the time that it had received news of Colonel Qaddafi's plans only at the last minute. The United Nations condemned the flight, as it has later trips by Colonel Qaddafi to Niger and Nigeria, where he traveled in May.
But the resolution today, after three days of talks by Arab foreign ministers, was unabashed in expressing support for Libya.
"We invite Arab countries to take measures to alleviate the sanctions on Libya until a peaceful and just solution to the crisis can be found," the resolution said.
It specifically urged the League's 22 members to allow flights carrying "the political leadership and official Libyan delegations participating in regional and international meetings" to land on their territories
That effectively means granting clearance for any flight carrying Colonel Qaddafi and his entourage.
The resolution also authorized Arab countries to allow flights for "humanitarian reasons such as the transport of the ill and the dead and medicine as well as religious flights."
The decision is bound to be seen as a new Arab challenge to the United Nations, which did not act last spring when Iraq sent elderly Muslim pilgrims to Saudi Arabia in defiance of a similar United nations travel ban.
Today's Arab League resolution also invited member countries to lift a freeze on Libyan accounts in Arab banks except for oil funds.
The resolution was passed at the end of a session in which the Arab officials seemed able to agree that Israel was at fault for the breakdown in the quest for a wider Middle East peace, but seemed unable to agree whether further punitive measures were required.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Asian Crisis Likely to Slow Economic Liberalization
American officials at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund were confronted by angry Asian leaders who contended that foreign investors set off Southeast Asia's financial crisis. The most extreme accusation came from Malaysia's Prime Minister, who charged the "great powers" -- a clear reference to the United States -- with manipulating Asian currencies to knock them off as competitors. 
 Few Asians at the meeting have endorsed the Malaysian call to outlaw currency trading. But several indicated that they plan to slow economic liberalization. [Page A1.]
 
The Malaysian leader squared off against the billionaire George Soros. The weapons: currency and influence. The stakes: Malaysia's prestige and, by some accounts, the global financial system itself. [A6.]
 
Help Securing Child Support
Enforcement of child support obligations enters a new era on Oct. 1, when the Federal Government will start operating a computerized directory showing every new hire by every employer in the country, so investigators can track down parents who owe money to their children. [A1.]
 
Crackdown on Electronic Diversions
Government and private-sector employers are cracking down on computer games, personal electronic mail and recreational Web surfing. Management measures include monitoring employees' computer files and tracking their electronic footprints on the World Wide Web. Workers are devising retaliatory measures. [A1.]
 
McCann-Erickson Will Reorganize
McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the world's second-largest advertising agency, is undertaking its most comprehensive reorganization in almost four decades. The plan spotlights the increasingly prominent role of marketing services. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D12.]
 
Low-Priced Computers Snapped Up
When computer makers cut the price of PC's to less than $1,000 earlier this year, consumers flocked to stores in search of deals. As a result, sales of such low-priced workhorse machines have skyrocketed. [D4.]
 
Fretful TV Season Begins
For network executives, the season that starts tonight is D-Day of sorts: a long-planned invasion marked by excitement and fear. Programmers always worry about specific offerings, but never before have so many been worried about the future of the entire business. Bill Carter: Broadcasting. [D9.]
 
Turner Hopes to Avoid Stock Sale
Ted Turner, the ebullient billionaire who last week pledged to give United Nations agencies up to $1 billion over 10 years, said Friday that he wanted to find a way to give the money away without selling his 58 million Time Warner shares. Mr. Turner has set his investment team to looking for alternatives to an actual stock sale. [D2.]
 
Photo Rekindles Controversy
A photograph purporting to show the dying Princess of Wales in a wrecked Mercedes, and its publication by a French newspaper, has set off a new controversy over the dissemination of inaccurate information over the Internet. But the incident says as much about traditional media as it does about the global computer network itself. [D9.]
 
Lots of Britons are talking about Kitty Kelley's new book, "The Royals." But because of tough British libel laws, they cannot buy the book in British stores or even read about it in British newspapers. [A4.]
 
Gilder Pushes New Revolution
George Gilder, who promoted supply-side economics in the 1980's, says that the nation is in the midst of a technological revolution that will shake up the telecommunications business as fundamentally as the microprocessor did the computing world during the 1980's. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Cross-Border Investment Hits Record Level

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 21

 BODY:
World business giants invested a record $349 billion last year expanding their operations overseas, and China took in far more money than any other developing country.
But annual growth in investment declined sharply from the late 1980's, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said. 
 Investment in 54 countries by major corporations climbed 10 percent from $317 billion in 1995, the organization said. The latest total is more than double the annual average of $142 billion for 1985-90.
The United States remains by far the largest investor abroad as well as the biggest recipient of foreign investment, the report said.
One of every four dollars invested abroad last year went to the United States, it said. Britain was in second place, followed by Germany. But China remained the boom economy of 1996, receiving more than $40 billion.
