HEADLINE: Asia's Economic Tigers Growl At World Monetary Conference

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 21

 BODY:
After a decade of persuading nations to open their financial markets, American officials at a tense conclave here have run into a wall of resistance as angry Asian leaders charge that foreign investors and Wall Street-style trading exacerbated Southeast Asia's financial crisis.
The most extreme of the accusations came from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia. In a fiery speech on Saturday evening, he accused the "great powers" -- a clear reference to the United States -- of pressing Asian countries to open their markets and then manipulating their currencies to knock them off as competitors. 
 Few Asians at the meeting of world financial leaders here have fully endorsed Mr. Mahathir's conspiracy theories or his contention that most forms of currency trading are "unnecessary, unproductive and immoral" and "should be made illegal."
Nonetheless, several have made clear that they are planning to slow -- and may reverse -- the liberalizations that have opened their economies to global forces.
In short, what has broken out at this usually plodding annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, with its endless seminars bearing titles like "Pension Reform and the Creation of Efficient Capital Markets," is a nasty skirmish in the escalating war between nations and global markets.
The search to assign blame comes as Asian officials are still struggling to contain the damage from a brutal cycle of currency devaluations, stock market sell-offs and, in the case of Thailand, political upheaval that has swept through the region.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is caught in the middle of these arguments, at once making the case for further opening of Asia's markets and fencing with Asian leaders over whether the fault for the current crisis lies in the markets or in themselves.
Mr. Rubin is a veteran of Wall Street who brings an international investor's eye to every policy debate.
He has spent the weekend arguing in private meetings that the markets are imposing badly need discipline on countries that failed to regulate their banks, pursued huge national projects that they could not afford and let cronyism win out over good judgment.
It is not exactly a welcome message.
At some moments the conflict here has mirrored the arguments in Congress over whether free trade accords undercut American workers. At other times it has been tinged with anti-American oratory, with particularly resentful comments about Washington's failure to take part in a bailout of Thailand this summer led by the monetary fund.
"It's really been quite remarkable," Mr. Rubin reflected tonight after a long dinner with his delegation, which is headed to China this week to assess many of the same issues addressed here. "For years, when I was at Goldman, Sachs and then when I first came to Washington, a number of us wondered when countries would fully engage in the debate about the effects of linking global markets."
Now, he said, as a result of an unexpected economic crisis, "people are beginning to put all the pieces together."
The crisis began in Thailand, one of the most successful of the "tiger" economies, which attracted billions of dollars in foreign investment -- more, it turns out, than it could wisely invest.
It quickly spread to Indonesia and Malaysia, where Mr. Mahathir quickly ordered restrictions on short sales -- trades that bet on a decline in prices -- and moved to prop up stock prices for Malaysians, but not for foreign investors.
That led investors to flee, and Mr. Mahathir was soon forced to make a sharp U-turn. But the damage to his country's financial credibility was done.
It would be easy to dismiss Mr. Mahathir's speech on Saturday as the angry ruminations of a prickly leader who enjoyed a string of economic successes only to see his grand plans to build airports, dams and a Southeast Asian Silicon Valley evaporate like numbers blipping off a trader's screen. Even in Southeast Asia, Mr. Mahathir's views are considered extremist.
But the fundamental emotion that he expressed clearly carries an extra resonance now, far beyond his country of 21 million.
This morning, for example, Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya Sunmday of Thailand agreed that Southeast Asia needed to create a "good system" to prevent speculators from driving down currencies. But when asked whether he endorsed the Mahathir idea that currency trading should be illegal, Mr. Thanong said, "I have no opinion."
Indonesia has sent mixed signals. In late August a newspaper close to the Government ran a public service advertisement with a picture of a currency trader wearing a terrorist mask made of American $100 bills. "Defend the Rupiah," it urged. "Defend Indonesia." But the country has largely kept its markets open and even relaxed rules on foreign ownership of some companies.
Leaders of 24 developing countries meeting here warned that proposals within the monetary fund to require further relaxation of investment rules around the world would "put additional stress on the economies that are already straining to adjust to globalization."
"The smell of things is definitely in the direction of slowing down, of reassessing," the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, said in an interview today.
Sitting on the stage with Mr. Mahathir on Saturday, he said that "you could just feel the rapt attention" as Mr. Mahathir deftly wove his theories of Western desires to suppress Asian competitors with the economic events of the last two months.
But Mr. Wolfensohn warned, "Of course you have to be careful that when you stop the flow of capital, you have the greater danger of stopping the flow of technology with it."
While there have been financial crises before -- Mexico in 1995, Latin America in the early 1980's -- the feel of what has happened in Southeast Asia is in some ways quite different. Asia's emerging markets came to view the private foreign investors as a virtually unlimited source of funds.
It is easy to understand why. Only seven years ago, private investment in developing nations around the world was a mere $30 billion, compared with official development aid of nearly $65 billion. Now the proportions are starkly different. Official aid has declined to $45 billion last year, and private investment ballooned to roughly $245 billion.
When that money was flowing in, Asian leaders had no complaints. They were being rewarded, they said, for hard work, rising productivity and the emergence of an educated middle-class that saved at rates that put Americans to shame.
Now that the money has begun to flow the other way, leaving many countries with huge debts denominated in dollars that must be paid back with devalued local currencies, their attitudes have begun to change. Quickly the argument has become part of the debate over "Asian values" versus "Western values," labels that overlook a diversity of views in both camps.
Mr. Rubin has become the standard-bearer of the Western view that markets impose discipline on nations, economies and, most of all, politicians. His 26 years in investment banking at Goldman, Sachs & Company steeped him in the belief that markets go to extremes but that in the long run, they reward countries that keep their houses in order and punish those that do not.
He is sometimes so cautious, though, about the market's potential response to his every utterance that he often uses terminology that obscures his message. This weekend he indirectly answered Mr. Mahathir by saying currency speculation is "part of the total activity in secondary markets" that "increases liquidity and lowers costs."
The Rubin prescription for avoiding crises like those in Mexico and Southeast Asia is to get countries to disclose financial information that many treat as state secrets. This weekend he pressed a plan to get central banks to publicize their own maneuvering in currency markets so that investors could better assess a country's financial reserves.
If countries know that alert investors are watching, the theory goes, they will hesitate before engaging in financial maneuvering that will prompt investors to hit the "sell" button.
Of course, national leaders do not like to hear that they must abide by the dictates of currency and bond traders. Like many American politicians, they argue that global market forces should be channeled to serve their national goals rather than dictate those goals.
"The Asian message is that they are not going to adopt the wholesale, free-market capitalism that America is pushing," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs and one of the thousands of investment bankers here to take the temperature. "There is resentment of the American pressure, and countries are pushing back."
It may be only temporary. After all, once Mexico got through the worst of its crisis, it again embraced the global financial markets. Asian countries have emerged from downturns before and concluded that they had no choice but to introduce more competition to their markets.

HEADLINE: Reunion Recalls a Limitless Age

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The young men of Stuyvesant High School's classes of 1947 and '48 came of age in an era of dizzying change. Born in the Depression, they were freshmen in the middle of World War II and graduated into a world that offered once unthinkable opportunities.
One graduate went on to become the deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Another gained national attention fighting childhood leukemia. Another, an anthropologist, lived among headhunting tribes in the Amazon and became a shaman. A fourth was the chief economist for the First Boston Corporation. 
 Now in their late 60's, these four men -- and more than 200 other members of their classes -- convened yesterday at the new Stuyvesant High School in Battery Park City, to celebrate their 50th reunion and the school's influence on their lives. (Pooling their resources, the two classes decided to celebrate together, the class of '48 a year early.)
One of a handful of public high schools in New York that still requires an examination for admission, Stuyvesant has long yielded an annual crop of high-achieving graduates. They include the actor James Cagney (class of 1918), the longtime teachers' union leader Albert Shanker ('46), and three Nobel laureates, one each in chemistry, physics and economics.
While the classes of '47 and '48 produced equally prominent citizens, they arguably had it tougher than most. Many of the 1,400 members of the two classes were immigrants, or the children of immigrants, who had fled the Nazis, only to grow up living on a shoestring in New York. And after they graduated, even those ranked near the top of the classes of '47 and '48 had difficulty getting into college, because so many slots were reserved for returning veterans.
"We lived through an enormous transition in history, from an America that was separate to an America that was part of the world," said Albert M. Wojnilower, the retired First Boston economist, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 1947, eight years after escaping with his family from Austria.
"When we were pushed out into that world from Stuyvesant," Mr. Wojnilower, 67, added, "we were much better prepared, because of the education we received there, to understand what those big changes had been."
Long considered one of the premier public high schools in the nation, Stuyvesant has had a reputation for fostering intellectual discourse. During the war years, that debate was particularly vigorous.
When the atom bomb was dropped on Japan during the summer of 1945, Mr. Wojnilower was immediately reminded of what he had learned in chemistry class the previous year.
"To the adults, it meant a lot of people would be killed and the war would be over," he recalled. "But if you were a chemistry student at Stuyvesant High, you knew that this was some kind of Faustian consummation."
One of Mr. Wojnilower's classmates, Hans M. Mark, would go on to develop nuclear weapons during the 1950's and 1960's. He was later appointed to the No. 2 job at NASA. Asked which specific weapons he had worked on, Dr. Mark, 68, simply said: "Can't talk about that."
For a school whose student body was, at the time, heavily populated with Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe, the end of the war brought a surge of emotions. Michael Harner, a '47 whose research on shamanism has won him an international following, said he remembers being at a gathering of reporters for the Stuyvesant Spectator soon after V-J Day.
"These kids were quite anti-Nazi, given their backgrounds," he said. "At one point, they stood up triumphantly and sang 'Deutschland Uber Alles' just to show that they had come through the war O.K."
"They were being sardonic," he added.
Though Stuyvesant graduates have routinely moved on to Ivy League institutions, getting into college in 1947 and 1948 was not easy. Not only were there quotas on Jewish applicants, but veterans were given first choice.
Dr. Harner had to wait six months before he was admitted to the University of Illinois. He went on to receive his Ph.D. in anthropology from the University of California at Berkeley. But he says he credits the archeology club at Stuyvesant -- as much as any higher education experience -- with influencing his decision to study headhunting tribes in Ecuador.
"It was a great gift from the City of New York that I feel emotional about even now,"said Dr. Harner, now a bald man with a long white beard, who traveled to the reunion from Mill Valley, Calif.
Dr. Mark, now thinner than in his yearbook photo, said he had been prodded to pursue a life in science from an unlikely direction -- his English teacher, Joseph T. Shipley.
"He said, among other things, that the future is in the laboratories," recalled Dr. Mark, who also went on to serve as Chancellor of the University of Texas and was Secretary of the Air Force under President Jimmy Carter.
Dr. Aaron R. Rausen, the director of pediatric oncology at New York University Medical Center and a pioneer in the treatment of childhood cancers, said he took for granted that many of his Stuyvesant teachers had doctorates. "They ended up helping people like myself get the equivalent of a college education," he said.
But much has changed since those days.
In the early 1970's, the first women graduated from Stuyvesant. And Dr. Mark is among many in the classes of '47 and '48 who said they wished there had been women nearby when he was in high school. "We always had to go on the bus or subway to social affairs," he said. "It would have been much more convenient to have them at Stuyvesant."
Not only are women walking the hallways at Stuyvesant, but those hallways are different: in 1992, Stuyvesant abandoned its 85-year-old home on 345 East 15th Street, near Second Avenue, and moved to its current site, a sprawling tan-brick building on the Hudson River.
The old building, as the alumni recalled yesterday, was dilapidated even in the 1940's, with graffiti-scratched wooden desks bolted to wood floors. As young classmates, Dr. Mark and Dr. Wojnilower shared a desk in drafting class with the initials "JC" carved into it -- a memento from Jimmy Cagney, their teacher swore to them.
Yesterday, as they toured the $150-million building, which includes an Olympic-sized swimming pool, the alumni seemed most in awe of the escalators that link the 10 floors of the soaring school and the electronic card reader that permits access to a library.
Everything, it seemed, was new.
But then they came upon Room 229, a working classroom that has been outfitted with the original desks and an original wood floor from the old building. Like many of his classmates, Dr. Rausen, the cancer specialist, could not help himself: he had to sit down in one of those chairs.
But he was surprised to find the space a bit tight between the seat and desk. "I guess I've gained a few pounds since then," he said.

Among the 200 who attended a 50th class reunion at Stuyvesant High School yesterday were, clockwise from top left, Dr. Michael Harner, Albert M. Wojnilower, Dr. Hans M. Mark and Dr. Aaron R. Rausen. INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Asian Leaders Vent Anger At Perils of Global Markets
Asian leaders used a world finance meeting in Hong Kong to vent frustrations against global markets, asserting that foreign investors and Wall Street-style trading had triggered a crisis in Southeast Asia. The most extreme accusations came from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia. He accused the "great powers" of pressing Asian countries to open their markets and then manipulating their currencies to knock them off as competitors. A1
 
The Envoy on War Crimes
In an entirely new position, David J. Scheffer, the Clinton Administration's Ambassador at Large for War Crimes Issues, has been handed the task of insuring that wartime atrocities, like those carried out in Rwanda, do not fade into history. The post is the brainchild of Secretary of State Madeleine Albright. Mr. Scheffer's challenge is to avoid becoming just a well-meaning idea. A1 

Gore Arrives in Moscow
Vice President Al Gore arrived in Moscow for three days of meetings with Russian leaders on a lengthy list of issues, including oil and religious freedom. No sooner had he landed than a Russian reporter asked if the fund-raising allegations that had dogged him at home would hamper his effectiveness. Mr. Gore said he was glad to see that Russia had a strong and free press. But his Russian hosts abruptly ended the impromptu news conference. A3
 
Arabs Defy U.N. Sanctions
The Arab League voted to defy United Nations sanctions against Libya by allowing planes carrying Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to land and to permit some other flights. The vote reflected rising animosity, especially toward the United States, for what the group regards as unevenhanded support of Israel in the latest Middle East crisis. The sanctions were imposed for Libya's refusal to hand over suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am flight that killed 270. A12
 
Ramos Backs Down in Manila
Some 200,000 people rallied in Manila in an outpouring of "people power" against President Fidel Ramos, who had flirted with an attempt to alter the Constitution so he could run for another six-year term. Mr. Ramos, who pledged not to run for re-election, said he had heard the voice of the people and would support constitutional changes only after he left office. A5
 
Solidarity Gains in Election
Poland's right-of-center Solidarity coalition appeared to have defeated the former Communists in a surprisingly strong showing in parliamentary elections. Although the former Communists had led the country through four years of economic growth, the revamped Solidarity appealed to the anti-Communist feelings of many voters. A7
 
NATIONAL A14-24
 
List Shows Clinton Was to Call Rich Donors
Justice Department investigators have obtained documents showing that President Clinton was urged to make as many as 40 fund-raising phone calls to wealthy contributors from the White House, nearly three times as many requests for solicitations than was previously known, officials said. Although it was unclear how many calls the President had actually made, most of those on the lists made large donations to the Democrats and, in some cases, portions of those donations were improperly transferred to an account that directly benefited Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign, a possible violation of the law, the officials said. A1
 
Personal Information Database
Enforcement of child support obligations enters a new era on Oct. 1, when the Federal Government will start operating a computerized directory showing every person newly hired by every employer in the country so that Federal and state investigators can track down parents who owe money to their children. The database will be one of the largest, most up-to-date files of personal information kept by the Government, raising concerns among some experts about the potential for intrusions on privacy. A1
 
Battle Over Artificial Lake
To Sierra Club directors, their proposal to drain Lake Powell, the nation's second-largest artificial lake, is breathtaking in its boldness. To many in Page, Ariz., the idea of destroying the nation's second most popular camping area is breathtaking in its arrogance. A14
 
A Pocketbook Issue in Virginia
Both candidates in the Virginia governor's race are promoting comprehensive programs to improve education, their highest priority. But with most statewide polls showing large numbers of undecided voters, and the rest almost equally split, the outcome could well turn on abortion and a pocketbook issue: an unpopular tax on cars and trucks. A14
 
Scrutiny for Watchdog Group
Citizen Action, a liberal grass-roots group, has long rallied against the influence of money in politics. But in a striking turnabout, Citizen Action now finds itself accused of illegally funneling money from the teamsters union and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to the campaign coffers of the teamsters president, Ron Carey, whose election has since been overturned. A18
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
Changes in Welfare Law Are Seen as Not Drastic
Experts say that New York State's new welfare law, which goes into effect in the coming weeks, differs from the approaches taken in many other states: New York's overhaul of the welfare system is not as severe in cutting benefits and pushing people off the welfare rolls, nor as ambitious in helping recipients find and keep jobs. As a result, advocates on both the left and the right regard New York's plan as dissatisfying. A1

ARTS E1-8
 
The Other Life of Karen Finley
To see Karen Finley at home in Nyack, N.Y., may bring to mind a portrait by Sargent. But Ms. Finley's flowing skirt and long hair are the off-stage persona of a performance artist whose name is synonymous with controversy, the "chocolate-smeared woman" of Senator Jesse Helms's nightmares. In an interview, Ms. Finley discussed both her art -- highly visceral, startling monologues on social issues -- and aspects of her life that had informed it. "I think I'm a dreamer. I like to laugh. I like to poke fun at things, and I'm also crying in these throes and bemoans," she said. "People think that I'm hysterical and out of control. They expect that I'll just be taking my clothes off and using foul language, and that I would do this in my kitchen." E1

I.B.M Ready for Faster Chips
I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has solved a fundamental problem holding back the development of faster semiconductor chips and will begin manufacturing chips early next year that are smaller and up to 40 percent more powerful than the most advanced chips currently being produced commercially. A Fight Among Friends
Michael Gartner, a former president of NBC News and now the editor of The Daily Tribune in Ames, Iowa, is waging a legal campaign against the local college newspaper, The Iowa State Daily. Mr. Gartner says that the college paper is using its tax-free status, its subsidized circulation and an increasingly professionalized, nonstudent business staff to compete unfairly with his paper. Complicating the dispute is the fact that Mr. Gartner also teaches journalism to the student reporters and editors. D1

HEADLINE: The Conservative as Techno-Libertarian

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Sept. 16

 BODY:
George Gilder has a warning for would-be entrepreneurs involved with new technologies: Watch out for emperors and morons.
To the irascible conservative economist and writer, emperors are the masters of the high technology universe, like Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates. And morons are Government bureaucrats, like the departing chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt. 
 According to Mr. Gilder, both groups conspire to hold back the tide of new technology that is destined to overwhelm the old economic order and create a vastly richer economy.
Though both men were invited, it is little wonder that neither Mr. Gates nor Mr. Hundt elected to attend the first Telecosm conference, which was held at the tony Ritz-Carlton resort here, near Palm Springs, to promote his notion that the nation is in the midst of a telecommunications upheaval, one that will shake up the business to the same extent that the microprocessor shook up the computing world in the 1980's.
This revolution, Mr. Gilder says, is based on the explosion of telecommunications bandwidth -- or network carrying capacity -- that new technologies are igniting, and on the rise of Sun Microsystems' Internet-friendly Java software programming language.
The counter-revolutionaries, he argues, are Microsoft, which he sees as intent on thwarting Java to protect its software hegemony, and the F.C.C., whose policies he derides for stifling technological innovation.
"The entire information infrastructure has to be reconstituted," he told the conference audience of about 350.
A senior Microsoft executive, reached by telephone from company headquarters in Redmond, Wash., was dismissive of Mr. Gilder's thesis. "George has a few ideas that are intellectually interesting and some that are just weird," said Nathan Myhrvold, Microsoft's head of research. "He mixes them up in a way that is often disconcerting."
Mr. Myhrvold had been listed as a speaker in some early conference material, but said he canceled because of a conflict and because he had no desire to play fall guy at the Gilder event.
Mr. Hundt of the F.C.C., who said he was unable to attend because of another commitment, acknowledged that Mr. Gilder was an eloquent critic, but one who frequently permitted his gift for description to outstrip his grasp of the facts.
"He's like a great soprano who learns an aria so well everyone loves it," Mr. Hundt said by phone from Washington. "Who cares if it is not true? It sounds so good."
Those who did turn out included venture capitalists and engineers who make up a loose-knit Friends of George confederation and two celebrity financier-felons from the 1980's, Michael R. Milken (who took part in a panel on high-technology investing) and Charles H. Keating Jr. (who sat in the audience and listened)
Also on hand: the magazine publisher and former Presidential candidate Steve Forbes. Mr. Forbes, the event's co-sponsor, confessed that he was "computer-illiterate." But sounding very much like he was tuning up a stump speech for his next Presidential campaign, he warned, "Politics and regulation can proliferate and alter or even suffocate creativity and entrepreneurship."
For his part, Mr. Gilder, 58, has never been one to sidestep the provocative. He made his mark in the early 1970's as author of "Men and Marriage," a polemic against feminism that prompted Time magazine to call him "the nation's leading male chauvinist pig author," and in the 80's with a supply-side tome, "Wealth and Poverty," which provided some of the intellectual underpinnings of the Reagan Administration. A post-feminist of sorts, he still shows up from time to time at workshops, sketcing his views on the state of male-female relations.
But Mr. Gilder has turned his word processor largely to new media and information technology, including articles in Forbes magazine and its high-technology supplement Forbes ASAP.
A year ago, he began the Gilder Technology Report as a joint venture between Forbes and the Gilder Technology Group Inc., a consulting and publishing company he established. The monthly eight-page newsletter, which costs $295, has drawn 8,000 subscribers in the first year.
Mr. Gilder's special passion these days is lambasting the the F.C.C. and the Clinton Administration for the strategy of privatizing the radio frequency spectrum by auctioning it off to corporations -- a market approach that Mr. Hundt said might seem to sit well with conservatives.
Not so for Mr. Gilder, who argues that bandwidth is essentially a free resource and that regulating it is foolhardy. He has been on a crusade for the last two years to convince anyone who will listen that by using new types of "smart radios," it would be possible for millions of users to share the airwaves. The smart radios would do this by sending and receiving transmissions that avoided collisions with each other, much the way car drivers generally do.
"The information highway model can apply to the spectrum," he said. "We don't speed, and we have rules of the road. You should give driver's licenses to people who want to transmit."
It is a radical -- and, for many radio engineers, a naively utopian -- view of the communications future.
"No one knows what the cost of wireless connection will be, or the technical issues of actually delivering such bandwidth in a reliable way," said Cary Lu, a researcher and author of the technical guide "Understanding Bandwidth," to be published later this year by the Microsoft Press. "To be honest, the cost of such data delivery by wire is not known, either."
Helping set the anti-Microsoft tone of the conference was Sun Microsystems' chief executive, Scott G. McNealy, who complained in an opening-night speech that his company and its Java programming language had become "ground zero" for what he called a Microsoft carpet-bombing approach to the software industry.
Mr. McNealy groused that it was difficult to compete against Mr. Gates, a man he suggested was able to "personally overdraw his checkbook by $400 million" -- a seeming allusion to Microsoft's recent purchase of the WebTV Networks, which provide Internet access through television sets.
Although Mr. Gilder did a brisk business at the conference selling copies of his books, which include "Life After Television" (1992), he did not carry out a plan to make the conference a coming-out party for his new book, "Telecosm," which has been appearing as excerpts for several years in Forbes ASAP.
As frequently happens with the software developers that Mr. Gilder celebrates in his writing, the project has fallen behind schedule. Mr. Gilder said he was still rewriting the opening chapters of "Telecosm" to set down the main themes in clearer form.
So it was left to a lieutenant, Charles Frank, vice president of the Gilder Technology Group, to tell those attending that they would have to wait for next year's conference, Telecosm 2.0, to buy the book.
But it will be worth the wait, Mr. Frank assured the crowd, adding, "This will be a Gilder version of 'It Takes a Village.' "

CORRECTION-DATE: September 24, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about an information technology conference organized by the author George Gilder referred incompletely to Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan executive, who attended. While he was convicted on charges stemming from the collapse of a savings and loan association, both Federal and state convictions were overturned last year.

HEADLINE: Small Daily Tries to Teach College Paper a Lesson

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa

 BODY:
This town may be as placid a place as there is in a state where good manners and neighborliness seem as much a part of the landscape as corn and soybeans. Yet a legal campaign by the owners of the local daily newspaper to curtail competition for advertising and readers from the campus paper could set off repercussions at dozens of public colleges whose student papers have come to act more and more like the commercial variety.
On the one side stands Michael G. Gartner, former editor of The Des Moines Register, former president of NBC News, a Pulitzer Prize winner and a lawyer. He maintains that The Iowa State Daily is using its tax-free status, its subsidized circulation and an increasingly professionalized, nonstudent business staff to compete unfairly with his paper, The Daily Tribune of Ames, first by trying to expand circulation off campus and now by soliciting advertising from noncampus businesses. 
 On the other side stand the student reporters and editors, and their paid business, advertising and production staff. They maintain that The Iowa State Daily would fail if it were forced to curtail its drive to expand off-campus.
Like any small town rivalry, the one here is complicated by the fact that both sides are closely intertwined. Mr. Gartner and his partner, Gary G. Gerlach, the publisher of The Tribune, teach journalism classes for the student reporters and editors who work on The Iowa State Daily. And so many of The Daily's students get their first professional newspaper jobs at The Tribune after graduation that it functions as the university's unofficial graduate school in journalism.
"I love the kids at The Daily," Mr. Gartner said. "I teach over there, I give them an enormous amount of my time, and I want to see them succeed. I just don't want them to stab me in my back when I put out my paper and sell my ads."
Citing an Iowa law banning competition from state agencies with private business, a law similar to ones in many states, Mr. Gartner and Mr. Gerlach, who is also a lawyer, have gone after The Iowa State Daily on several fronts. They have already succeeded in forcing The Daily to close a professionally produced free-distribution campus paper and to cut back its circulation area -- which briefly encompassed all of Ames and outlying parts of Story County -- back to the campus and its immediate surroundings.
The partners have brought an administrative action to force the university to expand the number of places their own free weekly, The Campus Reader, can be distributed. They are also in court seeking $130,000 in legal fees for another suit that produced a judgment that The Daily was a part of state government, and not a free-standing, nonprofit company, as The Daily had argued.
But the focus of the fight is advertising. Citing the anti-competition law, Mr. Gartner wants The Iowa State Daily, with a circulation of 14,000, to restrict its advertising to businesses on campus and in the immediate student-oriented tavern and restaurant district adjoining the campus. That would mean giving up the auto dealerships, the real estate agencies and other advertisers that have helped push The Daily's advertising revenues up from $600,000 in 1992 to more than $1 million last year, while the amount of advertising space sold rose 25 percent.
"I would say that there is some level of competition going on," said Warren R. Madden, vice president for business and finance at Iowa State University. "But I don't believe it is unfair competition. I assume local merchants want to advertise in a student newspaper to generate some business -- that's what a free market is all about."
The Tribune is profitable and its circulation has increased to 10,000 from about 8,000 since Mr. Gartner and Mr. Gerlach bought the paper 11 years ago. Yet the partners maintain that at least some of the business that now goes to The Daily would come to their paper if, as Mr. Gartner put it, "there weren't professionals selling and marketing the newspaper in ways that we believe they should not be."
The management of The Iowa State Daily, however, contends that a victory by the Tribune would kill both journalism education and the student paper itself. "What he is asking us to do is to pull back and try to live on ads for pizza and beer," said John Hobson, a senior in marketing who is chairman of the Publications Board, which oversees The Daily. "I doubt we could stay alive."
The Daily was in fact losing money during the recession earlier in the decade. It began building up large surpluses after 1992, as the economy improved and a new general manager -- hired from The Tribune -- and advertising director set the paper on an expansion course.
The added revenues have paid for new computers, digital cameras for campus photographers and a new computerized page-design system. The money also pays for a paid business staff of nine -- three of them employed year-round, five on a nine-month basis, and an hourly classified advertising manager -- with an annual payroll of $193,000. In 1977, when The Daily had a circulation of 15,000, there were only three.
To the partners, the accretion of paid professionals at The Daily is a detriment to the students, not a benefit. "Life on a big state university can be pretty comfortable," said Mr. Gerlach, who had been the publisher of The Des Moines Register when Mr. Gartner was editor. "The hours aren't too demanding, the benefits are pretty good, and I think some of these professionals have moved into these student organizations and kind of feathered their nests."
Yet most student dailies have similarly professionalized their business staffs over the years, supplying a management continuity that students cannot provide, said Mark Goodman, executive director of the Student Press Law Center, who had tried to mediate the town-gown newspaper war here before it could be echoed in other college towns.
"They might well argue that the advertising staff at The Daily is professional, but 80 percent of the campus papers in this country are set up in exactly the same way," Mr. Goodman said of Mr. Gartner and Mr. Gerlach. He added, "I cannot imagine more than a handful of college newspapers in the country that could continue in any way shape or form if they could not solicit ads off campus."
Predictably, as campus papers come to operate more and more like their private competitors, community papers have begun to grumble. "I think there would be fallout in other places if Michael wins this thing," said Charles T. Wanninger, publisher of The Iowa City Press-Citizen, which recently shifted from afternoon to morning publication in part to meet the competition from The Daily Iowan, the University of Iowa campus paper, which is also published in the morning. "Some people wonder why we worry about a campus paper, but they do compete in some key areas of the business, including for our readers' time."
A more glaring case is in Columbia, Mo., where the University of Missouri's School of Journalism publishes The Missourian, which is both professionally managed and edited, as a teaching experience, by faculty members. The use of both state-supported facilities and an editing staff reduces The Missourian's overhead costs to the point where it can undercut the advertising rates of The Columbia Daily Tribune, the local community daily.
"We have complained about it all the way to the university president," said Jim Robertson, managing editor of The Daily Tribune. "They always sound sympathetic, but nothing changes."
But then there are publishers like Lou Heldman of The Center Daily Times in College Station, Pa., who is conscious of the competition from The Collegian, the campus paper of Pennsylvania State University, without caring to do much about it.
"The Collegian is very strong and it gets a subsidy from the university and it certainly takes a lot of advertising revenue out of the market," Mr. Heldman said. "So on one hand it would be easy to be pretty upset about that. But I was the editor of the campus newspaper at Ohio State, which is very similar to The Collegian, and so many of us learned so much that's been so useful from that experience that I wouldn't have it in my heart to go after the campus newspaper. . . ."
Besides having no real estate taxes or utilities to pay for, The Iowa State Daily receives $100,000 a year from student fees to cover subscription costs for the free paper. That figure is close to the annual surplus the paper has produced over the last five years, $115,000 on average, and Mr. Gartner calls it The Daily's "slush fund" to undercut his own paper. Trim back the off-campus advertising, he says, make up the lost revenue by reducing the professional staff to its historic level, and he will back off.
The journalism professors who advise The Daily are divided on the issue. Richard H. Haws, this year's faculty adviser to The Daily, concedes that The Daily was the "aggressor" when it upset the traditional marketing balance between the two papers.
But Thomas L. Beell, who advised the paper last year, calls Mr. Gartner and Mr. Gerlach "corporate thugs" for expecting The Daily to confine its marketing area. "Students live and travel all over town," Mr. Beell said. "To assume that The Daily's advertisers have to be limited to the campus area is idiotic."
The success of The Ames Tribune has helped the partners assemble a small but growing cluster of daily and weekly papers in central Iowa. But despite this success elsewhere, neither man is inclined to back off the law suits. Indeed, both men are now watching The Daily's development of a World Wide Web site for any signs of advertising that would compete with The Tribune's own Web site. "That's the next lawsuit," Mr. Gartner said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1997, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Monday about a dispute between The Daily Tribune of Ames, Iowa, and The Iowa State Daily misstated the location of Penn State University. It is in State College, Pa., not College Station.

HEADLINE: Broadway Tries Analysis And Gets Shock Therapy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Despite some signs of life, the New York theater industry is still in decline and beset by rising costs and lagging audiences, an unusually detailed industry-sponsored study has concluded.
Bain & Company, a Boston-based consulting company that specializes in analyzing troubled businesses, has delivered a report that depicts the Broadway theater as performing at about half-capacity and losing market share to all other forms of entertainment. 
 Runaway costs have made the economics of mounting and operating a show so forbidding, the report says, that producers have gravitated to the most risk-free productions, making Broadway a showcase for revivals and large-scale, long-running musicals rather than for innovative new work.
"Generally speaking, the report shows an industry that has slowly, over time, declined," said Jack Goldstein, an official at Actors' Equity and the leader of the Broadway Initiative Working Group, which commissioned the report and includes theater owners, producers and unions. "We're not going out of business tomorrow, but if the problems outlined in the report are not addressed, the theater industry will be severely depleted."
The report has not been made public, but a copy was obtained by The New York Times from a member of the theater coalition, which is working on a $10 million production fund that it hopes will let Broadway offer more serious work through reduced theater rents, zoning changes and tax breaks.
The report is political as well as economic. Its immediate purpose was to unify the fractious members of the theater industry by administering a dose of shock therapy and, ultimately, to help Broadway present a persuasive case to the city for financial help or tax incentives. Bain was chosen, Mr. Goldstein said, in part because it had a good track record of analyzing troubled industries but also because, as an outsider, it would not be suspected of favoritism or bias.
The report relied on interviews and financial records gathered from producers, theatrical unions, advertising agencies and theater owners. It paints a picture of an industry with structural problems that invite comparison to the United States auto or steel industries in the 1970's.
The cost of producing a Broadway show has risen between 350 and 400 percent in real terms over the last 30 years, far outpacing the 80 percent increase in ticket prices over the same period, the report found. While top prices for musicals now can run to $75 a ticket, revenues have grown at an average annual rate of only 2 percent.
Cost increases have been especially high for advertising, union benefits and administrative charges imposed by theaters, and the greater technical demands for musicals have translated into soaring costs for building and installing sets, the report said.
Furthermore, the industry is plagued by underused capacity, with the smaller theaters lighted only 40 to 50 percent of the time.
While costs have shot upward, the Broadway audience has not grown, and the theater has lost market share to film, television, sports and casino gambling. On top of this, the report found, the theater's pool of writers, directors and actors has fled in large numbers to television and film.
The report takes a long historical view, comparing the Broadway of the 1920's with the Broadway of today. The contrasts are stark. In the 1920's, Broadway had 80 theaters presenting 218 productions each year, about 150 of them new plays and 45 of them new musicals. Only about 20 plays were revivals. In the 1990's, Broadway's 35 theaters have presented a little more than 30 productions each year. As in the 1920's, about a fifth have been new musicals, but new plays now account for only a third of the total, and revivals, once a tiny percentage of the total, now account for about a third of the shows on Broadway.
Revivals of plays and musicals have proved to be a less risky investments than new work, especially in the 1990's, when half of the play revivals on Broadway recouped their investment, compared with 24 percent of new plays. Seventy-three percent of musical revivals recouped investments, compared with 10 percent of new musicals.
In other words, the number of shows has dropped, but the percentage of shows recouping their investment has risen, as has the number of shows with at least 1,000 performances, from about 21 percent of all productions in the 1940's, to 35 percent in the 1970's and 80's. These statistics suggest a stagnant, conservative artistic institution.
Just as startling is the decline of Broadway as an originator of creative material. In the 1965-66 season, nearly two-thirds of the 50 shows that opened were new plays and musicals developed on Broadway, with most of the remaining productions being imports from London. In the 1995-96 season, about 10 percent of the 36 productions originated on Broadway. The rest came from London (10 percent), non-Broadway theaters (20 percent), the movies (5 percent) or were revivals (55 percent).
"From an overall financial point of view, the industry looks relatively healthy because of the great success of a few long-running musicals," the report stated. The success of such musicals, it argues, disguises the serious and growing problems facing plays and smaller musicals, and the creative vigor of Broadway as an institution. Patrick Graham, a partner at Bain, said, "If the issues are not addressed, I am convinced Broadway will dwindle to 5 or 10 theaters filled with musicals."
Not all the news was bleak. Broadway remains a potent brand name, the report concluded, with enormous potential for the kind of marketing and promotion common in other industries but untested by the theater. The way forward is likely to be difficult, however. Cost reduction is imperative, the report said, but "it will not be possible for Broadway to cost-reduce itself to prosperity." To survive, Broadway must expand its audience, increase production of new plays, make it easier to buy tickets and develop a ticket-pricing system that allows different audience segments to pay different prices.
The theater owners, producers and unions appear to have accepted the findings of the report, whose $100,000 cost was shared by the city Department of Planning and a joint fund administered by the Theater Development Fund and the League of American Theaters and Producers.
"They have accepted a very hard analysis," said Mr. Graham, the Bain partner. "We've told them: 'Look, you're losing out to every other form of entertainment in New York, but there's a lot you can do. You're not bankrupt, you're not dead, but everybody else is doing better. You guys have got to pull together, and you've got to get your costs in line."
The numbers did not come as a surprise, Mr. Graham said, but they had a sobering effect on the Broadway Initiative Working Group, which includes 30 industry representatives. "Everybody in the room knew some of it, but nobody knew all of it," he said. "The magnitudes were different than they expected. Not even they realized that returns to investors were what they are."
The report also depicts Broadway theaters as a social system with two classes: an aristocracy of large musical houses and a proletariat of small and medium-size theaters. The large musical houses, with 1,500 or more seats, have stayed lighted 80 percent of the time in the 1990's, compared with about half the time for the other houses.
For the struggling houses, the highway to profitability is steep, with very narrow shoulders. In 1965, a typical play in a 1,000-seat theater recouped its investment after a 15-week run at 85 percent of capacity or a 25-week run at 75 percent of capacity. In 1995, this play requires a 30-week run to break even at 85 percent of capacity, and the run would have to double, to 60 weeks, for the play to break eve at 75 percent of capacity.
In 1965, a musical in a 1,500-seat house could recoup in 20 weeks at 95 percent of capacity or 30 weeks at 90 percent. In 1995, a musical needed 65 weeks to break even at 95 percent of capacity or 90 weeks at 90 percent.
The report includes recommendations to expand the theater audience and increase production, including more aggressive marketing and a ticket-pricing policy that would raise prices for some segments of the audience and lower them for others.
"Broadway has many of the characteristics of an undersupported brand," Mr. Graham said. "They have never tried modern marketing. There are a range of things they can do to improve their situation, which is not nearly as dire as some of the industries we study."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Mixed Ahead Of Auctions

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, in trading that was slightly above average for a Monday.
The dollar's rise against most currencies in European trading yesterday lent some early strength to the bond market. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors who stand to gain on currency conversion. 
 Traders noted that the upward trend was also helped by the fact that few market participants expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates anytime soon.
But the session's gains faded at the close as the Government set up its note auctions this week, beginning with today's sale of $15.5 billion in new two-year notes and Wednesday's $11.5 billion in five-year notes. In when-issued trading the two-year maturity was offered at a price to yield 5.76 percent; the five-year to yield 5.95 percent.
Analysts said participants are waiting until the auctions are finished and more economic data are available before making any large bets.
The 30-year bond rose 10/32 to a price of 100 10/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, slipped to 6.35 percent, from 6.37 percent on Friday.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and manager of bond trading at Cowen & Company, said "Besides the supply factor, I think, if nothing else, the market is technically overbought, and without some backup in prices, there is a little reluctance on the part of investors to take new positions in front of coming supply."
He added that the market was so overbought that "this supply might be needed to correct that condition by provoking a little bit of selloff."
At yesterday's weekly bill auction, rates were down on good demand, given the economic turmoil in Southeast Asia and the fact that the end of the quarter is near. The average rate for a three-month bill was 4.90 percent, down from 4.91 percent last week, while the six-month maturity was 5.04 percent, down from 5.08 percent.
Mr. Gamba called all bills expensive. "Once you sell them, it's impossible to buy them back," he said.
But some economists said that the troubles in some Asian economies could eventually depress bond prices in this country, pushing up yields.
"All told, foreigners have purchased over $500 billion in U.S. Treasury securities since 1993," Sung Wong Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said. "The torrent of foreign money has not abated during the first half of this year. Furthermore, five Asian countries -- Japan, Singapore, China, Hong Kong and Taiwan -- accounted for 14 percent of total private holdings of Treasury securities. The five countries account for fully 40 percent of foreign purchases since 1994."
Mr. Sohn said there were two opposite forces at work. "First, there is the safe-haven effect," he said, adding, "Undoubtedly, the recent rally in Treasuries has been aided by this factor."
But Asia's depressed economies and currency markets could eventually have a ripple effect in the United States if Asian investors slow purchases or cash out some of their Treasury holdings, he noted.
"Many Asian investors and banks need to shore up weakened balance sheets," he said, so the longer-term effect here could be to force up interest rates.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Dips Against the Yen, But Shows Strength Elsewhere

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed against most major currencies but dipped against the Japanese yen yesterday after major industrial nations reiterated their concern that the yen might become too weak.
The Group of Seven industrial nations, meeting over the weekend in Hong Kong, issued a statement that they would fight excessive currency price moves that might cause large trade imbalances. 
 Officials at the conference said the statement was meant to convey that the Group of Seven nations opposed sharp declines by the yen, which would tend to increase Japan's already large trade surplus by making Japanese goods cheaper and more competitive in global markets.
"The G-7 said that it didn't want to see Japan weaken its currency to spur exports and it does look like the market is not willing to push the dollar higher," said Robert Sabia, vice president at ING Barings Capital Markets.
The dollar fell sharply against the yen when trading began in East Asia, but later rebounded just as sharply when short-term players booked profits.
"There was some extreme volatility, but when you take that out, it looks like a fairly benign news event," said Seth Garrett, chief dealer at Credit Suisse First Boston. " All in all, the fundamental economic picture has not changed dramatically."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 121.75 yen, down from 122.28 yen on Friday. The dollar rose to 1.7914 marks from 1.7759 marks and to 1.4712 Swiss francs from 1.4630 Swiss francs. The British pound fell to $1.6049 from $1.6124.
The dollar rose against the mark and other European currencies after German officials expressed comfort with current foreign exchange rates.
A member of the Bundesbank council, Edgar Meister, told reporters in Hong Kong that most currency rates were at broadly satisfactory levels and that Germany would not oppose a gradual rise by the dollar against the mark.
"The G-7 didn't do anything to disrupt existing trends among major exchange rates," said Bob Lynch, currency strategist at Banque Paribas in New York. "By and large, the group seems largely satisfied with the way things are going."

HEADLINE: Market Place: Quality Service, With Wings;
Midwest Express Profits By Pampering Passengers

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
Susan Dietman of Plano, Tex., has been flying Midwest Express between Dallas and Milwaukee almost every weekend for four years. Asked why she was so loyal, she ticked off some familiar reasons: adequate leg room, good food, nonstop flights and attentive service. Then she added a new one:
"When I pulled into the Dallas airport over Labor Day," said Ms. Dietman, an information systems manager at J. C. Penney, "it was threatening rain and the front window on the passenger side of my car disappeared inside the door, and I couldn't get it up." A Midwest ticket agent came to her rescue, spending 45 minutes fixing it. 
 "Then he took my tickets," Ms. Dietman said, "and while I drove to the parking lot he checked me in."
If that ticket agent's skills were surprising, his attitude was not -- not to Midwest Express loyalists, anyway. "A lot of airlines take the position, 'You have to fly. We're here, so get on board,' " said Don D. Johnson, a frequent flier and the owner of American Mail Service, a direct-mail company in Ralston, Neb. "Midwest Express people have the attitude that you represent money in their pocket, so how can they help?"
At a time when many carriers, judged by their economy-class service, could be called Spartan Air, Midwest consistently wins awards for pampering passengers on its all-coach planes. And while other carriers seem eager to lure ever more passengers with cut-rate fares, Midwest resists this temptation, content with its own modest, but profitable, niche.
Indeed, analysts also love Milwaukee-based Midwest Express, which traces its origins to 1948, when the Kimberly-Clark Corporation began transporting its employees to remote mill locations in a prop plane. In 1984, it started commercial service with two leased jets and daily flights from Milwaukee to Boston, Dallas and Appleton, Wis. Spun off by Kimberly-Clark in September 1995, it is on course toward its 11th consecutive profitable year -- a span that includes five of the worst years in airline history. In the two years since that spinoff, the stock has doubled.
[The shares closed Monday at $30.75, up 50 cents.]
"From 1990 through 1994, only Midwest Express and Southwest were profitable every year," said Timothy E. Hoeksema, Midwest's 50-year-old chairman, president and chief executive, in a recent interview at the Milwaukee headquarters. To be sure, some of those profits were razor thin. In the fallout from the Persian Gulf war, Midwest's earnings in 1991 nearly vanished: 2 cents a share, from 46 cents in 1990. But nearly all other airlines were in the red.
Mr. Hoeksema, who flew his first solo flight at 16 and later became Kimberly-Clark's chief pilot, is widely credited with imbuing Midwest Express with a culture unparalleled in commercial aviation.
"He's been able to transfer to the airline business the philosophy and business principles of the corporation, including the zeal for pleasing the customer," said Dennis Crabtree, vice president for operations.
From the beginning, Midwest Express's strategy has been relatively simple: focus primarily on business travelers in cities with strong business bases that have few if any nonstop flights -- especially nonstops to and from Milwaukee or Omaha, where in 1994 the carrier established a mini-hub.
The one time Midwest Express departed from its game plan, entering the highly competitive Milwaukee-Detroit market in 1988, it suffered substantial losses before pulling out four years later.
When Midwest said recently that it would acquire eight MD-80's, for delivery through 1999, Mr. Hoeksema said it was part of a strategy "of profitable and controlled growth." Some existing routes, he added, are candidates for expansion, and some new routes may be coming.
For all the adulation, relatively few people have flown Midwest Express. Although it now ventures as far afield as New York, San Diego, San Francisco and Orlando, Fla., most of its 35,000 yearly flights -- about the number flown by Delta, United or American in less than three weeks -- are not much longer than 600 miles, compared with an industry average of just under 1,000.
Its 1.4 million passengers last year were a blip next to the 581.2 million passengers flown by the nation's big airlines, or even the 62 million commuter airline passengers.
How has Midwest, with so few passengers, earned such lofty praise? One big reason is that at a time when coach passengers are routinely shoehorned into narrow knees-to-chin seats, Midwest's all-coach fleet -- 24 DC-9's and 2 (soon to be 10) MD-80's -- features all-leather seats that are several inches wider and deeper than is typical in economy class. And there are no middle seats.
In this year's Consumer Reports Travel Letter rating of coach seats, Midwest's DC-9's received a "comfort score" of 100 and its MD-80's a 98, while most other carriers scored between 64 and 80.
"Their seats are the equivalent of first-class seats on most aircraft," said Ernest Hanchey, a project manager with HKS Inc., an architectural firm in Dallas, who flies Midwest Express to Milwaukee about every two weeks. "But I also like the fact that you get a real meal instead of a bistro bag."
Midwest Express pampering includes free newspapers at check-in, free champagne at breakfast and free wine at lunch and dinner -- meals served on china with silverware and linen napkins. Dinners include lobster and steak, poached salmon, lobster thermidor, shrimp cocktail and fruit.
After lunch and dinner, the carrier serves its trademark chocolate chip cookies, hot from the on-board oven.
Despite shorter flights than those of most other airlines, Midwest spends more on food than any other carrier in the United States, an average of $9.59 for each passenger, according to Consumer Reports, about $2 more than American and United spend and more than twice the outlays of the other big airlines. At the bottom of the list were U.S. Airways, spending $2.50, and Southwest, which averages just 20 cents on its flights under three hours.
"Back in the early 1990's, when airlines were bleeding money," Mr. Hoeksema said, "we could have saved millions cutting back on our food, but we would have lost our reputation."
Indeed, Midwest is so uniformly popular with its customers that, unlike almost all the sizable airlines, it has not even been included in the Transportation Department's ranking of customer complaints in recent years because it has not received the minimum 10 complaints a year.
The revenues of Midwest Express Holdings -- the parent company of Midwest and Skyway Airlines, Midwest's eight-year-old commuter line -- have grown an average of 24 percent a year for 10 years. Its net income increased to almost $21.8 million last year, or $3.40 a share, compared with $19.1 million in 1995, or $2.77.
Moreover, the airline's revenue for each passenger flown, or yield, rose 8.1 percent last year, to 19.3 cents a mile. While the eight-month suspension of the 10 percent excise tax on airline tickets helped, Midwest's yield still far exceeded the industry average of 12.9 cents.
Its secret? While Midwest generally keeps its fares in line with those of its rivals, it rarely matches their rock-bottom promotional fares and keeps a careful check on seat inventory.
"On our Monday morning flights to New York," Mr. Hoeksema said, "we may only have four seats open for lower fares."
Mr. Hoeksema disclaims any desire to become "a huge airline."
With no debt, cash flow last year of $29.4 million, a $55 million line of bank credit and a backup $20 million from Kimberly-Clark until 2000, "capital is not our growth constraint," he said.
"The constraint to our growth," he continued, "is how fast we can grow without losing our focus and control of our quality."
His goal, he said, is to expand capacity 12 to 18 percent a year, to continue to be a good place to work and to earn the best return for stockholders. Midwest became 100 percent publicly owned in May 1996, when Kimberly-Clark, which had moved its headquarters from Neenah, Wis., to Dallas, sold its remaining 20 percent stake. Officers, directors and employees own about 6.4 percent of the 6.4 million shares.
Salaries at Midwest Express, a nonunion airline, are well below those of the major carriers, but about average for a carrier its size: pilots earn about $75,000 a year, and flight attendants' pay ranges from $14,500 to $24,000. Employees also received a bonus of 8 percent of their base salary last year from a profit-sharing plan.
Brenda Skelton, senior vice president for marketing services, attributes the carrier's success to its discipline in everything from routes to fares to its fleet, which consists of 14 company-owned planes and 12 leased ones.
Midwest buys used aircraft almost exclusively, paying about $8 million: half for the plane itself and the other $4 million to rebuild it and install "hush kits" -- noise-reduction devices that most airlines are installing to comply with the Dec. 31, 1999, deadline for meeting Federal noise reduction requirements.
"A new aircraft," Ms. Skelton said, "would cost north of $20 million." While Midwest is acquiring those eight MD-80's, for an undisclosed sum, it is considering turning the deal into a sale-leaseback.
The Midwest fleet is about 23 years old, one of the oldest in the industry, but is relatively youthful based on a more important gauge: landings and takeoffs, or cycles. Noting that DC-9's are certified for a life of at least 100,000 cycles, Robinson-Humphrey, the Atlanta brokerage firm, noted in a research report earlier this year that the Midwest fleet averages fewer than 50,000 because it buys planes with fewer cycles.
The only blot on the Midwest Express safety record occurred in September 1985, when one of its DC-9's crashed on takeoff in Milwaukee, killing all 31 aboard. The National Transportation Safety Board ruled that the probable cause was pilot error.
Fittingly for an airline that evolved from a corporate culture, most Midway Express flights are set up so that business travelers can get where they are going and return that night. And business travelers are in the majority even on its two daily nonstops to Orlando, arguably the family leisure capital of the world.
"When we thought about serving Orlando, we weren't interested in the $89 round trip; we said let's serve it as a business market," said Bob Bahlman, Midwest's chief financial officer. "If we wanted market share instead of profitability, we'd have five round trips a day, instead of two."
Similarly, the airline flies a daily nonstop between Milwaukee and San Francisco. But in the winter, it shifts that plane to Phoenix, which attracts many Midwestern "snowbirds." It also serves the Florida cities of Tampa, Fort Myers and Fort Lauderdale in winter, then shifts those planes to more profitable markets.
"In the beginning, we were afraid we might not get our regular passengers back, especially in San Francisco," Mr. Bahlman said. "But," he added, a satisfied gleam in his eye, "when we return, they're there waiting."

HEADLINE: Timothy W. Stanley, 69, Expert On Defense Policy and Strategies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Timothy Wadsworth Stanley, an authority on defense policy who served in the 1960's as assistant to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara for NATO force planning and then as a defense adviser, with the rank of minister, in the United States mission to NATO, died on Sunday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 69.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, said his daughter Alessandra, who is co-chief of The New York Times's Moscow bureau. 
 Mr. Stanley held defense posts in the Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Administrations. He was a special assistant on the White House staff during the Eisenhower Administration, from 1957 to 1959, and held other Pentagon posts before that and later. He was an assistant to Secretary McNamara, based in Paris, from 1965 to 1967, and a minister in the NATO mission, based in Paris and Brussels, from 1967 to 1969.
He was awarded the United States' Distinguished Civilian Service medal in 1969 for work he had done in Europe, including playing a key role in getting agreement from other NATO countries on the proposed strategy of "flexible response," which had been the subject of contention, within the alliance, since the Kennedy Administration began.
He went on to be a visiting professor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies in 1969 and 1970, and he also taught at Harvard and George Washington Universities over the years. In 1973 and 1974 he was special representative of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in Vienna, during negotiations about East-West mutual balanced force reductions.
Mr. Stanley later worked as a political economist specializing in international matters. He was president and then chairman of the International Economic Policy Association, a Washington-based consulting firm, from 1974 to 1987. During those years, he also became president of the International Economic Studies Institute, a Washington-based not-for-profit think tank. He held that post until 1996.
His many writings include the book "NATO in Transition: The Future of the Atlantic Alliance" (1965). In his later years he often testified as an expert witness before Congressional committees.
Mr. Stanley was born in Hartford, grew up in New Britain, Conn., received a bachelor's degree in 1950 from Yale and a law degree in 1955 and a doctorate in political science in 1957, both from Harvard.
He served in the Army from 1946 to 1948 and in 1951 and 1952, rising to first lieutenant. It was while he studied political science at Harvard that he became interested in defense and in international relations as policy matters. And he also went on to be admitted to the bars of the Supreme Courts of Connecticut and of the United States.
In addition to his daughter Alessandra, he is survived by his wife of 45 years, the former Nadia Leon; two sons, Timothy W. 3d of Manhattan and Christopher M. of Cambridge, Mass.; another daughter, Flavia M. of Northampton, Mass; and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Herzliya Journal;
Spring Forward, Fall Back Into a Religious Debate

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: HERZLIYA, Israel, Sept. 21

 BODY:
As the sun dipped toward the horizon late this afternoon, Yaniv and Efrat Peri hurried down to the beach to get in a quick walk before darkness fell on this seaside town north of Tel Aviv.
With temperatures here still in the 80's during Israel's lingering summer, the country has suddenly gone off daylight saving time, moving into what Israelis call the "winter clock" weeks ahead of neighboring countries, Europe and the United States. 
 On Sunday the Peris managed their first sunset walk after work since clocks were set back an hour on Sept. 13, bringing dusk soon after 5:30 P.M.
"What proper country is under such influence of the religious?" Mr. Peri said. "It's simply a disgrace."
He was referring to the move by Interior Minister Eliahu Suissa, a member of Shas, a strictly Orthodox party, to lop a month off Israeli daylight saving time, which began March 20 and was supposed to have lasted until Oct. 19.
Mr. Suissa has defended his decision on religious grounds, adding to the simmering debate here over the role religion should play in regulating everyday life. The debate has sharpened since the change of government after national elections last year, when Orthodox Jewish parties gained key Cabinet posts in the conservative coalition led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Setting back the clocks has pushed the balmy Mediterranean evenings here into the end of the workday and rush hour, forcing commuters to drive home in twilight. Children leave playgrounds earlier to go home, lights come on sooner and air-conditioners are switched on earlier in the morning to counter the effects of a stronger sun.
The Israel Electric Company says it saved $3 million during the period of daylight saving time this year, and the Manufacturers Association of Israel has estimated total savings for the Israeli economy at an average of $114,000 a day. Some Israeli studies have even shown a decline in traffic accidents during daylight saving time and higher worker productivity.
But Mr. Suissa says the change of rhythm is necessary for the approaching fast day of Yom Kippur and penitential prayers known as selihot said by observant Sephardic Jews at midnight or dawn during the month before the fast.
Setting back the clock, Mr. Suissa asserts, makes selihot prayer times more convenient and hastens the end of the Yom Kippur fast, which falls on Oct. 11 and is observed by many secular as well as religious Israelis.
To Mr. Suissa the time change is an act of consideration for Israel's religious minority, similar to allowances made for Israeli Arabs.
"We demand at least the same rights given to another population," Mr. Suissa said, arguing that daylight saving time has been delayed in the past to accommodate Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting. "I'm asking for at least the same right so I can fast decently on Yom Kippur."
Raphael Haim, an Orthodox Sephardic Jew in Jerusalem who recites selihot every night, said the cancellation of daylight saving time had moved up the starting hour for prayer, at the midpoint between sunset and sunrise.
"It's good for me because now we start at 11:30 P.M. instead of 12:30 A.M., which later leaves me an extra hour to sleep," he said. "It shouldn't bother anyone because it merely restores the original clock. It's also good for the family, because you can put the kids to bed earlier."
But Mr. Suissa's move has brought down the wrath of secular Israelis, who accuse him of trying to run their lives according to religious dictates.
"Minister Suissa thinks he is God," Yossi Sarid, a leader of the leftist Meretz party, said in remarks broadcast on army radio. "God says: 'Let there be light,' and there is light. God says: 'Let there be darkness,' and there is darkness. Minister Suissa has delusions of grandeur. It's not enough that he represents God, he is God himself. He says: 'Let there be darkness' in the middle of the summer, and he wants us to live in darkness."
Amit Artman, from Ramat Gan, near Tel Aviv, wrote an angry letter to the editor of the newspaper Haaretz recently, condemning "the winter clock inflicted on us prematurely by the Interior Minister, at a time when we are all still sweating in a hot and humid Mediterranean summer."
Zamira Segev wrote from Jerusalem that she had "the growing feeling that a whole country is being run in lunatic fashion, as if it were hostage to some strange cult." She added, "We won't take this much longer."
Mr. Suissa says he would rather do away with daylight saving time altogether, but he has formed a committee of experts to review the question, which has been the subject of political controversy and repeated study in Israel for years.
Periods of daylight saving time in Israel have fluctuated in recent decades, reflecting the tug-of-war between religious and economic considerations. Two years ago, experts in the Israeli Ministry of Energy recommended that daylight saving time last 240 days, from the beginning of March to late October, corresponding to the number of days in Israel when air-conditioning is usually needed.
The Interior and Energy Ministers of the Labor Government then in power planned a gradual extension of daylight saving time to meet that goal. But Mr. Suissa and the rightist-religious coalition voted into office last year reversed that trend, reducing the days of daylight saving time this year to 178. Parliament's Interior Committee voted last week to shorten daylight saving time next year even more, ending it on Sept. 6.
"It's depressing," said Zehava Alus, who caught the last rays of sun on a mostly deserted Herzliya beach. "There is religious coercion, and I think the religious will have a decisive influence in the next few years. It's going to be very serious."
