HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
New Economic Chief Sees Slow March to Open China Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 22

 BODY:
China's newly elevated economic chief, Zhu Rongji, said today that he planned to move cautiously in opening the nation's markets and exposing its sclerotic state-owned enterprises to foreign competition.
But Mr. Zhu, in his first public comments since becoming one of the country's three top leaders last week, also declared that it was "unreasonable to exclude China from the W.T.O.," a reference to the continued insistence by the United States that China agree to a rigorous timetable for liberalizing its economy before it can join the World Trade Organization. 
 The Clinton Administration, officials in Washington say, is under growing pressure to relax some of those requirements before President Jiang Zemin makes a state visit to Washington late next month. Later this week, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin will spend two days in Beijing to set the stage for that meeting.
While Mr. Zhu doled out morsels to a hungry audience of bankers and investors here today -- about new tax policies, protecting China's currency and finding work for millions of laborers whose jobs are threatened by privatization plans -- what he said was nearly overshadowed by how he said it. He joked easily, answered questions right from the floor, and made no effort to minimize the problems of China's deeply troubled banking system.
"It wasn't exactly Oprah," a senior American official said afterward, "but it wasn't the China we are used to seeing."
On a key question many in the audience wanted answered -- how, exactly, China plans to transfer ownership of industries from the Government to some form of shareholding without casting millions of workers into the streets -- Mr. Zhu bobbed and weaved. But that was expected, mainly because he is considered the likely successor to Prime Minister Li Peng next spring. He has nothing to gain by further angering local officials who already view him as the architect of the downsizing process sweeping through China's resolutely noncorporate factories.
For the Clinton Administration, perhaps the stickiest issue Mr. Zhu raised today was Chinese membership in the trade organization, a group of nearly 130 nations pledged to lower tariffs on imported goods and a regimen of steady economic liberalization. Two years ago, the Administration sent China a road map of changes it would have to make before it qualified, including a rapid end to subsidies of state enterprises. While some progress has been made in negotiations, officials fear there has not been enough for Mr. Clinton to declare at the talks next month that China is well on its way to membership.
"This problem will be solved eventually," Mr. Zhu said with a broad smile today. "It is unreasonable to make such demands on China, which is still a developing economy."
There are some hints that the United States may soon back away from its hard-line stance, showing flexibility over the amount of time China will be allowed before it must comply with the rules. Japan has said it is ready to let China into the organization, which also acts as a court of world trading rules. Mr. Rubin is expected to talk about the issue when he meets Mr. Zhu and President Jiang at the end of the week.
There were also hints today that China has been alarmed by the speed with which its Southeast Asian nations fell into a contagious currency crisis in recent weeks. Mr. Zhu said he had been advised to take his time before allowing investors to freely move capital of all kinds across Chinese borders.
The Government-controlled China Daily said today that Liu Jibin, vice minister of finance, was backing away from any quick move to make the Chinese currency fully convertible into dollars, and vice versa. Mr. Liu was quoted as saying that the Southeast Asia crisis had sent "a warning signal" to other developing nations about the dangers of surrendering control of the currency to speculators and investors.
Unlike the smaller Southeast Asians, though, China is coming to the markets well armed. Mr. Zhu disclosed today that foreign exchange reserves now stand at $131.6 billion, one of the highest levels in the world. They are so high, in fact, that officials traveling with Mr. Rubin say they believe the decision to keep that war chest securely in the bank may be unwise when the money could go toward buying power plants and other equipment that could help modernize industries that have changed little since Mao Zedong's death in the mid-70's.
But over the long haul, Mr. Zhu declared today, Washington will get what it seeks: a far more transparent financial system.
"To step up the reform of the financial system," he said, "China will strengthen the currency-regulation function of the central bank and the financial supervisory systems, and promote the commercialization of state-owned banks." It is unclear, however, how he will dispose of huge loans that the banks made for political reasons rather than on the basis of credit-worthiness to failing state industries.
"China will also improve the capital structure and quality of the commercial banks," he concluded, "vigorously but steadily develop and regulate the financial market, improve and enact financial laws and regulations, and learn modern financial-management expertise."
Already, Chinese leaders have found something in common with President Clinton that they can talk about next month: They have all been surprised that revenue has flowed into Government coffers faster than anyone expected.
As a result, Mr. Zhu said, China would restore a series of tax exemptions for foreign technology and other goods that was revoked last year.
"We will resume our policy of tax exemptions as early as possible," he said, leading some in the audience to speculate that in recent months the country had grown worried that American and Japanese companies were slowing their direct investments. Nonetheless, Motorola and General Motors, among others, are planning investments that could run into the hundreds of millions of dollars, and tax incentives might help close the deals.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	 I.M.F. to Raise Assessments
 By Bloomberg News
The International Monetary Fund plans to increase its members' contributions by 45 percent, to the equivalent of $285 billion, reflecting the increased size of the global economy.
In a statement, the I.M.F. said on Saturday that its executive board had agreed to recommend that the amount of money members add to the fund be increased by the equivalent of $88.4 billion.
The contributions, called quotas, determine the amount that a country can borrow from the fund as well as its voting power within the 181-member organization.
The increase comes as the fund is warning private lenders that they may have to share more of the pain in future bailouts like those engineered for Thailand and Mexico.
The United States is the biggest contributor, providing more than 18 percent of contributions, or $36.1 billion. This is to drop under the new formula to 17.73 percent, and the Administration is expected to ask Congress for a further $14.45 billion.

HEADLINE: The Hot Zone: Technology Issues Continue to Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
When Wall Street strategists were asked last December to select their favorite sector for the coming year, the choice was just about unanimous: technology.
They have not been disappointed. Through nearly three quarters, shares in technology companies have skyrocketed, largely because of robust sales of personal computers, sharply higher profit margins and a steady stream of news suggesting that technology will rule the stock market roost for some time to come. 
 This year, and especially this summer, technology issues have stormed ahead of almost every other sector, including the consumer goods industry, which has been bolstered by the performance of the likes of Colgate-Palmolive and Wal-Mart Stores.
Yesterday, for instance, technology shares led the market higher after I.B.M. -- one of the industry's senior citizens -- said it had developed a new computer chip using copper rather than aluminum, a manufacturing breakthrough that could result in faster and more powerful chips.
As a result, shares of I.B.M. soared 4 5/8 to 103 7/8, helping lift the Dow Jones industrial average 79.56 points, or 1 percent, to 7,996.83. The Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index fared even better, gaining 1.6 percent, while the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 2.7 percent, the equivalent of about 218 points on the Dow.
Just last week, the Intel Corporation, the semiconductor giant, said it, too, had developed a new process, one that doubles the storage capacity of some memory chips.
What all this means is more powerful and efficient computers, and with PC sales booming and companies like Microsoft weaving themselves into the lives of growing numbers of Americans, it is no surprise that shareholders are gobbling up more and more high-technology shares.
"At the end of the day, business results drive stock prices," Michael T. Moe, director of growth stocks at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said. "And what we've seen is that technology is playing an ever-increasing role in the new economy, in terms of productivity and competitiveness. Investing in technology is mission critical for a lot of companies."
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, has probably even intensified the investor hunger for technology as he has cited its key role in enabling the economy to grow at a steady pace without a resurgence in inflation.
There have been setbacks this year, and warnings of profit slowdowns at some high-technology companies -- which may be why some of the best-known technology leaders, like Microsoft, I.B.M. and Intel, have slipped below their all-time highs.
Still, investors seem eager to build on last year's solid gains, when the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite rose 22.7 percent, and the phenomenal returns of 1995, when the Morgan Stanley High-Tech Index rose 50.8 percent.
This year, technology shares have easily outperformed the stock market's major indexes. While the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is up 29 percent, the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index -- an index of 100 of the nation's leading technology companies -- is up 42 percent. The outperformance this summer has been even greater, with the S.& P. 500 index up 6.3 percent since June 20, while the technology index has risen 20.2 percent.
A driving force behind the summer romp was the sector's better-than-expected second-quarter earnings. "They were the best," said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call, which tracks earnings, noting that earnings for technology companies were 29 percent higher than a year ago. "Technology was head and shoulders ahead."
By comparison, earnings of consumer goods companies placed a distant second, Mr. Hill said, with a 14 percent gain. And the outlook for third-quarter profits? First Call said that analysts are estimating a gain of 25 percent for the technology sector over the period last year.
Mary Meeker, a managing director in the technology group at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said that investors are still rushing into technology stocks because they believe that regardless of the already dizzying ascent of the sector, individual issues can still take off.
"The thing that's driving this is money flows and a good economy," she said. "People are enthusiastic, but there's also a major supply-demand imbalance. And we've also hit an inflection point as far as Internet opportunity goes. People are saying, 'I'm Joe Investor and I missed Yahoo, but I'm not going to miss Amazon.com.' "
Yahoo, the hot Internet search engine stock, is up 373 percent this year, and Amazon.com, the online bookseller, has been in heavy demand recently. Yesterday, more than 1.4 million Amazon.com shares traded hands -- nearly one in every two shares available -- sending the stock up 6 5/8 a share, to 54.
Other big gainers yesterday were Texas Instruments, up 5 a share, to 139 5/8; Micron Technology, up 3 1/8, to 40 1/2, and Dell Computer, up 2 1/16, to 99 13/16. Intel rose 15/16, to 96 3/8, helping push the Nasdaq up 9.09 points, to 1,689.45, another closing high.
Indeed, sales of PC's seem to be fueling much of the optimism. That optimism has driven shares of Dell, the best performing S.& P. 500 stock this year, up 276 percent.
"The fundamental backdrop has been better than people expected," said Roger McNamee, a principal at Integral Partners. "The PC industry has seen phenomenal growth."
Mr. McNamee noted that this performance has come even as the industry has seen its share of problems this summer. "There's been a lot of bad news the market has just shrugged off," he said. "At the moment, investors are choosing to see something half full as overflowing."

HEADLINE: New York Police Issues Echo In Houston's Race for Mayor

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Lee P. Brown has never been known as the most loquacious of men. When he was Atlanta's Commissioner of Public Safety nearly 20 years ago, he spoke so tersely at public briefings that he acquired the nickname "No Rap Brown," a contrast to H. Rap Brown, the fiery former Black Panther leader.
And when he served as New York City's Police Commissioner, from 1990 to 1992, Mr. Brown also had a reputation for remoteness, one that singed him with controversy during the 1991 racial riots in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. A state inquiry concluded that "a leadership vacuum existed at the highest levels" of the Police Department during the affair, in which violent clashes between black and Jewish residents took place. 
 But here in Houston, where he served eight years as police chief and was widely credited with revamping a troubled department, Mr. Brown is positively expansive these days. He is basking in his standing as the current front-runner in this fall's race for Mayor. If he wins the election, he will be the first black mayor, indeed the first mayor from any racial minority group, in Houston's history.
Mr. Brown declares himself to have "a volcano in the belly," lest anyone question whether there is fire therein, and he is campaigning ferociously in the nation's fourth-largest city, outlining his vision of Houston as a "premier world-class city." And he is proclaiming his own record in law enforcement, even taking credit for the drop in New York City's crime rate under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"Anyone who's honest will tell you that crime is going down because of the foundation I laid," he says, offering an assessment shared by some crime experts. "He's benefiting from the groundwork that David Dinkins and I laid there in New York." And, so far, Crown Heights is not an issue in his campaign here, perhaps because Mr. Brown has warned his competitors that raising it could disturb the "sacred ground" of black-Jewish relations in Houston.
With the all-but-official support of Houston's popular incumbent Mayor, Bob Lanier, a wealthy developer who cannot run for re-election because of a term-limit law, Mr. Brown is widely acknowledged to be the likely leader in a crowded mayoral field in the city's election on Nov. 4.
But his path to city hall is by no means guaranteed, because he is not likely to capture the required 50 percent of the vote in the election. At least four candidates are considered to have a shot at finishing second and forcing a runoff a few weeks later.
Two strong challengers are Rob Mosbacher, a Houston businessman and the son of the Bush Administration's Commerce Secretary, Robert Mosbacher. The younger Mr. Mosbacher brings considerable financial resources to his campaign. Another candidate, George Greanias, is a former City Controller who is riding a solid reputation as a watchdog and proven citywide vote-getter.
Also running is City Councilwoman Helen Huey, whose supporters see her in the mold of Mr. Giuliani and Richard J. Riordan, Republicans who successfully stormed the Democratic bastions of city hall in New York and Los Angeles, respectively. And City Councilwoman Gracie Saenz is hoping to become the first Hispanic Mayor in a city where Hispanic residents now outnumber black residents, who were the largest minority group. But Hispanics vote in much lower percentages than other ethnic groups because more than half of the Hispanic adults here are not citizens, experts say.
But virtually all these candidates agree that Mr. Brown, who retired as New York's Police Commissioner to spend time with his dying wife, served as the nation's drug czar during President Clinton's first term and was also Atlanta's police chief, will be the man to beat. He returned to Houston in late 1995 to teach at Rice University's James A. Baker 3d Institute for Public Policy.
So far the campaign here has been remarkably genteel, with the major candidates engaging in so many joint appearances that they have taken to joking about being able to deliver one another's debate remarks. They have also cooperated in establishing an unusual site on the World Wide Web (www.MayorsRace.com), where all of the candidates have posted information about their qualifications and campaign pledges.
Much of the discourse has not electrified voters. During a debate here a few days ago, sponsored by the Community Associations Institute, the very first question on the agenda was: "What is your position on the expansion of the trash sponsorship program to include all homesteaded units in homeowner associations?"
So far, the turmoil in Crown Heights is perhaps the most controversial episode in Mr. Brown's long law enforcement career. But he dismissed criticism as "New York politics." There has been little interest in the issue here. "I think the report was a political report," said Mr. Brown, brushing aside conclusions by then-Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's top criminal-justice adviser that Mr. Brown "failed to fulfill his ultimate responsibility" in the Crown Heights episode. The trouble began when a car in the motorcade of Lubavitcher Rebbe Menachem M. Schneerson struck and killed a 7-year-old black boy, leading to clashes among blacks, Hasidim and the police, during which a 29-year-old Hasidic scholar was fatally stabbed.
"It's New York politics," continued Mr. Brown. "And everyone knows that New York politics is different than any other place in the country. I think the citizens of Houston understand that." Mr. Brown criticized the report, saying he believed the police response successfully prevented more violence.
But some candidates here have privately suggested that if they make the runoff, they would seek to make the Crown Heights violence and Mr. Brown's leadership there an issue. Mr. Brown already seems to be offering a counterattack by suggesting that hammering on Crown Heights might be racially divisive.
"I won't let anybody create negative relationships between the African-American community and the Jewish community, because I do consider this to be sacred ground," the former police commissioner said in an interview at his campaign headquarters just outside of downtown Houston. "We've gone through too much together over the years to allow anyone to try to separate us."
Houston sometimes likes to describe itself as one of the city's few truly "tri-ethnic" cities. Its 1.8 million residents are close to being evenly split: about 26 percent are black, about 33 percent Hispanic, about 6 or 7 percent Asian and the rest Caucasian, city demographers estimate.
But the typical pool of voters in a Mayor's race has been 28 percent black, 8 to 10 percent Hispanic, and the rest white or Asian, said Tatcho Mendiola, a sociology professor and director of the Center for Mexican American Studies at the University of Houston. This breakdown could make the bid by Ms. Saenz, whose campaign is not as well financed as Mr. Brown's or Mr. Mosbacher's, an uphill battle.
Houston has never had a Mayor who was a member of a racial minority group, although the city was on the verge of electing State Representative Sylvester Turner, who is black, six years ago, until a last-minute campaign controversy helped propel Mr. Lanier into office.
This time, Mr. Brown was clearly helped when Mr. Turner and Representative Sheila Jackson-Lee, who is black, decided to sit out the race. With support from a coterie of Mr. Lanier's advisers and downtown business leaders, as well as his base in the black community, Mr. Brown is clearly in a strong position to win, said Bob Stein, a political scientist and dean of the School of Social Sciences at Rice University.
So the most intriguing question now is: Who will make the expected runoff? Most speculation focuses on Mr. Mosbacher, expected to be omnipresent in television campaign commercials, and Mr. Greanias, the former controller and often a strident critic of Mr. Lanier.
Mr. Greanias, though not as flush with cash, is the "sleeper" in the race, said Professor Stein, a longtime observer of Houston politics.
Mayor Lanier "has done everything humanly possible, and then some, to make it impossible for George to get money," Mr. Stein said. "But he may have done too much."
So far, virtually all of the candidates have refrained from attacking one another too stridently. Mr. Greanias said he would largely stick to describing his own qualifications and plans. "I've run my own race, speaking to the issues, the way I've won four citywide races before me," Mr. Greanias said in an interview, though he added that was "four more than either of the other two leading candidates have."
Mr. Mosbacher, who has run unsuccessful statewide races for United States Senator and Lieutenant Governor, said his experience in business makes him the best qualified to lead Houston into the global economy of the future. He also said he would stress his qualifications, though he described the Crown Heights episode as "fair game" in a one-on-one race with Mr. Brown, who in turn predicted that attempts to use the issue "won't float" here.
"I think people in Houston watched me for eight years, and they know my career of 35 years," Mr. Brown said. "And they would not by any means conclude that that one three-day period in life where someone issued a bad report -- and I mean literally bad in terms of its methodology, bad in terms of its conclusions -- would be a method of judging Lee Brown for Mayor."

HEADLINE: Congresswoman Declares for Connecticut Governor

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Barbara Bailey Kennelly, scion of one of Connecticut's most powerful political families, announced today she would leave Congress after 18 years to try to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland.
Mrs. Kennelly, 61, who as vice chairwoman of the House Democratic Caucus is the fourth-ranking Democrat in the House of Representatives, took to the stump this afternoon promising to reunite a divided State Democratic Party that her father had once ruled without peer. 
 John M. Bailey was the boss who ran the state party from 1947 until his death in 1975. Mr. Bailey also was in John F. Kennedy's inner circle, one of Mr. Kennedy's earliest supporters and the man Mr. Kennedy named as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, a position Mr. Bailey held from 1960 through 1968.
Mrs. Kennelly's decision comes as Democrats attempt to win back almost a dozen governors' offices that they lost in the 1994 Republican landslide, when Republicans took control of a majority of the state executive offices. Mr. Rowland's victory that year was the first time Republicans had taken the governor's office in Connecticut in 20 years.
For months, many Democrats had been urging Mrs. Kennelly to challenge Mr. Rowland, and her deliberations had been closely watched. Even before she declared her intentions, two independent polls in June and July showed her in a virtual dead heat with Mr. Rowland. No other Democrat approached her strength.
Before a packed room in the Old State House here, a museum believed to be the oldest state house in the country, Mrs. Kennelly (pronounced ken-NELL-lee) said, "This is the place where I can make the biggest difference: right here at home." As she spoke, one supporter in the audience of several hundred waved a sign saying, "Barbara Bailey, Please Come Home to the Mansion," a reference to the governor's residence.
In an interview later, Mrs. Kennelly said that she had been thinking of her father, who never saw her take elective office, as she made today's announcement.
"I don't think he ever imagined that some day his daughter would be running for governor," she said. "He would have been very happy this afternoon. The Connecticut Democratic Party was his life. What I hope I can do is bring it back together." But Mrs. Kennelly's nomination is not guaranteed. William E. Curry Jr., the Democrat who lost to Mr. Rowland in 1994 after a bruising primary, declared his candidacy this summer, and has made a career out of pulling off upsets. Others, like Mayor Joseph Ganim of Bridgeport, are still eying the race.
"I'm in it all the way, and I'm in it to win," Mr. Curry said today. "I believe I not only would be the better governor, but also that I would be the strongest person to prosecute the case against John Rowland."
State Representative Chris DePino, the State Republican Party chairman, said, "Despite what she thinks, there's no monarchy in Democratic Party politics in Connecticut." Mr. DePino called her a "Washington insider" who was running on the "platform of Democratic politics past, the ghost that haunted the state until John Rowland became Governor."
Yet, in some respects, it is also that Democratic past that Republicans fear.
Until 1990, when an independent, Lowell P. Weicker, won the governor's office, the Democrats had controlled the office for every term but one since 1955. Mr. Rowland's victory in 1994 came in a four-way race after conservative Democrats abandoned the party when the moderate candidate, who had been endorsed by the party organization, was defeated in a primary.
At Mrs. Kennelly's news conference, she already appeared to be a unifying force. She was joined by former advisers to an earlier Democratic Governor, William A. O'Neill, and she won praise from top labor leaders who had backed Mr. Curry three years ago.
"I haven't seen this wide a range of Democrats in quite a while," said Patty McQueen, a Democratic Party consultant.
Mr. Rowland is a formidable opponent, a charismatic campaigner who has seen the state's economy rebound during his tenure. But Democrats insist he is vulnerable. In 1994, he won with only 36 percent of the vote, and polls suggest that his support among women is weak, while Mrs. Kennelly's appears to be strong.
Mrs. Kennelly said that she would finish out her term in Congress, but obviously could not seek re-election if she wins her party's nomination. The decision to leave the House was not easy, she said, and twice before she had passed up the chance to run for governor.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said Mrs. Kennelly may have chosen to stay in Congress because she was a ranking member of the Ways and Means Committee when Democrats held the majority. Although it is an honor to be caucus vice chairwoman, "it's not a great deal of power," he said.
"I'd rather be a senior member of the majority than head of the Democratic caucus in the minority," Mr. Schumer said.
But Mrs. Kennelly denied that this was a big factor, saying that ultimately she had "a lot of energy" and wanted to put it into a job that would most benefit the people of Connecticut. Her four children are grown, and her husband, James Kennelly, the former Speaker of the State House of Representatives, died two years ago.
At her announcement, Mrs. Kennelly never mentioned Mr. Rowland by name. But she took some swipes. At one point, she described her vision of a Connecticut "where public service is a public trust of the highest order," which many interpreted as a reference to ethical questions plaguing Mr. Rowland.
Although Mrs. Kennelly never mentioned the phrase "tax cut," the driving theme in Mr. Rowland's administration, Mrs. Kennelly indirectly referred to Mr. Rowland's campaign promise to repeal the state income tax by 2000, a pledge that it does not look Mr. Rowland will be able to honor.
Mrs. Kennelly said, "I can make my first promise about taxes to the people of the state of Connecticut today: If I make them a promise about taxes, I'll keep it."
Mrs. Kennelly became involved in politics in the early 1970's, when she was a member of the Hartford City Council. In 1978, she was elected Secretary of the State, and in 1982 was elected to Congress.
Among her colleagues in the Connecticut delegation, the mood was jubilant.
"Barbara Kennelly is Connecticut," said Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of New Haven, who is supporting her. "It's in her blood."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Bailey Kennelly, after announcing yesterday at the Old State House in Hartford that she will run for governor. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

Thalidomide May Be Used To Treat Several Diseases
Thalidomide, the drug whose use in the 1960's produced thousands of deformed babies, is on the verge of receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration for use in leprosy patients, nearly four decades after the agency rejected it for use in the United States. But experts expect doctors to begin prescribing it quickly for "off-label" uses. Thalidomide has been experiencing a revival of sorts, and scientists are experimenting with it for everything from AIDS to brain cancer and other autoimmune diseases. A1

HEADLINE: Clinton, at U.N., Says He'll Press Senate on Test Ban Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 22

 BODY:
 Almost a year after signing it, President Clinton announced here today that he was asking the Senate to approve the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, which he called "the longest-sought, hardest-fought prize in the history of arms control."
In a speech to the General Assembly that was intended to lay out his vision for protecting nations, human rights and the environment while fostering international prosperity, Mr. Clinton also urged the creation of a permanent international court by the end of the century to prosecute "the most serious violations of humanitarian law." 
 He spoke after the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, issued a tart plea for all nations to pay their debts to the United Nations, and Mr. Clinton promised that the United States would shortly repay most of the more than $1 billion that it owes. But mindful of the demands of Republicans in Congress, he continued to insist that the United Nations change its scale for assessing dues and ask less of the United States in the future.
While the President declared passage of the nuclear test ban treaty, which would ban all nuclear explosions, one of his top priorities, some senior Republicans said they doubted that the treaty would come to a vote this year.
For the bulk of his 21-minute address to the 52d session of the General Assembly, Mr. Clinton described what he saw as the possibilities at "the dawn of a new millennium" and the international arrangements necessary to take advantage of them.
"The forces of global integration are a great tide, inexorably wearing away the established order of things," he said. "But we must decide what will be left in its wake."
Declaring that "we're all vulnerable to the reckless acts of rogue states and to an unholy axis of terrorists, drug traffickers and international criminals," Mr. Clinton argued that military and trade alliances, as well as arms control agreements, could create a protective "web of institutions and arrangements."
Through such measures, he said, "nations are now setting the international ground rules for the 21st century, laying a foundation for security and prosperity for those who live within them, while isolating those who challenge them from the outside."
In his survey of binding international agreements, the President did not mention the ban on land mines drafted last week in Oslo. Although he called for such a ban in a speech here three years ago, the United States does not plan to sign the Oslo measure, because it did not include exceptions that the Clinton Administration said were essential for American security.
After his speech, Mr. Clinton attended a United Nations luncheon and also met individually with three foreign officials. In a half-hour conversation with Russia's Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, he discussed the state of the peacekeeping mission in Bosnia. Mr. Primakov assured him that the Russians would not oppose elections that the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, has called for next month, according to an account of the meeting provided by Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser.
Mr. Berger said Mr. Clinton had expressed concerns about a law passed by the Russian Parliament last week protecting the Russian Orthodox Church from competition from other Christian denominations.
Mr. Clinton also met today with the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, and the Prime Minister of India, Inder Kumar Gujral. The Indians have resisted the test ban. But according to a State Department account of their meeting, Mr. Gujral assured the President that "we would be pleased to engage you in discussion" on the ban and other matters.
The White House waited a year to send the test ban treaty to Congress in part because it wanted to secure approval of a treaty banning chemical weapons first. Further, the Administration has been analyzing the treaty to see precisely what it prohibits.
"We've certainly not been idle," said Bob Bell, senior director of the National Security Council. "We've worked very, very hard on this the last year to get the whole package ready for the Senate."
Mr. Bell said that rather than testing, the United States would maintain its nuclear arsenal through a "science-based, stockpile stewardship program," costing about $4.5 billion a year. Some Senate Republicans, however, harbor doubts that such a program, which uses laboratory experiments and computer simulations, can effectively replace test explosions in maintaining the arsenal.
Marc A. Thiessen, a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the ban "is not something that's on the front burner of the committee right now." He noted that 44 countries believed to have some sort of nuclear capability, whether for electricity, weapons or research, must approve the treaty before it takes effect. "That's certainly not going to happen in the next year, and may not happen in the next decade," he said.
But the Administration argues that the United States should take a leadership role by approving the treaty soon. "We intend to win this vote, and failure is not an option," Mr. Bell said. Of the 44 countries that must approve the treaty, only Japan has done so. In all, 146 nations have signed the treaty.
In his speech today, Mr. Clinton said the United Nations could play a crucial role, not only in keeping the peace and protecting human rights, but also in making sure that "as the global economy creates greater wealth, it does not produce growing disparities between the haves and have-nots, or threaten the global environment -- our common home."
He praised Ted Turner, the broadcast executive who last week announced he would give $1 billion for United Nations projects, as "a truly visionary American."
"His gesture highlights the potential for partnership between the U.N. and the private sector," he said. "I hope more will follow his lead."
Mr. Clinton said Congress's move toward paying most of America's back dues reflected "a strong bipartisan commitment to the United Nations and to America's role within it."
He said that while he supported expanding the Security Council -- a move that has strong opposition in the Senate -- he also wanted to see the scale for assessing dues changed.
"In more equitably sharing responsibility for its successes," Mr. Clinton said, "we can make the U.N. stronger and more democratic than it is today."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: New Jersey;
Diversity Propels New Jersey In Region Stung by a Recession

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Five years after the end of the deep, punishing recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, New Jersey's economy stands on the brink, finally, of full recovery.
Fueled by industries like consulting and law, accounting and telecommunications, the state has raced ahead of New York and Connecticut and, economists say, has achieved a sustainable new pattern of growth. As of August, it had regained all but 3 percent of the jobs lost in the downturn. 
 New Jersey's resurgence, economists say, owes much to its economic diversity. Going into the 1990's, the state was far less dependent on military manufacturing, for example, than Connecticut or Long Island, where the end of the cold war laid whole industries to waste. Many of New Jersey's largest corporations did not contract with the same severity as did those in New York and Connecticut in the waves of early 1990's downsizing.
And the recession, while far worse here than in the rest of the country, was also milder than in New York City, which lost 10 percent of its jobs and has gained only 40 percent of them back, or Connecticut, which also lost 10 percent and has recaptured about 66 percent.
"We have emerged in a very enviable position," said Joseph J. Seneca, an economist at Rutgers University and the chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors, which reports on the economy to the state government. "I see steady, modest growth for the rest of the decade."
Business people also credit Gov. Christine Todd Whitman with making the state more business friendly, by providing help to companies and making the state bureaucracy easier to deal with. But she is apparently not getting the same credit from voters. The political maxim that an incumbent always benefits from a growing economy is being challenged, with polls showing anxiety among voters about their place in the new prosperity.
"Things have changed, people have changed -- in the 1990's, decision making and spending are more tempered," said Bob Lowenstein, the owner of Jodo Gifts, an institution here on the Morristown green since before World War II. Mr. Lowenstein, standing outside his shop on a recent warm day, paused for perhaps the fifth or sixth time to say hello to friends or customers passing by.
"In the 1980's, you didn't have to work so hard," he said. "It was all more free flowing."
Economists agree that New Jersey's economy, from its corporate boardrooms to its smallest towns, does move to different rhythms in the late 1990's and that any analysis of strength is inevitably followed by a string of caveats. The state lost about the same percentage of its jobs as the rest of the region -- 7.1 percent of its total job base disappeared from 1989 to 1992, compared with about 7 percent in New York and 10.2 percent in Connecticut.
But it recovered differently, and suffered less from the corporate job cutting that plagued its neighbors. From 1991 to 1996, New Jersey actually gained jobs in companies with more than 1,000 employees. New York and Connecticut both lost heavily.
At the same time, the state's population growth has stagnated. Its cost advantage over New York City, long a great trump card in the region, has narrowed. Once a center of heavy industry, the state now has fewer manufacturing jobs than at any time since the eve of World War I. The cities and rural southern areas have been left behind. And while New Jersey may be a standout performer locally, the rest of the United States has moved ahead much faster. Most places made up the jobs lost in the recession years ago.
In her speeches and commercials, Governor Whitman has made the economy a cornerstone of her campaign for re-election, stressing repeatedly how much things have improved and how much promise the economy holds out for the future.
"The message is that New Jersey is stronger economically than it was four years ago, with far more jobs and lower taxes and a future that holds great promise and opportunity for all New Jerseyans," she said in a statement. "Jersey has come a long way."
Her opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, said that the state's job gains, a total that includes many low-wage jobs, must be measured against what has been lost, particularly in manufacturing.
"New Jersey will not retain its strategic position as a world-class economy by permitting its manufacturing base to hemorrhage while replacing it with food stores," Mr. McGreevey said.
 
Just Look Around, Store Owner Says
People like Mr. Lowenstein, the card store owner, say it is easy to see places where the state's bounty has not penetrated, or where things have actually gotten worse in the 1990's.
All he has to do is look down the block from his store. Four major businesses in prime locations facing the green have closed in the past few years. Barnes & Noble got rid of its smaller stores to focus on superstores. Macy's closed what it called "underperforming assets." A clothier based in Boston returned there. Shoetown went out of business.
Mr. Lowenstein said the closings sharply reduced the volume of walk-in traffic at his store and that to stay in business he had to find new customers. So he reached out to the giant corporations that surround the town. He changed his inventory to suit them -- more pens and watches and expensive-looking performance trophies. About 50 percent of his sales now come from the companies and their employees.
But he has realized, in watching those new customers shop, that many are scarred by the consolidations, closings and staff reductions that have become familiar themes in the resurgence of corporate America. And the same forces bolstering the corporate bottom line outside town are keeping a lid on the growth within.
"We've survived by being innovative," said Mr. Lowenstein "But everybody's careful now. Everybody's cautious."
A bedrock principle of local economics and politics in the New York region has been this: New Jersey is a bargain. This theme has touched off countless economic border wars and advertising campaigns and has colored the state's identity. Because the state had been less developed than Long Island or Westchester, land had been plentiful. Housing costs and wages had been lower.
But that gap has narrowed. The huge growth in commercial office space in the 1980's ate up land and raised prices. A growing sophistication in the telecommunications business, the state's largest single industry, boosted salaries. Perhaps most crucially, the cost of doing business in New York City fell by about 6.8 percent from 1989 to 1996, led by declines in labor costs, which have been held down by high unemployment.
In New Jersey, by contrast, only one of the five metropolitan areas in the state as classified by the Census Bureau -- Monmouth and Ocean Counties -- saw business costs fall by more than 2 percent. Two areas -- Bergen-Passaic and Trenton -- saw business costs rise.
"New Jersey is not a cheap buy anymore," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at the Regional Financial Association, a West Chester, Pa., economic research firm.
New York City, of course, remains far more costly than New Jersey overall, not to mention being more costly than most of the rest of the country. But the playing field has unquestionably leveled.
The shift toward higher prices is starkly visible in Jersey City at a giant housing and commercial complex called Newport, begun in the 1980's by the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens. The apartment towers completed before the recession were built for bargain hunters. The new generation of post-recession towers, the first of which is to be finished next month, has larger, nicer kitchens, better hardwood floors -- and higher rent. A 16th-floor two-bedroom apartment in the 1980's buildings rents for about $1,750; in the new building, such units start at $2,232.
Corporations are also making decisions differently now, and that is pushing prices higher. Stanley C. Gale, a principal at Gale & Wentworth, a developer that is building one of the largest office projects in the region, said that as corporate profits have risen, the relative importance of a slightly cheaper location has declined. That has forced his projects -- three buildings going up in Florham Park, just outside Morristown -- to compete by using better materials and designs.
As New Jersey's costs become more like those elsewhere in the region, the state will have to promote its other advantages -- its work force, quality of life, the quality of its schools -- Mr. Gale said. Finding those new selling points, he said, will change the state for the better.
"New Jersey is still attractive," he said. "But the cost disparities just aren't as large as they once were. That era is over."
New Jersey has added jobs in the 1990's both at the high end of the wage scale, in fields like information technology and computer software, and at the low end, in businesses like warehousing, where workers are loading trucks and processing orders for retail stores.
But the reasons for the job growth are completely opposite: High-wage jobs are growing because of an intense demand for people with certain skills, while low-wage jobs are growing, economists and business people say, because there is a big supply of workers, especially immigrants, who are available and willing to work for low pay.
Places like Bell Labs, now part of Lucent Technologies, show the high-end growth. The lab, based in Murray Hill, split in half last year when A T & T broke apart. Half the lab personnel went to Lucent, which kept the Bell Labs name, and half went to a new entity, A T & T Labs. For the company, and the New Jersey economy, the outlook was deeply uncertain.
But a year and half later, taken together the two labs have grown bigger than the old Bell Labs was before.
Both labs, spokesmen said, have increased their staffs in voice-recognition research in particular, as computers, telephones, traditional television broadcasting and Internet technology have merged.
Luis M. Ramos sees the other side. An assistant manager at a union affiliated with the garment workers union known as Unite, Mr. Ramos said that the kinds of employers he sees expanding in the state can find people happy to work for $5.50 an hour.
 
'They Line Up For Overtime'
In the airtight labor markets in the South, where many New York-based retailers have established distribution sites in recent years, warehouse workers demand and get $8.50 an hour or more, Mr. Ramos said, and employers say that they will not work overtime. In New Jersey, Mr. Ramos said, "They line up for overtime."
And in some cases, working people do not show up on economic charts at all. After years of dreaming about it, Jarmina Perez and her husband, Julian, opened Queen Bee Flowers, a flower shop in downtown Jersey City last summer. The store is large, airy and bustling, and Mrs. Perez hovers about like any proud business owner. But she laughs at the idea of paying anyone, at least for now. All her workers are family members -- her children, daughter-in-law and brother-in-law.
"I can't afford employees," she said. "I just feed them."
In New Jersey's last boom, in the 1980's, the great engines of its growth were local institutions with deep roots: Prudential Insurance Company, based in Newark, and the Chubb Corporation, based in Warren. The state's banks were major participants as well.
 
Power Has Shifted To Wall Street
Now those institutions have retreated. The new power comes from Wall Street, specifically the big pension funds and the real estate investment trusts that raise money by selling shares to the public. The rise of the trusts is certainly a national phenomenon, but in New Jersey, where so much of the 1980's boom centered on real estate, the implications of the change go deeper.
In effect, ownership of huge swaths of industrial and commercial property in New Jersey has moved out of state -- to the stock market.
It has also become concentrated: One of the largest trusts in the region, Cali Realty Corporation, is merging with another trust, the Mack Company. Together they would own 8 percent of the state's entire office stock. When the next economic downturn comes, many of those shareholders are likely to sell their shares, and what that might mean for the state has is being debated. Some experts argue that because the trusts are plugged into the ebbs and flows of the market more than the insurance companies or banks were, the boom-and-bust cycle of the real estate markets may be moderated.
Others say the pattern next time will be the same, or worse: Pressure to make profits for the investors who own the trusts will force property prices up beyond their real value. At some point, the pessimists say, the stocks will crash, and with them their real estate empires.
Thomas Wright, director of the New Jersey office of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit urban planning organization, said he believed that the state's 1990's-style stability, as unfulfilling as it might seem to some residents, would prove its worth in the end.
"This time it isn't a flash in the pan," he said.

HEADLINE: With Timber Scarce, Old Logs Deep in a Lake Become a Sunken Treasure

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: ASHLAND, Wis.

 BODY:
Russet sunlight skips across Lake Superior, the last waltz of a fading summer, as a scuba diver 30 feet below the surface swims toward a pile of ancient oak logs. They are sunken remnants of the virgin forest, felled in a boom-time fury, then lost and forgotten for a century.
"Jackpot!" exclaims the diver, Jeff Petrouski, 24, speaking to co-workers on the crew boat via radio, after the recent discovery of the lake-bed shelf of timber, cut years ago from an old forest and preserved by the cold. 
 From the Civil War to World War I, when lumberjacks largely denuded the rugged North Woods of Wisconsin, logs were often stored in floating masses on Lake Superior, and many sank. Rather than retrieve the logs, it was cheaper and easier to cut down more trees.
But now the scarcity of old timber, with its tight grain from slow growth, has made these logs sunken treasure. The Superior Water-Logged Lumber Company, headed by an underwater explorer who once made a living searching for shipwrecks, dries and mills the old timber, then sells it to furniture makers, artists and builders of stringed instruments.
"We've got a virgin forest at the bottom of the lake," said Scott Mitchen, the 39-year-old president of Water-Logged Lumber in this old port town, noting that millions of ancient logs could be recovered from the bottom of oceans, lakes and rivers around the world.
"Every tree we retrieve is a tree we don't have to cut down," Mr. Mitchen said. "This is environmentally friendly logging."
The United States Army Corps of Engineers and Wisconsin officials in June approved underwater logging in certain parts of Lake Superior.
The Water-Logged company, which operates in a formerly abandoned sawmill it purchased for $1 from this job-starved town, has recently started using sonar to locate the underwater logs, which tend to be plentiful near the sites of long-vanished mills along the lake shore.
For now, divers attach eye bolts to the logs, which are pulled up individually, using galvanized wire, to a barge. The company expects to retrieve about 10,000 by the end of October, when the water usually freezes. It has $7.5 million worth of orders for the old timber.
Starting next year, the company plans to use a crane on the barge to scoop up a large number of logs from the bottom at the same time. The aim is to pull up 20,000 to 30,000 logs in the warm months next year.
The idea for the company came to Mr. Mitchen while he was exploring for shipwrecks in Lake Superior in the early 90's, after he had seen countless logs in his dives. The abundance of old logs, together with rising timber prices, convinced Mr. Mitchen that a forgotten treasure was waiting in the water.
The Water-Logged company pays Wisconsin one-third of the value of each log, based on the current market value of freshly cut timber. After a drying process that takes weeks, the old wood is cut and sold for much higher prices than new wood, sometimes 10 times as much. About a dozen kinds of trees are retrieved, including oak, maple, birch, elm, ash and pine. Birds-eye maple, with its iridescent grain, sells for as much as $80 a foot after being cut.
While most of the salvaged wood goes for furniture and craft work, some has been used to make stringed instruments, like a flat-topped acoustic guitar the company is giving to the country singer Johnny Cash.
The company's keenest hopes lie in finding wood for exquisite violins. A sample of 300-year-old maple has been analyzed by Joseph Nagyvary, a researcher and violin builder at Texas A&M University, who has compared it to the material used by Antonio Stradivari, who built the world's finest violins in the 17th and 18th centuries in Italy.
"I have not seen anything like this in modern times -- it's in the same ball park as a Stradivarius," said Mr. Nagyvary, whose research has indicated that Stradivari soaked his wood in water, which removed gums and resins. So it is possible that the lake water has cleansed the old wood in a similar way.
But a guitar-builder who works for Water-Logged Lumber, Chris Hinton, said fewer than one in 1,000 old logs met the precise standards of size, weight and grain pattern required for such violins.
Terry Mace, a wood specialist for the state forestry department, said that, more than anything else, Water-Logged Lumber sold mystique. "People feel good about holding something that is that old, that harkens back to history," Mr. Mace said.
The nether reaches of Wisconsin were so heavily forested before 1870 that an early settler, Asaph Whittlesey, expressed fear that his wife would never be comfortable in a place where it was impossible to see the sky.
While lumberjacks largely cleared Wisconsin of virgin forests, the state still harvests 4.2 million cords of wood a year, much of it for paper, and 99,000 people work in the forestry industry.
In the logging boom of the late 1800's, when the mills in Ashland alone cut 500 million board feet of lumber a year, enough for about 50,000 houses, timber barons built mansions and grand hotels, civic boosters promoted Ashland as "the next Chicago," adventurous, hard-drinking men came to cut the trees and pack the saloons, and an enterprising Madison woman, Molly Cooper, became infamous for running the brothels that catered to them.
Much of the lumber milled here was shipped south to rebuild Chicago after its fire in 1871. The tree limbs left behind by lumberjacks sometimes fueled terrible blazes in northern Wisconsin. Indeed, a fire in the North Woods killed 1,152 people in the town of Peshtigo, half the population, on the very same day the Chicago Fire killed 250.
The ghosts of those audacious times still lurk in the little towns of the North Woods, where gracious old houses are paint-chipped, their wraparound porches sagging because of the want of money for repairs. Here in Ashland, there is the Chequamegon Hotel, a grand dowager on the bay, with a bar named for Molly Cooper. Some of the timber towns, like Nash and Sioux, have disappeared. Much of the old forest was long ago transformed to dairy farms.
While tourist money still flows into the port town of Bayfield, a charming old fishing village, the North Woods region is among the most economically depressed in Wisconsin.
Ashland, on Chequamegon Bay about 75 miles east of Duluth, had a population of more than 25,000 at the turn of the century. Today, it has a population of about 8,000.
But the town has hopes that Water-Logged Lumber, which has drawn about 15,000 curious visitors to its mill in the past year, could put some spark into a community that is fighting hard for its successes, like the revitalized Old Depot, once a grand train station and now a restaurant, bar and museum.
Water-Logged Lumber, which employs about 30 people, got a subsidized loan of $400,000 from the Wisconsin Department of Economic Development.
"This is a region where life has never been easy," said Jan Young, a local historian.
But those here stay for the beauty, the rolling hills thick with oaks, hemlock and tamarack; the pristine Apostle Islands, and the crashing waves of Lake Superior, the world's largest body of fresh water, and, residents insist, the cleanest.
The retrieval of the old logs, in the view of Mr. Mitchen, gives people here a tangible connection to their roots and their history.
"Our kids in Wisconsin know a lot about shipwrecks and pirates, but they know very little about their own heritage," said Mr. Mitchen, a Milwaukee native, noting that most people in the North Woods traced back to loggers. "This wood tells their story."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against Mark On German Economic Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the mark yesterday after reports of falling prices in Germany's two biggest states eased speculation that the Bundesbank, the country's central bank, might soon raise interest rates.
With German unemployment at a post-World War II high and signs of ebbing inflation, a rise in interest rates could brake the country's nascent recovery from a five-year economic slump, analysts said. 
 "The sentiment is changing as far as Germany's ability to hike rates," said Bob Fakhouri, foreign exchange manager at Generale Bank. "We could have a big dollar-mark rally."
The dollar rose as high as 1.8010 marks -- its highest since Sept. 10 -- before settling in New York trading at 1.7934 marks, up from 1.7914 marks on Monday.
The dollar also rose to 122.13 Japanese yen from 121.75 yen, but trading was light, with markets in Japan closed for a holiday. The British pound rose to $1.6137 from $1.6049.
Prices in North Rhine-Westphalia and Bavaria fell three-tenths of 1 percent in the month to mid-September, bringing down both states' annual inflation rates. The reports suggested that inflation in Germany as a whole might be waning enough to stay a move by the Bundesbank.
Traders will get a better reading on German prices either today or tomorrow when the West German consumer price index is expected to be released. Economists forecast that the index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in the month to mid-September, leaving its annual inflation rate unchanged at 2 percent.
In August, German inflation rose slightly more than the Bundesbank's desired ceiling of 2 percent for the first time in two and a half years.
While yesterday's price reports dampened immediate concerns about inflation, some traders were not ruling out a rate rise if the economy shows other signs of a pick-up.
"Today's price numbers buy the Bundesbank maybe two weeks" to keep rates steady, said J. P. Neergaard, manager of foreign exchange at Den Danske Bank. "The market shouldn't read too much into them."
Helping to stem the dollar's rise yesterday, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said that "the correction in the dollar has finished," suggesting he did not want it to rise much further.

HEADLINE: Diplomacy, Gore-Style, Is a Study In 'Process'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 23

 BODY:
After days of closed talks about the obstacles facing American oil companies in Russia, Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced a decision: They agreed to work on the problems over the next two months.
From the moment Mr. Gore arrived in Russia, his strategy has been to nudge issues toward resolution. It is a deliberate approach that avoids open confrontation and minimizes the risk of embarrassing failure. 
 Aides insist that Mr. Gore's workmanlike approach is vital to forging effective relations with the Russians. But it also makes Mr. Gore appear a less than dashing figure at a time when he is trying to demonstrate his skills as a statesman.
If Mr. Gore had a favorite word this week it has been "process." The two sides established a "process" for discussing American complaints that Russian scientists are selling missile technology to Iran, Mr. Gore noted proudly. They set up a "process" for airing their disagreements over a new bill that protects the Russian Orthodox Church from competition with other Christian faiths. And that was before tonight's "process" on oil investment disputes.
To be sure, some of these processes have eventually yielded results. The two sides, for example, sealed an agreement today to halt the production of weapons-grade plutonium in Russia.
Russia had agreed in 1994 to shut down three nuclear reactors used to heat the Siberian cities of Tomsk and Krasnoyarsk because of United States concerns that the plants also produce plutonium that can be used to make nuclear weapons. But Moscow later concluded that it could not carry out its pledge because it lacked the money to construct non-nuclear power plants.
Under the new accord, the Russians will continue to operate the reactors but will convert them so that the plutonium they produce is not weapons-grade. The United States will pay the $70 million cost and the work is to be completed by 2000. American officials had hoped to sign the agreement months ago, but it was held up by bureaucratic snags within the Russian Government.
But some emotionally charged disputes may not lend themselves to Mr. Gore's incremental approach.
Mr. Gore criticized the religion bill passed by the lower house of Parliament on Friday, saying that it discriminated against minority religious groups. He stressed that American and Russian experts would get together to discuss the bill and how it might be changed.
"We have set in motion a process that will convey to Russian officials the concern about certain aspects of this pending measure, which may abridge basic citizens' freedoms, as we read the language," Mr. Gore said.
But Sergei Yastrzhembsky, spokesman for President Boris N. Yeltsin, told the Itar-Tass news agency today that Mr. Yeltsin was basically satisfied with the wording of the new bill and is likely to sign it.
The dispute over billions of dollars in planning American oil projects will also be a difficult test.
There are plenty of problems. Amoco has run into major difficulties with its Russian partners. Exxon was outraged when the Government revoked its right to develop oil in the far north. The Timan Perchora project, run by a consortium of Western and Russian oil companies, has been thwarted by local authorities. Major projects are also still awaiting parliamentary approval.
To dramatize his case to Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Gore waved newspaper articles suggesting that Russia was acquiring a bad reputation among foreign investors.
A senior American official said Mr. Gore had succeeded in focusing Russian attention on the oil problem. American and Russian experts are to study the issue for two months and issue recommendations for solving it.
What will come out of the talks is unclear. The Russians have indicated that they will try to come up with a creative solution for Exxon's difficulties.
Moscow has also reversed -- at least temporarily -- its decision to end the privileged access Conoco and two other companies enjoy to oil pipelines under joint ventures with the Russians.
"We will eventually get to firm and final closure on these issues," a senior American official vowed tonight. "It may take time but we will succeed. The key to success is that the leading figures do not think the other side is out to snooker them."
Some oil executives, who have been struggling with the byzantine politics of oil for years here, were more skeptical.
But few doubt that, come what may, Mr. Gore will slog on. Next year, the United States will host the tenth session of the Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission on Economic, Security and Scientific Issues. It is part of the process.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Wall St. Giant Reports Net Soared 51%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter net income rose 51 percent, led by record profits in its securities and asset management businesses.
The firm, the largest in the nation in terms of capital, said net income for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose to $678 million, or $1.11 a share, from $450 million, or 74 cents, in the period a year earlier. 
 The results beat Wall Street forecasts, although the firm's stock fell 50 cents yesterday, to $55.9375.
Analysts surveyed by First Call had predicted earnings of 96 cents a share.
The firm was created in May when Morgan Stanley Group Inc., a securities firm, merged with Dean Witter, Discover & Company, a brokerage and credit card company. The year-ago results are presented as if the two companies had already merged.
"Great earnings," said Richard Strauss, a Goldman, Sachs & Company analyst. "The month of June, which was the strongest this year, helped. They had great results in all areas, thanks to strong markets."
The company returned 22.8 percent on equity in the latest quarter, compared with 18.1 percent in the period a year earlier. Its shares rose 24 percent in the last three months.
Morgan Stanley benefited from rising stocks, falling interest rates, a surge in corporate mergers and volatile markets. Last week, closely held Goldman, Sachs Group L.P. reported that its pretax profit rose 58 percent, to a record $932 million for many of the same reasons.
All that is good news for the United States securities industry, which is expected to earn about $3.1 billion in the third quarter, up 55 percent from a year ago, according to the Securities Industry Association.
Robust markets aside, Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter's results show that the merger is working so far, analysts said. "When you have a 51 percent increase in earnings, not all of that is produced by market conditions, which were favorable a year ago," said Charles Vincent, an analyst at PNC Asset Management in Philadelphia. "Part of the reason is the merger is working out."

HEADLINE: College, a Survivor, Digs for Wisdom, Limestone and Tenants

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: PARKVILLE, Mo., Sept. 23

 BODY:
From its tall bluff with a sweeping view of the Missouri River, the Gothic-style administration building of Park College seems to announce itself as a bastion of classical liberal education, one of the aspiring Harvards that Protestant dreamers scattered around the Midwest in the 19th century.
And so the impact could not be more jarring when, an hour later, the college president maneuvers his four-wheel drive vehicle up an unpaved road on campus and pulls over to allow a truck loaded with crushed rock to pass in a cloud of dust. 
 "Money in the bank," said Donald J. Breckon, the president, as he contemplated the dusty load, which had just been excavated from vast limestone deposits that underlie the campus. "Not too many college presidents have a 1,200-acre industrial park under their campus."
He does not either -- yet. But by mining and selling the limestone and then developing the resulting caverns as underground office and industrial space, the college is moving along that path. It has been selling crushed rock for use in cement and asphalt for more than 20 years and recently attracted its first tenant, the growing suburban Park Hill school district, which has moved some administrative, warehouse and maintenance operations into a 37,000-square-foot underground space.
Dr. Breckon believes the project will bring financial security to a college that nearly died when enrollment dropped in the 1970's, enabling it to broaden access while keeping tuition at levels equal to the nearby state universities. Park has 2,000 students on campus, plus part-time students at surrounding satellite sites.
The limestone under Park College and much of the metropolitan Kansas City area, of which Parkville is a suburb, was deposited by an inland sea that covered the region a few hundred million years ago and left behind the Missouri River and a ledge of high-quality limestone on either side as much as 100 miles wide.
Excavated caves were first put to use around Kansas City in 1939, but since the early 1970's, conversions have surged and there are now at least a dozen underground industrial parks. Their appeal is economic: construction costs about a third less than above-ground space, and tenants save on energy, since the average mean temperature underground is 56 degrees year-round.
Access to the sites "is as simple as driving back into the hillside from surface streets to gain access to the underground area, not having to change depth to go underground," said Donald R. Woodard, director of Park College's underground project and a former city planner.
Park College, named for its founder, Col. George S. Park, opened its doors in 1875. Affiliated with the Presbyterian Church, though not operated directly by the church, the college historically had 500 to 700 students. When enrollment dropped in the early 1970's, the college fell into debt and the Presbyterians canceled the affiliation agreement. The president at the time tried to sell the college but found no takers. Ultimately, the Reorganized Church of Latter-day Saints, based in Independence, Mo., agreed to an affiliation agreement and extended financial help.
About the same time, the college ordered core drilling of the campus and determined that it was sitting on two kinds of limestone, both high in calcium carbonate, that are in demand for road paving and other uses. A mining company began excavation, with the college receiving a percentage of sales -- about $50,000 to $150,000 a year. The sum is minuscule in an annual budget of $25 million, but the real payback is expected to come from what Mr. Woodard called "the byproduct" -- the underground office and industrial space.
When Dr. Breckon came to Park from Central Michigan University in 1987 he initiated the development of the campus caves. A thick overburden of stone, usually 12 to 20 feet thick, forms the ceilings of the caverns, and moisture is kept out by a layer of water-tight shale between the limestone ledges. Ceiling heights can be as high as 16 feet.
The first undertaking was a new library, some classrooms and faculty offices for the college itself. Access is through doors that look like any other building entrance on the campus. On entering, students go down a flight of stairs into the library. Aside from having no windows, it looks like any other small college library.
Next, he hired Mr. Woodard, who had experience on other underground developments, to find paying tenants. After deducting for underground roads and the immense support pillars that are created by the miners, spaced every 30 to 40 feet, the college currently has about 650,000 square feet of usable space to finish and lease for warehousing, maintenance operations, offices or light industry.
Annual rents for basic warehouse space, on a five-year lease, start at $2 a square foot, compared with $3.25 aboveground.
Excavation also continues, so space is continually being created. A second ledge, which lies 110 feet beneath the first ledge, is now under excavation, which will give Park College two levels of underground space. With 600 acres on each level, Dr. Breckon's calculates the 800-acre campus will eventually sit on a 1,200-acre industrial park.
"What it means," he said, "is that the underground will make a financially strong college, assuring that our doors never close."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Park College in Parkville, Mo., saved money by building its new library underground, in space once occupied by limestone. Up to 20 feet of rock form the roof, but there is one disadvantage -- the library lacks windows. (Roy Inman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Is Urged to Keep Close Eye on Cable Rates

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Cable television rates are once again spiraling upward. But rather than accuse the cable companies of price gouging, two consumer groups blamed the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, saying that it failed to keep a rein on the newly aggressive cable industry.
The Consumer Federation of America and Consumers Union said the F.C.C. had allowed cable rates to rise at three times the inflation rate since the new telecommunications law was passed in early 1996. The increases are almost as sharp as those that occurred when Congress deregulated the cable industry from 1986 to 1993. 
 "The cable industry feels utterly unconstrained by the F.C.C.," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, a nonprofit group that tests products and publishes Consumer Reports. "Without Big Brother watching them," he said, "cable companies feel they can let it rip, and that's exactly what they've done."
In a petition filed with the F.C.C., the groups called on the commission to freeze cable rates and to overhaul its formula for determining reasonable rates. In addition, they said the F.C.C. ought to clamp down on mergers between cable operators and cable programming services, which were relaxed in the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
The F.C.C. did not respond directly to these demands. In a statement, Meredith J. Jones, the chief of the commission's cable services bureau, said the most effective regulator of cable rates was more robust competition from satellite television services.
A senior F.C.C. official, who insisted on anonymity, said it was difficult to impose rate caps on cable because the industry is constantly adding new channels. The industry then argues that it ought to be compensated for giving viewers more choices.
Despite the steady upward climb of cable rates, there has not yet been a backlash from consumers as there was in the 1980's. In the absence of a public outcry, some industry experts said neither the F.C.C. nor Congress was likely to revisit the issue any time soon.
But Edward J. Markey, the ranking Democrat on the House Commerce Committee, said that cable remained a powerful monopoly in the video market, and the magnitude of the rate increases underscored that. He added that Congress should consider imposing permanent rate caps.
Under the terms of the Telecommunications Act, rates for basic cable service will be regulated until March 1999, when all restrictions disappear. In 1994, the F.C.C. allowed cable companies to raise rates if they added new channels. And in 1996, it permitted them to raise rates to account for the growing cost of their existing channels.
"Cable should have to justify that today's rates are reasonable, and I don't think they can do that," Mr. Markey said.
Cable rates began climbing almost immediately after President Clinton signed the telecommunications law in February 1996. Spot checks of major operators like Time Warner and Tele-Communications showed that many companies put through rate increases of more than 10 percent, which they said were necessary to make up for two years of rate freezes in 1993 and 1994.
Now, a study by Consumers Union documents that rates rose across the country. According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, average monthly cable rates have risen 5.6 percent a year, adjusted for inflation, in the 18 months since the passage of the new law. Between 1986 and 1993, when the cable industry was totally deregulated, average rates rose 4.3 percent, adjusted for inflation.
"The F.C.C.'s current regulation of the cable industry conceals pricing that is every bit as monopolistic as it was during the deregulatory heyday of the 1980's," Mr. Kimmelman said.
Cable executives, however, said they had to increase their monthly bills because services like ESPN, MTV and CNN were charging them more to be carried.
The problem is particularly pronounced among sports services like ESPN and Madison Square Garden Network, which must pay sky-high fees for the rights to football, baseball and other professional sports. One major cable operator, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said ESPN recently tried to increase its annual carriage fee by 23 percent.
"It's not the cable operators who are getting fat and sassy," said Marc B. Nathanson, the chairman of Falcon Cable TV, a cable operator in Westwood, Calif., with 1.1 million subscribers. "The ones who are getting fat and sassy are the programmers."
Mr. Nathanson, whose company raised rates an average of 5.8 percent from 1995 through 1997, said cable operators also needed capital to make costly upgrades to offer new services like pay-per-view movies and high-speed access to the Internet.
Several operators said they had moderated their rate increases after big one-time rises in 1996. The typical monthly bill for a Time Warner subscriber in Manhattan rose $1.50 this year, to $31.37 from $29.87. Last year, the bill jumped more than $2.50 a month.
T.C.I., which put through an across-the-board rate increase of 13 percent in 1996, said it raised rates an average of 6.5 percent this year. T.C.I.'s subscriber growth has been stalled in recent months as people try out direct-broadcast satellite services like DirecTV and Prime Star.
Lela Cocoros, a spokeswoman for Tele-Communications, said the company was pricing its service carefully because it was mindful of the threat from such services.
But Mr. Kimmelman noted that the growth of the direct-broadcast industry has tailed off in recent months. And he said that cable operators like T.C.I. and Time Warner could stymie future competition because they owned several of the most popular programming services, including CNN, TNT and HBO.
In their petition, Consumers Union and the Consumer Federation of America are also asking the F.C.C. to impose stricter rules on the vertical integration of cable companies and programming services. Such combinations are pernicious, Mr. Kimmelman said, because the big cable operators can effectively enrich themselves by inflating the cost of their networks and passing along that cost to their cable subscribers.
