HEADLINE: Lawmaker Takes Highway to Power

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Representative Bud Shuster says he has witnessed some "pretty heady stuff" in his 24 years in Congress, like flying into jungles with Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, and crossing the Khyber Pass with the mujahedeen guerrillas.
But his constituents could not care less about Mr. Shuster's adventures as a senior member of the Intelligence Committee. The majestic Khyber Pass? They are more interested in underpasses -- and cloverleafs, connectors, bridges and tunnels. 
 "We're not talking here about Bosnia, or about who slept in the Lincoln Bedroom," Mr. Shuster said. "We're talking about what affects virtually every American. It's the ultimate quality-of-life issue."
Mr. Shuster's passion for the decidedly passionless subject of asphalt is easily understood: As chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, Mr. Shuster has doled out money for so many projects in his colleagues' districts, not to mention the Bud Shuster Highway and Bud Shuster Byway in his district, that he has become one of the most powerful figures on Capitol Hill. And he has risen thus far, despite ongoing inquiries into whether his some of his actions were legal and ethical.
Only today, after a weekslong struggle with Speaker Newt Gingrich over a budget-breaking road bill, Mr. Shuster was blocked -- or at least detoured -- from his project to repave America. His massive, three-year $103 billion transportation package would have breached the balanced-budget bill by at least $30 billion, only weeks after it was signed.
But in a demonstration of Mr. Shuster's clout, Mr. Gingrich was unable to declare a full victory. Instead, he offered, and the Transportation Committee approved today, a compromise in which spending will remain at current levels for six months, and then Mr. Shuster's proposal will be reconsidered.
In an era of belt-tightening in the capital, when committee chairmen no longer hold sway as they once did, a defiant Bud Shuster stands not only as a grand purveyor of pork, but also as a reminder that some things have not changed. The key to Mr. Shuster's leverage is not that he is chairman of a committee -- it is that he is chairman of the 73-member Transportation Committee, the largest in Congress, and he knows how to use the platform to build a power base.
That is made easier by the fact that beyond his home district in hilly Altoona, Pa., Mr. Shuster can distribute booty to every state, winning the allegiance of many of his colleagues. (His largesse helps explain why the 65-year-old Congressman's most serious competitor in years was Nancy Kulp, who played a secretary on "The Beverly Hillbillies." He trounced her in the 1984 contest.)
"It represents an old way of doing business here on Capitol Hill," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Republican Conference.
Until 1994, when the Republicans took over the House, the committee had the pork-barrel-sounding name of Public Works and Transportation. Yet even with the name change, Mr. Shuster's success is a reminder that dispensing "pork" is hardly out of fashion. In a Congress where both parties cannot even seem to agree to disagree, the members of Mr. Shuster's panel behave like a happy family, bound by old-fashioned public works projects to transcend ideology.
"There's no such thing as a Republican or a Democratic road or airport or bridge," Mr. Shuster said in an interview in his Capitol Hill office, decorated with two prominent green replicas of the "Bud Shuster Highway" sign. "These are American assets. We're building America."
Challenging the stereotype of the free-wheeling, barrel-chested chairman, Mr. Shuster is a fitness buff who favors crisply starched shirts (always white) and well-tailored suits, and he does much of his business not over martinis but while pumping iron in the House gym. His demeanor is friendly, rather than that of an intimidating power broker.
But critics argue that Mr. Shuster's approach has less to do with rebuilding unsafe roads and more to do with reward and punishment.
"He's the crown prince of pavement pork," said Thomas A. Schatz, president of Citizens Against Government Waste. "He's an example of the kind of abuse that can still occur. There's lobbyists running all over the capital pushing his stuff."
While Mr. Shuster said he was constrained by formulas that help dictate who gets how much transportation money, he acknowledged that he sometimes had significant discretion. For example, he said two lawmakers from bordering states were in a "bloody fight" because each one wanted a new highway to go through his state and not the other. But he said he gave the project to one, because the person had been "very supportive of us," was "a good guy" and "cares about transportation." He also said that by choosing that lawmaker, he will have "negotiating bait" when the details are worked out.
Despite his successes, Mr. Shuster, who made a fortune building a computer business before coming to Congress, is facing mounting pressure from deficit hawks in his own party who are unwilling to be romanced by the prospect of new projects for their districts. These tensions are bound to surface repeatedly now that there is a balanced budget deal. No one knows whether lawmakers will completely support the budget deal or whether they will back projects that could win them favor with voters.
As an example, Representative Joe Scarborough, a Florida Republican who was elected in 1994, conceded that his state would draw far more transportation money if Mr. Shuster's bill passed. But he said he was willing to resist the projects if that would help balance the budget.
"I think he thinks we're from Mars, from another galaxy," Mr. Scarborough said of Mr. Shuster. "But even if we had a Joe Scarborough Memorial Highway from Key West to Pensacola, I'd have to vote against it if it didn't stay within the budget numbers."
Mr. Shuster, who has a Ph.D. in management and economics, insists that he cares about the deficit as much as anyone. But he contends that it is only fair that transportation projects get full funding because billions of dollars in special gasoline and other taxes were pumped into "trust funds" designated for transportation projects. But those funds are running a large surplus and the extra money has been used to mask the true size of the Federal deficit.
Mr. Gingrich's refusal to accede to Mr. Shuster's wishes was somewhat surprising given that the Pennsylvanian was one of the Speaker's staunchest defenders during the attempt to topple him in July.
"He was forceful," Mr. Shuster said of a showdown he had with Mr. Gingrich last week. "He said, 'Dammit! You can't break the budget. I can't let you move this bill now.' "
"I said, 'Newt, America's crumbling!' " Mr. Shuster recalled.
Mr. Shuster said Mr. Gingrich never directly threatened his chairmanship. But senior Republicans who are familiar with the conversation said the Speaker left no doubt that he would have taken such a step.
In six months, when the House again takes up Mr. Shuster's giant road-building program, he may have more to worry about than Republican resistance. He is being investigated by a Federal grand jury in Boston in connection with the multimillion-dollar tunnel and road project there known as the "Big Dig." Investigators are said to be examining whether Mr. Shuster and his former longtime aide, Ann Eppard, used their influence to obtain favorable terms for two contributors whose property lay in the way of the project.
The Justice Department is also examining whether a tangle of legislative, financial, political and personal ties between Mr. Shuster and Ms. Eppard may violate laws prohibiting giving or receiving gratuities for official favors. After 22 years as his top aide, Ms. Eppard left Mr. Shuster's office to start a lobbying firm in 1994, and has since earned hundreds of thousands of dollars, often lobbying for the interests of the Congressman's contributors. Mr. Shuster refused to discuss the accusations.
But Mr. Shuster has a history of never backing down. A few years ago, Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat from Florida, described Mr. Shuster's transportation projects as "little piglets" that had grown into "giant hogs." In response, Mr. Shuster blocked 14 demonstration projects in Florida.
"I said, 'Wait a minute: If you're against projects, fine, we won't have any projects in Florida,' " Mr. Shuster recalled. He said Mr. Graham made amends and the projects were restored.
This year, Mr. Shuster has a warning for the fiscal conservatives who are squawking that his projects would wreck the budget agreement: It is only human nature that he would not be as inclined to fund projects in their districts.
"I'm not a saint,' he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Labor Unions Not to Punish Free-Trade Democrats in Congress

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Aggressively defending his trade strategy before a skeptical labor audience, President Clinton urged the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today not to punish Congressional Democrats who vote to give him more freedom to negotiate trade deals.
Repeatedly stressing areas in which he had backed labor's goals, the President sought to create political cover for supporters of his "fast track" trade legislation, which sharply divides traditional Democratic allies and could cost some Democratic lawmakers the backing of unions in the 1998 elections. 
 Mr. Clinton, addressing the labor federation's national convention here, listed several pro-labor stands such Democrats had taken, like increasing the minimum wage and expanding health care.
"They have fought for you and for all working people," he said. "If they were to lose their positions because they stood up for what they believed was right for America's future, who would replace them?"
As he surveyed changing foreign markets and growing commercial ties among nations, Mr. Clinton declared that the stakes in the debate over the trade legislation were high. "The global economy is on a fast track," he said. "I believe leaving our trade relations on hold with the fastest-growing economies in the world will not create a single job in America."
The delegates' reception of Mr. Clinton was polite but not nearly so effusive as the one given Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the leading Democratic opponent of fast track, when he spoke here on Tuesday.
As Mr. Clinton began to discuss his trade policy today, a few delegates at the back of the convention hall started to chant, "No fast track!" But they quieted down as Mr. Clinton said he felt "passionately" about fast track and added sternly, "I think I've earned the right to be heard."
Mr. Clinton is seeking fast-track legislation to expand trade with Chile and other Latin American nations. Under the fast-track authority, which has been granted Presidents repeatedly for more than 20 years, he would have the power to negotiate trade deals that Congress could approve or reject but not amend. The Clinton Administration argues that no trading partner will negotiate an agreement if it fears that Congress will endlessly edit the fine print.
But the A.F.L.-C.I.O. worries that a trade agreement negotiated with fast-track authority would not sufficiently protect workers or the environment. The labor federation is conducting a $1 million advertising campaign against the trade legislation, which has broader support among Republicans than among Democrats.
Mr. Clinton couched his arguments in terms of fostering American jobs.
"We cannot create enough jobs and increase wages if we don't expand trade," he said.
But Ted Kirsch, the president of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, said that in seeking to change the delegates' minds on fast track, "he was trying to convert the, at this point, unconvertible."
After appearing at the labor convention, Mr. Clinton addressed a Democratic fund-raiser here. The party expected to raise $250,000 from the 80 guests.

HEADLINE: 3 Big Health Plans Join in Call for National Standards

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Three big health maintenance organizations joined two consumer groups today in calling for more regulation of managed health care, saying all health plans should be subject to "legally enforceable national standards."
Such standards, they said, are essential to restore confidence in the health care system, which has been eroded by reports from many H.M.O. patients that they have had difficulty getting the care they need. 
 The proposals represent a significant development in the struggle over regulation of the health care industry. That struggle is comparable to the debate over regulation of railroads in the second half of the 19th century, and it is just as important for consumers, businesses and the economy. Until now, H.M.O.'s had generally sought voluntary, not government, standards.
Today's "statement of principles for consumer protection" was issued by three nonprofit H.M.O.'s: Kaiser Permanente, HIP Health Insurance Plans, based in New York, and the Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound. Together, they have more than 10 million members.
The principles were worked out by the H.M.O.'s in a year of negotiations with two consumer groups, Families USA and the American Association of Retired Persons, which has more than 33 million members.
The proposed national standards would replace a crazy quilt pattern of regulation that now varies from state to state. The Federal Government has set basic standards for Medicare for the elderly and Medicaid for the poor. But states regulate private health plans and private insurers in radically different ways. Kaiser and HIP said it would be simpler to comply with national standards than with conflicting state regulations.
Daniel T. McGowan, president of the HIP Health Plan of New York, said: "We have failed to convince the public of our commitment to quality. That's the crisis we face today."
Anthony L. Watson, chairman of the parent company, HIP Health Insurance Plans, said that "we are more than willing to see laws enacted" to guarantee higher standards of care.
Kaiser, HIP and the Group Health Cooperative see themselves as having a deeper commitment to consumer protection than many commercial H.M.O.'s, but they say it is difficult to fulfill that commitment if they can be undercut by competitors not bound by the same standards.
Dr. David M. Lawrence, chairman of Kaiser Permanente, said that if the standards did not apply to all health plans "it would put us at a disadvantage competitively."
Kaiser Permanente, established in 1945, operates in 19 states. HIP, which does business in four states, and the Group Health Cooperative, which has customers in Washington State and Idaho, were formed in 1947.
Here are some of the proposed standards:
*Health plans should provide access to round-the-clock care seven days a week. Women should have direct access to obstetricians and gynecologists. Patients should be able to see outside doctors at no additional cost if their health plan does not have a doctor with "appropriate training and expertise."
*"Individuals should be given a choice of health plans."
*Health plans should be required to pay for emergency care in any situation that "a prudent lay person" would regard as an emergency. H.M.O.'s sometimes refuse to pay if, for example, chest pains are found to be a result of indigestion rather than a heart attack.
*Health plans should pay for experimental treatments if outside experts conclude that such services are necessary to treat a condition likely to cause the patient's death within two years. Likewise, when H.M.O.'s cover prescription drugs, they should be required to pay for items not on the list of approved medications if the items are necessary.
*Every H.M.O. should have an ombudsman to investigate patients' complaints and to help appeal the denial of coverage or services.
*Health plans should not pay doctors in any way that directly encourages them to limit medically necessary care.
Other H.M.O.'s were cool to the idea of more regulation. Susan M. Pisano, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Health Plans, which represents managed care companies, said, "Rather than micromanage, the Government should provide a framework in which the marketplace can play its proven role" in fostering innovation.
The authors of the new proposals said they had not yet decided how the standards should be enforced.
In a separate action, the General Accounting Office reported today that it had examined 1,150 contracts used by 529 H.M.O.'s and had not found any explicit "gag clauses" limiting what doctors can tell patients.
It found a number of contract provisions that doctors said could have a "chilling effect" on doctor-patient communications. But the General Accounting Office said that even those clauses were unlikely to alter doctors' behavior because doctors did not always read their contracts carefully and sometimes disregarded the restrictions.
The accounting office said that 38 states had passed laws to guarantee open communication between doctors and patients. Explicit gag clauses would violate such laws.In addition, the report said, many doctors fear that they will be sued for malpractice if they do not tell patients about all treatment options.
Senate Republican leaders cited the findings in arguing against heavy-handed regulation. Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant majority leader, said today, "This report provides a cautionary message about the Federal Government's typical knee-jerk reaction to a problem. We should not move forward pre-empting state law or regulatory authority on any issue without full consideration of sound science, thorough research and data."

HEADLINE: House Approves 2.3% Raise For Lawmakers and Judges

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Bucking a trend against rewarding themselves, the House of Representatives today voted for a 2.3 percent cost-of-living increase for members of Congress and Federal judges.
The vote, which came on a parliamentary procedure regarding the Treasury and Postal Service Appropriations bill, was 229 to 199 in favor of the pay increase. If the raise takes effect, it would be the first cost-of-living increase for lawmakers and the Federal judiciary since 1992. But the Senate is already on record as opposing the pay increase, so the differences will have to be worked out in a House-Senate conference. 
 With Republicans and Democrats split on the merits of the proposal, the final vote reflected the bipartisan nature of support and opposition. In the end, 114 Republicans and 115 Democrats voted in favor of the increase, while it was opposed by 110 Republicans, 88 Democrats and the lone independent.
"This is not so much a partisan issue as it is an institutional one," said Representative J. D. Hayworth, an Arizona Republican.
Mr. Hayworth was at the forefront of other junior Republicans who tried to block the increase, characterizing the vote as a referendum on the raise. But the action was in fact a procedural vote on appointing the team to negotiate with the Senate on the spending bill for the Treasury Department and the United States Postal Service.
Under a 1989 law, yearly cost-of-living increases for members of Congress are automatically granted unless legislation is passed to block it. That has been the case since 1992. But in the last year senior Republicans in the House, many of whom have children in college, have been clamoring for a pay increase.
Federal judges have also been seeking a raise. On Tuesday the Judicial Conference of the United States, the top policy-making body for the Federal courts, passed a resolution calling for the cost-of-living adjustment. A 2.3 percent increase would add about $3,000 to the annual salary of $133,600 for Federal judges and rank and file members of Congress.
The importance of the increase was signaled by the appearance of Speaker Newt Gingrich on the floor during the vote. Mr. Gingrich voted in favor of the raise, one of the few times he has voted on any measure during his tenure as Speaker.
Supporters of the increase were careful to portray it as a cost-of-living adjustment that would allow the lawmakers to keep pace with inflation. They also made the point that unless lawmakers' salaries kept pace, Congress would become the preserve of the wealthy and zealots who care nothing of money.
"We'll end up with what we are coming close to having today: a Congress of wackos and millionaires," said Representative Peter T. King, Republican of Long Island. At that point, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of Queens, jumped up and shouted mirthfully, "You got me on both counts!"
Among other House members from the New York region, 6 from New Jersey, 25 from New York and none from Connecticut voted in favor of the raise. Seven members from New Jersey and five from New York voted against it. One of those who voted in opposition was Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is running for the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
At first, Mr. Schumer voted for the pay increase. But at the last minute, after tally boards showed that the measure had more than the 218 votes it needed to pass, he switched his vote and was recorded as opposing it.
After the vote, Mr. Schumer said he had arrived late on the floor and mistakenly voted for the increase not knowing what the issue was. When he realized what was the question on the floor, he said he then corrected his mistake and voted against the raise.

HEADLINE: Messinger Assails Plan On Hospitals

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Signaling a new line of attack in her challenge to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Ruth W. Messinger last night assailed the Mayor's efforts to sell the city's public hospitals to private health care companies, saying it would jeopardize the care of poor and immigrant New Yorkers who rely on the system.
"I believe that all people, regardless of income or background or immigrant status, deserve access to quality health care," Ms. Messinger said at a health forum in Brooklyn that was sponsored by a citizens' group. "I think that the health of the city depends on that reality. I have been a longtime opponent of privatization of municipal facilities." 
 Ms. Messinger's latest attacks on Mr. Giuliani came as the city's Campaign Finance Board awarded the Mayor's campaign $870,836 in public matching funds, lifting a monthlong sanction the board had imposed on the campaign for accepting more than $300,000 in illegal contributions.
The board fined the campaign $220,000 last week for accepting the donations, which the campaign has returned. The campaign has said it will pay the fine, allowing it to receive the matching funds, but it has also said it will probably appeal the sanction.
Last night, at the forum sponsored by the Commission on the Public's Health System in New York City, Ms. Messinger gave a preview of what her aides said would be a new phase of her campaign, attacking the administration's early efforts to pare down the city municipal health system. She was referring to Mr. Giuliani's attempts, rebuffed in court, to sell Coney Island Hospital to a private health care company.
Ms. Messinger appeared before an audience of 45 people at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights to describe what she said were the Mayor's flawed health care policies.
Aides to Ms. Messinger said her proposals on public health and her criticism of Mr. Giuliani's record would assume a prominent place in her campaign, along with attacks on Mr. Giuliani's education and unemployment record. "Before the end of this campaign, I will be giving a major address on health care and public health," Ms. Messinger said.
Ms. Messinger cut her remarks short because she had to attend a black-tie banquet, and did not offer many details on her own health care proposals. However, she criticized Mr. Giuliani for what she described as weak-hearted lobbying in Albany and Washington on behalf of the city for health care financing.
"I think we're under the gun, but I don't think we are doing what we need to do to negotiate with Albany and Washington," she said.
Ms. Messinger pledged to direct more of the city's tax dollars to public health care. She also said the city should do more to make modern treatments available to poor people suffering from AIDS or H.I.V., and she called for the city to promote clean-needle exchanges for drug addicts.
The decision by the Campaign Finance Board to grant the Mayor's campaign matching funds appears to bring at least a temporary end to a politically uncomfortable situation for Mr. Giuliani: the former prosecutor had found his campaign financing practices under scrutiny.
The finance board made its decision at the first full meeting of the board attended by the Mayor's latest appointee, Joseph R. Erazo.
Mr. Erazo's sudden and unexpected appearance at a meeting last week, when the board first discussed fining the Giuliani campaign, prompted some advocacy groups to accuse the Mayor of trying to stack the board so he could avoid the fine. The groups have called for Mr. Erazo to step down, but he said yesterday after the meeting that he would not, though he declined to comment further on the circumstances surrounding his appointment.
Meanwhile, in an unwelcome development for Ms. Messinger, the board of directors of the Political Action Committee of the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League voted not to endorse either candidate this year. Mr. Giuliani opposed abortion rights before he entered public life, but has since changed his position. Ms. Messinger has long been an advocate of abortion rights.
But the league said it had weighed the candidates' current positions in deciding not to enter the race. "We are fortunate to live in a city where both major-party candidates, one a Republican and one a Democrat, have demonstrated a commitment to women's freedom to choose," said Kelli Conlin, executive director of the group.

INTERNATIONAL A3-17
 
Netanyahu Plans to Expand Settlements in West Bank
Vowing that the Jewish presence in the West Bank would continue to grow, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu promised to build 300 new housing units for settlers. A1 

Smog Blankets Southeast Asia
Smoke wafting from forest fires in Sumatra and Borneo has choked much of Southeast Asia with a hazy smog that has disrupted transport, schools and the respiratory comfort of millions of people. A1
 
Burmese Strongman Reappears
U Ne Win and a military entourage from Myanmar arrived in Jakarta for a personal visit at the invitation of President Suharto of Indonesia. Mr. Ne Win has rarely been seen since 1989, the year after he stepped down from 26 years of one-man rule during which he managed to isolate and impoverish the country formerly known as Burma. A14
 
Russia Oligarchs Put on Notice
Alleging that powerful business interests were jeopardizing Russia's economy, President Boris Yeltsin said the state's role in the economy would have to increase in order to insure free competition. His remarks were largely aimed at the financial oligarchs who helped bankroll his re-election, but whose business empires have flourished and who some suspect of corruption. A3
 
Call for Peace Surprises Algeria
The commander of Algeria's Army of Islamic Salvation, the military wing of the main opposition party, ordered a unilateral cease-fire and called for a truce in the country's civil war. Tens of thousands of lives have been lost in grisly combat in the six years since the Islamic Salvation Front's electoral success led the army to cancel voting. Analysts believed the move could signal a coming detente, but several recent massacres suggested that some guerrilla factions had moved far beyond the front's control. A8
 
Britain Protests Saudi Trial
Two British nurses charged with murdering an Australian colleague in Saudi Arabia lost their first appeal in a religious court there, leading to consternation in Britain about their sentences. One may be beheaded, and the other imprisoned for eight years after 500 lashes. The British Government has protested both the sentences and the way the trial was conducted, while senior Saudi officials insisted that they would not apply different standards of justice to Western expatriates. A8
 
F.B.I. Adds Mexican to List
United States officials added a 33-year-old cocaine smuggler to the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list, offering more than $2 million for information leading to the arrest of a man they described as the most ruthless drug trafficker in Mexico. Even so, they were skeptical that Mexico would extradite Ramon Arellano Felix, the leader of a Tijuana-based organization, who has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of drug smuggling and conspiracy. College Tuition Climbs Again
The cost of a college education rose by 5 percent this year, which administrators described as proof that they were bringing costs down from the upward spiral in the 1980's. But critics noted the rate of growth was still twice that of inflation and three times that of the growth of the average family income. A18
 
F.D.A. Gets New Authority
The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill that would enable the Food and Drug Administration to speed the availability of drugs and medical devices while giving manufacturers greater authority in reviewing and promoting their products. A29
 
Maverick in Governor's Race
Alfred A. Checchi, a wealthy businessman, has officially declared himself a candidate to become the next Governor of California. Mr. Checchi, a 49-year-old Democrat, who announced his candidacy on Tuesday in Sacramento, has never run for elective office. But he has a personal fortune estimated at $550 million, and he is apparently not shy about spending a good chunk of it in his political pursuits. A18
 
ABC to Revise Kennedy Report
ABC has decided to revise a planned documentary about President John F. Kennedy, saying documents the report was relying on to prove that the President made a deal with Marilyn Monroe to guarantee her silence on their long-rumored sexual affair were fakes. A26
 
Debate Seen on Campaign Laws
A day after Senate leaders agreed to debate campaign-finance legislation this fall, the House majority leader said that the House would also consider a similar bill this year. The lawmaker, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, said the timing and the substance of the House bill were still undecided. A24

Aggressively defending his trade strategy before a skeptical labor audience, President Clinton urged the A.F.L.-C.I.O. not to punish Congressional Democrats who vote to give him more freedom to negotiate trade deals. A28
 
Predictor for Obesity Cited
A study has found that among children under the age of 10, having an overweight parent roughly doubled the child's risk of becoming a heavy adult, even if the youngster was normal in size. A20

HEADLINE: 'Clean Money' Politics Keeps Fat Cats at Bay

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Despite allegations of fund-raising abuses (editorial, Sept. 22), President Clinton's approval ratings remain high, and he and Vice President Gore strike an attitude of indifference. So long as the economy is good, the people don't seem to care. 
 It reminds me of Edward Gibbon's description of the fall of the Roman Empire, starting with Septimius Severus in A.D. 195. Gibbon wrote that "the contemporaries of Severus, in the enjoyment of the peace and glory of his reign, forgave the cruelties by which it had been introduced. Posterity justly considered Severus as the principal author of the decline of Rome." If we citizens accept anything and anyone that keeps us peaceful and prosperous, we deserve no more than the Romans got.
 
DOUGLAS L. PRISCO
Roslyn, N.Y., Sept. 23, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: College Tuitions Climb 5 Percent, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The cost of a college education rose by 5 percent this year, which administrators described as proof that they were bringing costs down from the spiral upward in the 1980's. But critics noted that the rate was still twice that of inflation and three times that of the growth of the average family income.
The College Board, which released its annual survey yesterday, said that the rate of growth for 1997-98 tuition and fees at public and private four-year colleges was unchanged from last year. 
 Donald M. Stewart, the president of the College Board, said that "for most Americans, college is still accessible -- especially in the light of financial aid currently available." He urged students and parents to "keep college costs in perspective," adding that a majority of students at four-year institutions pay less than $4,000 per year.
The report showed that students at four-year private institutions were paying an average tuition of $13,664, and at four-year public institutions, $3,111. Tuition at two-year colleges increased 4 percent at private institutions, to $6,613 a year, and 2 percent at public institutions, to $1,501.
The National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities used the survey's release to point out that the rate of growth in the cost of attending private institutions has declined or remained steady for the past decade.
But a number of economists and others who study the cost of higher education contended that a comparison with the inflation rate -- under 2.5 percent last year -- was more meaningful.
They said that the gap between inflation and tuition increases reflected the growing value of a college degree in the United States.
"Essentially, colleges can get away with it," said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, who studies the cost of higher education. "The value of a college diploma has gone up tremendously in the last 20 years, more than the relative cost of the diploma."
Daniel S. Hamermesh, an economics professor at the University of Texas at Austin, said it was "like any other supply-and-demand situation -- there is little incentive to cut costs." Enrollment has been increasing on both coasts.
Data from the association of independent colleges support this view, in part: a wage earner with a high school diploma earns an average of $880,000 over a lifetime. With a bachelor's degree, the worker makes a $1.4 million, and with a master's, $1.6 million. A graduate with a law degree or a Ph.D. takes in $2.1 million.
Daniel Cheever, president of Simmons College in Boston, said he was pleased to see institutions moderate tuition rates but disturbed that the cost had increased at a rate higher than inflation or the growth in average family income, which is estimated at 1 percent to 2 percent.
"We've slipped back from the goal of making college affordable to nearly every family," Mr. Cheever contended.
Asked if the rate of increase reflected the growing value of a college degree, Mr. Cheever responded: "Just because you can do it doesn't mean you should do it. The market is bearing it today because students and their families are borrowing.
"Payback time will come in the next decade," he said, "and we don't know yet whether the market can bear it because we don't know how the debts will affect those graduates who may not be able to buy houses or go into their field of choice or save for their children's education because of their debts."
David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, said many of the 900 institutions he represents have faced steep costs to computerize their campuses and increase the technical level of their laboratories.
The College Board's report said that student financial aid was at a record high of $55 billion, an increase of 5.4 percent over last year after adjusting for inflation. It added, however, that most of the increase was in the form of loans rather than grants, and most of the increased borrowing was not subsidized.
"Headlines that scream about the inflation of tuition and fees only serve to inflate the fears of American families," Mr. Stewart of the College Board said. "The United States continues to extend higher education opportunities to a larger percent of the population than any country."
Mr. Warren of the association of independent colleges said he expected that by 2002, the rate of increase in college tuition would be in line with the rate of inflation.
"There is a lot of restructuring and downsizing going on" to keep tuition costs down, he said. "Colleges are making tough calls on which programs to keep."
The cost of higher education has come under growing scrutiny because of a perception that it has gotten out of hand in recent years.
Charles Clotfelter, professor of public policy at Duke University, wrote "Buying the Best: Cost Escalation in Elite Higher Education" (Princeton University Press, 1996).
He summed up his findings by quoting the economist Howard Bowen, who said that "each institution raises all the money it can" and "spends all it raises." Professor Clotfelter said that the "almost boundless desire to be excellent" at such universities creates "a bottomless demand for more money."
Professor Clotfelter also contended that the growth in financial aid offered by the institutions in recent years was not entirely altruistic, because it helped the colleges defend themselves against charges that the best education was available only to the rich.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Wednesday about increases in tuition omitted the effects of inflation in comparing college expenses with family income. Considering inflation, the real increase in tuition is expected to average 2.5 percent in 1997-1998, contrasted with an estimated 1.7 percent average increase in family income. The tuition increase is not expected to be three times as high as family income.

HEADLINE: A WALL STREET BEHEMOTH: THE STRATEGIST;
A Deal Maker's Dream Deal

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Sanford I. Weill can hardly contain himself.
At a time when most of his onetime peers on Wall Street have burned out -- or been booted out -- Mr. Weill, who is 64, has just scored a coup for Travelers Group, the company he built from other people's castoffs. He has bought Salomon Brothers, a firm known as the biggest, baddest bond trader on the Street, and maybe on the planet. 
 And Mr. Weill, who a decade ago was written off as a has-been, is clearly filled with glee. "He's having the time of his life," said James Dimon, his second-in-command for 15 years and the chief executive of Smith Barney, the Travelers brokerage firm.
Mr. Weill is grinning even as he takes on a challenge that has brought other Wall Street powerhouses to grief -- building a financial services firm that can do everything, everywhere, from advising China on billion-dollar deals to selling mutual funds to amateur investors in Cincinnati. And he is doing it by trying to swallow a firm with a troubled past and a high-testosterone culture that has resisted even Warren Buffett's efforts to tame it.
The Salomon deal is the culmination of a lifelong dream, he said, to build what he calls " a great financial services company without parallel." And if that means coping with the outsized egos -- and salaries -- that characterize Salomon, well, "I have experience with diverse cultures, and getting people to work together," he said.
The comment came in an interview in Mr. Weill's office on the 39th floor of the Travelers offices in TriBeCa in lower Manhattan, a building that towers over old factories and new apartment buildings. Filled with mementos -- photos and sculptures and signs, as well as a brass plaque engraved "Professional Busybody" -- his office hints at Mr. Weill's desire to be of Wall Street, and more than Wall Street. In fact, he has his back to the street that runs from Trinity Church past the New York Stock Exchange; the view is to the north, a glamorous panorama of midtown Manhattan. In the course of an hour's conversation, Mr. Weill boasted both of his years of experience and how he has "been out of just Wall Street" since 1981.
From his desk, Mr. Weill can also watch the computer screens that flash the price of his company's stock, which he noted ruefully yesterday was dropping. ("We're going broke," he joked.) The shares closed down $2.625, at $69.44.
And above the couch with its slightly worn leather is another view, of the house he grew up in, in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. From an early age, he was aggressive and energetic. "He was a member of the Junior Davis Cup Team, and he's been playing aggressive ball ever since," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, who has known Mr. Weill for decades.
At the age of 27, after just five years as a stockbroker, Mr. Weill opened his own firm with some friends, who used every penny they had to buy a seat on the stock exchange, said Roger Berlind, now a Broadway producer. "We started out working around the clock," Mr. Berlind said, "and Sandy's still doing that from everything I hear."
Through the stock market boom of the 1960's and the protracted market bust of the 1970's, Mr. Weill began buying other brokerage firms, assembling the huge network of stockbrokers that became Shearson Loeb Rhodes. He was famous for negotiating hard bargains and for inspiring the troops while slashing costs.
But in 1981, he made a deal that would lead to disaster for him. He sold Shearson to the American Express Company, the credit card giant. He had hoped, he says now, to "go beyond Wall Street to build a great American institution." But he and James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman of American Express, could not work out their differences; in 1985, Mr. Weill became unemployed.
But he was not alone; he took his assistant, the very young Mr. Dimon, known as Jamie, now 41. Despite a reputation for ruthlessness, Mr. Weill is well known for his loyalty and surrounds himself with old associates from Shearson and elsewhere. Admirers point out that he remains married to the woman he wed right out of college, Joan Mosher Weill, and that his son Marc works for Travelers. Deryck C. Maughan, the chairman of Salomon Brothers, is a friend of almost 10 years whom Mr. Weill persuaded to join the board of his pet charity, Carnegie Hall.
Indeed, in the midst of all the long phone calls and secret meetings in hotel rooms that characterize a big merger, Mr. Weill found time to place a condolence notice in the newspaper on Wednesday for William P. Overman, a money manager, "one of our first and most loyal investors," expressing gratitude not only for his friendship, but for "his lessons on the significance of free cash flow."
Making the numbers work has always been the key to Mr. Weill's success. In 1986, after a frustrated effort to buy Bank of America, he recognized the value of a troubled concern called Commercial Credit, a consumer-loan company that belonged to Control Data. In November of that year, Control Data sold most of Commercial Credit to the public and Mr. Weill took the reins; a year later, he bought the rest of the firm.
A spate of sales followed, along with some important acquisitions. In 1988, Mr. Weill bought Primerica, the parent of Smith Barney, which had been bleeding red ink in the wake of the stock market crash of 1987. The next year, he snapped up the small network of retail brokerage outlets that had belonged to Drexel Burnham Lambert, the junk-bond house under pressure from regulators.
In 1992, he began to buy Travelers, which had been plagued by bad real estate investments, and in 1993, he bought his old baby, Shearson, from American Express for $1.2 billion, which was considered a bargain.
Part of Shearson's problems stemmed from its efforts to move beyond just selling stocks to individuals -- what Wall Street calls "retail" -- and move into the riskier but sometimes more profitable business of investment banking by buying Lehman Brothers. It did not work.
Mr. Weill has had problems of his own trying to make the same transition. In 1993, he hired Robert Greenhill, a rainmaker from Morgan Stanley, and a coterie of investment bankers. Mr. Greenhill, who did not return a telephone call yesterday, left Smith Barney in 1996 to start his own investment-banking boutique.
Buying Salomon is an effort to beef up Smith Barney's investment banking business once and for all and to establish a global presence for a firm that is little known outside of the United States. In some ways, the purchase is vintage Weill. Tarred with a trading scandal several years ago and the defections of some important bond traders, Salomon has been searching for a buyer and comes relatively cheap, or so Mr. Weill thinks. Compared with others occurring on Wall Street, he said, "This is not a crazy deal."
In other ways, it represents a departure for Mr. Weill. "The driving force here is not cutting costs," he said. "It really is growth, and the entree into new markets."
Though he radiates confidence now, it wasn't that way a week ago. "When he gets close to a deal, he gets very, very nervous," said his friend and colleague of many years, Jeffrey B. Lane, the vice chairman of Travelers. "His strength is his insecurity."
And yet the deal may reflect a change in Mr. Weill himself, a change that his daughter, Jessica Bibliowicz, said she had noticed in the last few years. Ms. Bibliowicz, who is now the president and chief operating officer of John A. Levin & Company, worked at Smith Barney for four years.
"He's become much more of a long-term thinker," she said. After years of focusing on cutting costs, she explained, "he's focused on growth of the company, on increasing market share in every business; something doesn't have to be down and out for him to take it on now."

Museums and Sites
 
ABIGAIL ADAMS SMITH MUSEUM, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Built in 1799 as the carriage house for the planned estate of Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, the structure also served as the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; closed Mondays and holidays. Admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; 12 and under, free. "The Designers' Fare," an annual benefit to raise money for the museum's continuing restoration, runs through Sunday; the museum will remain open until 4:45 P.M. during the benefit. Thirteen interior designers have created period looks in some rooms and in the auditorium and gardens. Benefit admission: $10. Information: (212) 838-6878.
 
ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted in the 19th century to a Victorian cottage, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. On view indefinitely is the photographer's parlor, filled with period furniture, and the exhibition "Traveling With Alice Austen," a collection of travel photographs. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $3; students, children and the elderly, $1. Information: (718) 816-4506. 

AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ARTS AND LETTERS, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, upper Manhattan. A new gallery opens on Sunday featuring paintings, prints and drawings by Childe Hassam. Tours will be conducted throughout the building between 11 A.M. and 5 P.M.; tours in Spanish are offered at 12:30 and 2:30 P.M. Gallery exhibition and tours for one day only. The academy is among 10 cultural institutions in upper Manhattan that are participating in the annual "Uptown Treasures" event on Sunday; a free shuttle bus will provide transportation among institutions. The first bus leaves at 10:30 A.M. from Columbus Circle; information, (212) 342-7077. Free. Information: (212) 368-5900.
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. On permanent display are costumes, set pieces, filming equipment and other items relating to film, television and video. Special exhibitions include "Behind the Screen," a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the production, marketing and exhibition of moving images, and "Late Show With David Letterman," which presents the original set for the program, along with designs, drawings and props. Daily screenings include classic shorts, shown in Tut's Fever Movie Palace. A retrospective of the director Jim Jarmusch's films is to continue tomorrow, with "Mystery Train" (1989) and "It's All Right with Me" (1990) at 2 P.M., and on Sunday, with "Night on Earth" (1992) at 2 P.M. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. All activities are free with museum admission: $8; the elderly and students, $5; ages 5 to 18, $4. Information: (718) 784-0077.

There are also permanent displays and two IMAX films: "Survival Island" and "Cosmic Voyage." Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.

On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history from 600 B.C. to the present. The society is among 10 cultural institutions in upper Manhattan that are participating in the fifth "Uptown Treasures" event on Sunday; a free shuttle bus will provide transportation among the institutions. SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, lower Manhattan. The 19th-century port district has an array of restaurants, shops and bars. Among the display areas at the museum are three gallery spaces, a children's crafts center and a boat-building center. Among the current exhibitions: "City in Play: Toys and the Transformation of New York From 1865 to 1945" and "Traveling in Style: 20th-Century Ocean Liners." Hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays until 8. Admission: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: the museum, (212) 748-8600; the marketplace, 732-7678.

PUB-DATE: September 26, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 260 words

HEADLINE: Stealth Bomber Is Latest in String of Failures

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Representative John R. Kasich's reasoned call against further financing for the B-2 Stealth bomber (Op-Ed, Sept. 19) neglects to mention that this aircraft is quickly becoming the third failed Air Force strategic bomber in a row.
Forty years ago, the Air Force began development on the B-70 bomber, designed to replace the B-52 bomber. Despite Congressional and Air Force pressure, President Kennedy canceled the $9.2 billion program in 1961 after serious questions were raised about its effectiveness and necessity. 
 The B-1 bomber -- initiated in 1970, canceled by President Carter in 1977 and resurrected by President Reagan in 1981 -- was intended to bridge the gap between the aging but still capable B-52 and the B-2. Built at a cost of $33.7 billion and plagued by technical problems, the B-1, which also incorporates stealth technology, has never seen combat. By the end of the year, all 94 remaining B-1's will be transferred to the Air National Guard.
Now comes the B-2. Its technical and maintenance shortcomings, which Mr. Kasich mentions, are unlikely to be satisfactorily resolved. Meanwhile, the B-52, built for a mere $42.9 million apiece, continues to perform admirably after 35 years of service. The lesson seems clear: technological advances like stealth may be revolutionary, but they come at an increasingly unsupportable price, in terms of economic cost and military readiness.
 
STEPHEN I. SCHWARTZ
Washington, Sept. 22, 1997
 
Dir., Nuclear Weapons Cost Study
Project, Brookings Institution

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 10; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 649 words

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
The Cold War Is Back, Nuclear Bombs and All

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
The camera crosses over a bombed-out courtyard at a Sarajevo apartment house. It moves into the book-lined home of an erudite piano teacher who is gently giving a lesson to a young girl. In the language of "The Peacemaker," which is filled with catchy and ironic juxtapositions like this one, this scene can mean only one thing. The gentlemanly teacher is planning to blow up New York.
The prevalence of such hooks in "The Peacemaker," a breathless thriller about purloined nuclear warheads, might bring to mind Steven Spielberg even if he were not the mentor of Mimi Leder, who makes a forceful feature-directing debut after much experience directing television dramas (including "E.R." and "L.A. Law"). Speaking of hooks, this film introduces the sweetly whimsical new logo of the Dreamworks SKG studio, which shows a little boy fishing off a crescent moon. The first film he reels in is definitely a decent catch. 
 "The Peacemaker" begins in Russia with the hijacking of a trainload of nuclear devices that are meant to be deactivated in accordance with the Start treaty. Then it quickly summons an American team to the rescue. "God, I miss the cold war," says the national security adviser, echoing the movie's apparent sentiments. The story, with its taste for heavies from the former Soviet Union, is derived from reporting by Andrew and Leslie Cockburn about actual weapons smuggling but has the flavor of a Hollywood paranoid thriller.
Into the breach come George Clooney, who is naturally well cast as a charming roue, and Nicole Kidman. While he has the standard, affable role of a military intelligence officer, she plays someone more abrasive: Dr. Julia Kelly, acting head of the White House Nuclear Smuggling Group. Dr. Kelly is a humorless smarty-pants, the kind of woman who strides around barking orders and uses the term "A.S.A.P." in conversation. Like Jodie Foster's character in "Contact," she expresses womanly professionalism as fierce, hostile sternness. Some day we will look back to see the freakish exaggeration in this behavior.
Anyway, these two hit the ground running and never stop. With locations including France, Germany, Macedonia, Slovakia and the Czech Republic, "The Peacemaker" races in hot pursuit of the warheads. Highlights along the way include a picturesque Viennese car chase, satellite surveillance of the type used during the gulf war, and a furious truck-helicopter battle with the warheads at risk. Brusque Dr. Kelly, whose expertise includes familiarity with the works of Calvin Klein, manages to look wonderfully chic throughout this mayhem.
Eventually, the film locates the Bosnian terrorists who seek to avenge the recent past and plot to bring a nuclear weapon into the United States. "The Peacemaker" culminates in a show-stopping action sequence set in midtown Manhattan, directed by Ms. Leder with crisp economy and furious energy. The actors look great on the run in such circumstances, which is the major part of their job.
Also in "The Peacemaker," a film that noticeably skimps on its supporting cast, is Armin Mueller-Stahl as a kindly old comrade of Mr. Clooney's rakish officer. This courtly actor is a welcome presence for as long as his role lasts, but no secondary players in the restless "Peacemaker" stick around very long.
"The Peacemaker" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes mild profanity and moderate violence.
 
THE PEACEMAKER
 
Directed by Mimi Leder; written by Michael Schiffer; director of photography, Dietrich Lohmann; edited by David Rosenbloom; music by Hans Zimmer; production designer, Leslie Dilley; produced by Walter Parkes and Branko Lustig; released by Dreamworks SKG. Running time: 122 minutes. This film is rated R.
 
WITH: George Clooney (Thomas Devoe), Nicole Kidman (Julia Kelly) and Armin Mueller-Stahl (Dmitri Vertikoff).

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Signs of a German Rate Rise Push Dollar Lower vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the mark yesterday as strong German economic data and comments from the country's central bank, the Bundesbank, suggested that the bank could soon raise interest rates.
But the dollar gained against the yen, which was sold in favor of the mark and other European currencies. The European rally pushed the dollar to its lowest level against the British pound since Aug. 5. 
 "We're trading off expectations of the Bundesbank" raising interest rates, said Bob Near, a vice president at Bank of New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.7590 marks, down from 1.7727 on Wednesday and its lowest since July 10. The dollar rose to 120.88 yen from 120.40.
The mark was bolstered by a report that German import prices rose 5.4 percent in August compared with a year earlier, the steepest annual rise since May 1989. The surge led traders to believe that the Bundesbank might raise interest rates soon to cool inflationary pressure.
That belief was strengthened by remarks from the vice president of the Bundesbank, Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, who said a report on Wednesday showing a slowdown in western German consumer prices should not be seen as reversing the recent growth trend.
"The overriding message from the Bundesbank is dollar-negative," said Allison Montgomery, a currency analyst with I.D.E.A. Inc.
The mark's rally against the yen, on the perception that Germany was far more likely to raise interest rates than Japan, also strengthened the British pound and Swiss franc against the dollar and the yen.
The pound traded at $1.6300 in New York, up from $1.6142, while the dollar fell to 1.4488 Swiss francs from 1.4580 francs.
Against the yen, the dollar benefited as the American economy showed signs of growth while Japan's economy continues to struggle. Yesterday, Japan reported a slowdown in the growth of auto output, while the United States released positive factory order and unemployment data.
The dollar lost some of its gains against the yen in late trading after the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said again that Japan's trade surplus was causing concern in Washington.

HEADLINE: Stock Seesaw Tips Down As Dow Posts Loss of 58.70

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
It has been this way for more than six weeks now, a seesaw battle between those investors who are more bullish and those who are less so.
Yesterday, the game went to the lesser bulls, those who having made money this year, have recently become uneasy about inflation, earnings slowdowns and interest rates. 
 In short, the stock market has been stuck in neutral. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 58.70 points yesterday, its third consecutive loss, closing at 7,848.01, after interest rates in the bond market rose on reports that the economy was strengthening, lifting inflation worries.
Although inflation has been largely absent this year, economic strength continues to renew concerns that the economy could overheat. And when interest rates rise, analysts say, some money flows out of the stock market and into the bond market, as it did yesterday.
"It looks like we had a little hiccup in interest rates," said Steven H. Reynolds, chief investment officer at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago. "There was concern that the economy may be accelerating, or growing too quickly."
Those concerns arose after the Government said that factory orders for expensive items, like automobiles, airplanes and refrigerators, increased for the third consecutive month in August, and that home resales also soared. The Government reported that initial jobless claims for benefits fell last week, an indication that the employment market is tight, yet another element that could contribute to inflationary pressure.
Mr. Reynolds, however, said that the durable orders report was not troubling because it showed a big increase in spending on electronics and technology -- goods that increase productivity and offset employment gains, nullifying rather than igniting inflation.
"Technology spending decreases production costs," he said. "You get good economic growth because of high productivity, but little inflation."
Still, the markets' broadest measures all fell. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.57 points, to 937.91, and the Nasdaq composite lost 8.52 points, to 1,678.89. Volume on the Big Board was average, at 525 million shares, with slightly more stocks losing ground than gaining.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller- company stocks fell 0.66 point, to 447.92, as it continues to fare better than the blue-chip indexes.
For some time, small-capitalization and technology issues have been outperforming blue chips, partly because the stocks of large multinationals have grown too pricey, analysts said, and partly because investors sold them at huge profits after the Dow and S. & P. 500 rose about 30 percent from mid-April to early August.
Now, analysts say, the market is going through a period of consolidation, with blue chips in their worst drought of the year.
"We've been in a consolidation phase since early August, a churning phase," said James Crawford, chief investment officer at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen Inc. "Valuations in this market are far from cheap, and now you have a question mark about earnings and an economy that's working at a high level of capacity."
Despite the consolidation woes, money continues to flow into mutual funds at close to record levels, according to Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, which tracks such flows. About $17 billion went into United States equity funds through Sept. 22, Charles Biderman, the president, said.
Even with the recent weakness, the Dow is still up 21.7 percent this year, and the S. & P. 500 is up 26.6 percent. The Nasdaq, though, has done even better, up 30 percent.
Yesterday, 21 of the Dow's 30 component stocks fell, led down by Merck, which lost $2.1875, to $99.625. Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing was the best-performing Dow stock, up 87.5 cents, to $87.875.
Shares of Cognos , a software developer, fell 33 percent yesterday, down $10.6875, to $22.625, after the company said that growth would slow because of competition.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Climb a Hefty 2.7%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Record demand for electronic products during August led the third consecutive monthly increase in orders for durable goods, suggesting that the economy continued to expand at a healthy pace.
The Commerce Department said today that durable goods orders rose 2.7 percent last month, well above analysts' expectations, to nearly $186.6 billion, a record. The department revised its orders data for July to show a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent instead of the decline of three-tenths of 1 percent reported initially. 
 In a separate report today, the Labor Department said jobless claims fell unexpectedly last week, an indication that the unemployment rate would continue to hover below 5 percent -- its lowest level in nearly a quarter of a century.
First-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell by 2,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 306,000, while the total number of jobless workers collecting benefit checks declined to the lowest level since September 1989. In the previous week, jobless claims fell a revised 4,000.
Today's data caused bond prices to fall because of concerns that the pace of economic growth could prompt the Federal Reserve's policy makers, who meet next Tuesday, to raise interest rates to defend against an acceleration in inflation. Still, few analysts expect immediate action by the Fed because consumer prices have been rising at the slowest pace in 11 years. Orders for durable goods, expensive items intended to last more than three years, tend to be volatile from month to month, and economists caution against reading too much into one month's statistics.
Excluding transportation equipment, durable goods orders rose 2 percent during August. Excluding military hardware, orders increased 2.8 percent.
A record 28.4 percent surge in orders for electronic components, the first increase in that category since May, led August's gain over all in orders. In addition to components like circuit boards and semiconductors, the category includes telephones, televisions and refrigerators.
Orders for transportation equipment, led by aircraft, and for military capital goods also increased. Orders for metals and industrial equipment declined.
Unfilled orders for durable goods, a gauge of pent-up demand, increased 1.1 percent during August after having fallen half a percent in July. Shipments of durable goods, a gauge of current demand, fell 1.4 percent during the month on the heels of a 1.8 percent rise in July.
Separately, the National Association of Realtors said today that sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in August, to an annual rate of 4.32 million units, the highest level in nearly four years. Analysts had expected the report to show a decline.
The association had been scheduled to issue its monthly report this morning but postponed the announcement until Friday. The data were released by mistake by the industry group's research department and disclosed by a bank's economics department.
Home resales rose 6.5 percent in the West, to an annual rate of 980,000 units; 4.4 percent in the South, to 1.64 million units, and 3.3 percent in the Midwest, to a 1.1 million-unit rate. They fell 4.8 percent in the Northeast, to 600,000 units.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Signs of Life, and Wall St. Applause, for the Giant of Detroit

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, a sleeping giant on Wall Street, has reawakened.
In the last two months, G.M.'s shares have risen about 20 percent after treading water over most of the last three years. Some analysts predict that G.M. stock will continue its climb. 
 The turnabout has come as the company's market share in the United States has improved and its labor troubles seem to have receded. Apparently, investors have decided that the stock, with a rock-bottom price-to-earnings ratio, is a bargain after more than three years of poor performance.
G.M. executives share the optimism. "My judgment is that with the high prices for growth stocks, the market is backing away from that and they're looking at cyclicals -- and looking at cyclicals that have good value -- and we happen to be there," said John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, speaking with reporters in Frankfurt, Germany, earlier in the month.
Wall Street auto analysts said the run-up in G.M.'s stock, which began in July, partly reflected optimism that the company's long-promised turnaround could be materializing. "The sentiment has changed on G.M.," said David Bradley of J. P. Morgan Securities. "The cloud that hung over General Motors has lifted."
Skies had been gray for a long time. After war broke out in the Persian Gulf in 1990, G.M. shares fell to the $30 range after touching about $50. They rebounded briefly in 1992, only to slip back to $29.125 shortly before Mr. Smith replaced Robert C. Stempel as chief executive. About 18 months later, the stock climbed as high as $64.75 a share before slipping back again into the mid-50's. Much of this year, it has traded between $54 and $58. It closed at $54.25 on July 15 and began its run-up within days.
Last Friday, G.M.'s stock ended the day at a record $69.5625. Since then, it has faltered somewhat; analysts attribute the decline to profit taking. G.M. shares closed today at $65.125, down 87.5 cents.
Many Wall Street analysts think that the stock has room to rise further in the next few months. Wendy Beale Needham of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette predicts that G.M. shares will reach $81. Joseph S. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers said the stock could reach $75.
G.M.'s Mr. Smith refused to specify a target, but said that the company's price-to-earnings ratio of less than 9 was low. "We see that as being a number that could increase," he said.
Sentiment has changed for the auto maker, the world's largest, which has been struggling to right itself since the board room coup that ousted Mr. Stempel in favor of Mr. Smith. "The ship is finally starting to turn," Mr. Phillippi said. He and other analysts point to a number of reasons Wall Street has gained confidence in G.M.'s stock.
Perhaps most important, value investors have begun looking to General Motors and some other auto stocks because their price-earnings ratios make them seem like bargains compared with stocks that have risen significantly in the bull market. While G.M.'s P/E ratio is 8.7, the average P/E for the Standard & Poor's 500 is nearly 24.
"It is hard to find stocks with single-digit multiples whose earnings are decent," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst with Furman Selz Inc.
Mr. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers said value investors were becoming interested in auto stocks, and adding, "People are basically saying these stocks are cheap."
Perhaps the most obvious reason for the optimism about G.M. is the turnabout in the company's market share, which had steadily shrunk since the early 1960's, when it was about 60 percent.
All year long, General Motors has promised investors that if they would only be patient, they would see the market share rebound as buyers latched onto the 15 redesigned models G.M. began selling in 1997. The company's share of the United States market fell to a shockingly low 28.7 percent in June. But to the relief of Wall Street, it has steadily climbed since, to 31 percent in July and 32 percent in August.
Around the same time, an end seems in sight to labor problems. "I personally think that G.M. has come to their senses," Stephen P. Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers union, said earlier this month. G.M. has faced nine costly strikes in the last year and a half as it tried to negotiate agreements with its 105 local union bargaining units. It has now reached agreements with all but four.
G.M.'s plan to spin off its $6 billion military electronics unit to Raytheon has looked more and more promising to Wall Street this summer. In mid-July, the Internal Revenue Service issued a favorable tax ruling on the deal and the Air Force gave its approval. The deal awaits formal clearance from antitrust regulators.
Analysts expect G.M.'s earnings to be strong, partly because auto sales have been healthy this summer after a rocky first half. While third-quarter earnings are expected to be weaker than last year's third quarter, analysts are forecasting a robust second half because of an expected strong finish in the final three months of 1997. One reason is that G.M. is planning to build a larger number of profitable light trucks.
According to a survey by First Call, analysts estimate third-quarter earnings at $1.19 a share, down from $1.23 a year earlier. For the full year, G.M. is projected to earn $7.58 a share, well above $5.37 last year. And 1998 is expected to be even better. Analysts' estimates approach $8 a share.
As a result, some analysts have been hoping for a further dividend increase, perhaps as early as next month. G.M.'s dividend has been raised three times, most recently in January, and now stands at 50 cents a share. The stock may also have been helped by the $5 billion in buybacks the company has announced this year.
Yet, as for any stock that depends so much on the strength of the economy, a bet on G.M. is still a bet that the good times will keep on rolling.
"The economy is running strong and running at high unemployment and low inflation," Mr. Smith said, "and now I think people are starting to say, 'Gee, maybe there isn't a recession right around the corner.' We don't see 1998 as being a bad year."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation Fear Drops Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday to a nearly two-month low as reports on durable goods orders, jobless claims and home sales rekindled investor fears that the economy might be growing too fast.
An increase in inflation could force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, though most experts do not expect it will happen at next week's meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond tumbled 1 3/32, to a price of 99 24/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.39 percent from 6.31 percent on Wednesday.
A drop in the Conference Board's help-wanted index, along with hopes of short-covering and a coupon pass, in which the Fed buys various maturities to add money to the banking system, did help the market recover briefly, but it was talk of Fed selling for another foreign central bank that depressed bond prices.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the significant rise in yields came after the release of a surprisingly strong 2.7 percent gain in durable goods orders for August, to a seasonally adjusted $186.6 billion, a record.
"While a 51.6 percent surge in civilian aircraft orders certainly helped boost the final result, new orders for durable goods would have risen a solid 1.2 percent even without the leap in aircraft," he said. He also noted that the category with the largest increase was electronic and electrical equipment, and perhaps of greater interest was the fact that the greatest gains were concentrated in consumer products.
Mr. Fine said that while it might be premature to draw any conclusions based only on the numbers from one month, the August gains, excluding aircraft, did not seem to be related to exports and might be a sign of gearing up for the Christmas season.
"However, while the jumps in durable goods orders and existing- home sales may prove to be important down the road," he added, "these indicators are not likely to be decisive elements at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday, as it is the lack of inflationary signals that is keeping the Fed at bay.
"The Fed meeting will clearly be the most important event affecting financial markets next week, but with no change in monetary policy expected by virtually everyone at this point, calling it a highlight may be somewhat of an overstatement. The numbers today clearly showed that the previous day's euphoria was somewhat premature."
The drop in the help-wanted index may have given market participants the impression that there is a little less tightness in the labor market, but yesterday's weekly initial claims data continued to remain fairly low, offsetting the help-wanted index.
Initial claims for unemployment benefits fell 2,000, to a seasonally adjusted 306,000, in the week ended Saturday, consistent with a strong job market. A more complete picture of the jobs market will come next week when the Labor Department releases September nonfarm payroll numbers.
Existing-home sales for August, which were not supposed to be released until today, according to the National Association of Realtors, were accidentally leaked. The 3.3 percent rise in home sales only added more to signs of economic strength.
Prices also fell in the municipal bond market as the Transportation Corridor Agency of San Joaquin, Calif., initially priced $1.46 billion in toll-road refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney Inc. The bond sale was originally scheduled for next week, but many borrowers are moving earlier to take advantage of low rates.
Underwriters report that many of the bonds are insured to protect interest and principal payments. Smith Barney priced $450 million of capital appreciation bonds, or zero coupon bonds, which pay no interest but if held to maturity yield from 4.20 percent for a bond due in 2000 to 5.67 percent for one due in 2036.
For $605 million of the bonds, the yield ranged from 5.69 percent for an issue due in 2028, rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by Standard & Poor's, to 5.46 percent for an insured bond due in 2030. And $405 million of convertible capital appreciation bonds were priced to yield from 5.60 percent for a bond due in 2016 to 5.75 percent for one due in 2024.
