HEADLINE: In Intel Inquiry, U.S. Regulators Send a Message

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
With its investigation of the Intel Corporation, the Federal Trade Commission is signaling that the Government will continue to closely police the leading high-technology companies that play an increasing role in the economy, antitrust experts and industry analysts said yesterday.
The antitrust inquiry, which Intel confirmed Wednesday evening, is the second time the trade commission has examined the big microchip maker in the 1990's. The first investigation of Intel ended in 1993, after two years, without any charges of using unfair business methods to undermine competition. The Microsoft Corporation, the dominant maker of software for personal computers, has been under investigation by the Justice Department since 1993. 
 The commission sent subpoenas Tuesday evening to several personal computer and chip makers, seeking information and documents about Intel's practices in the industry.
But the agency staff has been doing preliminary research on Intel for several months, and the commission formally approved a resolution on Sept. 11 authorizing full use of its compulsory powers to investigate Intel. The resolution carries the name of the F.T.C. chairman, Robert Pitofsky, and three other commissioners. The inquiry from 1991 to 1993 seems to have been conducted at a lower level, under the auspices of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Competition, antitrust lawyers said.
For years, chip rivals have complained about the aggressive business practices of Intel, whose chips serve as the central processing "brain" in more than 80 percent of personal computers. PC makers who use Intel's chips have at times bridled at their dependence on a single supplier.
The F.T.C. investigation comes at a time when Intel's power in the industry is increasing further. Competition from chip makers like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Cyrix Corporation is being blunted. And Apple Computer Inc., which uses the so-called Power PC chip, made by Motorola and I.B.M., is considering a switch to the Intel standard.
At the same time, Intel is extending its reach, moving into the business of graphics chips used in multimedia computing. Its proposed acquisition of a maker of graphics chips, Chips and Technologies Inc., has already been delayed by a separate F.T.C. review.
Given the industry criticism of Intel and the company's growing power, antitrust experts said, the F.T.C. inquiry is not surprising. "Intel is a big target," said Charles F. Rule, a partner at Covington & Burling, a Washington law firm, and a former head of the Justice Department's antitrust division. "And an antitrust agency almost cannot afford to ignore a chorus of complaints about a powerful company. If you do, you set yourself up for charges of not doing your job."
Art Amolsch, editor of FTC: Watch, a biweekly newsletter, agreed. "This is antitrust due diligence by the Government," he said. "Any time you have a company gain as big a market share as Intel, in an industry that is so important to the economy, it is going to be under close antitrust scrutiny."
The subpoenas, called civil investigative demands, ask for information in several areas. Specifically, according to a copy of one subpoena, the F.T.C. is seeking any evidence of practices that would restrain a PC maker from using chips that compete with Intel's. Such practices, the subpoena states, include "any statement, action or policy" by Intel that it might "change the availability of Intel technical information" to any company that chose to use chips made by other companies as well as Intel.
The subpoena also seeks information on potentially restrictive practices by Intel, like refusing to allow engineers at PC companies to do design work on machines using non-Intel microprocessors if they have had access to Intel's technical information.
The Government is also requesting information on the subsidies Intel pays PC makers to feature its "Intel Inside" motto as part of the PC companies' print and television advertising.
The F.T.C.'s use of its compulsory powers mean that PC makers, who depend heavily on Intel, must comply with the Government requests for information -- mainly covering the years from 1994, but for some inquiries going back to 1992. If a company confers with Intel before complying with the subpoena, it must report that as well.
An Intel spokesman, Howard High, said the company would cooperate fully with the F.T.C. investigation. Intel, he added, is confident it has not violated any antitrust laws or engaged in anticompetitive practices.
Each year, thousands of Intel's managers, engineers, sales and technical support staff go through one-week training stints. One of the mandatory courses, Mr. High said, is on "current issues of antitrust and our responsibilities given our market position."
Indeed, the company even conducts simulated raids on managers' offices periodically, said Tim Jackson, author of "Inside Intel," a book about the company to be published next month by Dutton. In these mock raids, Mr. Jackson said, Intel employees pretending to be Federal agents enter a manager's office, seal it off and look for any documents that portray the company in a less-than-flattering light.
"By now," Mr. Jackson said, "Intel is one of the most careful companies in America. It's very aggressive, but it does everything possible to make sure it is just on the right side of antitrust law."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

I.R.S. Official Apologizes For Agency Mistreatment
The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service issued an extraordinary public apology to all Americans for the mistreatment some of them have endured from agency officials.
 
 After three days of hearings before the Senate Finance Committee, the official promised that he would make the agency more responsive to public complaints and would immediately end abuses. The hearings were the first formal oversight of the tax agency ever conducted by the Finance Committee. Page A1.
 
Kodak to Cut Managers' Jobs
Eastman Kodak said it would eliminate more than 200 senior and middle management positions and dismiss at least 10 percent of its general and administrative staff. The moves are meant to stop a decline in profits. Kodak announced last week that third- quarter income would decrease and earnings for the year could be as much as 25 percent below the $4.50 a share it earned in 1996. As a result, shares of the stock have declined. D4.
 
Durable Goods Orders Increase
Record demand for electronic products sent durable goods orders jumping 2.7 percent in August, well above analysts' expectations, to nearly $186.6 billion. The Labor Department also said jobless claims fell 2,000 last week, an indication that the unemployment rate would continue to hover below 5 percent. D6.
 
New Angle in Columbia Inquiry
Some of the hospitals owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare may have used rehabilitation units specifically created for Medicare patients as part of a financial scheme to increase reimbursement illegally, according to documents and testimony obtained by Federal prosecutors investigating the company. D2.
 
2 Advertisers Exit TV Show
Two advertisers, American Isuzu Motors and Weight Watchers International, have withdrawn from the ABC television series "Nothing Sacred," which is about a somewhat hip and self-doubting Roman Catholic priest played by Kevin Anderson. The pullouts by the advertisers come after several months of criticism from the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, which called for a boycott of the show. D4.
 
Icahn Starts Film Company
The corporate raider Carl C. Icahn is investing $50 million in a film distribution company that will be run by Paul E. Cohen, an executive with extensive experience in the independent film world. Mr. Icahn recently acquired Marvel Entertainment. D5.
 
Stocks Close Lower for 3d Day
The stock market declined for the third consecutive session after interest rates in the bond market rose on reports that the economy was strengthening, lifting inflation worries. The Dow Jones industrial average, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the Nasdaq composite and the Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks all fell. D6.
 
Treasury prices fell to a nearly two-month low. Bond yields rose to 6.39 percent from 6.31 percent on Wednesday. D16.
 
Dollar Falls Against the Mark
The dollar fell sharply against the mark as strong German economic data and comments from the country's central bank, the Bundesbank, suggested that the bank could soon raise interest rates. The dollar gained against the yen. D13.
 
Salomon Lease May Cost Millions
Salomon Brothers has been unlucky in real estate in the past, and might lose millions of dollars on its lease at 7 World Trade Center. The investment bank known for making huge profits buying and selling bonds agreed to be acquired by Travelers this week and plans to move into Travelers offices at 388 and 390 Greenwich Street in Manhattan. D6.

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
A Wonderful Summer For Rich and Infamous

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton 

 BODY:
The stories appeared week by week, most of them wire dispatches, not much bigger than dots on the professional sports landscape. There were lines to be drawn, though, connections to be made. When they were, it spelled out N.B.A., only N stood for naughty, B for battery, A for arrest.
By its typical expansionist standards, the National Basketball Association had a wonderful summer, with a capital W. But its stunning W.N.B.A. launch aside, the trend of players and other N.B.A. people who show up on police dockets or in embarrassing positions accelerated this off season. Drug busts, gun possession, drunken driving, sexual assault, bizarre behavior, tax evasion, wiretapping -- you name it, someone from the N.B.A. was doing it, and none of these raps could even be pinned on Dennis Rodman. 
 As if to speak directly -- though certainly not beneficially -- to the issue of life styles of the N.B.A.'s rich and infamous, its national voice, Marv Albert, pleaded guilty yesterday to assault and battery in his made-for-tabloid-television trial this week in Arlington, Va.
Also in Virginia, the league's 1996-97 rookie of the year, Allen Iverson, was arrested in early August, as the passenger in a car going 93 miles an hour in a 65-m.p.h. zone, with a gun and marijuana in the car.
Toronto's Marcus Camby was busted for marijuana and dogged by improprieties from his college career. Washington point guard Rod Strickland spent a night in jail for drunken driving and disorderly conduct. The Knicks' John Wallace reportedly assaulted the mother of his children. Portland's Jermaine O'Neal was arrested in South Carolina for, in part, cursing the police.
Prominent league referees were fired for cheating the Internal Revenue Service. The Orlando assistant coach Tree Rollins was charged with an illegal wiretap of his estranged wife's phone. The owner of the Charlotte Hornets, George Shinn, has been accused by a woman of kidnapping and sexual assault. And just in case anyone wished to argue that athletes are not accountable for messages they send to kids, the former Orlando and now Dallas forward Dennis Scott refused to sign autographs for his own campers and complained to them about his $3 million salary while rap music with obscenities in the lyrics blared from his car.
"I think the public has become somewhat used to the young athletes with the money and the problems that accompany it," said Marty Blackman of the New York sports marketing and consulting firm Blackman and Raber. "I'm not saying that it's healthy. You still turn off some people but it is not the great bolt from the sky."
Dave Checketts, the Madison Square Garden president, agreed that the country does seem more forgiving of celebrity transgressions. "Every time something negative comes up with President Clinton, his approval ratings go up," Checketts said. "I'm not sure John Kennedy could've survived what Clinton has."
The President enjoys a seemingly humming economy. The N.B.A. sells Michael Jordan, the most globally popular and seemingly untouchable sports icon of the television age. But Jordan carries around on his back an evolving N.B.A. that is getting younger, richer, rowdier. An N.B.A. in which Kevin Garnett, two years out of high school, rejects $103 million because he knows he can get more. An N.B.A. that has created an extraordinary thirst for stars but now strains to market them, sometimes simply wishing them into existence.
To an extent, N.B.A. players, coaches, owners and, yes, broadcasters, are paying a steeper price for public sins because of their league's success, visibility and hype. But Checketts understands that few have the Teflon qualities of Jordan, who -- with the assistance of a league that feared implosion -- shook off a gambling scandal several years ago as if it were John Starks.
"No matter what the public forgives, I don't think this sport is so popular that it can withstand these things at all," Checketts said, his eye on a Jordanless future. "No one wants to have a league where people believe they can go out and go 99 miles an hour, carry handguns and do drugs. I think we've really got to be able to take action."
Easier said than done when most significant contracts are long and guaranteed, where the loss of one impact player can bring a whole franchise down. Commissioner David Stern and his shoe company accomplices built an empire by marketing individuals and familiar faces. The post-Jordan future of that empire likely depends on judgments of multimillionaire 20-year-olds. For all his power, Stern is not chief of the N.B.A. police. For the most part, he can only hope that his players live cautious lives.
As for Marv Albert, he resigned from the Garden, saving Checketts -- a devout Mormon -- the trouble of firing him. Albert was fired by the NBC sports president, Dick Ebersol, partner-in-synergy with Stern. Some will ask why Albert isn't moral enough to call basketball games played by the likes of Iverson and Rodman, et al. The answer is this: He is replaceable. He is a messenger with a script, and that script becomes more crucial when too many players are ad-libbing themselves into trouble.
A messenger who embodies the wrong message is one problem that Stern can make disappear.

HEADLINE: In Little Rock, Clinton Warns Of Racial Split

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 25

 BODY:
Speaking from the steps of Little Rock Central High School, the same steps climbed 40 years ago by nine pathbreaking black students and their paratrooper protectors, President Clinton warned Americans today of the dangers of racial separation and pleaded with them not to give up on the idea of integration.
Although he offered no programmatic solutions, Mr. Clinton used the 40th anniversary of the desegregation of Central High to deplore that black and white Americans, despite the abolition of legalized segregation, remain disturbingly isolated from each other in their schools and in their everyday lives. 
 With the nine former students sitting at his side and with an integrated assemblage of students before him, Mr. Clinton lamented that the country's schools are resegregating, that the rollback of affirmative action is denying minorities access to college, and that Americans only rarely associate with those of another race. The White House regarded the address as a major speech in what is to be a yearlong focus by Mr. Clinton on racial issues. Excerpts, page A20.
In past addresses on the subject, Mr. Clinton has emphasized that America today is more integrated than ever. Today, however, in a speech that his press secretary said was "targeted at white America," he offered a blunt critique of the country's separatist tendencies.
"Segregation is no longer the law," he said, "but too often separation is still the rule."
Today's Central High School served as a fitting metaphor for Mr. Clinton's message. While the school is statistically integrated, with a student body that is 40 percent white, its honors classes, eating places and pep rallies remain largely divided by race.
"Today, children of every race walk through the same door, but then they often walk down different halls," Mr. Clinton said. "Not only in this school, but across America, they sit in different classrooms, they eat at different tables. They even sit in different parts of the bleachers at the football game.
"Far too many communities are all white, all black, all Latino, all Asian. Indeed, too many Americans of all races have actually begun to give up on the idea of integration and the search for common ground."
Mr. Clinton was an 11-year-old student at Ramble Elementary, a segregated school in Hot Springs, Ark., 50 miles away, when the integration crisis at Central High shook the country. But despite his youth, Mr. Clinton said the black-and-white images of white students abusing and harassing their black counterparts left an indelible impression.
"We saw what was happening in our own backyard and we had to deal with it," Mr. Clinton said. "Where did we stand? What did we believe? How did we want to live? It was Little Rock that made racial equality a driving obsession in my life."
In honoring the Little Rock Nine, as the black students came to be called, Mr. Clinton said, "Like so many Americans, I can never fully repay my debt to these nine people. For with their innocence, they purchased more freedom for me, too, and for all white people."
In returning to Little Rock today, the President lent his stature and attendant national news reports to the city's efforts to move beyond its past. And by providing Mr. Clinton with a poignantly symbolic setting, Central High gave the President an ideal stage for addressing an issue that the White House considers a key component of his legacy.
Pointing to civil wars and ethnic cleansing around the world, Mr. Clinton warned that any country that does not embrace its diversity will be doomed in the next century. "All of us should embrace ethnic pride and we should revere religious conviction," he said, "but we must reject separation and isolation."
He asserted that discrimination still exists in America. "There are still people who can't get over it, who can't let it go, who can't go through the day unless they have somebody else to look down on," he said. He added: "In so many ways, we still hold ourselves back. We retreat into the comfortable enclaves of ethnic isolation. We just don't deal with people who are different from us."
Indeed, the state and local chapters of the N.A.A.C.P. boycotted today's events because they maintain that little progress has been made over the last 40 years.
On Sept. 25, 1957, in one of the seminal events of the civil rights movement, the Little Rock Nine finally passed through the majestic front doorway of Central High School under the protection of Federal troops dispatched by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Their entrance into the school followed a tense three-week standoff created by Gov. Orval E. Faubus's decision to call out the Arkansas National Guard to prevent the court-ordered integration of the school.
When the students first tried to enter the school, on Sept. 4, they were turned away by a furious white mob that greeted them with racist epithets and threats of violence. And throughout their first year at Central, the students were assaulted, both physically and verbally.
Only one of the nine lives in Little Rock today. But the other eight returned for the commemoration, just as they had 10 years ago when Governor Clinton invited them into the Governor's Mansion where Mr. Faubus had once plotted against them.
In the dramatic denouement of today's ceremony, the nine former students, some with gray hair and beards, ambled slowly up the school's steps and through the front doors, as Mr. Clinton, Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, and Mayor Jim Dailey of Little Rock held them open. As one of the nine, Minnijean Brown Trickey, walked across the threshold, she was overcome with emotion. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Huckabee comforted her as they ushered her through the doors.
The nine former students are Melba Patillo Beals, 55, of Sausalito, Calif., a writer; Elizabeth Eckford, 55, of Little Rock, who is unemployed and on disability; Ernest Green, 56, of Washington, D.C., a managing director of Lehman Brothers investment bank; Gloria Ray Karlmark, 54, of Vught, the Netherlands, a retired lawyer; Carlotta Walls LaNier, 55, of Englewood, Colo., a real estate broker; Terrence D. Roberts, 55, of Pasadena, Calif., the chairman of the psychology department at Antioch University; Jefferson Thomas, 55, of Columbus, Ohio, a financial specialist with the Department of Defense; Ms. Trickey, 56, of Ottawa, Ontario, a social worker; and Thelma Mothershed Wair, 56, of Belleville, Ill., a retired educator.
For Little Rock, this week's commemorative events have been thick with historical symmetry.
Among those in the crowd today was Mr. Clinton's Director of Cabinet Affairs, Thurgood Marshall Jr., whose late father served as the lawyer for the Little Rock Nine. To set the musical mood before the event today, the White House advance team mixed bobby-soxer favorites like the Beach Boys' "Be True to Your School" with rap standards like Hammer's "Too Legit to Quit."
On Monday, Will Counts, a photographer who snapped a famous picture in 1957 of a stoic Ms. Eckford being taunted by a belligerent white girl, brought his two subjects together for a tour of the new Central High visitors center, where the picture is prominently displayed.
The white student, Hazel Bryan Massery, had apologized to Ms. Eckford in a telephone conversation five years after the incident. But the two had never met until this week.
Ms. Massery said in an interview that she has been ashamed by the photograph, which she said had captured her saying "Go home nigger."
"I was an immature 15-year-old," she said. "That's the way things were. I grew up in segregated society and I thought that was the way it was and that's the way it should be." Now, she said, she wants "to be the link between the past and the future. I don't want to pass this along to another generation."
Of today's speakers, it fell to Mr. Huckabee, Arkansas' Republican Governor, to issue the strongest denunciation of his state's past sins.
"Today we come to say once and for all that what happened here 40 years ago was simply wrong," he said. "It was evil, and we renounce it. What the people did who tried to hold those nine from entering the doors of this high school is forgivable, but it is not excusable."
Mr. Huckabee said the state should celebrate its racial progress, but acknowledged that it still has a long way to go.
To those Arkansans who ask how long the state will have to deal with the 40-year-old legacy of Little Rock, he said: "Until justice is the same for every human being, whether he or she is black or white we will deal with it. Until the same rules apply to get a bank loan for every person regardless of who he or she is, we will deal with it. As long as there are whites who turn around and see a black person coming and it brings fear to their hearts, we'll deal with it. And as long as there are blacks who have resentment toward a white person, we'll deal with it."

HEADLINE: Public Advocate Rivals Accuse Each Other of Opportunism

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The candidates for the office of Public Advocate met last night in a contentious debate largely highlighted by dueling charges of political opportunism.
The debate was the first between the incumbent, Mark Green, and Jules Polonetsky, the Democratic Assemblyman who was picked by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to run on the Republican and Liberal Party lines for the city's second-highest elective office. 
 In an hourlong forum in an auditorium at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, Mr. Polonetsky repeatedly attacked the incumbent, focusing primarily on Mr. Green's interest in running for re-election for Public Advocate this year while gearing up to run for the United States Senate next year. For his part, Mr. Green sought repeatedly to portray Mr. Polonetsky as someone walking so firmly in step with Mr. Giuliani that he was incapable of being an objective, independent ombudsman over city agencies.
At one point, for example, Mr. Polonetsky suggested that Mr. Green had not met even the most basic requirement of the office, presiding over City Council meetings. "Mr. Green has been so busy focusing on his Senate race," Mr. Polonetsky said, "that his attendance at City Council meetings has plummeted to 50 percent."
Mr. Polonetsky further charged that voters would be forced to pay more than $5 million to finance a special election to fill the Public Advocate position, should Mr. Green be re-elected and then win the Senate seat next year.
But Mr. Green countered forcefully, suggesting that Mr. Polonetsky was applying a double standard.
Mr. Green pointed out that Mr. Polonetsky had won his election to the Assembly in a special election and that "if he were to win, there would be a special election to fill his seat."
The debate, which was mandatory for Public Advocate candidates, was sponsored by the city's Campaign Finance Board for candidates who accept public financing of their campaigns.
The discussion also included a third candidate, Shoghi Fret, a 21-year-old garment worker who lives in Brooklyn and is running on the Socialist Workers Party ticket.
Mr. Green defended his stewardship of the Public Advocate's office, saying that in producing a long list of studies of the inefficiencies of certain city agencies, and taking a variety of positions on public policy issues he had insured that "citizens are getting a return on their investment."
Repeatedly, Mr. Polonetsky sought to link himself with the Republican Mayor, suggesting that a vote for him would help further the policies and objectives of the Giuliani administration. "I'm running for Public Advocate because I'd like to see four more years of a growing economy," he said. "I'd like to see four more years of crime going down."
In response to virtually every question, Mr. Polonetsky responded with a variation of his attacks on Mr. Green, repeatedly accusing him of relentlessly seeking publicity and operating the office as a launching pad for a candidacy for the Senate.
"New Yorkers want to see a Public Advocate who works with the Mayor," Mr. Polonetsky said, "not someone who sees the office as an opportunity for Sunday morning press conferences."
Mr. Green, while taking an occasional political jab at Mr. Polonetsky, sought to offer an image of himself as a consumer advocate, and focused more on the litany of reports and investigations his office has undertaken since coming to office nearly four years ago.
"I have a goal in public life," Mr. Green said, while discussing his investigations of the city's Child Welfare Administration and the conditions of pay phones in the city. "It's to take on big interests to help all the working families who can't afford the big-shot lawyers. I'm their lobbyist."

HEADLINE: Too Big To Fail

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, is a former Under Secretary of Commerce in the Clinton Administration and a former managing director of Lehman Brothers and the Blackstone Group.

 BODY:
The recent consolidation of firms on Wall Street accelerated on Wednesday when the Travelers Group announced its intention to pay $9 billion for Salomon Brothers.
Now the deal will be scrutinized from every angle: How will shareholders fare? How powerful will the new firm be? Who will be laid off? But one question should not be forgotten: Are these financial megamergers in the public interest? 
 It is no mystery why these behemoths are evolving. For the first time in half a century, financial deregulation is permitting banks to operate nationally and banking and securities underwriting to be done under one roof.
On top of this, a more open and brutally competitive world market requires firms with deep pockets and global reach. Mergers also save money because back office operations and investments in new technology can be consolidated.
But the rapid evolution of our financial system into a handful of conglomerates raises serious concerns. A few big banking supermarkets will simultaneously manage our savings, underwrite and distribute stock offerings, engineer and bankroll mergers and corporate restructurings, invest their own capital in big firms and in startups, and engage in speculative trading in risky options and futures contracts.
The sheer size of these firms will lead to ever more impersonal service, particularly for the average American with a checking account. Because their internal corporate cultures will be so hard to shape and manage, there will also be more opportunity for unsavory ethical practices -- a recurrent problem in the financial industry anyway.
But the most worrisome problem is that these new Goliaths will touch every American citizen and corporation, and will be so intertwined with major financial firms around the world that they will never be allowed to fail.
Knowing that they cannot go belly-up, these firms may take even more risks than they now do. On the one hand, taxpayers may be called upon to shore them up when they get into big trouble. But even if that doesn't happen, financial firms that are not disciplined by real threats of failure could create economic havoc by financing too much or too little and by exaggerating the already rising volatility in world stock markets and currencies.
None of the giants that are emerging would deliberately take foolish risks. But several factors could lead them into dangerous territory. They will be ferociously competing with one another and with their European and Asian rivals. The firms' top managements will be increasingly reliant on computers to assess investments precisely when human judgments about risk have never been more critical.
In addition, our Rube Goldberg regulatory system, composed as it is of the Federal Reserve, the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission, stock exchanges and numerous state authorities, may be too fragmented to keep up with the new conglomerates.
The changes deserve close public scrutiny. At a minimum, continuous Congressional oversight of the broader trends ought to be used to inform the public.
In addition, those who head up the new financial giants need to accept responsibility for much more than providing value to their own shareholders. Like it or not, these leaders, as well as their top lieutenants, also have a responsibility to the public.
The boards of these behemoths also need to be vigilant, independent and technically qualified. It would not be a bad idea, in fact, to set aside a directorship in big firms for someone who is nominated by the Fed or the S.E.C.
Mild as these measures may sound, it will be hard to persuade politicians and business leaders to take even these steps. The objective should not be to ignore market pressures but to recognize the potential risks to the public interest in the changing face of Wall Street.

HEADLINE: A 41-Story Tower Is to Rise Over the West Side Y.M.C.A.

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York said yesterday that it would proceed with a fiercely opposed and long-stalled plan for a 41-story condominium over its branch on West 63d Street, creating one of the tallest residential buildings to overlook Central Park.
The tower, first proposed in 1986, is to be built by two large real estate concerns, the Vornado Realty Trust and the New York development company owned by David Edelstein. Y.M.C.A. executives said they had signed a contract to sell their development rights to the two companies for $9.3 million in cash and improvements to their existing building valued at about $9 million. 
 The plan provoked immediate protests from community groups on the Upper West Side. They said they would challenge the proposal. Neighborhood groups had sued to stop the Y.M.C.A.'s 1986 plan, saying it would create too much traffic congestion, overburden municipal services and cast a long shadow over Central Park. Although the courts ultimately ruled in favor of the development plan, the Y.M.C.A. was forced to put the plan on hold when the city's real estate market sank into a deep recession at the end of the 1980's.
"If we can find a way to stop it, we will," said Olive Freud, vice president of the Committee for Environmentally Sound Development, which has challenged several large developments in the neighborhood.
Under the new proposal for the Y.M.C.A. site, the tower would be built over the former McBurney School, a five-story building that is owned by the Y.M.C.A. and adjoins the west side of its 14-story building at 5 West 63d Street. Meeting rooms, athletic areas and other Y.M.C.A. facilities would either be rebuilt or left untouched by the developers, and the ornate facade of McBurney School, which is protected as a New York City landmark, would be left intact.
The residences would begin on the sixth floor, with the eight lowest residential floors reserved as rental apartments for low-income people, senior citizens and artists.
Beginning on the building's fifteenth floor, where it would ascend over the ornate roof line and cantilever over the Y.M.C.A., it would become a luxurious building by any measure. Most, if not all, the condominiums would command sweeping views of Central Park, extending beyond the Y.M.C.A. and two smaller buildings on Central Park West that house the Ethical Culture Society and its school.
Real estate executives said the condominiums might fetch prices of almost $1,000 a square foot, or $1.2 million for a two-bedroom apartment.
Y.M.C.A. executives said they had received all necessary development approvals from the city and could begin to erect the new condominium immediately. John M. Preis, the chief financial officer of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York, said he expected construction to begin early next year, but he declined to be more specific.
One immediate cause for concern, according to many parents in the neighborhood, is the West Side Y.M.C.A. Co-op Nursery School, with 180 full-time students and educational programs for more than 1,000 others. Parents said they were informed of the Y.M.C.A.'s plan at a meeting on Monday night.
"They definitely didn't give parents enough notice," said Moisha Blechman, a resident of a cooperative building at 64th Street and Central Park West, who attended the meeting. "There will be noise, dust in the air and other disruption. Just being in that atmophere will create problems."
Mr. Preis said the Y.M.C.A. had retained a real estate broker, Cushman & Wakefield Inc., to find space in another nearby building for the school during construction. He also said other measures would be taken to protect children who will use the Y.M.C.A. building while construction takes place. "We know we are dealing with a bunch of 3-, 4- and 5-year-old children, and we will go the extra five miles," he said.
Others in the neighborhood said the Y.M.C.A. project may become a catalyst for the kind of tightly organized community resistance that emerged in the 1980's and has since ebbed even though several large condominiums and commercial buildings have been built or are nearing construction on nearby blocks. Indeed, the burst of building has made the blocks just west of the south end of Central Park one of the city's most active development areas.
"This is becoming Times Square North," said Arlene Simon, president of Landmark West, a community group. "People in this neighborhood don't want it to stand still, just slow down enough so we can evaluate what is going on around us."
But real estate executives said yesterday that rapidly rising real estate values, particularly along Central Park West and on the blocks around the West Side Y.M.C.A., are providing a powerful incentive for developers.
"The prices are astounding," said Clark Halstead, owner of the Halstead Property Company, who said prices in the most sought-after Central Park West buildings now exceed those along Park Avenue. He said the building planned over the Y.M.C.A. could become among the most expensive in the city.
Mr. Preis said the timing of the Y.M.C.A.'s decision was guided in part by the resurgence of property values.
Despite neighborhood protests, he said the money raised through the sale would be used mainly to expand and improve services in the West Side building.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Canadians Feeling Bruised By Relations With America
Canadians are feeling bruised and bewildered by their ally to the south. Tough new restrictions for crossing the border have upset them. Trade conflicts over milk and magazines have rattled Ottawa. And Canadians are profoundly disappointed by the failure of the United States to sign the anti-land-mine treaty, a Canadian-led move viewed as a national accomplishment. On top of all that is a deepening conflict over Pacific salmon. "What's going on here?" asked The Globe and Mail. A1 

Albright Rebukes Israel
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright rebuked Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for promising to build 300 new homes on the West Bank. She has repeatedly called for a "time out" from provocative actions like new construction in disputed territory. A8
 
Jewish settlers in Efrat, on the West Bank, say they cannot understand the dismay that the State Department has expressed at the pledge to add housing. Some 6,000 people live in the settlement; many commute to jobs in Jerusalem. A8
 
2 Sides Faulted for Danube Dam
Slovakia and Hungary are both at fault in the diversion of the Danube River for a hydroelectric dam, an international court in The Hague determined. The ruling's inconclusive nature disappointed environmentalists, who contend that thousands of acres of wetlands have been lost. The court held that Hungary was wrong to abandon its role in the dam project on environmental grounds, but that Slovakia had illegally diverted the river through the dam in 1992. The two countries were ordered to hold new talks. A12
 
Bosnia Funding Approved
The House and Senate passed a spending bill that would open an avenue for President Clinton to extend the stay of American troops in Bosnia beyond next June. A11
 
The Bosnian Serb president expressed confidence in the outcome of elections this autumn between herself and her opponents. The voting in November and December could be crucial to the president, Biljana Plavsic. (AP)
 
Italy's Aftermath of Terrorism 
Years of political violence in Italy in the 1970's and 80's put many terrorists behind bars. Now the country is debating whether to close the books on that era by reducing the sentences of those terrorists still in jail, 224 in all. The effort is reopening divisions in Italy's courts, politics and history books. A3
 
Australian Scandal Widens
One day after two senior ministers resigned in Australia in a financial scandal, the Prime Minister's office was swept up in the affair. Prime Minister John Howard admitted that members of his staff knew of the problem since May, though he insisted that he learned of it just this week. The dispute involved unsubstantiated travel allowances. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NATIONAL A16-25
 
Gingrich Dashes Prospects For Campaign Reform Plan
Speaker Newt Gingrich ruled out any chance that the House would pass the major bipartisan proposal for overhauling campaign finance that has been advanced in the Senate. His remarks came on a day when the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, decided to bring up campaign finance legislation for floor debate on Friday, weeks earlier than expected. A1
 
Clinton in Integration Appeal
President Clinton, speaking from the steps of Little Rock Central High School, warned Americans of the dangers of racial separation and pleaded with them not to give up on the idea of integration. Mr. Clinton used the 40th anniversary of the desegregation of Central High to declare that black and white Americans, despite the abolition of legalized segregation, remain isolated from each other in their schools and in their everyday lives. A1
 
Marv Albert Pleads Guilty
Marv Albert ended a trial filled with embarrassing testimony about his sex life by pleading guilty to a misdemeanor count of assault and battery. Hours later, he was dismissed by two networks for which he had worked as a sportscaster. A1
 
Astronaut Bound for Mir
NASA cleared the way for the astronaut David A. Wolf to replace another American aboard the Mir space station, saying that recent problems aboard the Russian craft were no more risky than in the past. Just a few hours later, the space shuttle Atlantis took off for its rendezvous with the Mir. A25
 
Election Panel Lacks Resources
An exasperated executive of the Federal Election Commission told a Senate committee that while campaign fund-raising complaints have skyrocketed, his agency is operating in an underfinanced "triage" mode, with only two investigators able to travel into the field. A22
 
Party Rallies Around Sanchez
House Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested that evidence of voter fraud is mounting against Representative Loretta Sanchez, who defeated Robert K. Dornan in last year's California election, a charge that has outraged Democrats and prompted them to rally anew around Ms. Sanchez. A23
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
Babbitt Demands Action On Hudson River Cleanup
Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, speaking from a hilltop overlooking the Hudson River, assailed General Electric as a corporate giant bent on delaying the restoration of the river and weakening a Federal program for cleaning toxic sites. Senior officials at General Electric criticized Mr. Babbitt for refusing to meet with them. A1
 
Police Cite Murder Confessions
Three Manhattan teen-agers seized in the savage murder of Nelson G. Gross acknowledged in videotaped confessions that they abducted him in a robbery plot and promised to release him once they had their money, but decided to kill him when it occurred to them that he might identify one conspirator who had worked in his New Jersey restaurant this summer, investigators said. B1
 
SPORTS C1-9
 
Alomar's Annus Horribilis
It has been a long year for Roberto Alomar, the Baltimore Orioles' second baseman, who is one of the best players in baseball, and, perhaps one of the most reviled since an incident last year in which he spat in an umpire's face during an argument. Not only does he draw boos from fans on the road but he also been injured and has run afoul of his manager and was fined heavily. C1
 
WEEKEND E1-31; E33-46
 
'Teletubbies' Due in U.S.
A new BBC show whose target audience is children not yet able to speak, and whose characters have television screens in their tummies and speak only baby talk, has just been sold to the Public Broadcasting Service. "Teletubbies," has caused some alarm in Britain, where parents object that children under 3 should not be targets of television. E3

BUSINESS DAY D1-19
 
I.R.S. Issues Broad Apology
The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, Michael P. Dolan, issued an extraordinary public apology to four individual taxpayers -- and, by extension, to all American taxpayers -- for severe mistreatment at the hands of agency officials and promised immediate changes to eliminate incentives for misconduct and make the I.R.S. more responsive to public complaints. At the conclusion of three days of hearings on I.R.S. abuses before the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dolan said that he was deeply troubled by charges leveled against the tax agency this week by taxpayers, current and former I.R.S. officials and outside watchdogs. A1
 
F.C.C. Approves New Bid Plan
Over the sharp objections of its chairman, the Federal Communications Commission approved a plan to help bidders who say they cannot pay for billions of dollars of wireless-communications licenses. D1
 
G.M.'s Shares Begin Climb
Shares of General Motors have risen about 20 percent in the past two months after treading water during most of the last three years. Some analysts predict G.M. stock will continue its climb. The stock's turnabout has come as the company's market share in the United States has improved and its labor troubles seem to have receded. D1

Record demand for electronic products during August led the third consecutive monthly increase in orders for durable goods, suggesting that the economy continued to expand at a healthy pace. D6

HEADLINE: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You report that doctors at health maintenance organizations sometimes ignore contract provisions that inhibit doctor-patient communication, in fear that patients will sue them for malpractice if they do not disclose all treatment options (news article, Sept. 25). But recent court decisions give little basis for such fears.
In Rust v. Sullivan, the United States Supreme Court upheld the Government's policy of enforcing silence about abortion as a method of family planning when doctors accept Federal money. 
 In litigation against my local health department, a New York State appellate court ruled that the department "clearly had the authority to direct the manner" in which I performed my duties. This precluded presentation of my honest views, to my patients and on their medical records, which other doctors then rely upon. The court in effect promised to protect me if I followed my employer's orders.
He who pays the piper calls the tune. The courts have recognized this law of economics, so when Americans sign up for third-party payments, deceit, or at least the risk of it, is what they get.
 
ROBERT CARLEN , M.D.
Sayville, N.Y., Sept. 25, 1997

HEADLINE: One to a Subway

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The New York City Transit Authority's plan to cut subway train crew size from two people to one is only half right (news article, Sept. 24). The Transit Authority has demonstrated that one individual can operate a train and open and close its doors when it is in the station. Yet reinvesting the savings in running more trains during off-peak hours and weekends could have a much bigger payoff for the city than the few dollars saved on the Transit Authority's budget. 
 A dramatic increase in evening and weekend service would encourage discretionary travel, strengthening the economy. The Transit Authority should address the full range of benefits of an attractive transit system -- fewer cars, less pollution, more stable communities -- and go beyond its narrow focus on nickel-and-dime savings.
 
GEORGE HAIKALIS
New York, Sept. 24, 1997
 
The writer is president of the Institute for Rational Urban Mobility.

HEADLINE: Mid-Atlantic Seafood Industry Is Suffering

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
While scientists say a toxic microbe that has killed millions of fish in Middle Atlantic waters this year poses no threat to fish-eaters, state officials in Maryland and Virginia say the outbreak is severely hurting their seafood industry.
In Maryland, where seafood sales normally reach $400 million a year, officials said today that wholesale and retail sales had fallen as much as 75 percent in some areas and that seafood orders in restaurants had declined by 30 percent. 
 In Virginia, Bob Stolle, the state's Deputy Secretary of Commerce and Trade, said sales of the seafood industry there, typically $465 million a year, were down 33 to 50 percent.
"There's never been anything like this before," said Noreen Eberly of the Maryland Agriculture Department's seafood marketing program. "People aren't eating Maryland seafood or seafood from anywhere else, including orange roughy from New Zealand and salmon from the Atlantic Ocean. People are just avoiding seafood at every level."
Ms. Eberly estimated that at current levels of seafood consumption in Maryland, the industry was losing $15 million to $20 million a month.
The microbe, Pfiesteria piscicida, which produces red lesions on fish, was first identified as a cause of death among them in 1991, after billions of menhadens died in North Carolina's Pamlico Sound.
Studies have found that the microbe can cause skin irritations, respiratory problems, memory loss and learning impairments in humans who are exposed to infested waters. But scientists have found no evidence that eating fish from the same waters causes similar symptoms, and no evidence that the microbe has had much effect on any species except menhaden, a fish harvested not for eating but for the production of oil and fertilizer.
Nonetheless, outbreaks this year in Maryland's Pocomoke River, Chicamacomico River and King's Creek and in Virginia's Rappahannock River sounded new alarms throughout the region. As scientists rushed in to monitor waters all around the Chesapeake Bay, and as Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland ordered the affected areas in his state closed, consumers began changing their eating habits.
By summer, several leading Maryland grocery chains had cleared their shelves of fish caught in Maryland. Even sales of blue crabs, a summertime favorite throughout the Middle Atlantic region, fell by as much 50 percent.
Suzie Robertson, who works for Evans Seafood in Shadyside, Md., south of Annapolis, said the business typically sold 1,000 pounds of rockfish a week for $2 a pound this time of year.
"But now," she said, "we've stopped fishing for them. No one's buying."
Lee Wilson, a fisherman from Crisfield, Md., who sells wholesale to markets in New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, said, "All of a sudden, people are scared to death of any of it."
Governor Glendening says the economic effect of the Pfiesteria outbreak has resulted largely from a perception that all waters around the Chesapeake Bay are contaminated. While the affected areas are waterways at the southern end of the bay, fishermen plying rivers and creeks 100 miles away and farther have encountered sluggish markets for their catches.
As a result, Mr. Glendening has mounted a highly visible public relations campaign to offset what state officials and environmentalists contend is a gross overreaction. In recent weeks, he has invited reporters to cover him eating hearty seafood lunches. Last week he invited governors from five nearby states to discuss Pfiesteria issues in Annapolis. On Thursday, he asked a House subcommittee for additional Federal spending on Pfiesteria research and persuaded several chains of Maryland supermarkets to resume their purchases of fish caught in state waters.
And today Mr. Glendening said the state would add $500,000 to seafood marketing programs that would otherwise have received only $137,000 in state support for the current fiscal year.
"Most of the recovery should occur within a matter of weeks," the Governor said in an interview, referring to an improvement in seafood sales expected with consumers' usual shift to oysters and crabs this time of year and the gradual cooling of bay waters, which would force Pfiesteria into a dormant stage. But he added:
"It will not be back to 100 percent until we are totally confident we have contained the Pfiesteria and started the process of eliminating the causes. That could take another year or so."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Like countless Middle Atlantic fishermen, Larry Linton, a Virginia crabber, must cope with consumers' concern about a toxic microbe.
(Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Data Showing Slower Growth Helps Treasury Bonds to Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds rallied yesterday as the Federal Reserve entered the market as a buyer and a revised figure for gross domestic product in the second quarter showed the economy growing at a slower pace than previously reported.
Trading was choppy with the shorter maturities outperforming the longer issues. By late in the day, the 30-year bond had gained 1 3/32 to 100 5/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, dropped to 6.36 percent from 6.39 percent on Thursday. 
 The Commerce Department gave its final estimate of second-quarter growth at 3.3 percent, down from the previous estimate of 3.6 percent. Another positive for the market was the University of Michigan's sentiment index for September, which showed a decrease to 106.0 from a preliminary reading of 106.8 made in midmonth.
"In a market that continues to be dominated by a healthy dose of positive sentiment, the G.D.P. report represented pretty good news because of the small downward revision," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Reviewing the consumer index data, Mr. Chan said, "the decline of the overall figures for September from the midmonth reading was very constructive for the market." He explained that "they seemed to imply that consumption may not grow faster in the fourth quarter compared to the possibility of 3 to 3.25 percent consumption growth in the third quarter."
Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data of Boston, noted some good flows among the shorter maturities, but said the market ran into trouble trading up from lofty price levels.
What sustained the market yesterday? Mr. Burtnick thought it might have been the purchases from small investors as they bought heavily in the short maturities, through the five-year note. "There was also some pretty good central bank buying, in the form of a coupon pass, in both the two-year and three-year maturities," he said.
In its coupon pass, the Fed bought $1.7 billion in securities maturing in two to five years, from September 1999 through August 2002. The coupon pass adds money permanently to the banking system, but does not signal any change in the central bank's monetary policy.
"Although the Fed meets on Tuesday," Mr. Chan of Banc One said, "it is quite clear that the current benign inflationary outlook is unlikely to permit policy makers to alter their current unchanged policy course.
"However, if labor markets become even firmer and inflation begins to reveal any signs of reincarnation, I would not be surprised if they moved to conduct one more insurance tightening as early as the November meeting."
The featured economic data next week will be the monthly employment report, scheduled for Friday.

HEADLINE: Skittish About Growth in Sleepy Hollow

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

DATELINE: SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y., Sept. 26

 BODY:
General Motors has proposed transforming the hulking automobile factory that was the clanging heart of North Tarrytown into a luxurious development that could be the humming new center of Sleepy Hollow.
Last week the auto company unveiled an ambitious plan to build a mini-village on the site of its closed factory, one of the largest parcels of land slated for development along the Hudson. But the village that changed its name last year as part of an effort to change its blue-collar image is saying the automaker's glittery plan may be too ambitious. 
 "I think General Motors came in with the deluxe luxury model," the Mayor, Sean Treacy, said today, "and we're more of a community looking for a midsize."
Planners hired by the automaker described for village officials a new riverfront community with a marina, apartment buildings, stores and perhaps a museum and a hotel. The planners from Cooper, Robertson & Partners, the Manhattan architectural firm that designed the master plan for Battery Park City, even described dredging out a new inlet, creating, in effect, an island that could be a prime location for luxury homes.
General Motors said the plan was merely a "conceptual' outline, intended as a blueprint that could be followed by the automaker itself or by a developer who might ultimately buy the 96-acre property.
Officials here said they were dazed by the magnitude of the carmaker's proposal: 1,900 residential units on the site just north of the Tappan Zee Bridge. By some calculations, that could add 4,000 people to a village with a current population of just 8,200, requiring new schools, roads, sewers and, most importantly, turning a small community into a bigger one almost overnight.
Some people said the issue was a classic collision between a desire for development that could bring much-needed dollars and an equally strong desire to preserve the small-town feeling that is a source of pride for many Hudson River towns.
"It would be a sociological jolt to the community," said Patrick Munroe, one of the village trustees who attended a recent presentation by General Motors. "It was like saying, 'O.K., folks, we used to be a little town with little streets and Mom and Pop stores on Beekman Avenue, but now: Get out of the way.' "
Several trustees said that they expected strong community resistance. The village could impose zoning restrictions that would limit development on the site, but officials said the plans were too premature for such measures. A spokeswoman for General Motors, Marcia McGee, said the proposal would conform to current zoning. She added that because of the high cost of construction at the site, high population density was necessary because "a developer has to make some money."
Experts on development said anxiety here about the density of the proposed community reflected a widespread concern in the region about how much large communities outside New York City can grow before they lose their character.
H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, which studies the 31-county metropolitan area, said such concerns were particularly important in the Hudson Valley.
"The one thing I think the Hudson Valley has to be very careful about is destroying the thing that makes it special, which is the quality of life: open space, access to the river, air and water quality."
At the same time, Mr. Shostal said, the Regional Plan Association says that development is appropriate for places that are, like the General Motors site, in the midst of existing communities with easy access to mass transportation. But the question officials must ask, he said, is: How much development is enough?
Some community leaders in Westchester County said they worried that by focusing so intensely on the density issue, village officials were forfeiting a chance to help shape one of the most significant open sites in the metropolitan area.
John H. Dobkin, president of Historic Hudson Valley, a foundation that runs six historic sites including Philipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow, said the critical questions for the New York region involved issues that were likely to get lost, like the creation of developments that stimulate economic growth.
"It is an extraordinary opportunity," Mr. Dobkin said. "You have 96 acres and what are you going to do with it? It not a once-in-a-lifetime challenge, it's a once-in-a-millennium challenge."
On Sleepy Hollow's Beekman Avenue today, there was anxiety as well as anticipation. For example, Hugh Casey, owner of Casey's Tarry Inn, said he thought General Motors was suggesting bringing in too many new residents. But some newcomers would be good for the village, he said. "The type of people they are talking about bringing in," he said, "are the type that don't cook home. They'll come out and have a drink and have dinner."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A General Motors plant on the Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, formerly North Tarrytown, closed last year. Now Mayor Sean Treacy, above, and others weigh the impact development would have on the site and village itself. (Susan Farley for The New York Times)
 
Map of Westchester highlighting site of former factory: Sleepy Hollow may sculpt its own future with land on the river.

HEADLINE: Data Show Economy Grew at 3.3% Pace in Spring

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 3.3 percent annual pace during the spring, new data showed today, somewhat slower than was previously thought but still faster than what most analysts consider the economy's speed limit, above which inflation would revive.
Still, despite a further pickup in economic growth over the summer, economists and Wall Street analysts say they expect Federal Reserve policy makers to leave interest rates unchanged when they meet on Tuesday. The absence of inflationary pressures in price data and the political climate have kept the Fed from trying to slow the economy's vibrant growth. Such inaction, however, could eventually chip away at the Fed's hard-won credibility as an inflation fighter. 
 Today's Commerce Department report also showed that final sales, adjusted for inflation and excluding the effects of inventory changes, rose 2.5 percent in the April-June period. But several analysts said the quarter just ending could show a rise of 4 percent.
"This is making the Fed very nervous," said James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago-NBD. "We're setting up a very, very rapid rebound in total spending."
The central bank, however, can point to nothing in price data at any stage of production or distribution to justify tightening monetary policy, thereby raising rates, to dampen growth.
"The Fed is looking at the lowest inflation rates in more than 30 years," observed John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns in New York.
Indeed, never in the postwar period has inflation been decelerating this far into a business expansion. The current one is more than six years old.
Without evidence of revived inflation, analysts say, the Fed finds itself forced to remain on the sidelines, at least for the time being, hoping that a big buildup of inventories during the first half of the year will help the economy slow down on its own.
Politically, "there's just no taste for a sustained pre-emptive move," said Mr. Annable, in contrast to 1994 when the Fed doubled the overnight interest rate it largely controls to 6 percent from 3 percent. After subsequent trims, the Fed raised the rate one-quarter point in March, to the current target of 5.5 percent, in what Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, called a form of insurance against a buildup of inflationary pressures.
Although the Fed is not expected to take any action on Tuesday -- and there has been no signal of any to the financial markets -- analysts say the meeting will most likely be spirited. Underlying the debate will be how to prepare for the next meeting on Nov. 12, when continued rapid growth might force the Fed's hand. So far, an unemployment rate of less than 5 percent and two increases in the minimum wage have not significantly driven up pay, which is the dominant business cost.
"Most regions are experiencing tight labor markets, recruiting difficulties or growing labor shortages," a survey of the Fed's 12 districts prepared for Tuesday's meeting found. "Two-thirds of the districts, however, report that these supply-demand imbalances are not translating into generally higher wages."
Some members of the Fed policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, generally those based outside Washington, are expected to argue for higher rates based on traditional assumptions about a trade-off in which more jobs come at the cost of higher inflation.
Others, including Mr. Greenspan, have increasingly accepted the view that the economy's "speed limit" has increased and that inflation can remain in check at a growth pace higher than the presumed 2 percent to 2.5 percent.
Regarding the accepted limit, "there's a lot of reasons to think that could be in error," said Lacy H. Hunt, an economist with Hoisington Investment Management in Austin, Tex.
He said that both the labor force, swelling with former welfare recipients, and productivity, the other determinant of the economy's speed limit, could combine to produce a noninflationary growth rate of "maybe 3, even 3 1/2 percent."
"There needs to be a smoking gun" of inflation for the Fed to tighten policy, Mr. Hunt said.
Today's Commerce Department report was its second revision of gross domestic product for the April-June quarter. Its first estimate of 2.2 percent in July was raised to 3.6 percent in August before today's revision to 3.3 percent.
The largest revised change was to exports of goods, the report showed, while real final sales were reduced to their 2.5 percent rate of increase from 2.8 percent at the preceding tally.
While the 3.3 percent pace of the spring G.D.P. rise was below the 4.9 percent of January through March, it was not the lull for which policy makers had hoped.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

British Parts Supplier Gets $2 Billion Federal-Mogul Bid
Federal-Mogul, an ailing American auto parts maker now showing signs of recovery, said it had offered about $2 billion in cash for T & N, a British auto supplier. The deal brought praise from Wall Street, which bid up Federal-Mogul shares by $3.75, to $37.25. T & N shares also rose in London trading.
 
 The move is part of a consolidation trend in auto parts. Indeed, in another deal, the Blackstone Capital Partners II Merchant Banking Fund agreed to buy a controlling stake in American Axle and Manufacturing for about $650 million. [Page D2.]
 
Stocks Rise on Revised G.D.P.
A revised Government estimate of second-quarter gross domestic product showing that economic growth was slower than expected fueled a rise in stocks, pushing broad market indexes up. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 74.17 points, to 7,922.18. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock gained 7.31 points, to 945.22, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.35 points, to 1,682.24. [D4.]
 
Treasury bonds rallied as the Federal Reserve entered the market as a buyer. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 6.36 percent, from 6.39 percent on Thursday. [D2.]
 
Union Head Linked to Schemes
Aides to Ron Carey, president of the teamsters union, have told Federal investigators that he had general knowledge of fraudulent schemes in which the union donated money to liberal groups and in exchange donors to those groups contributed to his campaign, officials involved in the investigation said. Mr. Carey has denied that he knew about or participated in such schemes to swap contributions, saying that he is the victim of his aides' lawbreaking. [A1.]
 
S.E.C. Charges Financial Adviser
School districts across Pennsylvania face the loss of more than $70 million that they invested with a financial adviser who secretly ran up big trading losses, Federal regulators said. The districts, about 75 of them, had invested more than $233 million with the adviser, Devon Capital Management, which is run by John Gardner Black from Tyrone, Pa., according to a complaint filed in Federal district court in Pittsburgh by the Securities and Exchange Commission. [A16.]
 
Anti-Dumping Duties Supported
The International Trade Commission voted 3 to 0 to back the imposition of punitive anti-dumping duties against the Vector supercomputers produced by NEC and other Japanese manufacturers. The commission, an independent trade panel, found that Cray Research had been financially injured by the pricing practices of Japan's supercomputer producers. The commission's ruling upheld anti-dumping tariffs of up to 450 percent against NEC, which the Commerce Department imposed in August. [D3.]
 
China's President Meets With Rubin
In his first meeting with a senior American official since consolidating his power as China's leader, President Jiang Zemin told Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin that he was irreversibly committed to the wide-ranging economic changes already under way. But Mr. Rubin said Mr. Jiang made clear that China would make major moves to open its markets only "as economic conditions improve, and at a pace that China feels it can handle." [A4.]
 
G.M. Proposal Stuns Town
General Motors, which closed its automobile plant in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., last year, has returned with a plan to develop the Hudson River site into a new riverfront community with a marina, apartment buildings, stores, perhaps a museum and hotel -- even creation of an island for luxury homes. There is general agreement that the G.M. plan would be a huge change for the village. And that is just the problem. [B5.]

HEADLINE: Market Reform Irreversible, Chinese Leader Tells U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 26

 BODY:
In his first meeting with a senior American official since consolidating his power as China's leader, President Jiang Zemin told Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin today that he was irreversibly committed to the wide-ranging economic reforms already under way here.
At the same time, Mr. Rubin said that during his hourlong session inside the ornate, lakeside compound where China's leadership lives and works, Mr. Jiang made clear that China would make major moves to open its markets only "as economic conditions improve, and at a pace that China feels it can handle." 
 Mr. Rubin's meeting with Mr. Jiang was primarily intended to set the tone for the Chinese leader's state visit to Washington late next month, the first by a Chinese leader in a dozen years. American officials described Mr. Jiang, normally a dour leader who carefully sticks to his briefing notes, as "slightly ebullient" after his successes at the 15th Communist Party Congress, which concluded last week.
During that session, the party endorsed many of the market-oriented changes already under way throughout the country. Mr. Jiang also managed to ease out several of his competitors in the top ranks of the country's leadership, replacing several military officials with a younger generation of non-military leaders whom he described today as more attuned to the imperatives of economic reform.
Mr. Rubin's meeting today came at the conclusion of a weeklong tour of Hong Kong and China, during which he assessed the prospects and pace of China's move toward privatizing its lumbering, state-owned enterprises and overhauling its ailing financial infrastructure.
Mr. Rubin said today that his meetings with a range of Chinese officials, especially with Mr. Jiang, "gave me a sense that there is a real vision of the direction the country has to move."
A senior Western diplomat based here said today that Mr. Jiang appears to view his trip to Washington as the capstone of a victorious year, one in which he presided over the return of Hong Kong to Chinese control and then tightened his control over the Communist Party. "He views this as almost a second normalization of relations," the diplomat said of the visit, a reference to President Nixon's trip to China that opened diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The content of Mr. Rubin's meetings here underscored how the Clinton Administration is trying to change the nature of its interchanges with China -- away from sporadic, angry exchanges about human rights and arms proliferation, and toward regular consultations that focus chiefly on how the world's biggest industrial economy and its biggest developing economy should interact.
"What struck me," Mr. Rubin said this evening, "is that they were willing for the first time to have truly informal, open, candid discussions" that included frank admissions of the country's biggest economic headaches.
The first among those problems, he said, is finding a way to streamline government-owned enterprises without setting off large-scale unemployment that could lead to political unrest. A second and related problem is stabilizing the country's teetering banking system, which has lent more money to the government-run enterprises than they have the revenues to repay.
Before his trip, Mr. Rubin said he hoped to use his meetings with China's economic leadership to establish the kind of rapport between mid-level American and Chinese financial officials that Washington has long had with Tokyo, and recently with Moscow. Today he said he thought that kind of trust was starting.
"The fact that we were able to explore these issues in detail, rather than just reading pieces of paper to each other, is perhaps the most important change," Mr. Rubin, a former investment banker who has worked with many troubled enterprises, said tonight. "It suggests that we're moving to a more mature, stable relationship."
Mr. Rubin also delivered a letter from President Clinton to Mr. Jiang about the coming summit meeting, which he declined to describe in detail. But other American officials said that as Mr. Jiang's trip approaches, the two countries are scrambling to put together a string of modest accomplishments that can be announced in Washington.
One may be a declaration by the Clinton Administration next month that China is no longer contributing to the spread of nuclear weapons. That would clear the way for American companies to resume the export of nuclear energy technology here. Westinghouse is considered the lead contender for contracts in excess of $2 billion to build nuclear power plants, which China desperately needs to keep up with its growing demand for electricity.
Officials say there may also be some progress on Chinese conventional arms exports to the Middle East, and probably some modest gesture in the human rights arena. In the past China has released a dissident or two from prison before such meetings.
But Administration officials conceded this week that they are unlikely to make any progress on their biggest economic initiative with China: getting it to agree to broad market openings in return for its admission to the World Trade Organization, the club of trading nations.
Today China's Finance Minister, Liu Zhongli, said his country was "willing to join the W.T.O." but not "if the requirements are not suitable for the Chinese situation, for a developing country."
