SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4205 words

HEADLINE: Technology Makes Us Better;
Our Oldest Computer, Upgraded

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a staff writer for the Magazine. In May, he wrote about the debate over rent stabilization in New York.

 BODY:
When the Sojourner's tiny wheels rolled over the Martian surface on July 5, it was in some ways a bigger leap for mankind than Neil Armstrong's first step on the Moon. You may not have realized that if you were watching network television, which gave the Mars landing relatively short shrift. But that was the beauty of this extraterrestrial event: you didn't need a television to follow it.
Anyone in the world with a computer and an Internet connection could see pictures from the spacecraft. You could study Martian sunsets or put on cardboard 3-D glasses to take in a 360-degree view of the landscape. With a few clicks of the mouse, you could read a treatise on Martian geology, check out the latest weather conditions on the planet, sit in on a news conference or watch scientists issuing commands from the mission-control room. One Web site provided a recipe for throwing a Mars Madness Celebration -- red and brown M & M's were recommended -- and gave directions to dozens of such gatherings across America. Other sites let you participate in on-line chats with planetary scientists as well as religious fundamentalists convinced that the mission was a hoax being staged in the Arizona desert. During the week of the landing, the various Mars Web sites were visited more than 200 million times. 
 It was easily the most popular event in the history of the Internet, proof at last that humanity could use this new medium for something loftier than viewing pictures of a naked Pamela Anderson Lee. The Moon landing was the apotheosis of the old technological order: a big-budget achievement of central planning, a cold-war triumph of the military-industrial complex packaged by politicians and presented to the masses by the media establishment. The Mars visit was a low-budget operation with a charming quirkiness to it, a peaceful scientific exercise instead of a propaganda victory over an enemy nation. In 1969, Communist authorities suppressed coverage of the Moon landing; this year, Russians followed the Mars mission on the World Wide Web, using the very machines that helped end the cold war.
Is this a better world? Has technology made us better? Tools can't change human nature, but they can encourage or suppress certain qualities, and most people would probably agree on what constitutes "better": wiser, happier, kinder, more equitable and cooperative, less duplicitous and belligerent. The tricky part is defining "us."
In the two centuries after the Industrial Revolution, individuals reaped enormous personal benefits that were accompanied by some social liabilities. As people abandoned farms and small towns, they lost communal bonds; as personal incomes rose, public air and water got dirtier; as power became concentrated in capital cities, elites controlled new tools of mass communication and mass destruction. Indoor plumbing and washing machines freed women of onerous work, but there was less socializing at wells. Trains and cars enabled workers to move away from industrial neighborhoods, but these suburbanites spent more time alone in their cars and backyards, lapping up the wisdom of distant publishers and broadcasters instead of chatting with relatives and neighbors. Although new technology is often described as a Faustian bargain, historically it has involved a trade-off not between materialism and spirituality -- lugging water from the well was not a spiritually uplifting exercise for most people, no matter how much it might appeal to the Unabomber -- but between individual freedom and social virtue.
Today's technologies offer a better deal for everyone. Individuals are acquiring more control over their lives, their minds and their bodies, even their genes, thanks to the transformations in medicine, communications, transportation and industry. At the same time, these technologies are providing social benefits and undoing some of the damage of the past. Technology helps to conserve natural resources and diminish pollution. Today's farmers are so efficient that unneeded cropland is reverting to forests and parks; the most high-tech countries have the cleanest air and water. The Information Revolution, besides enabling people to visit Mars at will, is fostering peaceful cooperation on Earth by decentralizing power. Political tyrants and demagogic warmongers are losing control now that their subjects have tools to communicate directly with one another. People are using the tools to do their jobs without leaving their families. They're forming new communities in cyberspace and forming new bonds with their neighbors in real space. Technology has the potential to increase individual freedom and strengthen community -- even though at the moment, so many people complain it does neither.
Technology's victims have become familiar images in the media: on-line addicts who don't know their next-door neighbors; satellite- dish owners who have stopped reading; computer users overwhelmed by E-mail, infuriated by software glitches and baffled by incomprehensible manuals; workers displaced by machines or forced to put in longer hours; frazzled parents, especially working mothers, too exhausted and busy to spend time with their children. We contrast these pathetic figures with images of a happier past, of families quietly relaxing in a pre-machine age when people still had time to read, contemplate the meaning of life, visit with their relatives and neighbors.
But when exactly were those halcyon days? If premachine means before the Industrial Revolution, the average person then was short-lived, illiterate and oblivious to most culture beyond the village. Women's lives were consumed with domestic chores and continual pregnancies, and women were especially unlikely to be educated. Marriage records from a region of 1750's England, then one of the world's most literate societies, show that two-thirds of the bridegrooms could sign their names, but only one-third of the brides could. It would be hard to call that a better world.
Living conditions and educational opportunities certainly improved after the Industrial Revolution, but people still didn't have much time to sit around discussing the classics or communing with nature. In the middle of the last century, the typical man in Britain worked more than 60 hours a week, with no annual vacation, from age 10 until he died at about 50. That left him with about 90,000 hours of free time over the course of his adult life -- barely a third of the free time enjoyed by today's workers. This trend shows no sign of abating, says Jesse H. Ausubel, director of the Program for the Human Environment at Rockefeller University. He projects that by the middle of the next century, the average workweek in America will be shorter than 28 hours.
Since 1965, Americans have gained an average of almost one hour of leisure each day, according to social scientists at the University of Maryland who have been studying people's "time diaries" over the past three decades. Americans are now spending a little more time reading books and magazines, exercising, pursuing hobbies and attending adult-education courses. Evidence from the diaries and other research shows that in recent decades, people have been going more frequently to art museums, the theater and the opera.
Contrary to popular stereotypes, the diaries show that the workweek has been shortening, that women have as much leisure time as men and that parents are spending as much time with their children as they did in the 1960's. These children, unfortunately, are less likely to live with two parents, which may be partly a consequence of technology that has made divorce and single parenthood less of an economic burden: men and women are presumably more inclined to live separately now that they can both support themselves outside the home, relying on machines to make clothes, clean house and do most food preparation. But new technology is hardly the only cause of the traditional family's decline, and in any case it's hard to get too nostalgic for the days when women had no choice but to stay in the kitchen.
Why, if men and women have more time and opportunity than ever to pursue their dreams, do they grouse so much about modern technology? One reason is that new technologies like computers usually are more trouble than they're worth -- at first. They're hard to learn and create resentment among workers, particularly the unskilled ones who fear displacement and are jealous of higher-paid experts in the new technology. The introduction last century of electricity to factories did not immediately increase workers' pay and productivity; the widespread benefits came only after several decades, when factory managers and workers finally learned how to use the new motors efficiently. Then wages increased for everyone, raising the standard of living and creating new kinds of jobs. Luddites have been warning for two centuries that technology destroys jobs, but the overall effect of automation is to free workers to concentrate on other, less-tedious tasks. Today's workers are richer and more cultured than their Luddite ancestors (and better dressed, thanks to mechanical looms). While they may have fewer jobs in the textile industry, they have more opportunities to work as teachers, social workers, travel agents, personal trainers, writers and museum curators.
As much discomfort as the personal computer has caused, there's no reason to assume that the machines will remain complicated. Gadgets become simpler as technologies mature and marketers appeal to the masses. George Orwell's despair over cars, gramophones and telephones was at least partly due to the crude state of those technologies in his day. The automobile was a relatively unreliable, high-maintenance machine until a couple of decades ago. Gramophones were cumbersome and yielded tinny sounds. Telephones were forever disturbing the peace of people trying to eat, converse or read. The phone didn't become wholly civilized until people were freed to ignore it by the invention of the answering machine -- a contraption that was despised before coming to be regarded as a necessity. Today, E-mail is a novelty that can be disruptive, but pioneers are developing techniques for coping, like automated responses when there's no time to deal with an overloaded mailbox and filters to sift out the junk mail.
Another reason we grouse about modernity is that our expectations are higher. The middle class wants perquisites once limited to the rich, from material luxuries to cultural experiences to intellectual fulfillment. Our ancestors may have been content to pass the time on the porch chatting with neighbors about the weather and crop prices, but they didn't have many other choices. Today most people -- including those academics who rhapsodize about traditional communities while working in offices far from their hometowns -- demand more stimulation than their relatives and neighbors can provide. We feel more rushed because we have more possibilities.
"Free time is increasing, but not as fast as our sense of the necessary," says Geoffrey Godbey, a co-author of "Time for Life," a report on the time-diary research project. "With technology we've upped the ante. Instead of corresponding with 6 or 7 people, we have 150 E-mail partners. Thirty years ago most people didn't bother shampooing their carpets or blow-drying their hair or making their own bread, but now that they have the equipment, they have higher standards."
The most dispiriting trend discovered by Godbey and his colleagues is the couch-potato paradox: people have been watching more television even though they rate it among their least-favorite forms of leisure. Americans average more than 16 hours a week, an increase of 4 hours since 1965, which means that most of our recently acquired free time has gone to the tube. A die-hard optimist could argue that television has been improving, that people are deriving joy and enlightenment from all those new cable channels, but it would be just as easy to argue that they're staring at cubic zirconium rings. The increase in tube-watching seems especially perverse considering that it coincides with a decline of two hours a week in the amount of time people spend socializing, an activity they consider much more enjoyable than television. A society of solitary people sitting at home enviously watching the camaraderie on "Friends" does not seem like a triumph of the communications revolution.
The good news is that people with computers are watching less television, and they've increased the amount of time spent socializing with family and friends (partly because they get together to play computer games). At the moment only about 40 percent of American households have computers, but the percentage is rising as the machines become cheaper and easier to use. Over the past year, home computers have begun outselling televisions in the United States, a statistic that cheers George Gilder, who in 1990 wrote a book titled "Life After Television." Now the editor of the Gilder Technology Report, he expects the broadcast-television empires to collapse -- and an intellectual culture to flourish -- once the masses can easily receive video and text from a computer network as diverse as the Internet.
"When I debate network television executives," Gilder says, "they come up to me afterward and say: 'Look, you don't understand. People like the stuff we put on. We've done market surveys and we've found that people are boobs.' Well, I'm a boob when faced with conventional TV. It's too much work to find something good, and if you do, it probably won't accord with your particular interests. Television is a lowest-common-denominator medium even with 50 or 500 channels. You'd never go to a bookstore with only 500 titles. In the book or the magazine industries, 99.7 percent of the stuff is by definition not for you, and that's what the Internet is like. It's a first-choice medium with a bias toward each individual's area of excellence instead of the few commonly shared interests, which are mostly prurient and sensational."
Now that the computer is combining the television with the telephone, it's clear that George Orwell got things precisely wrong in "1984." He was remarkably prescient to envision society's being transformed by a two-way communication device called the telescreen, but he didn't foresee that these telescreens would promote freedom. One-way television is useful to Big Brother, but two-way communication devices undermine central authority by communicating with one another. Totalitarian countries have fewer telephones than televisions; democracies have more telephones.
Why was Orwell so technophobic, so sure that telescreens would promote tyranny and war? Peter Huber, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute who analyzes the mistakes of "1984" in his recent book, "Orwell's Revenge," finds the answer in an essay Orwell wrote imagining how humans could free themselves of the drudgery of washing dishes. In this 1945 essay, Orwell considers the possibility of paper plates but settles on another solution: "Every morning the municipal van will stop at your door and carry off a box of dirty crocks, handing you a box of clean ones (marked with your initial, of course) in return." Orwell envisions a dishwashing factory run by a public agency -- Big Brother's Ministry of Crockery, as Huber calls it.
"The thought of private, automatic dishwashing machines never even surfaces," Huber writes. "For Orwell, the centralization of powerful machines is inescapable economic destiny in the industrial age." The most graphic refutation of Orwell was the famous Apple commercial broadcast during the 1984 Super Bowl, in which the enslaved masses were liberated by a lone woman hurling a sledgehammer at a demagogue on a huge telescreen.
At the time it was a wonderful image of the home computer's revolutionary potential. In hindsight, it's even more apt, because the target of the attack, I.B.M., which then seemed to be the omnipotent Big Blue, was about to be humbled. It was more Wizard of Oz than Big Brother. The company had dominated the era of mainframe computers, but it floundered in the late 1980's when it faced competition from upstarts offering cheaper, decentralized machines.
As these personal devices proliferate, it's becoming impossible for political leaders to censor information. Africa's leaders can control newspapers, but citizens in remote villages are now getting uncensored news from Africa Online. And as information becomes central to economies, the incentives for tyrants to wage war are diminishing. Military conquest of foreign lands made a certain amount of sense when the victors acquired manpower and resources from farms, mines and factories. Access to scarce natural resources was vital -- in the Middle Ages, armies fought wars over salt. Today wealth is based more and more on information, not natural resources, which is why the Congo is poor despite its vast mineral reserves, and why Hong Kong is rich even though it must import food and drinking water. The Beijing autocrats may have acquired title to Hong Kong's real estate, but they haven't conquered it. They can't seal its borders or appropriate its wealth. If they try to stop Hong Kong's telescreens from communicating, computer keyboards around the world will respond, and Hong Kong's money will start to flow away, followed shortly by its populace.
Now that the specter of Big Brother is receding, today's critics of technology have been focusing on the opposite danger: too much freedom. Conservatives worry that traditional values are threatened by on-line crudity; liberals worry that social injustice and selfishness will prevail in the unregulated realm of cyberspace. The critics correctly see that governments are losing some of their power to impose laws and moral standards, but that doesn't mean we're doomed to chaos and cruelty. Humans developed sociable rules and moral codes long before the era of centralized governments. The Internet may look like a dangerously anarchic world, but it's actually fairly similar to the ancient environment in which humans evolved to become the most cooperative, virtuous creatures on earth.
The original Information Revolution occurred during the Pleistocene, a decentralized era if there ever was one, when hunter-gatherers on the African savanna developed a powerful new computer: the human brain. The brain evolved to its large size because its information-processing capacity enabled humans to band together and increase their chances of survival. The size of a primate's brain correlates directly with the size of its social group, and the formula worked out by scientists indicates that the human brain is sized for a group of about 150, which by no coincidence is the number in a typical band of hunter-gatherers.
The large brain enabled our ancestors to work together because they had so much information about one another. They knew whom to trust because they could store memories of past behavior and obtain news about others' reputations. They developed instincts and customs that stigmatized selfishness and encouraged voluntary cooperation, especially within the band but also with outsiders. Other animals make sacrifices for the common good of their immediate kin, performing acts of altruism that insure the survival of their mutual genes, but humans go further. "We are just about the only animals who act altruistically toward nonrelatives," says Matt Ridley, a zoologist and the author of "The Origins of Virtue," a new book analyzing the evolution and economics of cooperative behavior. "Humans can be selfish, of course, but what makes us special is our instinct to be nice to one another. Every culture defines virtue almost exclusively as pro-social behavior, and vice as antisocial behavior."
This cooperative spirit has made possible the division of labor, which has been the source of all wealth, technology and culture. Just as Stone Age toolmakers independently developed complex trading networks for obtaining rock blades from distant tribes, 11th-century merchants established a trading system across Europe without any central guidance or enforcement authority. The merchants traveling among disparate kingdoms developed their own legal code and observed it voluntarily because they knew that a violator would be ostracized and unable to conduct business. The mere communication of information was enough to make them behave honorably.
"The Information Revolution is taking us back toward our better social instincts," Ridley says. "The Industrial Revolution helped centralize authority, creating hierarchical bureaucracies that tried to coerce cooperation but often brought out the most selfish instincts in both the rulers and their subjects. The way to regain community spirit is to have small institutions and horizontal networks of equals who voluntarily cooperate, like the people you see chatting on the Internet today. These virtual communities formed spontaneously because our brains are naturally inclined to this sort of information exchange. It's what we spent most of our time doing in the Pleistocene."
The Pleistocene savanna makes a good image for the Internet: a wide-open frontier being settled without any central planning. A few sociopaths are out there spreading computer viruses, and encounters among strangers can provoke viciously uncivil "flame" wars. But rules of etiquette are evolving as people coalesce into communities and networks. By trading information, they're discovering whom to trust and whom to avoid. They're writing E-mail letters to relatives and scheduling meetings with friends. Some, like merchants, are cooperating for profit, but a surprising number seem to be acting out of pure goodwill. They're freely providing information, from software to consumer advice to counsel for the lovelorn.
Most of the information is of no interest to most people, which is why the Internet can seem so pointless. My first few forays persuaded me that it was the world's most effective way to waste time. But in researching this article, I decided to give it another try. I had just read a good review of "Data Smog," a book by David Shenk about the dangers of the Information Revolution, so I looked for it among the 2.5 million books at the Amazon.com Web site. I found it right away, along with an assortment of reviews from newspapers and magazines. Some of the most succinct analysis ("Excellent at describing info glut, not so hot at solutions") came from laypeople who had volunteered their own comments.
There was also an area -- "Check out these titles!" -- listing other books ordered by buyers of this one, an extraordinarily useful cross-referencing feature. I began clicking from book to book, each time benefiting from the expertise of previous buyers to discover new related titles. It was like going from one Pleistocene water hole to another, at each stop picking up advice and directions to the next one.
Within a couple of hours I had found enough technophobic literature to keep George Orwell happy for years -- hundreds of books ranging from old scholarly critiques of the Industrial Revolution to titles like "Surviving the Media Jungle" and "Under Technology's Thumb." I discovered "Technolopoly," by Neil Postman, revealing that America has become the world's "totalitarian technocracy," a place with no "transcendent sense of purpose or meaning."
Within a week, Amazon.com had graciously delivered to my door a small library assailing its own electronic technology. I read "Data Smog" -- which decried the Internet's "fragmented, asynchronous, decentralized 'free-market' culture where the public good is sacrificed" -- as well as Clifford Stoll's "Silicon Snake Oil" and "Amusing Ourselves to Death," another lament by Postman. I went through treatises on information have-nots and spiritually deprived Internet surfers. I learned about a degraded electronic culture that is rendering books obsolete -- an ominous trend revealed in books purchased on line at the largest, most helpful bookstore in history. I tried to take the warnings seriously, but as the experts described the terrible plight of Americans drowning in data, there was something I couldn't get out of my mind.
It was the line spoken by Emperor Joseph II after the premiere of "The Abduction From the Seraglio": "Too many notes, my dear Mozart." He was expressing the feeling common among the day's elite that Mozart's complex music was too fast-paced and stimulating for the average listener.
Like new music, new technology is always disturbing, especially to the establishment, and it always causes unforeseen problems. The agricultural and industrial revolutions were accompanied by new plagues, pollutants and weapons of destruction. Today's revolution will bring troubles and trade-offs, but we can cope with them. Transmitting information from one willing individual to another is hardly a new menace.
Like Mozart's music, this is something our brains are equipped to handle. This is what we're good at, and what makes us better.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Electronic Gallery: Daniel Lee -- Because technology changes the way we live and the way we create, it also changes the way we look. My image, therefore, is an evolutionary self-portrait a look at the distant past and into the far-off future. My eyes shrink as electricity eradicates the need to see in the dark. My brain and forehead enlarge as information expands my mind. And my features blend as communication brings cultures closer and closer together -- Asian, Caucasian and so on. Only the ears remain the same size, because we'll never stop needing to listen.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1403 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Electricity and Gas;
Energy Deregulation: Lower Costs, More Confusion

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
JUST as the deregulation of telephone service brought down the price of long-distance calls at the cost of a bewildering range of carriers and choices, deregulation of energy offers the potential for similar savings and confusion for the owners and managers of office buildings.
Earlier this month, state regulators and Consolidated Edison, now a monopoly supplier of electricity in New York City and some suburbs, agreed to a deregulation plan that will cut rates across the board by 10 percent for residential and commercial companies and reorganize Con Ed into three companies. The rate reduction will at first apply to a small number of customers, but it is expected to spread across the customer base over about five years. 
 Natural gas was deregulated several years ago, but building managers have been slow to reach for lower-cost gas supplies because of uncertainty over how to take advantage of the lower prices available in gas fields hundreds of miles away and questions about relations with Con Ed, whose pipes will distribute gas through the parts of the city not served by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
The Durst Organization, however, eager to hold down operating costs as well as to provide environmental benefits, plans to make extensive use of gas at the new 48-story office building it is constructing along Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. The building, known as 4 Times Square, will use gas to fuel the chillers that will provide air-conditioning to the offices and public spaces. It will also use gas to generate part of the building's electric power through fuel cells, devices that convert the gas to electricity without any burning and with minimal pollution.
The first existing commercial building to shift to deregulated gas is at 320 West 13th Street, an office building managed by Sage Realty and owned by the William Kaufman Organization. Executives of Sage say that the conversion late last year produced immediate savings and that landlords in New York could collectively save millions of dollars annually by using deregulated gas.
"We saved 35 to 37 percent over a nine-month period at 320 West 13th," said Gene Haran, a senior property manager at Sage. "We already had both oil and gas in the building, so it was a natural candidate for the switchover."
Mr. Haran said the owners of the Kaufman Organization were so pleased with the results that they are converting another company property, at 767 Third Avenue, to deregulated gas and are considering taking the same approach at other properties.
But being first has some drawbacks, Mr. Haran said. "We get lots of phone calls," he said. "We hear from managers of apartment buildings as well as offices in the city and Long Island."
He said the only change was to meters and a phone line notifying Con Ed how much gas had been consumed. Although the gas had been purchased from a third party and belongs to the building's owners, Con Ed gets a distribution fee for delivering it to the burners in the building. He said the building is using a marketing company, Utilicorp in Kansas City, to handle the actual gas purchases.
"Typically the marketers get together once a month and take bids from the well heads and pipelines," said Richard Lorson, the chief executive of Lorec, an energy consulting company that helped Sage switch to deregulated gas. That is, they they compare prices for the gas as it comes out of a well, and the prices of the pipeline operators who pump it from wells in Texas and Louisiana and deliver it to Con Ed's main connection, known as its "city gate."
Because the 13th Street building has the capacity to use both oil and gas, its owners were able to opt for a class of service in which the flow of gas can be interrupted during periods of high demand. Rates for this interruptible service are 15 percent or more lower than service in which the supply of gas must be maintained at all times.
MR. LORSON said this capability allows managers to play the ebb and flow of oil and gas prices to achieve the lowest fuel cost. "The interruption is limited to 10 days for any reason, so you buy enough oil to cover that in the middle of summer when prices are low," Mr. Lorson said. "There is also the option of switching to oil if gas prices start going up."
The new Durst Building will use gas for air-conditioning, but the really new development is the decision to install two 200-kilowatt fuel cells in the building to supply some of its power needs. Although it is apparently the first time fuel cells have been installed in a large office building in an urban setting, the plan represents something of a setback for the Dursts, who had planned to install as many as eight and use Con Ed as a reserve power source.
The reasons for scaling back from eight cells to two for what? installing the cells? the smaller number of cells? have their roots both in the building's location in Times Square and in the nature of fuel-cell technology. Current zoning requires Times Square buildings to be festooned with large, brightly lighted signs -- which are a good source of revenue. Part of the plan was to use the cells to provide power for the signs instead of buying power from coal-fired generating plants that emit pollution. Since there is no combustion in a fuel cell, the emissions are much more benign.
One attraction of fuel cells is that they have few moving parts -- once started, they typically run steadily for about five years. But they are hard to start and stop. And the demand for power in a Times Square building varies widely during a 24-hour period.
"The signs get turned off at night," said Daniel Kaplan, an architect with the firm of Fox & Fowle, which is designing 4 Times Square. "A lot of them are off from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M."
"Signage is an excellent use" for the power produced by the cells, said Jonathan D. Durst, executive vice president of the Durst Organization. He said it was not clear that all the signs would be turned off every night and that the ones at the top of the building might be operated differently from those at the base. He said that with the two cells producing 400 kilowatts, they could handle about 50 percent of the building's nighttime load, but only about 2 to 2.5 percent of the daytime peak.
The Dursts say they are proceeding with installing photovoltaic panels in the building's skin, in another effort to develop an alternate form of energy. The amount of electricity generated by the panels' conversion of sunlight to power will be minimal, but the owners hope to learn how they operate in an urban setting so they can be replaced when more efficient photovoltaics are developed. "This is an experiment to further understand how photovoltaics operate on vertical surfaces," said Mr. Durst, known to his colleagues as Jody. "We are going to put them in different parts of the building and different elevations. We are going to study how light bouncing off other buildings affects ours."
Since gas deregulation has preceded that of electricity, some managers are looking at what happened with gas to help devise strategies to deal with the changing power market. But some experts say the deregulation of electricity will be much more complicated and will take longer.
"Gas is much simpler," said Mr. Lorson. "You just dig it out of the ground and you can use it. Electricity has to be generated." In addition, gas is easily stored, while electricity must be used as it is generated.
The process is expected to be particularly complicated and difficult in Manhattan, because Con Ed owns all the local generation plants and there are parts of the city, called "load pockets," where the Con Ed distribution system makes it impossible to use power from non-Con Ed sources.
"Con Ed will have to sell off its local generating capacity over a period of years, which should solve the load pocket problem," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, who helped devise the recent deregulation compromise.
The question, he said, is whether Con Ed will be allowed to sell all the plants to one buyer or be forced to sell to many. It would probably get a higher price with one buyer, but that buyer would have enough market power to keep rates high. Selling to multiple buyers would yield a lower price to Con Ed. But the increased competition would likely lead to lower electricity prices.

PUB-DATE: September 28, 1997

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 10; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1485 words

HEADLINE: I Found the Best Trail for Me and My Horse

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
ROY ROGERS had the right idea about Happy Trails -- the hard part was finding some in the area.
It's not that my horse, like his owner pretty much the suburban Connecticut bumpkin, had any preconceived grievances about living in Brooklyn. For a while, it was an educational experience. Where else could he awaken to the sight and sound of the Concorde nosing its way toward Europe, a mere jog away through the marsh bogs of Sheepshead Bay. Where else could he jostle for street space with limousines whose occupants, unseen behind tinted glass, weren't just reputed members of crime families: they were his neighbors. Protective of their Rolls-Royce bumpers, they always afforded his shiny chestnut 1,200-pound bulk the proper respect. 
 In Brooklyn, he broadened his culinary horizons, acquiring a taste for seeded semolina loaves and the odd bagel. He navigated a trail, the only available trail, whose landmarks consisted of junked cars, chain link fences and a couple of conveniently placed playgrounds, and he learned not to flinch at the various bangs and booms that peppered the summer air -- the firecrackers, the backfires, the whatever.
From his time in Brooklyn he gained a composure that's made it easy for him to co-exist with the popgun noise created by the local skeet shooters at a club near the gentrified Old Westbury digs where he ultimately ended up. Because after a year in Brooklyn, I pined for new digs for both of us, especially Copper, who was then a boisterous six-year-old American Saddlebred with energy to spare.
I wanted to see him strutting his stuff in a setting where the grains of dirty sand in his paddock didn't outnumber the blades of grass by a zillion to none. Eventually,
a suitably unprissy barn was located that straddled the railroad tracks on the East Hampton-Amagansett border and offered sprawling pastures shaded by scrub pines. Most important, it had access to a shrinking network of trails that meandered around the potato and corn fields and brought us within saluting-or shooting-distance of the rather tame deer that, because they sprinkled Lyme ticks wherever they ranged, seemed to be responsible for scaring most other riders away from the trails.
This being the Hamptons, the occasional celebrity could not be avoided. Copper bonded with a big brute of a horse owned by Jerry Dellafemina, who was then in the business of buying up East Hampton. Christie Brinkley briefly stabled her first-ever horse, a slim gray mare who was a gift from then-husband Billy Joel, at the barn and dutifully posted through her lessons in the adjacent schooling ring. Brinkley, pristine in her Jackie Kennedy riding habit, rode often and attracted everybody's notice. That meant Copper and I came and went unnoticed: perfect.
What wasn't perfect was having to leave paradise for Brooklyn at the end of August; I couldn't bear to turn my country mouse of a horse back into a city mouse again. And that's when divine providence, in the form of a harness racing publicist, Joey Goldstein, intervened. When I told him I was depressed about leaving my horse way out east just to keep him in fresh air, Goldstein steered me to horse heaven: Tom Quinn's unadvertised barn in Old Westbury, a mom-and-pop operation surrounded by the finest trails this side of the Virginia hunt country, 30 miles of nirvana plotted and maintained by the Old Westbury Horsemen's Foundation.
Ten years ago we carted Copper up a long gravel driveway framed by trees and adjudicated by a single octagonal sign that reads WHOA instead of STOP, and he's lived there happily ever after. Gaining stall space in Mr. Quinn's barn was a variation on passing inspection by a co-op board with admission based on the quality of one's idiosyncrasies.
Truly an operation where the inmates run the asylum, the 15 or so horses, divided among several pastures based on who gets along with whom, gallop en masse into the barn, a former Whitney property, twice a day for their grain. Unless the weather is inclement, they spend the rest of their time grazing, napping and shooting the equine breeze outdoors. Or else they and their lucky owners are off exploring the trails.
And what trails they are. One minute you're slogging along a dirt path alongside the L.I.E.'s access road, traffic humming and 18-wheelers reverberating on the Post Road overpass, the next you're enveloped in trees and racing along through the woods with bluejays and hawks shrieking in indignation overhead. One minute you're marching past an estate with a gigantic backyard sculpture that looks like a Calder (and probably is), hunkering alone on the lawn like some futuristic weathervane, then you're trotting past a transplanted English castle with Grecian pillars that lend a touch of ancient formality to its less-than-ancient Olympic swimming pool, and suddenly you're scrambling up the near-90 degree incline of Suicide Hill, oblivious to everything except the fact you've foolishly scorned the purchase of life insurance for yourself and your steed.
Once at the top, you're deep into the woods again, clomping past a ghostly abandoned indoor tennis court, all that remains of Mrs. E. P. Garvan's estate, that and a battered old wooden sign that's long outlived its purpose. Along the trail, the hermit thrushes trill like xylophones and, over on defunct Whitney-Phipps-Garvan Drive, there's a fallen tree just begging to be jumped over. Who needs life insurance? Life is good.
According to John J. Shalam, the president of Old Westbury Horsemen's Foundation, his horse refuses to tackle Suicide Hill, but every weekend morning, he and friends traverse the trails, a trip that can take 45 minutes, if they choose to economize, or requires a good three hours if they make the trek toward Stone Arches where, with 500 more acres of trails, the Muttontown Preserve is waiting.
There are 185 members in the foundation, the only active civic organization in Old Westbury, and not all are horsey: some are homeowners who cherish the bucolic sight of the occasional trail rider outside their windows. It costs $7,000 yearly to keep the trails, which ramble around the campuses of SUNY Old Westbury, New York Institute of Technology and C. W.Post, clear and rideable. Another $3,000 is spent on liability insurance. And Mr. Shalam passes ample hours making certain that the constant creep of suburbia (the Round Hill and Wheatley Farms developments have provided the latest disruptions to a trail system that, along some stretches, is almost a century old) does not smother the trails.
It helps that the foundation is on blissful terms with village officials, including the trustees who approve the easements that allow the trails, and the pricey subdivisions, to co-exist. It helps that Old Westbury's Mayor, Sydell Weinstein, was among the group of horse-loving citizens of this village, settled in 1658 and divided for its first 225 years between 42 Quaker owned-and-operated farms, who got together 26 years ago to clear, preserve and improve the trails. Twice a year, the Smithtown Hunt, a group that's been riding to the hounds since 1900, tests the foundation's trails and jumps in a daylong race that does not, in fact, involve the pursuit of an actual fox.
But the foxes are out there. My sister, Cynni, found that out one chilly November afternoon when we borrowed a horse, an Appaloosa antique named Doc, and took a post-Thankgiving ride to burn off our turkey dinners. Just after proclaiming that "a dead person" could ride old Doc, my sister found herself soaring unmerrily through the air after her vehicle, spooked by a fox that seemed to be chasing us, switched into high gear. She broke her wrist, wore a cast for six months, and hasn't ridden since. I'm not sure whether it was Doc or the fox that had the last laugh.
Copper and I haven't had any accidents to report. If anything, our sunset rides (we're soloists, and always ride in the evening) have become rituals that mark the passage of time like a living calendar. In summer, we canter through thickets of wild asters with gangs of goldfinches quivering above us. In the fall, we know winter's on the way when big gray clouds of Canada geese begin making pit stops in the beautiful poplar-lined meadows, remnants of the old Bell estate, on the SUNY campus. In winter, we're able to thunder along the trails with Copper's hoofbeats muffled by snow; in spring, we linger in the dusk and he roots out the best clover as owls, ready for the evening hunt, hoot from the treetops.
In any season, we make our journeys in virtual isolation: it's hard to believe we're smack in the middle of Long Island, hard to believe that on the clearest nights, it's the shimmer and glimmer of New York City we see from the peak of a hill. No phones are ringing. No horns are honking. No rose and silver sky could impart a greater sense of peace and quiet.

GRAPHIC: Photos: There are many inviting places for riding. John Shalam and Martin Sternberg on some secluded trails in Old Westbury. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Now for Some of the Bad Things

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
THE assignment was to write an essay about the worst of Long Island, to temper the accolades about to be recorded in a special section dedicated to the Island's best. At first I refused, offended by the suggestion that Long Island is anything but a suburban Eden, a fish-shaped isle of serenity.
Where else does there exist an unwritten zoning law that requires a delicatessen within a half-mile of every resident? What other diverse population recognizes the Entenmann's raspberry danish as the communal bread of life? Name another society that exalts its women not for their beauty or intellect but for the integrity of their shellacked fingernails; that raises its men to communicate with the revving of a motor and an economical hand gesture, rather than with mere words. 
 But other images of the Island gradually came into focus, displacing those happy thoughts of Babylon docks and North Fork fruit stands. The Long Island Expressway, where the flashing advisory of "normal traffic conditions ahead" is more threat than comfort. The Long Island Rail Road, whose trains seem to run on the life force they suck from passengers. The Hamptons, where the rich prance about the beach in vegetable costumes to raise money for some endangered legume or Democrat.
Here, then, are gentle reminders of what is unlikely to appear in any tourist guide to Long Island, from one whose pedigree is impeccable. Raised in Deer Park (Exit 51 usually, but Exit 50 if you know the back roads), I have consumed my weight in 7-11 slurpees, sliced the sale bologna in three delicatessens, and learned at the feet of neighborhood elders how to mangle my diphthongs (toilet becomes "terlet"; girl becomes "goil"). It is true; I am fluent in the language of Buttaffuoco.
By far, the greatest problem with living on the Island is trying to get off it. Mass transit on Long Island is a contradiction in terms, and owning a car is essential to keeping Island fever at bay. And let us say that one day you feel the need to see mountains more majestic than Dix Hills.
Long Island is, after all, surrounded by water, and its western border is pressed against a concrete-and-steel impediment called New York City. That means that in order to leave your 2.5 million neighbors on the Island, you must first drive through a city of 8 million. Whether it is the Belt Parkway to the south or the Grand Central Parkway to the north, nothing moves but the time, and always in the 10-minute increments of radio traffic updates.
During these many hours of unwanted reflection, I have developed an addiction for the calming voice of Neal Busch, who hovers above us all as the traffic reporter in the WCBS helicopter. Every other day he tells us that our life's plans are ruined because a tractor-trailer has "wandered" onto the parkway, like some stray dinosaur. But he informs us so soothingly that we suppress the desire to hunt down that truck driver to exact some good ol' Long Island vengeance. His traffic reports are about as close as I get to therapy.
An astute reader might notice that I have not mentioned the escape routes offered by the ferry systems at Port Jefferson and Orient Point. There is a reason for this: As a Long Island native, I have a hard time with the concept of making reservations for a destination called Connecticut. Know what I'm sayin'?
Other entries in the "worst of Long Island" category flood the mind. There are the deserted minimalls that mar the landscape, and those small shopping plazas that are like atolls for misfit stores: a pool-supply store, a yarn store, a sports-memorabilia store -- and the ubiquitous deli. There is the puzzling question of why so many New York City police officers caught in some heinous scandal are found to be living on Long Island -- with their mothers.
On a more personal note, there is Robert Moses State Park Field No. 2, at noon on a summer Saturday, with a father wearing knee-high black socks and flip-flops, smoking a Marlboro and leading a brood of translucent-skinned children in search of sand space, including one son so embarrassed that -- oh, never mind.
Overall, these are minor annoyances, because the second greatest problem with living on Long Island is trying to return once you have left.
This is particularly true in the summer, when the Uriah Heeps of Manhattan advertising and commerce clog all roads leading to the Hamptons, where they trust that someone will care about how much they made in the last quarter. Nine months of the year they snicker about Amy Fisher, Jessica Hahn and other local luminaries. They spend the remaining three months skulking about Southampton, hoping to spot Kim Basinger in the market. For them, may the westward traffic always flow.

HEADLINE: Saving the Ghosts of the State's Industrial Past

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THE DARK ZONE. It may sound like the title of a spooky movie but it is really nothing that scary. The Dark Zone is simply a nickname given to the dimly lighted storage area at the Museum of Connecticut History, in the State Library building in Hartford.
If most people have never heard of the Museum of Connecticut History, the state's official historical museum, much less its Dark Zone, there is good reason: the General Assembly provides no money for its promotion. 
 Consequently, David J. Corrigan. one of the two museum curators (and one third of the total full-time professional staff) describes the museum as "one of the best kept secrets in the state."
"We have no brochures and no guides," says Mr. Corrigan. "We used to stay open half a day on Saturdays but that was cut out five years ago."
The library building is at 231 Capitol Avenue, across from the State Capitol. On weekdays, particularly when the legislature is in session, metered parking spaces are at a premium in the area and cars parked overtime are at risk of being towed. So the museum attracts relatively few visitors, at least of adult size. The vast majority of the estimated 30,000 visitors a year are schoolchildren who arrive in buses.
The children wander through an ornate Memorial Hall where paintings of all the state's governors are displayed, by a well-known collection of Colt firearms, by uniforms worn by Connecticut soldiers in wars since the Revolution, by some more recent artifacts like a big hand-lettered sign to "Axe the Tax" that was part of a demonstration on the State Capitol lawn against the newly imposed state income tax in 1991. What visitors, big or little, do not see is the Dark Zone, the back room of the museum. But that may be its most fascinating part.
In the gloom of the big storage room are the ghosts, many of them from Connecticut's industrial past. There is old machinery, big and weighty, some pieces so strange looking they nearly defy description. The one attribute they share is that they were once part of an inventive and bustling economy that made Connecticut a powerhouse of the Industrial Revolution and brought fame and prosperity to it in the 19th century and in the first half of this century.
One bizarre contraption looks like a big iron carousel but in actuality was a complicated machine used by Union Metallic Cartridge Company of Bridgeport to make parts of shotgun shells.
Another is an 18-foot lathe of Parmalee and Mix Company of West Haven that was made to reshape rollers for woolen mills in eastern Connecticut. Nearby is another creation, to turn elephant tusks into piano keys at the Pratt, Read Company in Essex.
Most of the companies that used the machinery are memories now and the machines are disappearing rapidly as deserted factory buildings and storage areas continue to be torn down.
Because of that, Mr. Corrigan says, for the past several years he and his fellow curator, Howard L. Miller, and the museum administrator, Dean Nelson, have been buying up what they can.
"We go to antique shows, flea markets, tag sales, anywhere, anytime," he said.
What they buy is then stored in the Dark Zone or at a few other state buildings with vacant space, like Department of Transportation garages and the former Mansfield Training School.
The state has not provided money for the acquisitions, he says. The money comes from a fund set up after an auction held several years ago to get rid of duplicate rare coins from the museum's collection. And big money is not involved.
"Mostly, we're talking a couple of hundred dollars," Mr. Corrigan said. "Some of the time we're competing at auctions on a per-pound price with metal dealers bidding on old machinery so they can sell it for scrap."
Occasionally, one of the three men will come a across a real prize for little money.
The best thus far is a Weed sewing machine Mr. Nelson discovered in a small-town antiques store. The machine, which looks as if it had been made yesterday, was produced in 1867 on Capitol Avenue in Hartford, down the street from the museum. Weed sewing machines, very rare now, once went West in covered wagons.
Today, the three collectors are bidding against time, Mr. Corrigan says. "A lot of the machinery is disappearing," he said. "You won't find it tomorrow. The time to get it is now and we're the only organization collecting statewide and dedicated to tell the story of Connecticut industry."
The ultimate goal, he says, is to use the space of the Dark Zone to create a a permanent display of the machines that made Connecticut famous.
Estimated cost: $250,000. For the past 10 years a proposal to do that has been made to each session of the General Assembly. And in each session it has been rejected.
Mr. Corrigan says the museum will keep collecting, and keep submitting plans.
The old machines might appear to be big and ugly and strange, and they are reminders that factories were once safety nightmares of belts and shafts and flywheels and floors slippery with oil.
But industry made Connecticut famous and Mr. Corrigan thinks it should be celebrated. If the official museum of the state can't do that, who will?

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Corrigan, a curator, among machines in storage at the Museum of Connecticut History in Hartford. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Huge Hills Project Gaining Momentum in Bernards

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
IN construction that began in 1994 and picked up momentum in the last year, 1,158 town houses and detached homes have been or are being built in the Bernards Township portion of the 1,800-acre Hills development atop the Watchung Hills, which spills into neighboring Bedminster.
Now plans are moving ahead in this Somerset County community to develop the remaining 735 residences planned here. They will join the 3,000 units, all but 25 built and occupied, on the Bedminster side, and nudge the state's largest planned community toward its final stage after 16 years. 
 The push is coming from some big developers involved in the project who are trying to take advantage of the state's reviving economy and housing market. Among them are Pulte Homes Corporation of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., the country's largest residential developer; Toll Brothers of Huntingdon Valley Pa., a large regional builder, and K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, New Jersey's largest developer.
In many ways the activity at The Hills, at the intersection of Interstates 78 and 287, reflects the steady increase in housing production in New Jersey in general and in Somerset County in particular. Through July there were 15,454 housing permits issued statewide, up from 12,341 the same time last year; of that total 1,377 were in Somerset County, the fourth highest among the state's 21 counties, according to data from the New Jersey Department of Labor.
If the pace continues the number of permits issued this year should equal or surpass last year's total of 24,000. In either case the number, while higher than the trough of 14,856 permits issued in 1991, is still much lower than the 57,353 issued in the peak year of 1986.
In terms of new construction the reason The Hills development draws attention is the old real estate adage of "location, location, location," said David J. Schoner, vice president of the metropolitan New York region for the new homes division of Coldwell Banker, a large brokerage headquartered in Short Hills.
The area where The Hills sits -- near I-287 and I-78 and corporate complexes like those of AT&T and Hoechst Celanese -- is considered a key development site and Somerset County among the state's fastest growing counties. Its population is expected to rise to 311,300 in 2005 from 260,677 in 1994 and its job base to expand to 190,500 from 154,500, according to state estimates.
Those factors are not lost on builders who have purchased sites at The Hills, which was born of the first lawsuit under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines. Those doctrines require all municipalities to provide the opportunity for housing low- and moderate-income families.
"While a case can be made that The Hills is Levittownish," said Mr. Schoner, "the land plan there has created nice communities." It also has homes of varying sizes and prices in an area that offers good schools and a suburban lifestyle, he said, noting "people always buy community first."
The average sales price for new homes in the county has risen, he added. For detached homes the price is $397,599, up from $383,325 last year; for town houses it is $196,197, up from $179,902.
The original developer, the Hills Development Company, built most of the homes in Bedminster, including 620 Mount Laurel units, but is also building on the Bernards side. In 1993, it started selling parcels there "to accelerate housing production and sales and take the community to another level with the endorsement of other developers," said Thomas H. Dillon, a principal at Gale, Wentworth & Dillon of Bedminster, a residential developer that has managed the project since 1992. He is also president of Hills Development Company.
The Hills Development Company is a partnership of Saudi Arabian investors and SD Partners, led by William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury under President Ronald Reagan. SD bought out the 50 percent of the property owned by Johns-Mansville Property Corporation, which filed the Mount Laurel suit in 1987.
For Bernards, having so large a development within its 24.5 square miles has its pluses and minuses. "I can't say we are better off because of The Hills and obviously most people would have wanted its 1,200 acres in Bernards left as open space," said Peter A. Messina, Township Planner as well as Township Engineer. "But it is one way of solving our Mount Laurel obligation."
The Hills Development Company is paying to have 237 of the Mount Laurel units required as part of the Bernards Township portion of its development built in Phillipsburg. Of the remaining 315 units of its obligation, 225 were built as part of other projects here, 43 are proposed for other projects here and elsewhere and the township has received credits for 47 existing residences.
S TILL, said Mr. Messina, The Hills "is the best we could hope for because it has a mix of housing, is planned out so there are no surprises and is screened from the road so it doesn't hit you in the face."
He said 400 acres would remain undeveloped, adding that sites within that area had been set aside for a 60-acre municipal park and a 12-acre elementary school. The school, to be built by 1999, will help "handle the influx of children from The Hills and other developments," he added.
For developers, The Hills also provides an added benefit -- properly zoned land with public utilities, roads and recreational amenities in place. Among the latter are an 18-hole public golf course and two clubhouses, the second of which opened in June; two pools, tennis and basketball courts and baseball and soccer fields.
Pulte entered the central Jersey market this summer. Gary J. Stefanoni, the company's director of sales and marketing, said the reason was simple: "Our research shows that this market is very active and given the number of corporations and jobs there the housing demand will continue."
He added that buying approved lots at The Hills, which he described "as a high profile community in an A location," enabled his company to "hit the ground running."
In Bernards, the company is building 57 detached homes, with 2,000 to 2,400 square feet of space and priced in the low- to mid-$300,000 range. Since sales opened in May, 16 have been sold. It is also building the last 25 homes on the Bedminister side. They will have 2,500 to 3,000 square feet of space and cost in the high-$300,000 to mid-$400,000 range.
Hovnanian has built and sold all 400 town houses and duplex single family homes in its first two projects at The Hills in Bernards. In May the company started a third, Hamilton Crest, containing 158 town houses with garages, ranging from 1,500 to 2,000 square feet of space and selling for $194,950 to $230,000. Before model homes opened last weekend, 50 units were sold.
Sales are also under way at the third Toll Brothers detached-house project in The Hills, which is now under way. Called Independence Hill, it will have 44 houses ranging in size from 3,600 to 4,100 square feet, some fronting the golf course. Base prices will range from $532,000 to $590,000.Thomas A. Argyis Jr., a Toll Brothers vice president, said the new homes were in response to buyer demand for bigger houses than the 137 offered at the company's first two projects.
Betting that demand will continue, Toll Brothers is under contract to buy an additional 130 acres in Bernards for up to a total of 526 town houses and detached homes. The company is awaiting final site plan approval from the township's planning board, but Mr. Argyis said that as now envisioned the detached homes will range in size from 2,400 to 3,500 square feet, and the town houses, 2,000 to 3,000 square feet.
A ND the Hills Development Company is building Amherst Mews, 123 town houses ranging in size from 2,700 to 3,300 square feet and in price from $371,000 to $449,000. Mr. Dillon said there was one section left that could support the final 209 homes planned at The Hills. He said his company intended to seek approval for the site, but had not decided whether to sell it to other builders or develop it itself.
"We know we are a hot spot," said Mr. Messina, Bernards' planner. "We know what is coming and are gearing up for it."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Combining Adjacent Apartments

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHEN suburban homeowners need more living space, their options are relatively clear -- buy a bigger house and move or add to the existing house and stay. But co-op shareholders and condominium owners in similar circumstances face a more limited array of alternatives. They can buy a bigger apartment and move, or . . . what?
"They can buy the apartment next door and expand," said Dan Gerstein, vice president of DG Neary Realty Ltd. in Manhattan. 
 While combining adjacent apartments is hardly a new idea, real estate experts say that the number of such conversions has significantly increased over the last few years. "It's becoming more and more common," said Elliott Meisel, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "People are finding that it's economically more beneficial for them to combine two small apartments into one than to go out and buy a larger apartment."
It is also advantageous for the co-op, Mr. Meisel said, because a building with larger apartments commanding higher prices is more attractive to lenders and makes existing apartments more salable.
Indeed, Mr. Meisel said, the high prices now being demanded for two- and three-bedroom apartments are the driving force behind the rising number of combined apartments. In fact, he said, when two apartments are combined "the whole is greater than the sum of the parts."
Matthew Bank and Peter Hemmel experienced "sticker shock" when they started looking for a two-bedroom apartment with a formal dining room in lower Manhattan. "The last apartment we saw was going for $500,000," Mr. Bank said. "It was frustrating, to say the least."
The men then found three adjacent apartments -- two studios and a one-bedroom -- for sale in a co-op at 300 West 23d Street, at Eighth Avenue, in the Chelsea neighborhood. "The total cost for the three of them ended up being about $320,000," Mr. Bank said, adding that because of the layout of the apartments little renovation will be needed to connect them.
And since the per-square-foot maintenance charges for studios in the building are lower than those for larger units, the total charges on the new combined 1,700-square-foot apartment will be less than the charges on existing two-bedroom apartments of a similar size in the building.
Moreover, Mr. Bank said, four other unit-owners in the building who are combining apartments have agreed to share the cost of hiring an attorney and an architect to obtain the necessary permits and an amended certificate of occupancy.
"That's going to result in major savings for all of us," Mr. Bank said.
In fact, experts say, the "soft costs" of combining two apartments can represent a major portion of the total cost of the project.
"There's almost always an enormous amount of paperwork involved," said Marcel de Winter, a registered architect in Manhattan. Generally, he said, unit owners who want to combine apartments must submit plans for the project to the building's board of directors for examination by its engineer. In most cases, he said, boards require the applicant to pay the engineer's fee for reviewing the plans.
Once the board has given its approval, Mr. de Winter said, the architect or engineer must then submit the plans to the Department of Buildings and obtain a construction permit. The cost of the permit, he said, is typically dependent upon the estimated cost of the construction.
Once a permit has been obtained, it is almost always necessary for the owner or shareholder to apply and pay for an amended certificate of occupancy for the entire building.
"That's where the biggest bottleneck can occur," Mr. de Winter said. He explained that, even under the best of circumstances, amending a certificate of occupancy can mean navigating a morass of red tape. Overall, he said, it can take several months, and several thousand dollars, to prepare and process the necessary paperwork and to obtain the various approvals, inspections, reviews and permits that are typically required.
But it is not always necessary to officially combine two adjacent apartments in order to use them as one residence.
"From a legal perspective, there are two ways of combining apartments," said Mr. Meisel, the Manhattan lawyer. The first and typically less expensive way, he said, is to own the units as two separate units and provide access from one to the other through a fire-rated door in a common wall.
The advantages of that approach, he said, are that it is usually not necessary to obtain a certificate of occupancy and the units can be sold separately if the extra space is no longer needed. Moreover, the renovation costs are lower because the only construction required is the installation of the doorway between the apartments.
There is one distinct disadvantage to that approach, however.
"What you often end up with are two nice apartments separated by a big, ugly fire door," Mr. Meisel said.
On the other hand, he said, the more expensive and time-consuming option of creating a single entity from two units enables the owner to totally or partially remove the wall separating the two apartments -- if structurally feasible, of course. That option is not available when the units remain independent legal entities.
"You can end up with a huge living room or family room, more light and a feeling of more spaciousness," he said, noting that such qualities could add significant value to an apartment.
Moreover, if the apartments are at the end of a hallway it is often possible to negotiate with the co-op's board of directors for permission to acquire a portion of the hallway for personal use in return for paying additional maintenance charges on the space. Boards will often consent to such a request, Mr. Meisel said, as long as the work can be accomplished in an esthetically pleasing manner and doesn't interfere with the rights of other shareholders or owners.
And what might all of this cost?
"You could easily be looking at $50,000 in renovation costs," said Mr. Gerstein of DG Neary Realty, the company that sold Mr. Bank and Mr. Hemmel their three-unit combination on West 23d Street. "In New York City, renovation costs are never cheap."
Then again, neither are $500,000 two-bedroom apartments with formal dining rooms in lower Manhattan.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Deidre O'Byrne And Paul Staller

 BODY:
Deidre Gerarda O'Byrne, a daughter of Margaret O'Byrne of West Long Branch, N.J., and the late John P. O'Byrne, was married on Friday to Paul George Staller, the son of Dorothy and George Staller of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Charles J. O'Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bride's brother, performed the ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in New York.
Ms. O'Byrne, 31, who is keeping her name, graduated cum laude from Princeton University. She received a master's degree in Russian and East European studies from Yale University and a law degree from Columbia University. Next month she is to begin as an associate at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. 
 Her father was the principal of Public School 53 in Bay Terrace, Staten Island. Her mother retired as the school psychologist at the Bradley Beach (N.J.) School.
Mr. Staller, 31, is a project manager in New York for Berlitz Translation Services. He graduated from Cornell University, where he also received a master's degree in public affairs. His father is a professor of economics at Cornell.
