HEADLINE: For Libraries, a Time of Rebirth

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
DON'T bother to shush. This ample room, luminous in morning light that streams through a glass curtain wall, will soon be the multicultural center of the Queens Borough Public Library's Flushing branch. But for now, it is a construction site. And no librarian is going to stop the whine of a 14-inch saw buzzing through metal studs.
Nor is the din confined to Main Street, Queens. Across New York City, more than $300 million is being spent on the construction and renovation of public and private libraries. 
 "It's a phenomenal moment of rebirth," said Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library, which embraces Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. "I imagine this is what it felt like when Andrew Carnegie was building libraries all over New York."
No longer doing constant battle for subsistence-level funding, library executives say they now count on steady support from elected officials. They are also benefiting from the improved economy.
"There's a high point in funding in part because Wall Street is doing so well," said Martin Gomez, executive director of the Brooklyn Public Library.
Libraries are being updated for an era in which data ports are as vital as dust jackets. But the work goes beyond electrical risers and telecommunication lines. It involves reclaiming architectural features that have been lost for generations, like the two-story atrium in the Brooklyn Public Library's Flatbush branch on Linden Boulevard, which was carved up 30 years ago to accommodate air-conditioning equipment.
It also involves the creation of generous new spaces, like the glass-enclosed stairway cascading through the Flushing branch or the cavernous rotunda at the heart of the William D. Walsh Family Library on Fordham University's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.
The goal is more than esthetic satisfaction and spiritual uplift. A wide-open space tends to demystify the building, allowing users to orient themselves quickly and figure out where to go to get what. Another advantage is security. Such spaces make it easier for the staff to keep watch on visitors and collections.
Libraries are also being redesigned to acknowledge that they are, in a sense, competing with the likes of Barnes & Noble, which has made homey seating nooks and espresso machines an increasingly integral adjunct to reading.
Butler Library at Columbia University is to get a student lounge as part of the $20 million second phase of its 10-year renovation. The lounge will be in Room 233, originally designed as the business school library but used in recent years as a cataloguing center. On one side will be an E-mail "bar," where students can pick up electronic messages, and on the other will be the entrance to a coffee bar. Between them will be cafe tables and banquettes for group studying.
"Even though the students all have access to the network from their rooms, they want to be in the libraries," said Kristine N. Kavanaugh, Columbia's assistant vice president for libraries and academic computing. She was not alone in noting the libraries' enduring social function in the technological age.
"Cyberspace is pretty arid," said Brian J. Byrne, vice president for administration at Fordham, which is to dedicate the $54 million Walsh Library next month. "Learning is communal. You have to have a sense of place."
Creating a sense of place is one goal of the $25 million renovation planned at the New York Public Library of the Performing Arts, which has been hiding in plain sight at Lincoln Center for three decades. Unknown to most of the millions who pass below, the deep roof slab of the Vivian Beaumont Theater actually contains the library's stacks, reading and viewing rooms and offices. Broad new windows are to be opened on three sides of the travertine-clad slab as part of the library's first major makeover since its 1965 debut.
"The building is bursting at the seams," said Robert Marx, the library's executive director. "This building was never meant to accommodate 400,000 people a year." Sometimes, he said, there are lines of researchers waiting to get into the theater division.
There are lines, too, outside branches of the Brooklyn system, Mr. Gomez said: youngsters arriving after school to use the computers inside, sometimes waiting 90 minutes just for the chance to log on.
"You don't want to turn people away," he said. "But that's a strong statement that we're doing something right and that buildings created at the turn of the century have not only met their demand but are being challenged to meet greater demands."
Mr. LeClerc said 750,000 people used the new Science, Industry and Business Library at Madison Avenue and 34th Street in its first year. "New Yorkers want libraries that are well stocked, comfortable and technologically sophisticated," he said.
And elected officials, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Speaker Peter F. Vallone, Borough Presidents and City Council members have taken notice. The city's Department of Design and Construction said that it spent $21.1 million on 73 library projects in the last fiscal year, almost triple what was spent in the 1990 fiscal year.
At the beginning of the decade, budget cutting had pared service at some branch libraries to two days a week. But in 1992, Mayor David N. Dinkins restored five-day-a-week service throughout the system, raising it to six days in 1993.
From all points, the message seems clear. "Books are here to stay and people are here to stay," said Marshall Rose, chairman of the New York Public Library and managing partner of the Georgetown Group, a real estate development and financial services company. "We have an obligation to give people the sense of humanity that comes from working in grand spaces."
Perhaps the grandest space of any is Room 315, the Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library's central building on Fifth Avenue, which is now known as the Center for the Humanities.
The room was closed two months ago for a $15 million renovation that is meant to enhance its utility and recover its Beaux-Arts splendor. The project has been underwritten by Frederick P. Rose, chairman of Rose Associates, and his wife Sandra Priest Rose, a member of the library's board.
A scaffold now reaches to the heavens -- or at least the clouds that roll across vast ceiling murals by James Wall Finn, 51 feet overhead. The chandeliers are swaddled in bubble-wrap cocoons and the ranks of jade-colored lampshades on the desktops resemble a ghostly millinery display.
The architects are Davis Brody Bond, a Manhattan firm that is responsible for the overall $70 million renovation of the central building in a series of projects running through 2001. With Garrison McNeil, the firm is also designing the new Langston Hughes branch of the Queens Borough Public Library in Corona.
Work on the Main Reading Room is starting quite literally at the top, as the murals have for a long time been badly marred by broad, chalky patches where water has ruined the surface. On other fronts, seating capacity will be increased, power and data ports will be added and the mechanical system that delivers books from the stacks will be rehabilitated.
With 23,000 square feet of space, Room 315 is more than twice the size of the entire Gerritsen Beach branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, a $4 million structure that opened four months ago in an almost pastoral seaside setting across from Marine Park and to the east of Sheepshead Bay.
But the Gerritsen Beach branch, designed by Ciardullo Associates, has an undeniable dignity of its own. There is a clock tower outside and an airy, gabled ceiling within, supported on an intricate network of exposed timber trusses. A tall picture window offers a panorama of small boats along the Shell Bank Canal.
"It captures the public nature of libraries at their best: the proportions, the soaring heights, the natural light," said Elisabeth Martin, director of planning, design and facilities for the Brooklyn system.
IN its design, its array of resources and its neighborhood role, Ms. Martin said the new building was a worthy successor to the Carnegie libraries -- 67 branch buildings constructed citywide from 1901 to 1929 under a gift from Andrew Carnegie.
Some of the greatest New York architects are represented in the Carnegie portfolio, including McKim, Mead & White and Carrere & Hastings, and 54 of the buildings survive as functioning libraries. Though revered now, however, many have been altered unsympathetically.
For example, the Flatbush branch at 22 Linden Boulevard once had a vaulted central atrium, almost 30 feet high, ringed with Ionic columns and filled with light from semicircular clerestory windows.
Today, as the result of a heedless 1966 renovation, the ceiling is only 15 feet high. What was open space is now a mechanical attic filled with rumbling equipment. But a close look in the gloomy attic reveals six broad arches in the brickwork, vestiges of the great semicircular windows.
When Ms. Martin arrived at the Brooklyn system from the Department of Design and Construction, where she had been program director for the libraries unit, the plan for Flatbush was simply to replace the air-conditioning equipment in place.
But she could not pass up the opportunity to restore the atrium. "Anyone with architectural training who left this building the way it is could not have much warm blood circulating in their body," Ms. Martin said.
Under current renovation plans, designed by Margaret Helfand, the equipment will be moved and the intermediate floor level taken out. A vaulted ceiling will be constructed and the clerestory windows and open balconies will be restored.
Another Carnegie library that fared poorly was the Flushing branch, which was built in 1906 and torn down in 1957. It was replaced with a structure that eventually proved inadequate for the heavy demand.
In approaching the design for a new $20.75 million library, the largest branch in the Queens system, Polshek and Partners deliberately turned away from the "temple of knowledge" paradigm, in which patrons ascend into a sanctified realm.
"A lot of people are intimidated by those kinds of buildings, especially new immigrants," said Todd H. Schliemann, associate partner in the Polshek firm. "We said: 'This is not a bank. This a public building.' We had to demystify the idea of books.
"In Queens," he said, "you have a huge immigrant population that relies on the library system in different ways: first, as a place to learn the language; second, as a community center and third, for research and entertainment."
No Corinthian columns here. Instead, a diaphanous glass wall flows coolly along Main Street, bending gently as it approaches the oblique intersection with Kissena Boulevard. The curving curtain wall actually extends a few feet beyond the masonry shell of the building, which heightens the sense of transparency. To strengthen the visual link between library patrons and Main Street pedestrians, the main stairway and reading areas have all been placed just behind the glass curtain wall.
A pointed exception to this openness is the adult learning center. It has been located discreetly in the basement, out of deference to the self-consciousness of those coming to learn English. The new branch is to open next spring.
VISIBILITY is key in the renovation of the performing arts library, also designed by the Polshek firm. Work is to begin next July and run through the summer of 2000. "We do want people to know we're up here," Mr. Marx said, as he made his way through the sprawling but windowless warren contained in a rectilinear, travertine-frosted doughnut wrapped around the Beaumont stage house.
The music collection is directly over the auditorium. And during the run of "Anything Goes," librarians discovered that the structure was not as soundproof as they would have liked. "Boulez may be in here looking at a Mahler manuscript, but what he's hearing is Cole Porter," Mr. Marx said.
Because there are separate reading rooms for each collection -- theater, music and dance -- lines can form in one room while seats are empty in another. Under the renovation, a consolidated reading room will be created in the western end of the slab, with a new window overlooking Amsterdam Avenue. (The east facade, facing the reflecting pool, will not be altered.)
New reading rooms are also a feature of the Butler renovation at Columbia University, a 10-year project that began in July 1995. The first phase, costing $20 million, involved a mechanical and electrical infrastructure to cope with demands not possibly foreseen when Butler opened, as South Hall, in 1934.
"We need to be connected," said Charles J. Maikish, the former director of the World Trade Center, who is now Columbia's vice president for facilities management. "That seems to be a buzzword. But it's a reality for us. We had to create new risers."
A riser is no more than a vertical pipe. But imagine trying to open a 4-by-10-foot riser shaft -- for air, chilled and hot water, electric power, data lines and fuel oil -- through an existing building with concrete floors that has to keep operating while the work is being performed. As Sean Joyner, the project manager, put it, "We've simply done a heart, lung and brain transplant -- "
" -- while the patient was living and breathing," Mr. Maikish added.
With that work largely completed, Columbia is now turning to the far more visible second phase, which is to begin in January, with completion in two and a half years. A network of reading rooms and a media center, with audio, video and CD-ROM equipment, will be built around the stack core, four levels of which will also be renovated. The second floor is to be the heart of a new undergraduate library within Butler.
The architects of the Butler project are Shepley Bulfinch Richardson & Abbott of Boston, a firm that has long specialized in library design. With the Manhattan firm of Buttrick White & Burtis, they are currently working on the design of a 105,000-square-foot expansion of the LaGuardia Library at Brooklyn College. They are also the architects of Fordham's new library.
Named for a Fordham alumnus and venture capitalist whose $10.5 million gift met one-fifth of the project cost, the Walsh library has 240,000 square feet over five floors. It anchors both the Fordham Plaza transportation and commercial hub at Fordham Road and Third Avenue, and the southwest corner of the 85-acre campus.
THE facade, of randomly coursed fieldstone, rises in a series of complex setbacks to a neo-Gothic tower, complete with buttresses and finials. "That building looks like it's always been there," said Fordham's president, the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, repeating the compliment of a visitor from another Jesuit institution.
"You go to any campus and there are a beloved set of buildings and a hated set of buildings," said Alexander Howe of the Shepley firm, explaining the decision to drape a 21st-century library in a Gothic veil. "We're looking for flexibility but we're also looking for a building that's expressed in concert with the 'beloveds' on the campus."
The Walsh library is a hive of electronic information, with 331 computers, 369 desks and carrels wired for laptops and a regional educational technology center serving high schools in the Bronx and lower Westchester County. But it is also a repository of 900,000 volumes, including books printed in the 1400's, known as incunabula.
"I think -- or I want to think, it's too soon to tell -- that this library will add dimension to the life of the mind at Fordham," Father O'Hare said. The building is to be dedicated on Oct. 17 by John Cardinal O'Connor but it has been in service since May.
Walsh Library is already being used by about 2,000 people a day, roughly double the number that used its predecessor, Duane Library, said James P. McCabe, the university librarian.
One satisfied patron is Leo Hoar, associate professor of Spanish, who was found at a cherrywood carrel in the reference section. "I even have a Vatican Library card and these are better surroundings," he said.
Of course, any brand-new building has its glitches. There was the day that Father O'Hare arrived at the electronic turnstiles with his updated identification card in hand. He swiped it through -- and was denied entry by the machine. "All the bells went off," he recounted cheerily.
Earlier this month, this time in the company of a reporter, Father O'Hare gamely gave it another try with a new card.
He got in.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY;
For Clammers, a Chance to Thrive, Not Just Survive

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
As a boy, growing up in the North Wildwood community of Angelsea, Bob Kelleher used to pull surf clams out of the shallow water with his feet.
"You could just walk a few yards off shore barefoot and sort of dig them out," remembered Mr. Kelleher, 56. "If you wanted a bushel, you could come out with a clam rake and pull out a lot more. It wasn't as much fun as being in a boat out on the ocean. That's why I became a clammer. I just wanted to be out on the ocean." 
 Mr. Kelleher never imagined that surf clams and their larger cousins, ocean quahogs (pronounced KOH-hogs), would become the New Jersey fishing industry's largest cash crop, netting $27 million last year. These clams are not eaten raw, like the smaller littleneck and cherrystone clams. Surf clams, whose fist-sized shells are visible along Jersey beaches, and quahogs, which can be 10 inches wide, are sold exclusively to a half-dozen regional seafood processing companies that use them in canned chowders and fried clam strips.
In the nearly half century that Mr. Kelleher has been clamming, his vocation has changed from a dangerous, unregulated, low-paying job to a lucrative industry that has permitted him to pay for his children's education and foresee a comfortable retirement.
Recalling the risks of the early years, he said: "Every year a half-dozen men would not come back. I tried to keep my son off the boats. He wouldn't listen."
Now, in partnership with his son, Jim, Mr. Kelleher owns four boats, three docked in Atlantic City, one in Point Pleasant.
" "A fellow can get into it now and find a future for himself," Mr. Kelleher said.
That such a future exists is a result of a partnership between the clamming industry and the National Marine Fisheries Service, a branch of the Federal government that regulates commercial fishing within 200 miles of coastal waters.
This partnership is praised by some as a rational compromise between those who make their living from natural resources and those charged with protecting such resources from exploitation. It has also been derided by the environmental group Greenpeace as an environmentally and economically destructive strategy whose consequences may prove devastating in the next century.
Known as the individual transferable quota system, the compromise is a result of a struggle between clammers and environmentalists that began in 1977, when a red tide killed most of the surf clams and quahogs off the New Jersey coast. Responding to environmentalists' fears about the clam population's recovery, the National Marine Fisheries Service limited clam boats to one six-hour day of fishing a week, later reduced to only six hours every two weeks. Clammers who violated this regulation were fined.
"That's when it became really dangerous," Mr. Kelleher recalled. "You were given your day to go out, and if there was bad weather, you could make it up the next day, but not the day after that. So you had a lot of boats going out in bad weather. And, with only six hours to fish, you had boats loading themselves up so much that they went down if the weather got rough."
Then, in 1990, Lee Anderson, an economist at the University of Delaware and former chairman of the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council, one of nine regional councils that supervise fisheries for the National Marine Fisheries Service, devised the quota system.
The Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council set a maximum quota for the number of clams the industry could catch (measured in bushels); it allocated that quota among the 140 vessels in the fleet, including 40 or so that sail from Atlantic City and Point Pleasant.
Each boat's individual quota was a share of the total yearly harvest, which the Council has reduced some 30 percent over the last five years, to 2.6 million bushels of surf clams and 4.5 million bushels of quahogs. Like shares of stock in a corporation, those quotas could be transferred -- that is, sold, leased or even used as collateral -- by the boat owners.
The advent of the quota system caused a shakeout among the clammers. "The little guys who were starving were able to get out, sell their allocations, and use the money to get into another business, or just retire," said Thomas Rossi, a Wildwood lawyer specializing in fishery regulation. "The bigger guys bought those allocations, used them to catch more clams, and put the money back into their businesses. From the standpoint of anyone in the industry, it was a win-win situation."
Jim Kelleher, who owns four quotas and leases others, estimates that of $12 to $13 he can get for a bushel of clams, $7 goes to the holder of the quota. He said the new system has caused the industry to shrink from more than 100 clammers to perhaps a dozen.
Right now the largest single owner of clamming quotas, known as I.T.Q.'s, is not an individual, but the international accounting firm of KFMG Peat Marwick, a situation that Greenpeace has criticized.
"The result of I.T.Q.'s has been to take the fishing business out of the hands of the fishermen and put it into the hands of bankers," said Niaz Dorry, a Massachusetts-based Greenpeace staff member. "They've made it more expensive for smaller fishermen to stay in business, and there has been no proof that the I.T.Q.'s are doing what they were supposed to do -- and that's protect the clams from being fished to death."
So far, quotas have been used to regulate wreck fishing in Florida and halibut in Alaska. The National Academy of Sciences expects to release a study of the quotas' economic and environmental impacts in October 1998.
Bob Kelleher's views have not been solicited by the Academy. "I prefer when government keeps to itself," he said. "They sit there in their offices and come up with stuff, but, come the morning, it's people like us that still have to catch the clams. And that part of the job hasn't gotten any easier."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Ramsey unloading clams from the Melissa J. in Atlantic City. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q[A]
There's Something Old and Something New as Trades Museum Reopens

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:

WHAT -- A glass and steel conservatory.
 
WHERE -- Built as an addition to the turn-of-the century building that now houses the Museum of Early Trades and Crafts in the James Library Building on Main Street in Madison. 

WHY BUILT -- The two-story conservatory houses stairways, elevators and handicapped-accessible entries to help people get into and around the museum. The design was chosen because glass conservatories were common in buildings of the Richardsonian Romanesque Revival style like the library, which was built in 1900. The conservatory was designed to look as if it was built at the same time as the rest of the building, which is on the State and National Registers of Historic Places, said Elaine Clements Zopes, museum director.
 
WHO BUILT IT -- The manufacturer, Amdega of Durham, England, which has been in business building conservatories since 1874, constructed the addition and shipped it in eight pieces to Madison where it was put together.
 
ABOUT THE LIBRARY BUILDING -- The conservatory is attached to what was the Madison public library. The library outgrew its space and was relocated in the mid-1960's and the museum moved in 1970.
The museum has four major rooms that have triple stained glass windows, eight large brass and glass chandeliers, dark oak paneling, vaulted ceilings and an elaborate design of stencils on the 20-foot high brick walls. The building was designed to create "a quiet effect rather than gaudy," according to the library's founder, D. Willis James. The Museum of Early Trades and Crafts now leases the building from the borough. The museum is the last of the buildings in Madison from that era that is open to the public.
 
RENOVATION -- The conservatory was built as part of a $1 million restoration of the building that was just completed.
 
WHAT IS AT THE MUSEUM -- The museum started with the collection of Edgar and Agnes Land, Madison residents who had put together 8,500 items used in 40 trades and crafts practiced in pre-industrial New Jersey, including those used in making cabinets and barrels, in metal working, in making cidar, and in keeping a home. It also has a copper still once used for producing "Jersey Lightning."
"School buses were showing up at the Land's home to see the collection," Ms. Zopes said. "The couple had a dream of opening it to the public so it was moved to the old library building."
The exhibits are designed to show life in New Jersey in the 18th and 19th centuries.
A "Craft and Community" exhibit focuses on four crafts people who lived and worked in Madison, explaining how their businesses were interrelated.
Another new exhibit explores the life of a 19th-century New Jersey farm family, making clear that the children as well as the parents had responsibilities important to the family's economic survival.
"It shows how the different members of the family contributed to the economy of the family and of the community including the children. People don't think of children contributing to the economy of the family, but it was a necessity then," Ms. Zopes said.
Elsewhere, museum visitors can try their hand at urban planning, using floor-size maps and miniature buildings to recreate the town of Madison. Would-be architects can test their design skills using scaled models, architectural drawings and a supply of building blocks. KAREN DeMASTERS
 
Opening Day, and Beyond
 The Museum of Early Trades and Crafts, closed since May 1996, will reopen Saturday, with new space, a new gift and a new logo, above.
A ribbon-cutting ceremony will be at 1 P.M. at the James Library Building, Main Street and Green Village Road in Madison. The day's activities, which coincide with Madison's annual Bottle Hill Day festival, run from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; they include musicians, a choral group, actors in period costumes and games for children.
 The museum's regular hours will be Tuesdays through Saturdays 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Sundays noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $3.50 for adults, $2 for children 6 to 17, students, and senior citizens; children 5 and under are admitted without charge.
To get a calendar of museum events, call (973) 377-2982.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elaine Clements Zopes outside the Early Trades and Crafts Museum in Madison, which reopens Saturday with a new glass and steel conservatory. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ECONOMY;
For the Economy: Better Times, But Not the Good Old Days

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New Jersey's economy has arrived at an uncertain, anxiety-producing place in the late 1990's: It's called prosperity.
The state has now recovered -- far in advance of New York and Connecticut -- almost all the jobs that were lost in the three-year-long recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. 
 Its clout and image as a center of telecommunications research, one of the hottest areas of the national economy, has grown. The statewide unemployment rate has reached a seven-year-low.
But the problem for residents, and for Governor Whitman, who has struggled mightily to convince voters that things are in fact doing quite well in the state, is that this 1990's-style economic growth is not at all familiar.
The state still rumbles with the aftershocks of corporate restructuring and downsizing. The dizzy pace of change in telecommunications, a bedrock industry, makes the future harder to predict.
And what is perhaps most disturbing to the equilibrium of a place where the culture and identity -- not to mention a majority of the voters -- are so firmly middle class, is that many of the economic gains are going to people in the economic strata above and below the mid-range.
"In the 90's, the high-end occupations in New Jersey have done very well and the low-end have done O.K.," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic research firm based in Westchester, Pa. "In the middle tier are the ones who have gotten hurt."
Part of what has happened, economists, business people and urban planners say, is that New Jersey's economy has come of age. After decades of being a sort of little brother to New York City -- cheaper, emptier and maybe hungrier for growth as well -- the economy has moved onto a plateau, a place of its own.
The driving force of that maturity was the real-estate boom of the 1980's. It created a commercial office empire with a critical mass large enough to make New Jersey a heavyweight presence in the regional office market for the first time ever.
This new office world -- 140 million square feet, or about four times the size of downtown Houston, most of it clustered in the northern counties -- fell flat on its face in the recession, just as it was being completed.
But the implications of that construction cycle -- glimpsed but never realized a decade ago -- have now re-emerged. Like a set of clothes that the state had to grow into, this huge, if geographically diffuse city is now out there, and, for the first time, mostly occupied.
"The buildup set into concrete terms the New Jersey economy of the 21st century," said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
The second great force that is making New Jersey grow up is that it is no longer the bargain it once was as a place of business, as compared to New York.
The real-estate build-up contributed there, eating up much of the vacant land in the state, especially in places like Morris, Middlesex and Somerset counties.
Another reason is that New Jersey's economy, though it was certainly hurt in the recession, did not fall as hard or as deep as the rest of the New York region because its mix of businesses was more diverse and thus less dependent on any one shrinking industry. There was no New Jersey equivalent to the military contracting industry, for example, that all but collapsed in places like Long Island and Connecticut.
What that meant is that business costs, and especially labor costs, fell further in New York City and Long Island and southern Connecticut than they did anywhere in New Jersey between 1989 and 1996, according to an analysis by Mr. Zandi's firm.
"It's not a slam-dunk for New Jersey anymore," as Mr. Zandi put it.
Business people and economists say that Mrs. Whitman does deserve credit for helping make the state friendlier to businesses and more responsive to companies in times of trouble as well.
Many of those business experts also stress that the narrowed cost gap with New York is not the Governor's fault either -- indeed, quite the opposite, the cost gap has narrowed because of the state's strengths, not its weaknesses.
But the fact remains that New Jersey's reputation and self-image, along with its economy, have been altered and that the world going forward will have to take those changes into account.
An economy that once prided itself on being a place of heavy industry has seen much of that industry move away.
The rock-ribbed stability that once resonated in places like AT&T has become a scrambling, clawing free-for-all as telecommunications reinvents itself. The corporations that once needed thousands of middle managers no longer do.
There is, in other words, no going back, only forward. Better times may yet return for all the state's residents, but the good old days will not.

HEADLINE: A Bookseller Becomes a Legend

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
Canio Pavone, the founder of one of Sag Harbor's true institutions, Canio's Books, was reminiscing about how he came to learn Japanese, having already mastered his grandfather'ss native Italian at home, and French and Spanish in college, when the pounding on his store's door began.
"Please let me in," pleaded Arnold Gorlick, a tanned, silver-haired man in Bermuda shorts, his nose pressed against the store's glassdoor. "I know you don't open for 10 minutes, but I must find a book." Mr. Pavone, sensing the customer's desperation, asked his guest'sforbearance to attend to a literary emergency? Mr. Pavone, known as Canio to most people in Sag Harbor, unlocked the door and asked how he could help. 
 "Do you have Wislawa Szymborska's 'View With a Grain of Sand,' in paperback?" the stranger asked.
Mr. Pavone pointed to a table stacked high with books of poetry by obscure and famous authors, among them numerous copies of the work by Wislawa Szymborska, the Polish poet who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1996. "No problem," Mr. Pavone replied, permitting himself a tiny smile.
"I knew you would have it!" exclaimed a visibly relieved Mr. Gorlick, a New Haven, Conn., resident and art cinema owner. "Bookhampton didn't have it, and Encore Books had never even heard of her," he said, snapping up two copies of the verses, which he proudly gave to two friends who had trailed him into the store, an Italian guest who began chatting with Canio in Italian, and Meredith Nadler, a Sag Harbor resident who had introduced Mr. Gorlick to Canio's several years ago.
Though the hand-painted sign on the door announces that Canio's is open between 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. every day, Mr. Pavone'ss hours are usually flexible enough to accommodate such literary crises. Alas, he says, they are becoming all too common given the endangered status of independent stores like his on Long Island and in New York City, indeed throughout the United States.
Canio's does not sell coffee and is not a hangout for the chic, young, single set. Crowded from floor to ceiling with new and old books and what a sign proclaims as collectibles, Canio's is a real bookstore.
"I've survived because I've kept overhead low," Mr. Pavone said, lamenting that soaring rents have forced so many small independent booksellers to close and now threaten even the chain stores in the malls and other high-rent locations.
Canio's reflects its owner's curiosity about everything from Asian art to flamenco dancing (which he taught for several years) as well as his passion for books. Mr. Pavone, 62, opened this store at the far end of Main Street with his own collection of overflow books in 1981 when most houses in the rundown village could be bought for less than $50,000. But he didn't abandon his house in Babylon and his teaching job in Harborfields High School in Greenlawn until 1990, after his threechildren were grown. Rather than move to New York City, he bought a house in the area. The rent then was $200.
Though located out of the way, on Upper Main Street, far from the touristy center of town, the store has grown in popularity among the writers and readers who live in Sag Harbor. In 1981, Canio's became one of the first bookstores to offer readings by local writers. And in 1983, Mr. Pavone started what became a Labor Day tradition, , a marathon reading of "Moby Dick," the Melville classic that was partly set in Sag Harbor. But Canio ended the marathon a decade later. "It was getting too big for the shop," he said, "and people were coming to hear the 'stars' read rather than to listen to the words of 'Moby Dick.' It was losing its original spirit."
Mr. Pavone, however, has hardly been idle. In early 1990 he started his own small press dedicated to publishing Long Island poets and writers. In 1991, Canio Editions published 2,000 copies of the first of its slender paperbacks, "Powder and Echo," poems by Dan Giancola about the Revolutionary War on Long Island. The book is still selling, he said.
Since then, Canio Editions has published 16 more books, "little works of love," Mr. Pavone calls them. Most break even but some, like "Simply Black," poems by Beverley Wiggins Wells, a local black feminist poet with a national following, have made a healthy profit.
In 1995, Mr. Pavone found that he was running out of book space again. Rather than sell off some of his volumes at a steep discount or stop ordering new books, he opened another store on the pier near the village'ss Bay Street Theater.
The other Canio's, which is run by Norha Barros, a Colombian-born artist whom Mr. Pavone met and married in 1960 while teaching Spanish in Medellin, specializes in the arts, especially in theater. "Of course, opening a second small shop in the same small town didn't really make economic sense," he acknowledged. Maximizing profit, however, is hardly the point. What excites him, he says, is "community," specifically the community of lovers of the word for whom his store remains a hub.
On Saturday evening over the Labor Day weekend, more than 25 people crammed the tiny store to hear Peter Trachtenberg read from his moving new book, "7 Tattoos." The audience ranged from well-known local writers like Frederic Tuten to a postal worker in Bridgehampton, a self-confessed book addict.
Eager to prolong the experience, they peppered Mr. Trachtenberg with questions about his work. Their enthusiasm, Mr. Pavone said, was a reminder of why Sag Harbor has kept its integrity. "Nothing stays the same," he said, turning out the store's lights, "but if we're lucky, despite the East End's sudden wealth, we can preserve the village's spirit, which is, after all, what brought us here in the first place."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
So What Will He Do After November?

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE

 BODY:
TOM WILSON does not get out much these days. While his boss, Governor Whitman, crisscrosses the state in search of votes, he remains holed up in an office suite here, running meetings, taking calls and keeping tabs on the opposition.
Because even though Mr. Wilson is the Governor's campaign manager, she does not want him glued to her elbow, whispering advice in her ear. Instead, his job is to hang around campaign headquarters seven days a week and make sure everything -- from ordering office supplies to rebutting criticism from Mrs. Whitman's Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey -- goes off without a hitch. 
 "It's not my job to make a candidate, especially in this case," Mr. Wilson said on Tuesday, sitting in his office while phones trilled constantly outside the door. "It's a well-known truth that if anyone ever tries to get this Governor to say something she doesn't believe in, they fail miserably. I learned that early."
That and everything else about the job, it seems. At the tender age of 30, Mr. Wilson is running a closely watched, unexpectedly competitive campaign for one of the nation's best-known governors. Although he has never managed a statewide campaign before, much less one attracting national attention, he has been mapping strategies for politicians since 1987, when he was 20. One basic tenet applies to every race, no matter who the candidate, Mr. Wilson said.
"Elections are about winning 50 percent plus one more point," he said. "It doesn't matter whether it's a campaign for President or for local council. The techniques and the planning process, it's all the same."
Much of the job comes down to common sense. Never schedule big campaign events on Fridays, because, as Mr. Wilson said, "nobody reads the Saturday papers." Resist the urge to root through the trash outside the opponent's campaign headquarters. If your candidate's allergies are giving her laryngitis, as was the case with Mrs. Whitman last week, lighten her schedule.
"I have to be mindful that she's only a human being," Mr. Wilson said. "She needs time to eat, to sleep, to rest. She can't start every day at 7 A.M. and end at 8 P.M. and still be O.K."
To make sure Mrs. Whitman and her image remain healthy between now and Election Day, Mr. Wilson has hired a staff of 20 schedulers, media-relations people, researchers and others who keep track of finances, all of whom meet three mornings a week to discuss their roles in the Governor's campaign schedule for the next 10 days. Their office is a cross between an airport control tower and a fraternity house, with maps hung everywhere, computer screens glowing and pizza boxes on the floor. A six-month-old piece of pizza has been taped to one door, and a picture of Mr. McGreevey from his high school yearbook, unearthed by mischievous Whitman operatives, has been posted prominently.
"It's important to have fun," said Mr. Wilson, who seemed especially proud of the fossilized pizza slice.
Although Mrs. Whitman rarely visits her campaign headquarters, every Thursday or Friday she meets with Mr. Wilson and at least three other strategists: Michael E. Murphy, the Governor's chief political consultant; Cliff Pintak, Mr. Murphy's partner; Lyn Nofziger, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan and an old friend of Mrs. Whitman who is also a consultant, and Dave Sackett, who conducts polls for the campaign. Others, like Dan Todd, the Governor's brother and the campaign's finance director, and Harriet Derman, her chief of staff, might also attend.
"We spend two hours putting everything on the table, and the Governor says, 'I feel most comfortable going this way or that way." ' Mr. Wilson said. "We try to make our critical decisions, talking about what a spot looks like or what we hear to be the latest line of attack from the McGreevey camp."
When he is not in meetings, Mr. Wilson is usually on the phone, talking to Mr. Murphy, Mr. Nofziger, Ms. Derman or Becky Taylor, the Governor's press secretary. He also takes dozens of calls from "friends and talkers in the field," including Republican mayors, legislators and donors who want to pass on advice for Mrs. Whitman or simply want her to visit their town. Mr. Wilson, who grew up in Bridgewater and left New Jersey only to attend college at the University of Vermont, said that knowing so many people makes his job harder than that of Mr. McGreevey's campaign manager, Doug Heyl, who is from South Carolina. (Mr. Heyl declined an invitation to be interviewed for a separate article about his role in the McGreevey campaign.)
On the other hand, knowing all the Republican movers and shakers in New Jersey has been the key to Mr. Wilson's rapid ascent in the party. His first political role model was State Senator Raymond Bateman, a powerful Republican from Somerville who is a family friend and Mr. Wilson's godfather. When Mr. Bateman tried to unseat Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, a Democrat, in 1977, 10-year-old Tom Wilson helped served the pancakes at his fund-raising breakfasts.
That early foray into politics did not hook Mr. Wilson, who said he never even considered participating in student government at Bridgewater-Raritan High School East, playing on the golf team instead. But by the time Mr. Wilson enrolled at the University of Vermont in 1985, President Reagan was at the height of his popularity and Mr. Wilson, intrigued by Mr. Reagan's ability to charm the masses, began paying attention to his policies.
"He had such an enormous amount of charisma," Mr. Wilson said. "Obviously when you're attracted to someone from that perspective, you start listening to what they have to say."
Mr. Wilson declared a major in political science, and after his sophomore year, his family connection started paying off. A son of Mr. Bateman who was working for Gov. Thomas H. Kean arranged a summer job for Mr. Wilson in the State House, helping members of the Assembly plan re-election campaigns. He liked the job so much that he put college on hold, spending that fall analyzing voting precincts on behalf of Assembly incumbents.
FROM then on, Mr. Wilson said, college was a blur. After graduating in 1989, he called Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, then chairman of the Assembly Republican Majority, a state Republican fund-raising organization, who hired him to help plan re-election campaigns for Assembly incumbents. Although the Republicans lost the majority that year, Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase changed their luck.
"It was great to be there to catch the fumble when it happened," said Mr. Wilson, who ran the fund-raising organization through the legislative elections of 1991. By then, Mr. Haytaian had become a mentor to Mr. Wilson and as the new Speaker of the Assembly, he hired Mr. Wilson, then 24, as the director of his office.
By the end of 1992, Mr. Wilson was dating Lysa Israel, a former co-worker from the Assembly Republican Majority, who convinced him to join her on the campaign staff of Carey Edwards, a Republican gubernatorial candidate who lost the 1993 primary to a fairly obscure opponent: Christine Todd Whitman. Mr. Wilson and Ms. Israel married that year, and Ms. Israel started a company that now helps raise funds for the Whitman campaign.
Mr. Wilson continued networking with Republicans between 1993 and 1995, when he worked for David Welch, a political consultant, on New Jersey legislative races. His career got another boost in 1995, when Mr. Haytaian was tapped to be chairman of the Republican State Committee and made Mr. Wilson, then 27, his executive director.
Mr. Haytaian, who is still chairman of the Republican State Committee, said in an interview that Mr. Wilson had three qualities that impressed him early on.
"He was bright, articulate and aggressive," Mr. Haytaian said. "He was also Ray Bateman's godson, and Ray and I have been friends forever."
It was Mr. Haytaian who urged Governor Whitman to hire Mr. Wilson as her campaign manager. Although Mr. Haytaian said he never thought Mr. Wilson's age or lack of experience running statewide campaigns were an issue, Mr. Wilson said he wavered when Peter Verneiro, then the Governor's chief of staff, approached him about the job early in 1996.
"I though there would be a whole host of other people who would be way ahead in line, who were a lot smarter about this stuff," Mr. Wilson said. But after several long talks with Mr. Verneiro, he changed his mind.
"This is my state, I know it," he said. "And I'd been getting up to speed for 29 years at that point."
But now that Mr. Wilson is proving he can manage a gubernatorial campaign, he is thinking that he doesn't want to do it again. He would eventually like to open a bed-and-breakfast in Vermont or on the Jersey Shore, but for now, journalism and public relations are more likely choices, he said.
Mr. Wilson said that after Election Day, he would vacation in the Caribbean, peruse all his back issues of Bon Appetit and return to his favorite hobby, cooking. To keep up his energy between now and then, Mr. Wilson said he planned to emerge from his office occasionally to hit the campaign trail.
"Dealing with minutiae, consultants, staff, you forget that what this is really about is 7 million New Jerseyans who by and large happen to really like the Governor," he said, sounding downright gushy. "I head out there when I need a dose of vitamin C. That's Vitamin Christie."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
It's Not the Economy, It's the Monthly Bills

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The national economy must be doing better if voters in New Jersey, and Virginia, the only states with gubernatorial elections this year, are preoccupied with the cost of running a car.
In New Jersey, it is the cost of automobile insurance that is dominating the debate in the race between Governor Whitman and her Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey. 
 In Virginia, it is a personal property tax on cars that is infuriating voters and prompting both the Republican and Democratic gubernatorial candidates there to say they will consider eliminating that tax and come up with alternative sources of revenue.
So, why auto insurance and excise taxes? As one political expert said, voters focus on minor irritants during a strong economy when they are not as worried about the next paycheck. It would be easy to conclude that voters here in New Jersey, and perhaps in Virginia, are just cranky and have nothing else to complain about it.
But interviews with dozens of New Jerseyans over the last few weeks suggest that they are not just bellyaching. There is a high level of frustration over the cost of auto insurance, as well as property taxes, here in New Jersey because voters do not believe that they are getting ahead despite the strength in the economy and Governor Whitman's tax cuts.
Only 16 percent of New Jerseyans surveyed in the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll believe that their state income taxes have gone down. Another 28 percent said that their income taxes have gone up. The the largest share of respondents, 43 percent, said their state income taxes had remained the same.
Why did 40 percent of those surveyed in the same poll spontaneously cite the cost of auto insurance as their top concern, and property taxes as their next biggest gripe? Their concerns over these two issues reflect the growing financial pressures on many working families and senior citizens to make ends meet. Unlike the telephone bill or the electric bill, or even the mortgage, the property tax bill and the auto insurance bill are two bills that voters believe government can lower. They are two measures that they can point to and argue, rightfully, that government can do something about.
As everyone knows by now, New Jerseyans pay the highest auto insurance rates in the nation. The average cost of auto insurance per vehicle in the state is $1,113. And according to a recent study by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy in Washington, New Jerseyans also pay the highest property tax bills. The average young married couple who own a home in New Jersey paid $3,562 in property taxes in 1995. The next highest property tax bills were in Connecticut. The average bill there is $2,573.
The Dow may be soaring, but not everyone in the state is benefiting from the Wall Street boom. New Jersey may be on the verge of replacing all of the jobs that the state lost in the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. However, many of the jobs lost were in manufacturing, where workers without college educations could rely on getting decent salaries and benefits. Many of the new jobs are in the service industry. They do not pay nearly as well, and they do not always come with benefits.
Meanwhile, property taxes and automobile insurance bills continued to rise over the last four years, further squeezing already tight household budgets across the state. And while Governor Whitman has taken some steps to address both bills, polls show that voters do not think that she has done enough.
"In our family, two 80-year-old widows had to give up their homes because they could not afford the property taxes on their homes," said Jean Phillips, 50, of Roselle. "The property taxes on one house was $7,800 a year. On the other house, the property taxes were $5,500. This is not the American way. And the cost of automobile insurance is outrageous."
Mrs. Phillips said that she voted for the Governor in 1993. "I will not vote for her again," she said. "I don't think that she has done anything."
Mr. McGreevey is seeking to tap into this frustration and anger among voters who want government to do something to ease their daily financial pressures. Last week, he unleashed his first television advertisement spot, reminding residents that they are paying the nation's highest auto insurance and property tax rates. His campaign advisers said that they will focus on these two issues and education.
Mr. McGreevey is getting the attention of voters by recognizing their plight. But empathy alone will not help him win the State House.
This campaign is really not about auto insurance and property taxes. It is about paying the monthly bills without relying on the line of credit in your checking account.
In the final weeks leading up to the Nov. 4 election, voters are hoping that the candidates will present their plan to bring down monthly household expenses by addressing those two big bills. Folks are just looking for a break.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
The Talk of the Town

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
SPEAKING slowly and ever-so optimistically, Don Williams, the self-styled "conservative with compassion," has been the highest-rated morning talk radio host in Atlantic City since he started his show on WOND-AM in 1985. A transplant from Pennsylvania whose brothers are in the Atlantic City police and fire departments, Mr. Williams soothes, teases but mostly agrees with an audience, that, according to the latest Arbitron ratings, accounts for some 6,300 listeners from Toms River to Cape May.
"They hear us in Rehoboth and there's a trucker that calls in from Wilmington," Mr. Williams noted. "We get all kinds." 
 In the space of four hours on the air, Mr. Williams may complain about how much his brothers are paid -- along with the rest of Atlantic City's firefighters and police officers ("I don't believe in giving a blank check to anybody; if money was all that mattered in that job, why is it that there's never a shortage of people who want those jobs?"); praise Mayor James Whelan, state Senator William Gormley and Governor Whitman as godsends ("If not for them, we wouldn't have a future to dream about") and rap Donald Trump's knuckles ("Some of the things he's been doing to block progress in Atlantic City -- if they aren't illegal they should be").
He'll also dodge a question about his age and bachelor status ("Let's just say I'm old enough to be thinking about things I should've done and the gals I should've done them with"), give his pet charity a plug ("Marine Corps Law Enforcement Foundation, Mountain Lakes, New Jersey, gives scholarships and support to families of armed service and law enforcement people killed in the line of duty -- you can't do much better than that for people who died for their country"). And he will restrain himself from lambasting the occasional caller mentioning Atlantic City residents who have been shut out of the casino boom.
"We get the occasional liberal in need of re-education," Mr. Williams said. "But I don't think they represent the majority view. The majority of people realize that Atlantic City is no longer in the doldrums. We feel like this town has been born again."
According to Arbitron ratings, Mr. Williams' listeners just might represent a majority, perhaps one living mostly in the affluent beach towns and mainland suburban communities that have benefited economically from Atlantic City's rebirth.
Mr. Williams has not won his audience by being one of the attack dogs of talk radio. "I know how to ruffle feathers if I want to," he says. But he will stop short of plucking them out.
"This is a community. Communities are built on treating people fairly and with respect."
Which is how Mr. Williams views the casino industry's relationship to the Atlantic City region. "They are part of our community. If you stack up the benefits against the losses, there is just no comparison."
Casino moguls, he said, "are taking on an enormous responsibility in developing this town. It's not a good idea to take sides when they argue among themselves, but I'll take a side if I think it's the right one."
The side that Mr. Williams has been on most consistently has been that of Mirage Resorts' Steve Wynn, to whom Mayor Whelan gave a 155-acre parcel of city-owned land for casino development for the equivalent of $10 million in clean-up and acquisition costs.
"Bill Gormley and Mayor Whelan did the right thing in giving the land to him," Mr. Williams said. "Steve Wynn is going to change this city for the better."
Donald Trump has used numerous strategies, including lawsuits, to stop Mr. Wynn and and a $330 million automobile tunnel linking the Atlantic City Expressway to the city's marina district that Mr. Wynn made a condition for building a casino in Atlantic City. Earlier this year, Mr. Trump canceled his casinos' advertisements on Mr. Williams's show.
"Didn't bother me in the least," Mr. Williams said, adding that he would support the tunnel even if it did not benefit the casino industry. A resident of Brigantine, Mr. Williams must drive through Atlantic City to reach the mainland. "I call the tunnel the War at the Shore, because it's really divided the community. But the fact is, the traffic in and out of the marina district has been impossible for years."
"I remember when people didn't want the state to build the Atlantic City Expressway," he said. "I don't hear anybody complaining now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Don Williams in the studio of radio station WOND-AM, where he is host of a talk show. (Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Among Those Who Can, a Switch to Teaching

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
DAVE MOSS had just received a promotion and a 19 percent increase in salary when he quit his banking career at age 35. Instead, Mr. Moss, who had been working as a commercial loan officer, began pursuing a 15-year dream: becoming a teacher.
He had three teen-age children at the time, and he needed 18 months to obtain his teacher's certificate. The switch also meant a 60 percent cut in pay, to a starting salary of $18,500. But five years later, he does not regret it. 
 "I'll never make the money in education that I probably could have made as a banker," said Mr. Moss, who lives in Sandy, Utah, and teaches the fourth grade. "But after I found something that I really enjoyed doing, our family realized, amazingly, that we didn't miss the money."
Career switching is not new to the teaching business. But it has become more popular lately, amid growing concerns over teacher shortages in some areas. And teachers' pay is starting to keep pace with inflation.
Today, a typical career switcher into teaching has been out of college for 8 to 10 years. But more of these new teachers are men, and more are people in their late 50's or their 60's. And while new teachers still tend to come directly out of college, the number of career switchers has probably doubled in the last 15 years, to perhaps 50,000, education experts said.
People who want to make the jump can choose among 300 programs nationwide, half of them created since 1990. The largest is the Troops to Teachers program, for military personnel; it has produced 2,300 new teachers since 1994. There are also programs for physicists, retired engineers, returning Peace Corps volunteers and "para-educators" like teacher's aides.
Some people are still enrolling in alternative certification programs that take just a few weeks; school districts started offering more of them in the early 1990's to deal with teacher shortages. But about three-quarters of the career switchers, education experts say, are turning to programs that are usually considerably longer and often exhaustingly intense, but that steep students in teaching theory, child-development courses and classroom experience.
Educators applaud the interest. They say many school districts prefer career switchers as teachers, and for several reasons: They tend to bring more maturity, self-confidence and self-discipline to the job, and they are less likely to leave the profession.
Still, educators caution, a classroom perch is not for everyone. Those who are happiest with the change, they say, have usually made a realistic assessment of their skills and have some experience working with children or schools.
"People often think that just because they're good at working with people that they're right for this," said Michael Andrew, director of teacher education at the University of New Hampshire. "But they often underestimate the emotional and mental stress of the job, and often they don't have the abilities to relate effectively with today's multicultural, pluralistic classroom."
Mr. Moss said: "If large purchases, money and titles are important to you, teaching is not the way to go. People who are stuck in a 9-to-5 habit or who look at it as just a job shouldn't consider it too strongly, either. In my case, I'm working with 26 different personalities during the day, and I have to take the time to deal with each personality individually."
For David A. Krane, an elementary-school teacher in Lexington, Mass., the decision to switch careers also took a big bite out of his family's income.
Mr. Krane, 43, had worked as a carpenter and building contractor for almost 20 years before September 1996, when he became a full-time student in an intensive yearlong teacher training course at the Shady Hill School in Cambridge, Mass. He had run a successful business, but found himself "running from job to job, doing more management and less hands-on building."
Luckily, Mr. Krane's wife was able to increase her earnings, to help offset the loss of income. But Mr. Krane, who has two daughters, 5 and 8, still had to borrow almost $8,000, as well as tap into his savings to the tune of a few thousand dollars a month. "It began to get quite dicey toward the end," he said.
Financial sacrifices are not new to Pablo Millares, either. Mr. Millares, 35, is a former American Express bill collector who is now happily teaching kindergarten in North Miami Beach, Fla. But to reach his goal, Mr. Millares had to obtain an $8,000 education loan and spend three years going to school on Saturdays and in the evenings. Even after he finished his courses, he still had to take a leave of absence from his collection job to finish a nine-month internship.
Now, rather than spending his entire day on the phone, Mr. Millares teaches up to 44 kindergarteners at a time.
"The biggest change I had was suddenly becoming my own boss," he said. "I was the one running the factory, so to speak, and to these kids, I was a friend, a psychiatrist and Mom and Dad all rolled into one.
"I didn't have gray hair when I started teaching," he added.
Mr. Millares was lucky in finding a job: Just three weeks into his internship, he was hired by the school where he was working. But Mr. Krane had a tougher task. While interviewing for a job in a multi-age classroom -- a teaching approach that mixes students of slightly different ages -- he discovered that there were 350 to 500 applicants for each job.
After sending out more than 100 letters, Mr. Krane eventually landed a job, teaching in a multi-age class of first and second graders. But many of his friends, he said, had to work out of state, because so many universities in the Boston area churn out new teachers annually.
EDUCATION experts advise career switchers to assess training programs carefully.
David Haselkorn, the president of Recruiting New Teachers, a nonprofit group in Belmont, Mass., said that more than 40 states offered alternative certification programs intended to license teaching candidates who already hold bachelor's degrees and who have expertise in a particular subject. But, he added, these programs vary widely. Some require just nine additional hours of graduate course work, while others require obtaining a master's degree and extensive field work.
"Some of these programs are just emergency programs with fig leaves," he said.
Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor at Teachers College at Columbia University, agreed.
"We've found that the programs that are the most successful are those that are usually launched by universities and that have created strong partnerships with local schools," she said. "These programs combine intensive course work in learning theory, child cognition and development with internships with master teachers at local schools."
She added: "The programs that fail are the four- to six-week summer programs, where there's just enough time for orientation and learning tricks of the trade. With these programs, students often obtain very little knowledge of how kids develop, and they also get no special-education training, even though classrooms now average two students with learning disabilities apiece. As a result, students usually run out of teaching tools by the second week of school."
Professor Darling-Hammond said career switchers who completed longer, more intense certification programs were about three times as likely to stay in teaching as new college graduates. But career switchers who choose the quick programs have a higher dropout rate; 20 to 50 percent leave after the first year. By contrast, career switchers who train well have an attrition rate of about 5 percent.
"School districts think they're saving money with these programs, but a lot of them are penny wise and pound foolish," Professor Darling-Hammond said.
Still, for many switchers, training well can be taxing. At the teaching training program at the University of New Hampshire, students first endure a a wilderness week in the White Mountains that, like many Outward Bound programs, helps them adapt problem-solving methods to the classroom. After that, the students are required to run a five-week-long summer school for elementary and secondary students, and completes a yearlong internship.
"This is basically a full-time commitment," Professor Andrew said. "Most mid-career people have saved up to do this."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
Greek Jews Still Gather On Broome

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
On Broome Street, just west of Allen Street, most of the signs have Chinese lettering. But there is a modest wooden door inscribed with Hebrew letters; behind it sits Kehila Kedosha Janina, the last Greek Jewish synagogue in the city, its members and Jewish historians say.
After Saturday morning services, 15 or 20 congregants eat chocolate cake in the basement. Sitting at a separate table from the women, some of the men drink ouzo, the Greek liqueur. 
 They are Greek Jews, from a town in northwest Greece called Janina, once the capital of Greek Jewry. They also belong to a little-known division of Judaism, the main ones being Ashkenazic and Sephardic. "We use Sephardic prayer books, although we have our own special chants," said Hy Genee, the synagogue's president.
From about 1890 to 1935, economic and natural disasters spurred a mass migration of Greek Jews to the Lower East Side, where several synagogues were established. The Kehila Kedosha Janina synagogue, founded in 1927, once had three rabbis. Some of Greece's Jewish population survived most of the Holocaust, only to perish during its last six months, on death trains to Auschwitz or in a death camp in Athens.
In May, the synagogue celebrated its 70th anniversary with the opening of a museum detailing Greek Jewish history on its second floor.
The museum was the project of Isaac Dostis, whose father took him as a child to the Kehila Kedosha Janina synagogue, and who recently rediscovered his religious and cultural roots. "I thought I was Sephardic," said Mr. Dostis, who runs an acting troupe in New Jersey.
Convinced that the Greek Jewish culture in New York was in danger of disappearing into oblivion, he created a tiny museum in the women's gallery. It is open from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Sundays, and Mr. Dostis has plans for expanding it with a library, art gallery and Greek cafe.
He estimates that the synagogue has 1,000 members. On Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, perhaps 150 come. But on Saturdays, the number is seldom greater than 35.
The synagogue survives on private donations, said Murray Eskononts, the vice president, who was born across the street. "We have very few expenses," he said, pointing out that there is no ordained rabbi and the synagogue is run by volunteers. "Although we could use a paint job. I don't think it's been painted since it was opened." JANET ALLON

GRAPHIC: Photo: Isaac Dostis, who created a small museum at a Greek synagogue. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "MILESTONES -- Greek Jews: The History"
70 A.D. -- First Jews settle in area that will become Janina (lonnina) in northwestern Greece, after escaping from a Roman slaveship.
 
MIDDLE AGES -- Jews are persecuted in the Byzantine empire. Ionnina is taken by the Turks in 1431. The Jewish community grows when refugees from the Spanish Inquisition arrive.
 
1890-1915 -- Earthquakes, famine and exonomics spur many Greek Jews to move to the New World.
 
1994 -- Nearly 2,000 Jews from Janina, along with those from other parts of a divided Greece are sent to the Haidari concentration camp in Athens or put on Trains to Auschwitz. It is estimated that 65,000 of 80,000 Greek Jews died in the Holocaust.
(Source: Kehila Kedosha Janina Synagogue and Museum, 280 Broome Street)

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Goal Line to Bottom Line: Degrees in Sports Management

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
AMARA E. WOODCOCK is an avowed sports fanatic. So it did not take her long to enroll in the bachelor's degree program in sports management at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.
"I was dissatisfied with my first choice and saw the program as a way to pair my love of sports with a career in management," said Ms. Woodcock, 21, who is a senior at Seton Hall. "This is also an up-and-coming industry." 
 The university began the program in its business school three years ago because sports now "is a lot more about dollars, and our students need to go into it with a whole different set of skills," said Ann M. Mayo, the director of the Center for Sports Management. Courses range from sports law and the economics of the sports industry to sports financing. An undergraduate student in the program finishes with a bachelor's degree in business administration with a major in sports management.
This program differs from the usual management program in that the core courses teach students how to apply management skills to areas that are particular to sports, like collective bargaining, sponsorships and endorsements, Dr. Mayo said.
"Students will come out with a broad set of basic skills and a specialty," she said.
That appeals to David R. Shipitofsky, a 21-year-old senior.
"I love sports," he said. "And how many jobs are there that you can talk about last night's game without getting in trouble with the boss?" Besides, he said, "if it doesn't work out, I have all the basic courses to fall back on."
Such business school programs are becoming increasingly common on campuses, reflecting a major move beyond degree programs in physical education for those who want to make sports their vocation. And more and more students are betting that a sports management degree will improve their odds of landing a job.
The competition for employment is fierce, and starting pay is often low. Craig N. Tartasky, vice president of E. J. Krause & Associates, a sports conference and management consulting firm in Bethesda, Md., said the starting salary for a college graduate with a sports management degree could be $20,000 or less, and positions are typically tied to sales. In addition, students who get jobs can anticipate working long hours. With luck, the best of those hired can move up quickly, he added, perhaps to $45,000 a year after a few years. Of course, for the truly successful, salaries in the stratosphere are not impossible.
Students who enroll in sports management programs, while avid fans, are not frustrated athletes, Dr. Mayo said. The draw, she said, is working in a field that "is a little more glamorous and fun."
Other educators agree. Today, 200 colleges and universities nationwide offer undergraduate degrees or courses in sports management, up from 20 in 1985, according to estimates from the North American Society for Sport Management, an academic and research group based at the University of New Brunswick in Canada. Among the earliest to establish programs were Ohio University and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
Some schools also offer master's and Ph.D. degrees. Some even have a combination course that grants an M.B.A. in sports management and a law degree. Amy C. Johnson, 21, is pursuing such a combination at Seton Hall. "If I wanted to make money, I would become a tax attorney," she said. "But I would rather do something I like, that interests me."
The growing number of programs, many sports industry executives say, is as much a response to student demand as a way to capitalize on the growth of the sports industry over the last dozen years.
Mr. Tartasky said other factors have included the boom in sports channels and programs on cable television, and corporate America's realization that sports sponsorships, advertisements and team ownership can be very profitable. Yet other elements are the expansion of major and minor league teams and the creation of new leagues like the Women's National Basketball Association and Major League Soccer.
The new job opportunities go beyond managing professional and amateur teams. They include working in public relations, labor relations, apparel licensing and advertising, negotiating sponsorship agreements, organizing events and managing stadiums and arenas. Which is not to forget sports representation, an occupation that gained fame through Tom Cruise's portrayal of a sports agent in the movie "Jerry Maguire."
Whatever number of jobs are available in sports, industry executives say, the total is far smaller than that for other growing industries, like computer programming, and far fewer than the number of people chasing them.
A sports management degree helps, but by how much?
"The degree is not nearly as important as the person's personality, passion for sports and practical experience," said William Allard, president of Proserv, the large sports management and marketing agency in Washington.
Many universities have structured their programs with that in mind, placing students in internships to gain firsthand knowledge of how the industry runs. That is the case at the University of Massachusetts, "where internships are the core," said William A. Sutton, an associate professor in the sports management program.
Just as important, he said, is what the faculty members can offer to students from their own work experience and contacts. "Having the degree is not a lock on a job, by any stretch of the imagination," he said.
Seton Hall's program also focuses on internships. Last summer, Mr. Shipitofsky worked for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, making ticket arrangements for events at the Meadowlands. Ms. Woodcock has done office work at Seton Hall's Sports Information Center and production management at MTV Sports. This semester, both she and Mr. Shipitofsky are interns in marketing and promotions for the New Jersey Devils.
Ms. Woodcock said she used to fret over "how she would stand out" in such a crowded job market. But she thinks her degree and internships will give her an edge. Breaking into the sports industry, after all, is not a cakewalk, especially for women. "I won't lie," Ms. Woodcock said. "There are days it disturbs me that people don't take me seriously."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ann Mayo, director of Seton Hall's sports management program, confers with some of her charges: Amara Woodcock, left, and David Shipitofsky and Amy Johnson, right. (Norman Y. Lono/The New York Times)
