LENGTH: 1549 words

HEADLINE: Panama Leader Accused of Cronyism Over Appointees to Run the Canal

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
As a presidential candidate in 1994, Ernesto Perez Balladares was burdened by voters' misgivings about his party's unsavory ties to the deposed dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. To allay those fears, he promised that, if elected, he would treat the Panama Canal not as the spoils of victory, but as the jewel of the national patrimony.
Now, having announced his choices for the board of directors that will run the vital waterway after the United States hands it over to Panama in 1999, Mr. Perez Balladares is being accused of breaking his word. Among his nominees to what will be an 11-member board are four members of his own or his wife's family, including a first cousin, a son-in-law and the spouses of two other cousins. 
 In addition, Mr. Perez Balladares has appointed one of the chief fund-raisers of his election campaign, a businessman famous for being embroiled in lawsuits. Other selections include two leading members of the Revolutionary Democratic Party who served General Noriega as his Foreign Minister and Interior Minister, and the son of Mr. Perez Balladares's own former Foreign Minister.
Reaction to the President's appointments among opposition groups, unions and the press has been caustic and angry. A cartoon published in the country's leading newspaper, La Prensa, early in September showed Mr. Perez Balladares greedily stuffing himself with pieces of a birthday cake labeled "Canal" as a voice calls out, "Darling, your relatives have arrived," while four other hands reach for portions.
In an editorial, the newspaper reproached Mr. Perez Balladares for violating "a tacit understanding among the leaders of all parties that the Canal is to be placed above and beyond the political fray" and "out of the reach of ignoble appetites." With the naming of the new board, the newspaper continued, "the Canal has been converted into a fount of juicy sinecures for the relatives and associates of the President."
As required by a pair of treaties signed 20 years ago, the waterway is currently managed by the Panama Canal Commission, an American Government agency whose board has five American and four Panamanian members. At noon on Dec. 31, 1999, that panel will give way to the Panama Canal Authority, to be directed by the all-Panamanian board appointed by the Government here.
Shipping companies and foreign governments have never questioned the ability of ordinary canal employees, whose professionalism and dedication to the waterway were demonstrated during the Noriega dictatorship. Already, more than 92 percent of the waterway's 9,800 workers, including more than two-thirds of the pilots who steer ships through the canal, are Panamanians.
Nor have the qualifications of the Panama Canal's administrator, Alberto Aleman Zubieta, been challenged. A Panamanian engineer educated in the United States, Mr. Aleman was appointed last year, and has been praised as a capable and impartial civil servant by shippers concerned about the canal's transition from American to Panamanian hands.
But shippers, diplomats, canal employees and their unions have not expressed the same confidence in Mr. Perez Balladares's decision to turn to relatives, friends and political associates to set canal policy.
"This sends the wrong signal to everyone who uses the canal and wonders if Panama can run it as efficiently and honestly as the Americans," said a European shipping company executive who attended a congress on the future of the canal held here Sept. 7 to 10.
Jorge E. Ritter, whom Mr. Perez Balladares appointed in July as Minister of Canal Affairs and has named to head the future Panama Canal Authority, did not respond to requests for an interview regarding the board's composition. But in an interview late last year, he argued that while "being a friend of the President cannot be the only credential, neither should it be an impediment."
In addition, Joe R. Reeder, the American chairman of the Panama Canal Commission, said in early September that some of the local criticism of Mr. Perez Balladares's choices was unfair and misdirected. Several of the nominees, he pointed out, already serve as members of the commission or the technical or legal working groups that are overseeing the transition.
"I know almost all of them, and I couldn't be more pleased," he said. "In a nation of under three million people, there are many relationships among the established families. But I think the key is the quality and background these individuals bring as successful businessmen and bankers already involved intimately in the business of the canal."
 On Sept. 15, in a move that analysts of canal affairs called surprising, Mr. Reeder announced that he was resigning. His successor is expected to be named in October.
But the prominence of Mr. Ritter, who served first as Panama's Ambassador to Colombia and then as Foreign Minister when General Noriega was in power, is itself seen by many here as a sign of politicization of the canal's administration. Though regarded as enjoying the President's confidence, Mr. Ritter is neither an engineer nor a transportation expert, and testimony during General Noriega's 1991 trial in Miami implicated him in the sale of a car to a member of a Colombian drug cartel.
"We still have to show him where Miraflores is," a union official said in jest, referring to a set of locks just north of the capital. When the United States ran the canal alone, the official said, the board "used to have people who had something to do with transportation, who didn't draw a blank when you said the word 'ship.' "
Concerns about nepotism have been fed by a recent controversy in which a company owned by a cousin of the President, Nicolas Gonzalez Revilla, acquired a virtual stranglehold on television broadcasting in Panama. Mr. Perez Balladares is also a shareholder in the company, Medios Panamenos, which originally owned just one of the country's three networks.
Over the last year, however, Mr. Gonzalez Revilla has gained control of a second network and the country's only cable television service. Press reports here have suggested that the acquisitions were completed and approved with unusual swiftness so that they would not run afoul of a new anti-trust law that, in effect, prevents the emergence of any serious rival.
During the same period, the Government also canceled the license it had awarded to a company that had outbid Mr. Gonzalez Revilla for authorization to offer satellite dish service here. That process, which local press reports said was rife with irregularities, has greatly enhanced the profitability and value of Medios Panamenos, diplomats and bankers here said.
More recently, the Government has been embroiled in a dispute over oddities in the privatization of two ports at either end of the Panama Canal. Last year, five American companies were passed over in favor of a Hong Kong company, Hutchison Whampoa, after a bidding process that the American Ambassador here, William Hughes, criticized as "unfair" and "lacking in transparency."
Now, it appears that Hutchison Whampoa may have also been granted 106 acres of valuable real estate set aside for a railway modernization project being undertaken by an American railroad company. The director of the National Port Authority, Hugo Torrijos, did not respond to requests for an interview to discuss the confusion, but news reports here say that developers of a new airport and a shopping mall may also have claims to pieces of the same parcel.
The United States Transportation Secretary, Rodney Slater, here during the congress on the future of the canal, said Panama had shown signs of responding "to some of the questions that have been raised there." But, he said, "Those are the things people will continue to monitor and focus on."
Amid these controversies, Mr. Perez Balladares, who is scheduled to leave office on Sept. 1, 1999, is attempting to have Panama's Constitution amended so that he can be re-elected. Ever since the country gained its independence from Colombia 94 years ago, no President has been allowed to succeed himself in office.
Under the current Constitution, Mr. Perez Balladares would have to wait two terms, or 10 years, before being eligible to run again. But the Legislative Assembly, which his party controls, is expected to approve soon a proposal that would set a date for a referendum sometime next year on whether Mr. Perez Balladares can remain in office for a second consecutive term, until 2004.
Almost as soon as it takes control of the canal, Panama will have to decide whether to build a new set of locks to accommodate increasing traffic -- a project expected to cost at least $6.5 billion -- and which construction companies should be given the task. There are also proposals afoot, shippers and canal workers say, to privatize some potentially lucrative canal services, such as maintenance.
"Whoever is in power for the next term will have the opportunity to take some big decisions and grant some important contracts," said Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former Vice President and a leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Party. "That generates economic power, and if not done transparently, offers ways to favor certain economic interests and law firms."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1555 words

HEADLINE: Scholar Takes On His Toughest Study of Race

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C.

 BODY:
For John Hope Franklin, the problem was maddening: the orchids he was trying to grow 37 years ago in the window box of his Brooklyn apartment either died or failed to bloom. His solution was typical of his approach to a lifelong study of race relations in America: he read everything he could on the subject.
"They're not tough to grow," he said in an interview about his collection of beautiful but temperamental flowers -- including pink doritinopsis and spidery brown and yellow brassidium thriving in his greenhouse. 
 "They enjoy a reputation of being tough," Mr. Franklin added, "the kind of reputation that some people enjoy: being tough when they really aren't."
His successful cultivation of orchids -- including one he developed and named for himself -- may be reflective of his methodical ways. But now, as a professor emeritus at Duke University who wrote "From Slavery to Freedom," which remains the seminal book on African-American history 50 years after it was published, he has taken on a new challenge. It is one that could prove the most daunting of his 82 years: helping to solve the country's vexing racial problems.
As chairman of the advisory board for President Clinton's Initiative on Race and Reconciliation, Mr. Franklin is not lowering expectations.
"I hope it will turn the corner for this nation once and for all with respect to the question of race," he said of the panel, which is to conclude its work in a year and issue recommendations for an action plan by the President, Congress and the American people.
"I don't mean it will all be solved by that time," Mr. Franklin continued. "But I hope it will have the significance of turning the corner so we can look back and say this was the decisive moment, this was the watershed. That's a lot to ask for, but that's what I'm asking."
 President Clinton, in a speech on Thursday in Little Rock commemorating the 40th anniversary of the integration of Central High School there, urged that Americans "not replace the tyranny of segregation with the tragedy of low expectations." Mr. Clinton, who would like to make a turning point in race relations a legacy of his Presidency, may attend the panel's next meeting on Tuesday, Administration officials said.
Despite such an ambitious goal, the seven people on the panel -- three whites, two blacks, one Asian-American and one Hispanic member -- has gotten off to a slow start and has been criticized for not representing a sufficient diversity of political opinion.
Although Mr. Franklin and the other board members were named in June, the White House has yet to fill the panel's 25 to 30 staff jobs. Their only meeting so far, held in mid-July in a conference center across from the White House, was taken up by a wandering discussion of the many issues and institutions the board might examine, including enforcement of civil rights laws, the criminal justice system, education, environmental racism, health services and immigration.
Christopher Edley, a professor at Harvard Law School who is a consultant to the board, "respectfully" suggested that it face the question of how "not to turn this into a commission about everything." The board settled on exploring the effects of race on education and economic opportunities -- at least at the start.
Conservative critics fault the Administration for stacking the board with people whose positions on race relations mirror its own, like support for preference-based affirmative action programs.
"I'm not sure one more commission, having one more discussion with itself, will change America's future," said Speaker Newt Gingrich, who did not respond to Mr. Franklin's overture to Congressional leaders for guidance and suggestions.
Mr. Franklin is unapologetic about the panel's makeup.
"I don't think it's characteristic of Presidents to appoint a representative body that will constitute a debating society," he said. "He wants to get something done. I don't remember President Reagan saying, 'Now that I've appointed one conservative to the Supreme Court, let me go and find a liberal to balance that.' "
Considering the barbs and the panel's confused start, one wonders why Mr. Franklin even took on the job. At his age, he could be pursuing his favorite pastimes, tending his flowers or fishing in a tranquil pond, contemplating nothing more weighty than whether the bluegills are biting crickets or angle worms.
"I hope I still have my mental faculties and I hope I have some of my physical stamina," he said. "But if I have some time left, I can see no better way to spend it than to try to do something about this problem that has deeply affected me personally and this nation throughout the years."
A tall, angular, chocolate-brown man with large hands and the elongated fingers of a basketball player or a concert pianist, Mr. Franklin seems to have the mental acuity and physical endurance of someone 30 years younger.
He gave up jogging five years ago, but still works out on an exercise bicycle and walks briskly for two miles, three times a week. He still enjoys cooking, making everything, including pancakes, from scratch. "There are no mixes allowed in the house," said his son, John Whittington Franklin, a program manager at the American Folklife Center at the Smithsonian Institution.
In between speaking, lecturing, reading and coordinating the work of the advisory board, Mr. Franklin is writing another history book -- his 13th -- this one on runaway slaves. After he finishes that work, he says, he wants to write an autobiography.
"He has boundless energy," said Walter Brown, his friend for more than 50 years and his fishing buddy since Mr. Franklin moved to North Carolina in 1980. "He's a man who can shift gears readily; that may be be part of the secret to his survival and his mental health."
But President Clinton did not select him to head the panel merely for his vigor. Mr. Franklin and others think he was chosen because the President felt that relations between the races could not be understood or improved without some knowledge of history.
"So many books come out these days that assume racism is a dead issue, that it is, in effect, history and let's move forward," said Eric Foner, a professor of history at Columbia University. "I don't think we should wallow in history. But I think you can't understand the current racial situation without some understanding of history. So the choice of a historian to head this committee is a wise one."
In Mr. Franklin's case, he has lived, not just studied, the history of black people in America.
He worked with Thurgood Marshall in 1953, writing briefs in the historic desegregation case, Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kan. And he marched with Martin Luther King Jr. in Montgomery, Ala., in 1965.
As a 10-year-old boy in Rentiesville, Okla., he fretted with his mother over the fate of his father, a lawyer who was caught in the infamous 1921 race riot in nearby Tulsa when mobs of whites, jealous of the economic success of blacks in north Tulsa, went on a rampage, killing blacks, pillaging and burning buildings, even dropping dynamite from airplanes. More than 100 blacks were killed. The elder Franklin was spared, but his office was destroyed.
Mr. Franklin attended the segregated Booker T. Washington High School in Tulsa. While white students at a nearby high school were taught French, Spanish and calculus, the youngsters at Booker T. Washington were offered typing, shorthand, auto mechanics and home economics.
Asked how racism had most affected him, Mr. Franklin, who has traveled extensively, lamented his lack of facility in any foreign language. "I felt it deeply when I went to France and Germany and Austria and Italy to lecture, and to the Soviet Union and to China," he recalled with a sigh. "And across town, they were teaching modern foreign languages, but not in my high school."
Despite these setbacks, Mr. Franklin has displayed a surprising lack of bitterness throughout most of his life. Indeed, when "From Slavery to Freedom" was published in 1947, reviewers noted its lack of rancor or polemics. It was, some reviewers and historians said, black history without a chip on its shoulder.
The tone of the book became more critical in later years, Mr. Franklin said, as it went through several editions -- it is in its seventh printing -- and the state of race relations changed. His pessimism reached its low point between the third edition, which was published in 1967, the year of the riots in Newark and Detroit when black-white relations became intensely polarized, and the fourth edition printed in 1974.
"I wasn't very happy about what I was seeing," he recalled. "And I thought those editions reflected my unhappiness."
As he has aged, however, he says he has softened. He is worried about the stalling of black progress but says he is no longer despairing.
"Over all, I think the book might reflect cautious optimism," he recently told reporters at a symposium at Duke commemorating the 50th anniversary of its publication.
"I think that's where I stand today with respect to the President's initiative on race, and where we are in the history of African-Americans. I'm cautiously optimistic about the future, which means that I have some reservations and a lot of caveats."

The advisory board for President Clinton's Initiative on Race and Reconciliation contains six members besides John Hope Franklin.

"I think the discussion is definitely multiracial. I think what we were trying to factor is to make sure we don't leave out the historical perspective on how we got here and that there is a time line and a journey that brought us to this point. And we can't ignore the journey, but we must also not stay at this point, but go forward."

HEADLINE: LEADERS OF G.O.P. SEEK TO OVERHAUL FEDERAL TAX CODE

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
On the third anniversary of their Contract with America, Republican leaders in Congress have begun a concerted drive to move beyond their signature issue of tax cuts and shift the national debate to a radical revision of the tax code.
The push toward fundamentally revising the progressive income tax, or scrapping it altogether, comes as the Republican Party begins an intense internal debate over a fiscal agenda to follow the balanced-budget agreement. It also reflects the fact that pollsters say voters are becoming less responsive to simple promises of tax cuts. 
 "As we've talked to citizens in the last few months about where to go beyond the Contract, over and over people have said to us, 'Don't just cut taxes -- reform the system,' " said Speaker Newt Gingrich in a telephone interview.
To lay the groundwork, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, and Representative W. J. Tauzin of Louisiana, announced this week that they were embarking on a three-city "Scrap the Code" tax tour in October. The pair plan to debate the merits of Mr. Armey's proposal for a flat tax and Mr. Tauzin's call to substitute a national retail sales tax for the income tax.
Even inside the Republican Party, this promises to be a divisive debate. House Republican leaders acknowledge that no consensus yet exists among their members on what kind of tax revision to embrace.
Some wary Republicans remember how Steve Forbes's call for a flat tax came under attack in the 1996 Republican primaries by critics saying it would sacrifice billions in Federal revenue and help the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.
And because Mr. Gingrich has also pledged that the party will push for a new tax cut every year, his remarks have sent Republicans in the House and Senate rushing to promote a favorite idea for consideration, even though most targeted tax breaks would be eviscerated under any radical tax revision.
Republicans are also split over whether to push the tax revision issue forward next spring in time for the 1998 midterm Congressional elections or wait for the Presidential campaign two years later. To force the tax issue to the top of the Presidential agenda, several House Republicans have already introduced bills to have the Federal tax code simply expire in 2000 or 2001.
"The ultimate goal, obviously, is to have radical tax reform," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip. "We have not decided exactly how you get there."
The ferment inside the G.O.P. comes at a time when the nation looks toward a balanced budget at century's end.
With majorities of both political parties in Congress having voted for the plan to erase the Federal deficit by 2002 and to trim taxes, Democrats have cut into the Republicans' traditional advantage on fiscal issues.
Moreover, some Republicans say that 16 years after Ronald Reagan rode into office as the apostle of slashing taxes, pollsters are finding cynicism about tax cuts.
"What pollsters are telling us," a House Republican aide said, "is that the tax cut issue doesn't pack the punch it once packed, but Republicans would be foolish to walk away from the tax cut issue because it's ours and we should keep it."
In a recent 222-page advice manual he sent to Republican lawmakers, Frank Luntz, a consultant who helped craft the Contract with America, described taxes as "the perennial G.O.P. issue, an issue we can never, ever afford to cede to the Democrats."
He said he had found "enormous political support" for "tax reform." But he warned that because former President George Bush and President Clinton had both made tax pledges that they broke, "the public just doesn't trust politicians who promise tax cuts."
In addition, he said: "Our success has shot us in the foot. We did such a good job expressing the urgency of balancing the Federal budget that any talk of tax 'cuts' makes the public think about the balanced budget. Where the alleged 'cuts' are going to come from?"
Mr. Luntz advised Republicans to talk about tax relief instead of tax cuts and to campaign against the Internal Revenue Service.
Another factor driving the G.O.P. debate, lawmakers say, is the belief that the booming economy will probably bring in more tax revenue in the next few years than had been projected in the balanced-budget agreement. That has started lawmakers in both parties thinking about the politics of a surplus.
Some Republicans have been arguing that at least some part of any surplus money should go to pay off not just the deficit, but the national debt. Representative Mark W. Neumann, a Wisconsin Republican, has proposed capping spending below revenue and dedicating two-thirds of the surplus to debt reduction and a third to tax reduction.
Other Republicans continue to focus on tax-cutting. House sophomores are proposing the elimination of the so-called marriage penalty, under which many married couples who file jointly are pushed into higher tax brackets because of their combined income. Several House freshmen said that they were crafting a tax cut plan for 1998.
Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri has a proposal to let people deduct from their taxable income the part of their payroll taxes that goes to Social Security. "Frankly, at a time when a political party is in the majority, it's time for it to broaden its base, not just to reinforce its base," Mr. Ashcroft said.
But the longer-term goal, party leaders say, is to shift the debate toward the radical revision of the nation's tax system.
"I think the first thing we need to do is to have a rock-solid opinion in the country that the current system is so flawed that it can't be fixed and that it needs to be replaced," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Republican Conference. "And there's a national discussion that needs to go on to validate that that's in fact the case."
Part of that discussion began this week when the Senate Finance Committee held hearings on the I.R.S. The panel heard emotional testimony from four taxpayers, including a retired priest who was wrongly assessed $18,000 in taxes from his mother's estate and a California woman who struggled with the agency for 17 years over a mixup about her husband's identity.
On Thursday, Mr. Armey and Mr. Tauzin, wearing tags proclaiming "Scrap the Code," announced their tax tour to Columbus, Ohio, Atlanta and Chicago and theatrically tossed tomes containing the Federal tax code into a large garbage can. Pointing to the Senate hearings, Mr. Armey said: "You want a civilized agency, you've got to have a civilized code. The current code is an abomination. The American people do not want it. The American people should be rid of it."
Mr. Tauzin, who supports a national retail sales tax, condemned the income tax as "too complex, too misunderstandable, too incomprehensible for anyone.
"You know what someone once said?" Mr. Tauzin asked with relish. "The hardest thing to understand is the United States income tax system. And you know who said it? Albert Einstein. Albert Einstein couldn't understand this tax code."
In the past, Republican leaders had acknowledged that they had no hope of pushing through a fundamental change in the tax code as long as President Clinton was in the White House.
Mr. Clinton dismissed the flat tax in a television interview last year, saying, "I have never seen a single tax rate that did not either raise taxes on everybody that was making less than $100,000 a year or leave us with a much bigger deficit." And Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Mr. Clinton's most influential economic adviser, staunchly defends the progressive income tax system.
Not all Republicans have an appetite for getting into a veto fight with Mr. Clinton next year over the tax code, uncertain whether the debate would help them in 1998 or backfire.
And even without opposition from Democrats, the Republicans would have a difficult time transforming theoretical approaches to changing the tax code into reality. The practical difficulties of shifting from one tax system to another would be enormous in an economy as big and complex as the United States, economists say. The scramble for preferential treatment among interest groups would be intense if the old system were to be thrown out. In the past, flat tax proposals have brought demands for the preservation of popular tax breaks like the mortgage-interest deduction for homeowners.
Aware of the potential difficulties, some Republican leaders are cautious about getting ahead of public opinion. "Some have said that if the time is right, we move this summer, but I can't believe the time would be right this summer," Mr. DeLay said.
One of the most ardent Congressional proponents of a national sales or consumption tax is Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which oversees tax matters. Even so, he passed up the chance to go on the road to debate with Mr. Armey.
"I have been very reluctant to do this because I would prefer to see us resolve our differences within the party and have a unified approach to the people," he said. "To me, we should be focusing on a process that would bring about that decision."
But Mr. Gingrich says he thinks the time could be ripe to act as early as next spring. "Tax reform becomes our answer to campaign finance reform because what people really mean is they don't want a lot of high-paid lobbyists running around getting paid to pressure the system," he said.
"The country's sick of lobbyists," he said, "and nothing will do more to lead to unemployment of lobbyists."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercury Grand Marquis;
Rear Drive but Refusing to Retire: A Case of Modern Maturity

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR By LEONARD M. APCAR

 BODY:
MY first thought as I slid behind the wheel of a tan Mercury Grand Marquis: "Detroit sure doesn't make cars like this anymore." But it does. The front bench seat, split into two sections, is as long and supple as a sofa. One's legs stretch out in a space that is deep and wide, and the top of the dashboard, which swoops from pillar to pillar, has the look of a surfboard. Up front is a powerful V8 and in the back, the traditional gearing for rear-wheel drive.
My second thought: "Does anybody buy these?" Sure, the Grand Marquis is commonly used by car services in New York City and its similar sibling, the Ford Crown Victoria, is ubiquitous as a taxi. Police departments around the country snap up the Crown Vic, too. But do hard-working Americans, faced with an array of four-wheel-drive sport utilities, snazzy front-drive sedans and smart neo-luxury cars, sign the papers to drive away in what amounts to an updated version of a family car of the 1960's? 
 You bet they do. Ford sold more than 200,000 copies of the Grand Marquis and Crown Vic last year, comparable to the sales of all Chrysler-brand cars, and many of those went to repeat buyers. They like the old-style 4.6-liter V8 with its 190 horsepower and the room for six people. They love the monstrous trunk.
Consumer Reports and other car-buying guides recommend the Grand Marquis for reliability, safety and value. Nicely equipped, the sticker price on the spiffier LS version I drove approached $27,000. But a little haggling and a $1,500 rebate, which expires on Tuesday, can whittle that down considerably.
And for all the acceptance of front-wheel drive, its advantages in snow and its compact design, rear-wheel drive is still preferred by many purists who like the handling and control it provides. Indeed, it is still the powertrain of choice for the fussy engineers responsible for high-performance automobiles like Jaguars, BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes. They like it for its weight distribution and its superb handling in high-speed turns.
Climb in, rev the engine and step on the gas. The hood rises up, you sink back in the plush seat and the rear wheels literally push you down the road. It's a thrill some people will never part with. To them, everything else is just mass transit.
While General Motors and Chrysler have abandoned the market for V8-powered, rear-drive sedans, Ford carries on. With the Lincoln Town Car, Grand Marquis and Crown Victoria, it has catered to a niche that is very profitable -- and made more so by G.M.'s withdrawal from the segment last year. In fact, these are among the few car lines that make money for Ford.
And the company fully intends to keep making them. A restyled 1998 Town Car arrives on Nov. 26, and the modestly freshened '98 Grand Marquis and Crown Victoria, with new roof lines and different front and rear styling, will be available in late December. You can expect more drastic changes in about four years.
For now, the Grand Marquis is a lot of old-fashioned car. I found it easily carried six people, as advertised. On highways, particularly straight ones, it made driving effortless and comfortable, especially with the optional "twin comfort seats" with big armrests and power lumbar support for the driver. Wind noise at highway speeds was surprisingly low for a large car with a generous silhouette. The ride, while soft, was not so mushy that I felt I was bouncing down the road.
And though this is a big, old-fashioned car, it doesn't quite drive like one. Piloting one of Detroit's big old boats used to make you feel you were maneuvering an aircraft carrier. But with a touch of aerodynamic styling the view over the hood is complete, and good visibility to the rear makes parallel parking simple -- even though, at nearly 18 feet, this is one of the longest cars on the road.
Where handling suffered was on the twists and turns. This is no rival to the performance sedans of BMW, Mercedes and Infiniti. The Grand Marquis tends to sway and buck into a turn at even modest speeds. Some of that is because the chassis is bolted to the frame, an old-fashioned, two-piece design that has been largely replaced by "unit body" construction in which the floor, roof and pillars make up the frame.
Mercury offers a handling package that includes 16-inch wheels, a tuned suspension and stabilizer bars that should help the car feel more like one harmonious unit, but this is still a large cruiser, not a driving machine. (Ford says it is making the handling of the 1998 version more crisp.)
Inside the big Mercury, comforts abound. On a hot summer day in California, where the temperature was 60 degrees at sunrise and exceeded 100 by midafternoon, the automatic air-conditioning system cooled the entire cabin quickly and consistently. The electronic instrument panel included two trip odometers, which keep fuel economy separate from day-trip mileage, and the dash included two cup holders. For storage there were compartments in the front doors and pockets behind the front seats. The lockable glove box was good sized; someone had remembered to rig it up to drop slowly and quietly, a nice detail.
And the trunk was practically a bottomless pit. At 20.6 cubic feet, the trunk of the '97 model is second only to the Town Car, which golfers celebrate for its ability to tote four bags of clubs. On a family trip, the Grand Marquis swallowed two large suitcases, two garment bags, a set of golf clubs, a modest-sized cardboard box and four small duffel bags. No wonder traveling salespeople love this trunk.
In the 1998 redesigns, the Town Car's trunk will lose nearly two cubic feet of cargo room. The way the rear window slopes down cuts into space at the back of the trunk. The '98 Mercury's rear window design is similar but the trunk will turn out to be the same size as the '97.
When I tested this car, I tended to notice who else was driving them. And virtually all the drivers I spotted looked as if they were, well, enjoying their retirement -- or getting ready for it. Ford acknowledges that the average buyer is up there in years, reflecting the car's appeal to a generation that grew up in roomy, rear-drive cars. The disadvantage is that they won't be buyers forever.
But there is one advantage to having customers with extra time on their hands. On next year's auto show circuit, enthusiastic Grand Marquis owners will be at the exhibits, Ford says, to talk about how much they like their Mercurys.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A car for the ages.

HEADLINE: Slowly, U.S. Is Returning Some Envoys To the Sudan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Revising its strategy of treating the Sudan as a complete pariah state, the Clinton Administration decided this week to put a handful of diplomats back in Khartoum to press the North African nation to stop harboring Palestinian, Lebanese, Egyptian and Algerian terrorists.
The Sudan's Islamic Government welcomed the announcement as a victory in its efforts to soften the American diplomatic line against it. But Administration officials said that sending diplomats back to the Sudan would allow the United States to increase pressure on Khartoum. 
 The United States says the Sudan is guilty of promoting slavery, torturing Christians, conspiring to plan the bombing of the United Nations headquarters and other New York City landmarks in 1993 and participating in an assassination attempt on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in 1995.
"With a permanent presence, we can nudge and push and argue," said Timothy M. Carney, the United States Ambassador to the Sudan, who was removed from Khartoum, the capital, in February 1996 with his staff of 24 diplomats and Marine Corps guards.
Up to eight American officials, though not Mr. Carney, will return to Khartoum over the next few months to investigate human rights abuses, monitor and encourage peace talks between the Government and a rebel army operating in the southern Sudan, and to push Khartoum to fulfill its recent public promises to oppose terrorism, State Department officials said.
Administration officials said the new embassy staff also would be able to gather intelligence on a number of terrorist groups they say are operating out of the Sudan, including the Lebanese Party of God, or Hezbollah; Hamas, and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad.
The question of whether it is better to isolate or to talk with hostile states like the Sudan, Iran, Libya or North Korea is as old as diplomacy itself. No easy answers have emerged.
In early 1996, John M. Deutch, who was then the Central Intelligence Agency's director, persuaded the Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, to remove American diplomats from Khartoum, citing rising security concerns. Over the last nine months, a consensus emerged within the State Department and the C.I.A. to reopen the diplomatic mission, Administration officials said, but two senior members of the National Security Council staff argued against reversing policy.
"The question was whether we would be giving the regime too much comfort," Mr. Carney, a consistent proponent of engagement with the Sudan, said in a telephone interview.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright broke the deadlock this month, Administration officials said, after concluding that the Sudanese Government's more moderate public stance over the last year should be tested. But to make sure that Washington's intentions are not misunderstood, the Administration will increase levels of nonlethal military aid to Ethiopia and Eritrea, two countries fighting insurgencies supported by the Sudan, said a State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The Administration is also considering new economic sanctions against Khartoum as well as renewed diplomatic efforts to persuade France and other European countries not to develop their economic relations with the Sudan.
Mr. Carney said he would not return to Khartoum, so the embassy will be staffed by lower-ranking diplomats. Instead, he will continue to shuttle between his home in Nairobi, Kenya, and Khartoum, as he has since he was withdrawn.
Mahdi Ibrahim Mohamed, the Sudan's Ambassador to Washington, said he viewed the Administration's willingness to put diplomats back in Khartoum as a major development toward improving relations. "This is a natural step in the direction of deepening the dialogue," he said.
Asked if his Government would now respond to American concerns about the Sudanese Government's alleged encouragement of terrorism, he said, "I don't want to be dragged into issues that only perpetuate hostilities between our two countries."
Mr. Mohamed's repeated pleas for warmer relations since his arrival in Washington in February 1996 have been part of a concerted effort by the Sudan to promote a more moderate image. Last year, the ruling National Islamic Front deported Osama bin Laden, a Saudi-born financier of extremist groups, and also turned the famed terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal over to France.
Mr. Carney noted that the Sudan had indicated that it was ready to sever its relations with other terrorists, but that its "efforts have been discreet and not insistent." With a permanent American diplomatic presence in the Sudan, he said, "We will press Khartoum to make good on its continual public statements that it opposes terrorism."

HEADLINE: Panama Leader Accused of Cronyism Over Appointees to Run the Canal

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
As a presidential candidate in 1994, Ernesto Perez Balladares was burdened by voters' misgivings about his party's unsavory ties to the deposed dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. To allay those fears, he promised that, if elected, he would treat the Panama Canal not as the spoils of victory, but as the jewel of the national patrimony.
Now, having announced his choices for the board of directors that will run the vital waterway after the United States hands it over to Panama in 1999, Mr. Perez Balladares is being accused of breaking his word. Among his nominees to what will be an 11-member board are four members of his own or his wife's family, including a first cousin, a son-in-law and the spouses of two other cousins. 
 In addition, Mr. Perez Balladares has appointed one of the chief fund-raisers of his election campaign, a businessman famous for being embroiled in lawsuits. Other selections include two leading members of the Revolutionary Democratic Party who served General Noriega as his Foreign Minister and Interior Minister, and the son of Mr. Perez Balladares's own former Foreign Minister.
Reaction to the President's appointments among opposition groups, unions and the press has been caustic and angry. A cartoon published in the country's leading newspaper, La Prensa, early in September showed Mr. Perez Balladares greedily stuffing himself with pieces of a birthday cake labeled "Canal" as a voice calls out, "Darling, your relatives have arrived," while four other hands reach for portions.
In an editorial, the newspaper reproached Mr. Perez Balladares for violating "a tacit understanding among the leaders of all parties that the Canal is to be placed above and beyond the political fray" and "out of the reach of ignoble appetites." With the naming of the new board, the newspaper continued, "the Canal has been converted into a fount of juicy sinecures for the relatives and associates of the President."
As required by a pair of treaties signed 20 years ago, the waterway is currently managed by the Panama Canal Commission, an American Government agency whose board has five American and four Panamanian members. At noon on Dec. 31, 1999, that panel will give way to the Panama Canal Authority, to be directed by the all-Panamanian board appointed by the Government here.
Shipping companies and foreign governments have never questioned the ability of ordinary canal employees, whose professionalism and dedication to the waterway were demonstrated during the Noriega dictatorship. Already, more than 92 percent of the waterway's 9,800 workers, including more than two-thirds of the pilots who steer ships through the canal, are Panamanians.
Nor have the qualifications of the Panama Canal's administrator, Alberto Aleman Zubieta, been challenged. A Panamanian engineer educated in the United States, Mr. Aleman was appointed last year, and has been praised as a capable and impartial civil servant by shippers concerned about the canal's transition from American to Panamanian hands.
But shippers, diplomats, canal employees and their unions have not expressed the same confidence in Mr. Perez Balladares's decision to turn to relatives, friends and political associates to set canal policy.
"This sends the wrong signal to everyone who uses the canal and wonders if Panama can run it as efficiently and honestly as the Americans," said a European shipping company executive who attended a congress on the future of the canal held here Sept. 7 to 10.
Jorge E. Ritter, whom Mr. Perez Balladares appointed in July as Minister of Canal Affairs and has named to head the future Panama Canal Authority, did not respond to requests for an interview regarding the board's composition. But in an interview late last year, he argued that while "being a friend of the President cannot be the only credential, neither should it be an impediment."
In addition, Joe R. Reeder, the American chairman of the Panama Canal Commission, said in early September that some of the local criticism of Mr. Perez Balladares's choices was unfair and misdirected. Several of the nominees, he pointed out, already serve as members of the commission or the technical or legal working groups that are overseeing the transition.
"I know almost all of them, and I couldn't be more pleased," he said. "In a nation of under three million people, there are many relationships among the established families. But I think the key is the quality and background these individuals bring as successful businessmen and bankers already involved intimately in the business of the canal."
 On Sept. 15, in a move that analysts of canal affairs called surprising, Mr. Reeder announced that he was resigning. His successor is expected to be named in October.
But the prominence of Mr. Ritter, who served first as Panama's Ambassador to Colombia and then as Foreign Minister when General Noriega was in power, is itself seen by many here as a sign of politicization of the canal's administration. Though regarded as enjoying the President's confidence, Mr. Ritter is neither an engineer nor a transportation expert, and testimony during General Noriega's 1991 trial in Miami implicated him in the sale of a car to a member of a Colombian drug cartel.
"We still have to show him where Miraflores is," a union official said in jest, referring to a set of locks just north of the capital. When the United States ran the canal alone, the official said, the board "used to have people who had something to do with transportation, who didn't draw a blank when you said the word 'ship.' "
Concerns about nepotism have been fed by a recent controversy in which a company owned by a cousin of the President, Nicolas Gonzalez Revilla, acquired a virtual stranglehold on television broadcasting in Panama. Mr. Perez Balladares is also a shareholder in the company, Medios Panamenos, which originally owned just one of the country's three networks.
Over the last year, however, Mr. Gonzalez Revilla has gained control of a second network and the country's only cable television service. Press reports here have suggested that the acquisitions were completed and approved with unusual swiftness so that they would not run afoul of a new anti-trust law that, in effect, prevents the emergence of any serious rival.
During the same period, the Government also canceled the license it had awarded to a company that had outbid Mr. Gonzalez Revilla for authorization to offer satellite dish service here. That process, which local press reports said was rife with irregularities, has greatly enhanced the profitability and value of Medios Panamenos, diplomats and bankers here said.
More recently, the Government has been embroiled in a dispute over oddities in the privatization of two ports at either end of the Panama Canal. Last year, five American companies were passed over in favor of a Hong Kong company, Hutchison Whampoa, after a bidding process that the American Ambassador here, William Hughes, criticized as "unfair" and "lacking in transparency."
Now, it appears that Hutchison Whampoa may have also been granted 106 acres of valuable real estate set aside for a railway modernization project being undertaken by an American railroad company. The director of the National Port Authority, Hugo Torrijos, did not respond to requests for an interview to discuss the confusion, but news reports here say that developers of a new airport and a shopping mall may also have claims to pieces of the same parcel.
The United States Transportation Secretary, Rodney Slater, here during the congress on the future of the canal, said Panama had shown signs of responding "to some of the questions that have been raised there." But, he said, "Those are the things people will continue to monitor and focus on."
Amid these controversies, Mr. Perez Balladares, who is scheduled to leave office on Sept. 1, 1999, is attempting to have Panama's Constitution amended so that he can be re-elected. Ever since the country gained its independence from Colombia 94 years ago, no President has been allowed to succeed himself in office.
Under the current Constitution, Mr. Perez Balladares would have to wait two terms, or 10 years, before being eligible to run again. But the Legislative Assembly, which his party controls, is expected to approve soon a proposal that would set a date for a referendum sometime next year on whether Mr. Perez Balladares can remain in office for a second consecutive term, until 2004.
Almost as soon as it takes control of the canal, Panama will have to decide whether to build a new set of locks to accommodate increasing traffic -- a project expected to cost at least $6.5 billion -- and which construction companies should be given the task. There are also proposals afoot, shippers and canal workers say, to privatize some potentially lucrative canal services, such as maintenance.
"Whoever is in power for the next term will have the opportunity to take some big decisions and grant some important contracts," said Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former Vice President and a leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Party. "That generates economic power, and if not done transparently, offers ways to favor certain economic interests and law firms."

HEADLINE: The World;
Poland Achieves Politics as Usual

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
THE change of government in Poland from the remodeled former Communists to the heirs of the fiercely anti-Communist Solidarity movement was surprise enough in last week's elections. But will this mean much difference in the direction of increasingly prosperous, westward-looking Poland? Probably not.
The big news was not so much the results of the vote but the widespread feeling that Poland had achieved a milestone in the deepening of its democratic process. 
 If a mature democracy is marked by broad consensus on most issues, Poland seems to be fast approaching adulthood. George Wallace used to say about the big American political parties, "Not a dime's worth of difference." Indeed, some in the Polish press equate the two major parties to American counterparts: for shorthand, the former Communists, paradoxically, are referred to as the Republicans (supported by big business) and Solidarity as the Democrats (supported by trade unions).
The difference in the origins of Poland's two main political parties could not be more stark: they were, to begin, Communists and anti-Communists. But each side -- in Solidarity's case it is not so much a party as an umbrella for more than three dozen groups -- has been nudged toward the center. Both sides agree that Poland's security depends on membership in NATO and its economic well-being on entry to the European Union.
Within these broad strands of agreement, there are, of course, differences on how to achieve them.
Solidarity's supporters tend to work in heavy industry and agriculture, two sectors that will be adversely affected by integration into Europe. Hence, Solidarity is more Euro-skeptical. As it proceeds with Poland's accession to NATO, Solidarity will tend to follow Washington's lead rather than voices from the European capitals.
At home, Solidarity voters were expressing discontent with a judicial system subject to political pressure from the last four years of rule by the former Communists and a civil service packed with recruits from the old guard. Some politicians, helped by having cronies at the helm of big industries, controlled whole chunks of the economy, a situation that rankled.
 
The Big Two
On these and similar issues, the voters made their choices. But many, demonstrating that they had learned much about the realities of political parties, abandoned smaller parties they had favored in the past and chose instead between the big two.
"This is real progress," said Wojciech Pawlak, the president of OBOP, the major Polish polling organization. "Voters realized that the smaller parties are irrelevant." Thus, Poland has moved from a series of fragmented Parliaments in the first few years after the fall of Communism to a "fairly non-representative Parliament" in the last four years to a "most representative Parliament," Mr. Pawlak said.
More than 30 percent of the voters in the 1993 parliamentary elections voted for small parties that did not get more than 5 percent of the total -- the threshold for representation in Parliament. This time, some minor parties joined forces with Solidarity; those that still insisted on fielding candidates were virtually ignored by the voters.
There were other tactical moves by the increasingly sophisticated electorate. Some who opposed the return of the former Communists voted for Solidarity, even while they really preferred the centrist Freedom Union party, led by Leszek Balcerowicz, to insure a big margin for Solidarity. As it turned out, Solidarity won with 34 percent, followed by the former Communists, known as the Left Democratic Alliance, with 27 percent. The Freedom Union, the choice of the emerging business and professional class, intellectuals and former dissidents, received 13 percent. Solidarity and Freedom Union started negotiations after the vote about the shape of the coalition government they plan to form.
It took little time for the former Communists to understand that they had been badly beaten. They announced that they would form a "loyal opposition" in Parliament, an important promise if Poland's current economic growth -- an annual rate of about 6 percent -- is to be maintained.
President Aleksander Kwasniewski, a telegenic 47-year-old former Communist, who enjoys high ratings, seemed disappointed, though not chagrined, that his popularity did not translate into more votes for his party. He sounded almost enthusiastic about the prospect of cohabitation with a government from the opposite side of the political spectrum, and admonished his own party leaders for running a "nothing" campaign.
The conclusion seemed to be that this was yet more proof of how discerning Polish voters had become since their first heady days of democracy. It was only seven years ago that an unknown Canadian businessman with Polish roots, Stanislaw Tyminski, promised instant wealth to Poles and defeated the well known Polish Catholic intellectual Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the first round of the presidential elections.
Last week's surprise could hardly compare. And as if to show that Poland had become an exceedingly normal country, foreign investment interests, which had generally preferred the former Communists, seemed unfazed by the Solidarity victory. "Who won?" asked an American banking executive in Warsaw after being been locked in meetings the day after the election. The result, he conceded, was unlikely to have an effect on his booming business.

HEADLINE: High-Technology Job Fair Is Now an Industry in Itself

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Allied Signal Aerospace has a chronic need for embedded software developers, people who write the programs that are already installed when someone buys a computer. That is why Christopher A. Lewis, a senior staffing consultant, was at a Tech Expo job fair recently, schmoozing and collecting resumes.
"The competition for these people is so intense, that even if I only hire two of them, it's worth it," he said. 
 The Metropolitan Museum of Art only needed a couple of people to run its data systems. But it took a booth anyway at the most recent fair held by Net Result Technical Job Fairs Inc. "The fair puts our name out as a bona fide employer for high-tech people," said Peggy Saldok, the museum's deputy administrator for human resources.
People in other professions can bemoan corporate cutbacks. But when it comes to people with technological skills, the supply never seems to approach demand.
All of which may cause nightmares for information technology managers. But it is the stuff of the sweetest dreams to one of the latest nascent industries to spin off from the high-technology world: job fairs.
"This business is just exploding," said Richard Johnson, president of Net Result.
It is also getting cutthroat. Some job fair entrepreneurs seem to wait until a competitor has advertised a fair, then schedule theirs a day earlier. And corporate recruiters report that when they participate in one fair, they inevitably are offered a steep discount at competing ones.
The ploy can work. Manpower Technical Services went to a recent Tech Expo fair because "they cut us a very good deal," said Karl Muhlbauer Jr., a recruiter at Manpower.
The concept of a job fair -- a place where job seekers and recruiters meet and greet in a trade-show-like atmosphere -- is nothing new. Universities use them to place graduates. Corporations hold them in collaboration with professional associations of women, minorities or other groups that are underrepresented in the work force. Many newspapers, The New York Times among them, now hold job fairs as a free service for major advertisers.
But none of those fairs are held for profit, and few focus exclusively on technology jobs. Until recently, the for-profit segment of the market also catered primarily to companies looking for sales and office staff.
Not anymore. One by one, longtime job fair companies like the Lendman Group in Virginia Beach, Va., which started holding sales and clerical fairs in 1964, and Tech Expo in New York, whose parent Job Expo International started with sales fairs in 1992, have branched into technology jobs. And myriad newcomers like Net Result have sprung up solely to match programmers, software engineers and such with new homes.
The fairs generally cost less than $30,000 each to hold. Companies pay $2,000 to $4,500 to participate -- less than the cost of a prominent major-market newspaper ad. "We don't find price resistance," said Ernest M. Lendman, chairman of the Lendman Group, which recently raised its rate by $500, to $4,250.
Virtually no one knows how many job fair companies there are. But the ranks are clearly swelling.
"I cannot tell you how much correspondence and mail we get wanting us to attend fairs," said Jennie L. Mays, manager of experienced professional recruiting at I.B.M., which participates in 6 to 10 fairs a month.
Clearly, the fairs meet a need. The New York Times used to get about 70 exhibitors at each of its four annual fairs. More than 100 companies showed up for its fair last Thursday.
For applicants, the fairs provide a way to interact with dozens of potential employers, and a safe way to check what is out there, whether they have the right skills, and if they are being paid enough.
"I haven't been job hunting, but I'm here to see if I should be," said one young jeans-clad man who dropped in on the Tech Expo fair.
The fairs have multiple lures for corporations, too. Good fairs will expose a company to 2,000 technology candidates. They let recruiters measure the salaries they offer against that of the competition. And, they provide leads to clients. "The job fairs let us meet people we might hire, and people who might hire us," Mr. Muhlbauer of Manpower said.
Of course, all that is predicated on a well-attended job fair. One bad showing, and corporate clients move on for good. "I have no use for a fair that pulls 200 people," said Mr. Lewis of Allied Signal, who has whittled down the number of fairs he attends.
Setting up a successful job fair can be like walking a minefield. Pick the wrong space, and applicants will not show up, as Westech Expocorp discovered when its fair at the inconveniently situated Javits Center in Manhattan pulled about a quarter of the traffic that Tech Expo's same-day fair commanded at the centrally situated Sheraton Center.
Advertise in too narrow a venue -- say, newspapers to the exclusion of the Internet or commute-time radio shows -- and the applicant pool will be equally small.
"You need to reach the person who isn't looking to answer an ad," said Fred Faltersack, Westech's president.
But perhaps most important, try to run a high-technology fair in low-technology mode, and failure is assured. Until recently, a job fair company only provided exhibit space, a private area to interview promising candidates, and maybe a free lunch or afternoon snack. It would include each company's name in pre-fair advertising and in employment guides handed out to candidates.
Nowadays, practically every job fair company has its own World Wide Web site, and many have links to large Internet career sites like Career Mosaic. Companies and applicants alike post information about themselves a week or so before the fair. Some job fair companies even hold reduced-fee virtual fairs, in which companies and applicants can interact without coming to the fair.
The job fair companies keep the postings on the net for a couple of weeks after the fair. They also gather resumes at the fairs, and provide them to participating corporations either as hard copies or CD-ROM's.
The technological bells and whistles cost money, and not all of the added costs can be passed on in higher prices. Inevitably, many job fair companies have left the business. Even the survivors are finding their profit margins shaved razor thin. "If three or four companies don't pay, there goes my profit," said Bradford Rand, president of Tech Expo, which expects revenues of nearly $3 million this year, twice last year's number.
Not surprisingly, many of the job fair companies are looking for merger partners to get expansion capital.
"Our revenues are $13 million a year now, but with the right capitalization we could do $100 million," said Mr. Lendman, who is in merger talks with a media company.
Last year, Central Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Indianapolis Star and The Arizona Republic, bought 80 percent of Westech. The new parent's deep pockets let Westech, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and had concentrated on the West and Southwest, purchase Target Career Fairs, an East Coast company. The combined company will hold nearly 70 job fairs this year, and bring in close to $32 million.
"It made no sense to add to the East Coast competition when we could hook up with a strong competitor," Mr. Faltersack said.
It was probably a wise decision. Despite the nasty competition, the job fair companies are developing their cadre of loyalists. "We stick to the fairs that are proven draws," Ms. Mays of I.B.M. said. "A $500 discount doesn't make a difference."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Job fairs are the latest growth sector in technology. A job seeker talked with a potential employer earlier this month at a fair in Woburn, Mass. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Microsoft vs. Netscape: The Border War Heats Up

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The software war between Microsoft and Netscape escalates this week, as each company moves more aggressively onto the other's technological turf.
The Microsoft Corporation plans to ship to customers the long-delayed fourth version of its Internet Explorer browser software. The program is designed to give users almost seamless integration between the World Wide Web and the desktop display of the personal computer. 
 In fact, so tightly does the new Microsoft software link the Internet to the P.C.'s hard disk that some industry executives and consumer advocates see the program as raising troubling new questions about the vast economic clout wielded by the Redmond, Wash., software giant.
The Netscape Communications Corporation, meanwhile, hopes to blunt the impact of Microsoft's rollout by demonstrating its own Web-to-P.C. integration software on Monday at an industry trade show here. Code-named Aurora, the program is designed as a component of Netscape's Communicator Web-browser software and is intended to offer users a smoother ride between the Internet and files stored on their own P.C.'s.
With Microsoft the dominant provider of P.C. operating system software and Netscape still the leader in Web-browser software, each company is trying to use its own foothold to get a leg up on the competition. Microsoft, in effect, is trying to subsume Internet navigation into the P.C. operating system. Netscape's approach is to try to make operating the P.C. and surfing the Internet virtually synonymous.
Consumer advocates are increasingly concerned about Microsoft's power over ever-broader swaths of the software business. Earlier this month, for example, Ralph Nader met with the three top officials in the Justice Department's antitrust division in an effort to convince them that Microsoft's monopoly over personal computer operating system software is detrimental to the public.
"We think it's an outrage that the Justice Department hasn't taken action to stop Microsoft," said James Love, director of Mr. Nader's lobbying group, the Consumer Project on Technology.
Microsoft's Internet Explorer 4.0 will be distributed by computer makers and Internet service providers and will be accessible free from Microsoft's World Wide Web site beginning on Tuesday. The program is a precursor to the Windows 98 operating system, which Microsoft plans to introduce next year and which is to completely integrate the desktop personal computer and the Internet.
Although Netscape still has a significant lead, controlling 70 to 75 percent of the browser market, Microsoft is intent on shipping tens of millions of copies of its new browser.
The most visually striking aspect of the new software is what Microsoft is calling the Active Desktop, which adds an array of 30 corporate logos to the basic control panel or P.C. "dashboard."
The feature makes it possible to reach many popular Internet locations with a single mouse click. Company logos on the new dashboard include those of the Walt Disney Company, Time Warner, America Online, National Geographic, Pointcast, Intuit and others -- including Corbus, the electronic photograph archive owned by Microsoft's chairman, William Gates.
Such prime placement on the Active Desktop screen, tantamount to an advertisement, is likely to mean that the Web sites of these companies will get even heavier traffic.
Microsoft executives said that the company had not charged money for placement on the Active Desktop and that a user would be able to delete the logos, if desired. But critics are saying that the display screen will nonetheless become an electronic choke point that gives Microsoft and its allies powerful control over which information on the Internet is seen by the most Web travelers.
"The question is, 'Who owns your keyboard and the pixels on your screen?' " said Daniel Nachbar, director of the Public Software Institute, a public-interest group in Amherst, Mass. "Do you or do the producers of information?
Mr. Nachbar said his organization was in the early stages of designing an alternative browser that will have the equivalent of a "mute" button to block out Internet advertisements.
The heated competition between Microsoft and Netscape over the browser market is turning out to be more beneficial to advertisers than to consumers, Mr. Love said.
But Microsoft executives contend that the newest version of its Internet Explorer actually gives users more and easier options for customizing the software to their own needs.
"You can either add or delete things with a single click of the mouse," said Yusuf Mehdi, director of marketing for Microsoft's Internet software division. "We're giving users an unprecedented amount of control over the information on the Web that they've never had before."

HEADLINE: At F.C.C. Confirmation Hearings, Emphasis Will Be on Competition

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
When William E. Kennard, President Clinton's nominee for the chairman's post of the Federal Communications Commission, sits down at his Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday, the biggest implicit question may not be his fitness for the job but whom he will listen to in Washington once he gets it.
It is close to a foregone conclusion within the capital's telecommunications fraternity that absent a bombshell revelation, Mr. Kennard and the three other people who have been nominated to the F.C.C. will be approved by the Senate Commerce Committee. As is often the case within the Beltway, the essential politicking over the nominations occurred before they were even announced. 
 But Mr. Kennard's hearing on Wednesday, and those tomorrow of the other commission nominees -- Harold Furchtgott-Roth, Michael Powell and Gloria Tristani -- are nonetheless expected to be among the best attended, and most closely watched, confirmation proceedings of the year.
In the wake of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which was meant to open most parts of the communications industry to competition, the F.C.C. has become perhaps the most prominent regulatory panel in Washington.
But it is the act's failure to create such widespread competition, at least so far, that is expected to have the senators exercised on Wednesday. They will want to know what Mr. Kennard, the F.C.C.'s general counsel, intends to do about it. And some may try to influence his thinking.
"I don't think this hearing will be about whether Bill Kennard has the qualifications," said Scott Blake Harris, a former head of the F.C.C.'s international bureau. "This will be a hearing where the senators share their concerns about the Telecom Act of 1996."
Mr. Kennard declined to be interviewed for this article.
The F.C.C. has regulatory responsibility for a broad swath of the economy. But despite concerns about the growing concentration of ownership of radio and television stations and debates about the responsibilities of broadcasters to provide digital broadcasts and public service programming, many politicians and regulators are more worried by the absence of competition in most local telecommunications markets.
Nearly 18 months after the act was signed into law, the rich competition that the bill's proponents predicted would emerge in local telephone and cable television markets has not developed. Most Americans live in a world where there is one local telephone company and one cable television provider.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and chairman of the Commerce Committee, has been a blunt critic of the law, which he says gave the F.C.C. too much power over the entry of companies into new lines of business. Rather than embrace competition, in Mr. McCain's view, the F.C.C. has impeded it.
"The telecommunications reform act has been over all a failure," he said in a telephone interview last week. "We've got rising cable rates, rising long-distance rates, mergers instead of competition, failure of parts of the telecommunications industry to get into others.
"I'd like to see a much less bureaucratic commission," he added, "a commission that will implement the Telecommunications Act so they don't get their actions stayed in court every time."
As the commission's top lawyer, Mr. Kennard has led a general counsel's office that has won about 85 percent of its cases in Federal appeals court -- an impressive record for an agency that finds almost every decision of consequence drawing an appeal from one disgruntled faction or another. Yet the Kennard record has not spared the commission the derision of some members of Congress for losing a case brought by dozens of states after the F.C.C. invoked the Telecommunications Act in trying to dictate how local phone monopolies should open their networks to competitors.
In July, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis ruled that states have the right to set essential terms of competition within their borders.
The issue is not going away, however. The decision by the appeals court has not deterred the commission from continuing to pursue the Federal approach to deregulating the telecommunications industry that was charted by Reed E. Hundt, its departing chairman and a close adviser to Vice President Al Gore. One of the chief concerns of the Commerce Committee's Republican majority is how Mr. Kennard, a Democrat, intends to deal with state regulators.
On Friday, Mr. Hundt's F.C.C. overruled regulations in Texas that it described as standing in the way of competiton. The commission rejected regulations that would have prevented large long-distance carriers in Texas like the MCI Communications Corporation from offering local telephone service in areas served by tiny local companies.
The commission also struck down a Texas regulation that would have required large long-distance carriers to build extensive local networks of their own rather than simply reselling a local phone company's service.
Congress "wanted us to guarantee that states truly have a level playing field," Mr. Hundt said. "We have done that."
Friday's actions are almost certain to draw fire from local telephone companies and their supporters in addition to Republican members of the committee, who tend to be sympathetic to the rights of state and local governments.
"The commission is going to have to have some sort of realization that local governments will have a big part to play in their policy," said Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, who is a member of the committee.
State and local governments, meanwhile, tend to be more sympathetic than the F.C.C. toward the regional Bell companies, which are big local employers and taxpayers.
Representative W. J. Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who leads the House subcommittee on telecommunications and who wields influence on telecommunications issues in both houses of Congress, is also one of the F.C.C.'s chief critics. "They are setting the bar for Bell entry into long-distance unnecessarily high," Mr. Tauzin said. "There is a reluctance within the F.C.C. itself to get this competition going because it makes them less relevant."
But criticizing the F.C.C. is not only a Republican sport. Sen. Ernest Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina and the ranking minority member of the Commerce Committee, defends the Telecommunications Act as "a good bill" but is also critical of the F.C.C.'s posture. "We've got to break that lawyer approach," he said.
But the commission does have its defenders on Capitol Hill. Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who is Mr. Tauzin's Democratic counterpart as the ranking minority member of the House telecommunications subcommittee, said the Bell companies, not the F.C.C., were to blame for the slow pace of competition.
"I don't think anyone anticipated the vehement opposition that the regional Bell companies would mount to any meaningful competition in their local marketplace," he said. "We're trying to break down a 100-year-old monopoly in the local loop and it's not going to be surrendered easily."
As F.C.C. chairman, Mr. Hundt has put a low priority on catering to Capitol Hill. But Mr. Kennard, whom Mr. Hundt named the commission's general counsel in 1993, appears to have avoided being tarred by association with his boss, even by some of the commission's harshest critics.
"He is extremely intelligent," Mr. Tauzin said. "It would be wrong to judge him on the basis of his service to Reed Hundt. I'm prepared to encourage his confirmation."
Senator McCain was more circumspect in his praise.
"Would he have been my nominee? No," he said. "I have real questions about his underlying philosophy, but I do not see a reason to disqualify him -- yet."
Mr. Kennard was widely seen as a compromise candidate. Senator Hollings originally supported one of his former aides, Ralph Everett, for the chairman's post, while Vice President Gore had backed Kathleen Wallman, a former head of the commission's Common Carrier Bureau, who is now a White House lawyer.
Mr. Furchtgott-Roth, chief economist for the Commerce Committee, is one of two Republican nominees for the commission and was tapped by Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, said people on Capitol Hill who insisted on anonymity.
Senator McCain chose the other Republican nominee for the five-member commission, Mr. Powell, the chief of staff of the antitrust division at the Justice Department and a son of Gen. Colin Powell.
Ms. Tristani, a Democratic telephone regulator from New Mexico, is perceived by many in Washington as a representative of the interests of rural states.
The fifth member of the commission is Susan Ness, a Democrat, who is retaining her seat.
