HEADLINE: Arts in America;
In Nashville, It's Not the Same Old Song Anymore

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Late Wednesday night, as the tourists, music business executives and the biggest stars in country music celebrated the Country Music Association awards here in renowned venues like Opryland, the Wildhorse Saloon and the Sunset Grill, Ernest Van Trease nursed a beer at Third and Lindsley's, a roomy honky-tonk on the outskirts of downtown.
Mr. Van Trease, 56, who was born here, has played keyboards for Ray Charles for more than a decade. He was among the few dozen jazz fans who stayed up past midnight at midweek to hear the final set of a high-decibel rock-jazz fusion band of considerable skill led by two local brothers, the Wootens, with Reggie on guitar and Joe on keyboards. It was loud, raucous, occasionally dissonant and frequently stirring. It wasn't anywhere near country music, and when a newcomer to the bar, probably the only out-of-towner in the place, expressed surprise, Mr. Van Trease's response was, "Nashville is full of music nobody knows about." 
 As it happens, Nashville is not only full of music nobody knows about, it's more or less empty of the music everybody knows about. People say it all the time: there's nowhere to go to hear top-flight country music.
"If you want to go to a club to hear music, you'll have a hard time hearing country," said Steve Turner, a well-known session drummer who has played behind Dolly Parton and also plays jazz.
There is some hyperbole in this, but the point is that the live music scene in Nashville is not exactly as its reputation would have it. Country music is still the economic foundation of the music business here, of course, but rock, rhythm-and-blues and, increasingly, jazz, have become the staples of nightlife; country is more of an export commodity. Part of the reason, said Tony Brown, country music producer and the president of MCA Nashville, is that most country musicians come to town from elsewhere because they are tired of having to play in clubs.
"They aspire to play sessions," Mr. Brown said. "Here if you play in a club you're probably not good enough to play on recordings." On the other hand, he added, "It's a cool thing to see a successful player at a jazz club, because you know he's doing it for the music."
At the same time, the success of the music industry here has created a vast pool of talented players, country and otherwise, who are here for the work. With 26 record labels in town, each of which has maybe 15 performers in its stable, there is an enormous amount of recording going on in hundreds of studios. For musicians tired of the itinerant life or unable to make ends meet in places like New York and Los Angeles, Nashville is a natural alternative.
"The technology's here and the players are as good as anyplace else," said Jim Hoke, a saxophonist with the rock band NRBQ who led his new nine-piece jazz ensemble, Hoke and the Jump Daddies, into Third and Lindsley's on Thursday. "Plus, you can park your car." And many who work sessions in the studios by day or tour with the country stars who live here, are interested in their off hours in exercising different, noncountry chops. "I came here to play steel guitar 20 years ago," said Mel Deal, the Jump Daddies' guitarist, "and I just got tired of hanging out with those country guys."
A result has been a expansion in the range of local talent. "We have a wonderful musician pool now," said Cliff Richmond, a guitarist and leader of a popular local jazz band, the CliffNotes. Mr. Richmond, who moved here 19 years ago and runs a tutoring business to supplement his income, sees the growing numbers of musicians whetting the local appetite for jazz. "It's like that biological soup that made humans," he said.
No one is saying that jazz is about to replace country music as the local industry. But there are signs that the taste of the town is being modified. A light jazz radio station, WJZC-FM, the city's first (a public station, WMOT, devoted to traditional jazz, is in nearby Murfreesboro) began broadcasting last December, and has steadily increased its audience, said its program director, Billy Shears. This fall, two concerts, one featuring Chick Corea and Gary Burton and the other Herbie Hancock and Wayne Shorter, are booked at the 2,000-seat Ryman Auditorium.
Ron Brice, the owner of Third and Lindsley's, has just expanded his club for the second time, to 225 seats, up from 100 five years ago. And Pino Squillace, owner of Caffe Milano, a year-old upscale downtown club that has presented Branford Marsalis, Bela Fleck and the Flecktones, Nancy Wilson and John Pizzarelli (Chuck Mangione is also to perform), is also expanding. "I remember people saying to me, 'What are you? Nuts? A jazz club in Nashville?"' Mr. Squillace said. "But I always believed there was a place for it. And it worked."
Last weekend, in the wake of the city's biggest annual country music extravaganza, jazz was all over town. At the cavernous Ace of Clubs on Second Avenue, El Bu'ho, a trumpeter also known as Gary Gazzaway who has played with the rock band Phish, led his acid, Latin-tinged electric ensemble; a traditional trio, Birdsong, played the tiny lounge of F. Scott's in the southwestern Green Hills section of town, just around the corner from the famous country songwriters' showcase, the Bluebird Cafe, and there were the Wooten Brothers and the Jump Daddies, a band whose sound is like a melding of the Duke Ellington and Lyle Lovett big bands.
"It's a small scene, but it's pretty good," said Pat McDonald, 31, a drummer for the Wooten Brothers who, very early Thursday morning after the final set, was considering not going to sleep at all; he had to leave at sunup on the bus with Tanya Tucker. "You can't stay alive just playing clubs. But one night a week you get to do something hip."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Off the country road: Hoke and the Jump Daddies, a jazz ensemble, at Third and Lindsley's in Nashville. (Christopher Berkey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Pound Is Steadier as Britain Denies Change of Euro Plans

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The pound steadied a bit yesterday from a sharp selloff on Friday after several British ministers over the weekend denied that there had been a change in the Government's policy on European monetary union.
The dollar was little changed against most other major currencies as traders awaited important economic reports in Japan and the United States as well as a possible move on interest rates by the Bundesbank. 
 The pound was spurred higher by weekend comments from the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, and the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, both of whom dismissed as speculation a report that the Government was considering joining the European single-currency union somewhat sooner than expected. Their comments followed a report on Friday in The Financial Times, quoting an unidentified Cabinet minister, that the Cabinet was discussing joining the monetary union shortly after the single currency, the euro, was introduced in 1999.
"I still think the threat of the U.K. going back into the E.M.U. is probably going to hang over sterling," said Bob Steiner, a currency trader at the Mellon Bank.
Also bolstering the pound yesterday were stronger-than-expected British economic data, including consumer credit for August, September money supply and a survey showing a healthy increase in British house prices in September.
The pound rose as high as $1.6206 before settling in New York trading at $1.6093, down from $1.6111 on Friday. The dollar was also quoted at 1.7621 marks, up from 1.7577 marks, and 120.95 yen, down from 121.25 yen.
The dollar remained in a narrow range against most other major currencies.
Today, the Bundesbank will announce the terms for its weekly auction. A move to a variable rate rather than the current 3 percent fixed rate would be seen as the first move toward higher interest rates in Germany. The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee also meets today, though the Fed is expected to leave rates unchanged.
Tomorrow, the Bank of Japan will release its quarterly business sentiment survey, and on Friday, the United States will issue the September employment report.

HEADLINE: Albert G. Hart, 88, Monetary Policy Specialist

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Albert Gailord Hart, a former professor of economics at Columbia University known for his research in monetary policy and economic development, died Sept. 19at his home in Sherman, Conn., at the age of 88.
Mr. Hart, a graduate of Harvard College who earned his Ph.D. at the University of Chicago, was widely viewed as a rising star in the profession, turning down a coveted position at Chicago to come to Columbia in 1946. 
 He was best known among his peers for his book "Anticipations, Uncertainty and Dynamic Planning," which was published in 1940. "This was early and very exciting work, incorporating expectations and probability in economic models," recalled Paul Samuelson, the Nobel Prize-winning economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But Mr. Hart's deepest interests were in more practical aspects of economics. Early in his career, he worked on tax policy for the United States Treasury and the Committee for Economic Development -- in particular on reworking the income tax to make it more equitable. Later he focused on methods for fine-turning the control of the money supply, the Federal Government's key lever in trying to contain inflation and smooth the business cycle. And during the 1960's, he served as a consultant on public finance to the Governments of Chile and Venezuela, as well as to the Organization of American States.
The American Economic Association recognized his achievements in 1963, electing him to the largely honorary post of vice president.
His boundless energy and high-speed chatter gave him a reputation as a campus eccentric. But those who listened respected him for his intellectual insight and generosity. "People wrote books on ideas Albert tossed out," said Shirley Johnson-Lens, a former student of Mr. Hart who now teaches at Vassar College.
He did not confine his enthusiasm to economics. A singer and musician, he was a member of the New Amsterdam Singers and later conducted his own amateur choral groups.
Mr. Hart is survived by Ann Webster Hart, his wife of 61 years, and two children, Stephen Hart of Buffalo and Josephine Hart Bristol of Sherman, Conn.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mostly Flat; Trading Thin

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday in thin volume, as investors and traders awaited news from the Federal Reserve meeting today on monetary policy. Most expected no change.
Beyond the one-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting, market participants are focusing on other events that could influence trading this week, notably a monthly survey on the manufacturing economy from United States factory purchasing executives and the Labor Department's September employment data. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was down 8/32, to 99 29/32. The yield, which rises when the price falls, advanced to 6.38 percent, from 6.36 percent Friday. Shorter-term maturities were unchanged or marginally lower. The Commerce Department's report that August income rose six-tenths of 1 percent and spending gained three-tenths of 1 percent were within expectations, but some market participants used the data as an excuse to take profits. Overnight weakness set the tone for the session.
Today's Fed policy meeting was viewed largely as a nonevent. Almost everyone expects no shift in policy because inflation has still not become an immediate or future threat.
So the market's focus turned to the September manufacturing report by the National Association of Purchasing Management tomorrow and the Labor Department's monthly employment statistics on Friday. More often than not investors will demand a premium if they feel that are taking added risks ahead of market-moving numbers, particularly the employment data, which many view as the key to growth and inflation.
"For the past five years, there has been a major debate among economists, analysts and policy makers about the mystery of strong growth with no inflation." said Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a consulting and forecasting firm.
"Yet here we are in what is already the fourth longest economic expansion in the past 15 years, with the lowest unemployment rate since the early 1970's, in an economy that has just recorded the strongest first-half growth in 13 years, and inflation is at its lowest level in 30 years, and it is falling," Mr. McCarthy said.
He said the phenomenon had "caused even such an ardent inflation fighter as Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan to wonder if there isn't something different on today's economy."
Mr. McCarthy said he believed the economy was slowing. "That's why I don't expect Fed to move this year at all," he said. "The economy is repeating a pattern of the past couple of years, where there is a spurt of growth followed by a consolidation."
The last time the Fed raised short-term interest rates was in March, when it moved the target range for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent. Fed policy makers elected to leave rates unchanged in the last three meetings in May, July and August.
Interest rates at yesterday's weekly Treasury auction increased slightly. The average rate for a three-month bill rose to 4.93 percent, from 4.90 percent last week, while the six-month maturity increased to 5.08 percent from 5.04 percent.

HEADLINE: Incomes Gained in August; Spending Rose Moderately

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Steady job gains pushed incomes solidly higher in August, the Commerce Department said today, as consumers raised their spending at a moderate rate.
Total income from wages, salaries, interest, rents and all other sources rose six-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $6.919 trillion, after a revised gain in July of two-tenths of a percent and an increase of six-tenths of a percent in June. 
 The strong pickup in incomes obscured the effects of a two-week strike by United Parcel Service workers last month that the Government said cost about $2.5 billion in lost wages and salaries.
Spending increased three-tenths of a percent, to a rate of $5.521 trillion in August, after a revised 1 percent jump in July, the biggest monthly gain since 1.1 percent in January.
The income and spending data were the last Government reports on the economy before a meeting on Tuesday by Federal Reserve policy makers on interest-rate strategy. Analysts said the figures suggested steady growth at a healthy pace in the third quarter but not enough to result in a rate increase.
Robert Dederick, an economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said the personal incomes report confirmed that consumers were once more shopping after a slowdown in spending during the second quarter.
"The basic story is that the consumer remains a full-fledged participant in the expansion," he said.
Gains in personal income are fundamental for steady growth, since consumer spending on goods and services accounts for the majority of national economic activity.
Mr. Dederick said he expected the economy, measured by gross domestic product, to expand at a 3.2 percent annual rate in the third quarter ending this month. Last Friday, the Commerce Department said G.D.P. grew at a 3.3 percent rate in the second quarter.
Previously, the department said July incomes had risen one-tenth of 1 percent and that spending had increased by eight-tenths of a percent. But it revised both figures upward.
Even with steady spending rises in August, consumers were able to increase their savings, putting 3.8 cents out of each dollar earned into bank accounts or investments. That was up from 3.6 cents in July.
August spending on costly durable goods rose three-tenths of a percent, to $669.6 billion a year, much weaker than July's 3.2 percent increase. Spending on quickly used nondurables, like paper and food products, was up two-tenths of a percent last month, to $1.595 trillion, after a rise in July of six-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 69.25; Small Stocks Lift Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, with shares of smaller companies resuming their record-setting march as investors took an optimistic posture ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting today and some key economic reports due later in the week.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 69.25 points, to 7,991.43. The blue-chip index, which has not closed above 8,000 since Aug. 20, started the day with a 28-point deficit but quickly turned higher. 
Broader stock indicators also shrugged off early weakness to post some sizable gains.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, which had set record closings for eight straight sessions before slumping on Wednesday and Thursday, moved back into record territory, and other closely watched measures moved within striking distance of new highs.
"It's an encouraging performance, even though the Dow has once again shied away from the 8,000 mark," said Eugene Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, adding that the Dow "is trending toward the upper part of its range."
The Dow, still about 270 points below its Aug. 6 peak of 8,259.31, bobbed above 8,000 during four sessions in the last two weeks, but quickly retreated each time.
There was little reaction to yesterday morning's news that consumer spending rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in August -- down from a 1 percent spurt in July -- despite a healthy six-tenths of 1 percent gain in personal income.
The report, which met most forecasts, was the last piece of Government data before the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee gathers today.
Few analysts expect any change in monetary policy by the Fed, which has not raised its interest rate targets since March, when it pushed up rates to prevent a resurgence of inflation.
Even if the Fed leaves rates unchanged, however, investors are expected to trade cautiously before economic reports due later in the week that will offer the first taste of September data.
"I don't think the market will be vulnerable to anything but the worst news," Mr. Peroni said.
The most important reports should be tomorrow's reading on manufacturing activity and Friday's data on payroll and wage levels. The Fed's chief concern is whether a strong job market has forced manufacturers to raise wages significantly, as they try to keep up with heavy demand.
Yesterday's gains were spread across a broad spectrum. The only Dow component that gained more than 2 points was I.B.M., which rose 2 3/8, to 105; the next biggest Dow gainers were Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 1 7/8, to 92 5/16; Alcoa, up 1 9/16, to 81 7/8; Chevron, up 1 7/16, to 84 1/2, and Merck, up 1 7/16, to 101 9/16.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 4-to-3 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled a modest 477.1 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 8.12 points, to 953.34; the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 3.78, to 498.98, just shy of last Monday's record close of 499.16, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 12.74, to 1,694.98, less than 3 points from its record high set last Tuesday.
The Russell 2000 rose 2.43, to 451.31, beating last Tuesday's record close of 449.42. The American Stock Exchange composite index, which is dominated by smaller companies, rose 4.82, to 694.66, beating last Monday's record mark of 689.94.

HEADLINE: Union Pacific, With Cargo Backlog, Goes to Sea

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: OMAHA, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad company, said today that it planned to ship some cargo by sea to ease a backlog.
Television sets, tennis shoes, clothing, paper goods and appliances are being held in 3,000 containers the size of trucks in the Los Angeles area. The railroad will use APL Ltd. of Oakland, Calif., to move 660 containers around Mexico, through the Panama Canal and up to Savannah, Ga. The trip will take two weeks. By rail it would take six days. 
 "In order to unclog that area we had to look in the box for something we normally would not do," Mark Davis, a spokesman for the railroad, said. "It is safe to say this is the first time that we have ever done anything like this." The plan was reported today in The Wall Street Journal.
The Omaha-based Union Pacific predicted growing pains when it merged with Southern Pacific one year ago. Computer systems, labor agreements and dispatching duties are being cobbled together.
But aggravating the merger difficulties are three accidents that killed seven people and prompted a safety crackdown and a booming economy that heightened demand for train service, a record fall wheat harvest and the coming Christmas season.
Union Pacific traffic is backed up, sometimes by two weeks, particularly in its southern tier from California across Arizona, New Mexico, Texas and into the East Coast.
"I thought this merger would probably go pretty smoothly," said Eugenia Simpson of the investment firm Kirkpatrick Pettis in Omaha. "Apparently it's not."
Chemical and plastic manufacturers say they are losing $36 million a month and idling thousands of workers because Union Pacific is not hauling materials to and from plants in Texas. Lumber, steel and grain producers in the Northwest say they are worried about delays.
"We haven't made any secret of the fact that this backlog has caused problems throughout our system," said Mike Furtney, a spokesman for the railroad in San Francisco.
Union Pacific said it hoped that a combined computer system, expanded rail yards and new labor accords would be felt by early November.

HEADLINE: Clash of Cultures Tears Texas City

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 25

 BODY:
Everyone here agrees that Rosa Gonzales and Ester Hernandez were hired at the Allied Insurance Agency because they spoke Spanish. But the question that has set off a remarkably passionate debate here in the Texas Panhandle is this: Should they have been dismissed for the same reason?
The two women, who were born in Texas and are fluent in both English and Spanish, worked as clerks at a small insurance agency where many customers speak Spanish as their primary language. The agency's owner, Pat Polk, who said he had been irritated that the women had also chatted in Spanish with each other during the workday, asked them to sign a pledge making Allied Insurance "an English speaking office except when we have customers who can't speak our language." 
 Mrs. Gonzales and Mrs. Hernandez refused, and what happened next is still in dispute. The women say they were dismissed in July, while Mr. Polk says their refusal to sign the pledge meant that they quit. The state has accepted Mr. Polk's version and denied the women unemployment benefits, a decision they are appealing.
The ensuing fracas has led to a boycott of Allied by two Hispanic groups here, threats of lawsuits, unsuccessful efforts at mediation by local law professors, a surge of local media interest and lively arguments on talk-radio programs in the area.
More broadly, the whole question of whether the two women had the right to speak Spanish to each other while in Mr. Polk's employment clearly goes to the core of the fusing of Anglo and Hispanic cultures across the Southwest. It is a mix that has long given the region a unique vibrancy, one that shows up in its art, music, food and even in the language: the two women at the insurance agency said they tended to talk to each other in "Spanglish," a popular hybrid of the two languages.
But it is also one that has produced ethnic tensions, which seem to be especially volatile in places like West Texas, where the Hispanic population is growing much more quickly than the long-dominant Anglo population.
The language dispute at the insurance company here is by no means isolated. Just two years ago, an Amarillo judge sparked a national controversy when he ordered a Mexican-American woman involved in a custody dispute to speak English to her 5-year-old daughter. Otherwise, he said, "You're abusing that child and you're relegating her to the position of housemaid." (The judge later issued an apology to the woman and to "the profession of housekeeping.")
Last year, a dispute was set off in another Texas Panhandle town when the local school district refused to allow a celebration of Cinco de Mayo, the Mexican holiday.
Now along comes the dispute over Mrs. Gonzales and Mrs. Hernandez, who are both West Texas natives. In many ways, it seems to be the most intense of all.
While local Hispanic leaders are furious over what happened to the women, Mr. Polk has drawn support from some quarters, including the local branch of the Texas Workforce Commission, the state agency that denied the women unemployment benefits.
In announcing that decision, agency officials sent letters to the two women last month that said, "Our investigation found you left your last work rather than carry out a reasonable request from your employer." The women are appealing the finding, but no date has been set for a hearing.
Both women say they were highly offended when Mr. Polk handed them his handwritten pledge and said, "If you can't live with the rules here -- draw your pay and make the rules at your next job."
Mrs. Hernandez, a 28-year-old mother of two who had worked previously as a cashier at J.C. Penney, recalled: "I said, 'I can't sign that. I just don't think this is right.' "
Mrs. Gonzales, 33, a mother of three who had worked at the mammoth beef-packing plant here at the edge of town, said: "I told him no. This is what I am; this is what I do. This is normal to me. I'm not doing it to offend anybody. It just feels comfortable."
But Mr. Polk, 56, also a West Texas native, said the women's refusal to follow the rules set by him and his wife, Linda, the agency's co-owners, was outrageous.
"The only thing I asked was, 'Let's work together in a language we can all understand,' " he said. Mrs. Polk said the women's chatting in Spanish was "almost like they were whispering to each other behind our backs. It was very rude." Mr. Polk said he had taken two years of Spanish in high school and could not remember any of it.
Neither side is about to apologize to the other. "Oh, no," Mr. Polk said. "I'm not about to reward somebody for insubordination."
Mrs. Gonzales said: "I think he was wrong. It's like he was telling us to deny who we are, forget our heritage."
The community reaction here, while fervent, has fallen largely, but by no means completely, along ethnic lines. Mr. Polk said he had received support from many of his Hispanic customers. He said they had told him that he was right to enforce his English-only rule. Many residents of Amarillo -- whose population of 168,000 is about 75 percent non-Hispanic white, 15 percent Hispanic and 6 percent black -- have defended the women in call-in programs and letters to the editor.
Both Mrs. Gonzales and Mrs. Hernandez had worked for several months at the agency, a small storefront office in the Barrio, a heavily Hispanic neighborhood in south Amarillo. They were paid $5 an hour in jobs that involved selling insurance, offering quotes, filing accident reports and helping to settle claims.
What set off the clash remains in dispute, though there seems to have been tension in the office over many things, including what station to play on radios in the office.
Mrs. Gonzales described a dispute with Mrs. Polk over the radios. "Linda said she wanted them on all-country, and we were joking about doing it on all-Tejano."
Mr. Polk, whose agency was picketed on Sept. 20 and on two weekends previously, said he was angry that the dispute had escalated into an ethnic confrontation.
"It's been made into me belittling the Spanish people, and it's not that way," he said. "They're trying to make this a racial thing, and it's not."
In letters that Mr. Polk has sent to just about every elected official in the region, he has cast the women's refusal to sign the pledge as a matter of both rudeness and dereliction of duty.
"Our office is a four-employee office," he wrote. "We had three Spanish and one Caucasian woman working for us. The Spanish women were chatting in Spanish a great portion of the day amongst themselves, while I, my wife and the other woman were left out of the conversations, as we don't understand Spanish."
Mr. Polk and Mrs. Gonzales and Mrs. Hernandez also dispute whether Mr. Polk had ever asked them not to speak Spanish to each other before confronting them with the pledge. He said he and his wife had repeatedly made that request, but they say he never did. Joan Weigand, the other Anglo employee in the office, backs up the Polks's contention. When the remaining employee, Edna Mobley, 31, was asked about the matter in the Polks's presence, she said, "I really don't remember."
Ms. Mobley, who is fluent in both languages, said she had signed the pledge to speak English, to which a beaming Mr. Polk beckoned to a visitor and said, "That's one sharp little Mexican girl right there!"
The legal terrain in the matter is murky. A handbook published by the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission says that a rule requiring employees to speak English at all times on the job may violate civil rights laws "unless an employer shows it is necessary for conducing business." But some Federal courts have upheld English-only requirements. The Amarillo case is unusual because while the women often spoke Spanish to conduct business, the issue is whether they could use it socially while on the job.
The division in the community over the issue is evident among the customers who come to Allied.
Alarene Williamson, 32, a co-owner of Dr. Buff's Detail Shop, said, speaking of Mr. Polk: "It's his company, right? I think it's totally fair to ask the people who work there to speak English."
But her fiance, Wayne Collins, the other co-owner of the detail shop, said: "It's a free country, so I think they should be able to speak whatever language they want. And if it really bothers the guy that much that he doesn't understand it, then maybe he should learn Spanish. I mean, he could take a class or something."

HEADLINE: White House Opens Attack On I.R.S. Oversight Proposal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today harshly criticized a Congressional proposal to revamp oversight of the Internal Revenue Service, saying the plan would create new problems as the agency responds to disclosures that its agents harassed taxpayers.
Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy director, said the bipartisan Congressional proposal -- which would take oversight of the tax agency away from the Treasury Department and place it in the hands of a management board including seven private citizens -- would create the potential for conflicts of interest and diminished Government accountability for the I.R.S.'s performance. 
Mr. Sperling told reporters at a White House briefing that the Administration was committed to halting the kinds of abuses of taxpayers highlighted last week in hearings before the Senate Finance Committee.
But with Republicans eagerly seeking to turn the issue to their political advantage, Mr. Sperling suggested that the White House had no inclination to budge from the position previously staked out by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin: that the best way to overhaul the I.R.S. is to allow the Treasury Department to continue tightening management of tax collection procedures, punish agents who mistreat taxpayers, improve the agency's computer systems and create an oversight board made up of Government officials drawn from the executive branch.
"It is a recipe for conflicts of interest," Mr. Sperling said of the Congressional proposal. "And the notion that the right way to deal with these problems with the I.R.S. is to decrease accountability and have part-time managers who would be themselves involved in a range of financial transactions would be a serious step backwards."
The proposal being debated in Congress is based on recommendations made by Representative Rob Portman, an Ohio Republican, and Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska. Legislation that the two lawmakers have proposed would create a management board made up of the Treasury Secretary, the head of the Treasury workers' union and seven private citizens who would be nominated by the President and subject to Senate confirmation.
The legislation would also strip the President of the right to name the Internal Revenue Commissioner, although members of Congress say they are discussing compromise language that would permit the White House to retain that right.
The legislation is likely to come to a vote in the House Ways and Means Committee late next month and in the full House by early November. The Senate has not set a timetable for considering the bill, and might postpone any action until next year.
But in a sign of how politically charged the issue is becoming, the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, sent a letter to President Clinton today saying he was "greatly alarmed" by Mr. Sperling's comments.
"If you do not repudiate the statements made by Mr. Sperling today, you will have allied yourself with the I.R.S.'s bureaucratic machine and turned your back on millions of Americans who have been pulled through its gears," Mr. Gingrich told Mr. Clinton in the letter.
In an interview, Mr. Rubin said the Administration had been adopting sweeping management changes at the I.R.S. for the last several years. As an illustration of the shifts, he cited Mr. Clinton's nomination of a computer software executive, Charles O. Rossotti, to be the Internal Revenue Commissioner, part of an effort to bring more managerial strength to the sprawling agency.
"The I.R.S.'s problems go back a long way," Mr. Rubin said, "but this has been a very active period relative to our oversight and to reform of I.R.S. management."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ruling Helps Hilton In Its Bid for ITT
A judge ruled that ITT directors cannot split the company into three businesses without shareholder approval, a decision that buoyed Hilton's hostile $11.5 billion bid for ITT. The judge gave the company until Nov. 14 to hold a shareholders meeting.
The three-way split was part of a strategy announced by Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of ITT, to defeat the unsolicited bid that Hilton announced in January. Page D8. 

Stocks Rebound From Early Dip
Stocks rose strongly as investors were optimistic that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged today. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 69.25 points, to 7,991.43, after early sluggishness. D10.
 
Treasury securities ended little changed in thin trading, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 6.38 percent from 6.36. D21.
 
Republic to Sell Security Unit
H. Wayne Huizenga has soured on the security business. Republic Industries, which he controls, plans to sell its security operations to Ameritech for $610 million, making Ameritech No. 2 in that field behind ADT, which Republic had unsuccessfully tried to acquire. D8.
 
Incomes and Spending Rise
Steady job gains pushed incomes solidly higher in August, as consumers raised their spending at a moderate rate. D8.
 
Penguin Books in Settlement
Penguin Books and a trade association for independent bookstores have struck a deal to settle a feud arising from a multimillion-dollar accounting scandal that involved unauthorized discounts to large retailers. D6.
 
Backlog at Union Pacific
Union Pacific, the nation's largest railroad, said that it planned to ship some cargo by sea to ease a backlog, amid growing pains after its merger with Southern Pacific. D4.
 
The Doctor Is a Nurse
More and more nurses are acting in roles traditionally filled by doctors, helping patients deal with common complaints and referring those with complicated problems to specialists. The trend, like others in health care, is driven in part by the move to cut costs. A1.
 
France Stands Behind Iran Deal
France's Prime Minister voiced strong support for a $2 billion contract signed between Total, the French oil company, and Iran to explore natural gas fields. He rejected what he called America's attempts to impose its laws on the world through a measure that authorizes sanctions against companies investing in Iran or Libya. A1.
 
Caution About Cash Cards
Consumers in a Canadian test of electronic cash cards have been reluctant to give up their "loonies," as dollar coins are known there. A similar test is coming to the Upper West Side of Manhattan. D2.
 
British Pound Bounces Back a Bit
The pound steadied a bit from a sharp selloff after several British ministers over the weekend denied a report that there had been a change in the Government's policy on European monetary union. D17.
 
Natural Gas Futures Plunge
Natural gas futures fell sharply on a forecast of warm weather for the coming week. D17.
 
A Dispute Over Language
Everyone agrees that two women were hired by an insurance agency in Amarillo, Tex., because they spoke Spanish. But the question that has set off a remarkably passionate debate is this: Should they have been dismissed for the same reason? A14.

HEADLINE: Union Strategy Results in Coup At US Airways

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In the biggest union organizing election in private business in a decade, nearly 10,000 reservations takers, gate agents and ticket sellers at U S Airways have voted to join the Communications Workers of America, Federal labor officials announced yesterday.
The union won the support of the airline's passenger-service workers by following a strategy being embraced throughout labor -- emphasizing that corporate profits have rebounded while employee pay and benefits have languished. 
 Union leaders immediately hailed the victory, saying it showed that white-collar workers were fertile ground for labor's message and that the union movement's new focus on recruiting workers was paying off.
"The victory at U S Airways is very significant," said Kate Bronfenbrenner, director of labor education research at Cornell University. "It's not just because it involved so many workers, but it's the kind of workers that people questioned whether the labor movement could organize. These are white-collar workers in an industry where unions have really been struggling."
John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, and other labor leaders have looked to the U S Airways organizing drive as a bellwether to show whether labor was reversing its decline, especially in the private sector. Labor unions represent 14.5 percent of the overall work force, a sharp drop from 35 percent in the 1950's.
"The level of unionization has reached a 50-year low in this country, with unions representing just 10 percent of the private sector, compared with 40 percent in the public sector," said Kent Wong, director of the Center for Labor Research and Education at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has focused tremendous attention lately on organizing in the private sector, and they've been looking for a big win like this for some time. They want to show that unions can win in the private sector."
Nonetheless, union officials acknowledge that it will often be an uphill battle to unionize workers at many companies, especially when employers take such action as dismissing workers who head organizing drives.
In a statement, U S Airways said today that it would accept its legal obligations to recognize and bargain with the communications workers, while it appeals a mediator's decision that allowed the election. Richard Weintraub, a company spokesman declined further comment.
Union leaders cite the U S Airways drive as an example of labor's increased ability to succeed in complex organizing drives, in which thousands of workers are spread across many states -- the U S Airways workers are in 110 cities, from San Diego to Orlando, Fla., to New York.
Jeffrey Miller, a spokesman for the communications workers, said his union hoped to use the U S Airways victory as a springboard to unionize 14,000 passenger-service workers at United Air Lines. Industry officials estimate that there are 60,000 passenger-service workers in the airline industry who do not belong to unions. The only passenger-service workers who are organized are at Northwest Airlines and T.W.A.
U S Airways workers who voted for the union said they did so because they wanted a collective voice to represent them in dealing with a company that froze their wages and reduced their pensions and sick leave over the last four years while nursing itself back to financial health.
U S Airways lost more than $3 billion in the early 1990's but has been regaining ground recently in the strong United States economy. The airline, profitable for the last five quarters, had net income of $263 million in 1996.
The pilots union at the airline, meanwhile, was negotiating feverishly with the company yesterday in hopes of reaching a new contract. Article, Business Day, Page D1.
 Many of the airline's passenger-service workers have been especially unhappy that they have had to accept larger concessions than those agreed to by the airline's unionized pilots, mechanics and flight attendants.
In cutting costs to restore its profitability, U S Airways eliminated paid holidays and sick days for passenger-service workers, deducting their sick days from vacation time.
"The issue that really started this was all the other labor groups were represented and had a voice when the company hit a downturn," said Timothy Yost, a a Pittsburgh-based customer service agent. "But we were told we'd have to take worse concessions that the other labor groups. They were forced upon us. Having a union should put us on a level playing field."
Josie Esposito, a reservations agent in San Diego, also strongly backed the organizing campaign. "People are finally waking up to the fact that they need protection and that means a union," she said. "The company's stock has been going up, from $4 to over $40, and our wages haven't gone anywhere." Shares of the company rose 83 cents to $42.69 yesterday.
Because the U S Airways workers are covered by the Railway Labor Act, rather than the National Labor Relations Act, an absolute majority of all workers in the proposed bargaining unit must vote for unionization for the union to win the right to represent them.
Under the rules set by the National Mediation Board, which oversaw the election, only the 8,800 passenger-service workers hired before April 1996 were allowed to vote. But with the union's triumph, the communications workers will represent all 10,000 passenger-service workers.
In the election, in which ballots were mailed in and then counted yesterday, 4,773 workers, or 54 percent, voted to join the communications workers, while 77 voted for other unions.
Last January, the communications workers failed to organize the U S Airways workers because the union fell 280 votes short of a majority. But the National Mediation Board ordered a new election, finding that the company had made improper claims about how many changes could be wrought by an in-house employees committee set up by the company.
U S Airways said today that it would continue to appeal the board's decision to overturn the previous election. In fighting the union, U S Airways executives contended that they would be fair to all employee groups and would treat passenger-service workers as well as others. The company also argued that the workers could deal with the company more easily without a union.
Union officials said it was a daunting task to make sure that more than 50 percent of the workers cast ballots. At each of 110 sites, the union recruited what they called employee activists to oversee the drives.
The union also published a newsletter with articles saying that passenger-service workers had not received their fair share of the company's improved profits.
Richard Bensinger of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said, "These are highly educated, white-collar workers, part of the information age, knowledge-based new economy. What's interesting is they were so supportive of the union. One woman there told me, they want to be players, not pawns."

HEADLINE: Offering a Glimpse of a 2d Term, Giuliani Vows a War on Drugs

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29

 BODY:
In the first glimmer of a new policy he intends to pursue if re-elected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today promised a widespread effort to reduce drug use in New York City, outlining a three-part program that would focus on law enforcement, anti-drug education and increased treatment programs.
In a speech to a standing-room audience of students at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, the Mayor said that the problem of drug abuse has never been addressed in a comprehensive way, and threatens the gains the city has made in reducing crime. Between 60 and 70 percent of those charged with crimes in the city test positive for drugs, he said. 
 The Mayor did not provide many details of his plans, promising to do so in a few days. But he said the Police Department would step up its enforcement effort against drug dealers in an expansion of existing programs in northern Manhattan, the Bushwick section of Brooklyn and the South Bronx. At the same time, he said, the city would increase its drug treatment programs, and the school system would begin a comprehensive education program against drugs, he said.
Although the Mayor used the phrase "zero tolerance" to describe the new policy, he said he was not under the illusion that the city could wipe out drug use. Instead, he said, the city would try to reduce the sense of immunity possessed by many drug dealers and users, providing, for example, a tips line for citizens to report drug dealing.
"A society that has an increasing number of people becoming dependent in the most basic sense is a society that is deteriorating, and we have to face up to the problem of drugs, and we haven't done it as a society," he said. "But I believe we are now in a position to really do it, to take all the cynics and naysayers and people who say you can't substantially reduce it and do the same thing we did on reducing murder."
With only five weeks left before the election, Mr. Giuliani has until now said little about any new directions he intends to pursue if re-elected.The Mayor's aides have said he believes he can run successfully by stressing the accomplishments of his first term, and most of his speech tonight was devoted to praising what he and his administration have already done.
When future historians look back at New York at the turn of the millennium, he said, they will see a place where the fundamental needs of society were met, where the arts and culture flourished, where government was accountable, and where people lived free from fear.
"As the city becomes safer, what's happened to the spirit of the city is more people are becoming in a very real sense, free, becoming more independent," he said. "They're becoming free in society to make the choices they like to make about their lives, and that unleashes a really wonderful spirit about people having the sense they have control over their lives."
With the exception of the drug issue, Mr. Giuliani did not suggest that there were any significant remaining problems in New York, despite the city's high unemployment rate, continuing homeless population and an economy that relies heavily on the volatile financial sector. In mentioning jobs, for example, he cited only the city's growth in employment since the recession of the early 1990's, not its current 10 percent unemployment rate.
A group of student protesters was on hand, however, with written reminders of a few of the issues that still confront Mr. Giuliani. A few minutes into his speech, about five students stood and held posters protesting continued police brutality, crowded schools and the city's workfare program. Three students also held up toilet plungers, a reminder of the case of a Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was abused by police officers. The Mayor jokingly said "welcome," but otherwise ignored the protesters.
Leland T. Jones, the chief spokesman for the campaign of Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said Mr. Giuliani's speech ignored many problems.
"When it comes to the notion of educational reform there is not a single solitary new idea here," Mr. Jones said. "When it comes to getting people who are unemployed back into employment there is not a single solitary new idea here. It is more just a selective rewriting of the past than it is an expansive vision of the future."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: Testing Giant Exceeds Roots, Drawing Business Rivals' Ire

SERIES: THE TESTING EMPIRE: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER and DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
The Educational Testing Service has the trappings of an affluent small college or an adjunct campus of nearby Princeton University in New Jersey. Its lush 360-acre property is dotted with low, tasteful brick buildings, tennis courts, a swimming pool, a private hotel and an impressive home where its president lives rent free. Employees are often referred to as faculty and one in five holds an advanced degree.
But the academic aura is deceptive. Over the last decade, the testing service has transformed itself from a small nonprofit educational institution into the world's largest testing company, administering nine million yearly examinations that help determine the future of millions of Americans and foreigners trying to get into good schools or professions. It has quietly grown into a multinational operation, complete with for-profit subsidiaries, a reserve fund of $91 million, and revenue last year of $411 million. 
 And along with that growth -- and its increasingly important place in American society -- have come new questions and criticism from inside and out.
As it celebrates its 50th anniversary this year, E.T.S. has come under fire not only for its failure to address increased incidents of cheating and fraud, but also for what its critics say is its transformation into a highly competitive business operation that is as much multinational monopoly as nonprofit institution, one capable of charging hefty fees, laying off workers and using sharp elbows in competing against rivals.
Yet as E.T.S. edges more toward an enormous, competitive company, it remains a nonprofit organization, a status that critics say gives the testing service unfair advantages. As a nonprofit, E.T.S. does not have to pay corporate income taxes, which saves it tens of millions of dollars, freeing up cash to hire workers and develop ever more sophisticated tests. Last year, E.T.S. also set up a for-profit subsidiary to compete directly with private businesses in the booming industry of professional licensing and government testing. What has also riled the critics is E.T.S.'s decision to break out of its academic mold and compete with private businesses by selling material that helps students prepare for the very tests it administers, using such advertising phrases as "We prepare the tests -- let us help prepare you."
Last November, one of the testing service's main nonprofit competitors, ACT Inc. of Iowa City, filed a Federal lawsuit contending that a multimillion dollar deal that E.T.S. has with Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., a for-profit company with headquarters in Baltimore, was part of an effort by Sylvan to violate antitrust law and monopolize the market in computerized testing, the wave of the future in the industry. Sylvan has denied the allegations.
E.T.S. was not named as a defendant, but the suit asserted that Sylvan had worked with the new for-profit subsidiary of E.T.S., the Chauncey Group International, to try to steal ACT customers.
The mounting criticism has rekindled an old debate about whether E.T.S. deserves its nonprofit status, which has exempted it from tens of millions of dollars in Federal income taxes, the same as a major foundation or charity.
"E.T.S. is standing on the cusp of deciding whether it is an education institution or a commercial institution," said Winton H. Manning, a former E.T.S. senior vice president who retired two years ago. "I'm disappointed in the direction they have taken away from education and public service."
Nancy S. Cole, the president of E.T.S., says the company is aware that its nonprofit status is a source of concern, particularly to outsiders, as the testing service increases its competition with for-profit businesses.
"We do constantly test ourselves with the basic question of what is the unique contribution of a nonprofit,"Mrs. Cole said. "There's still no for-profit competition for the basic admissions testing that we do, and really the bulk of our revenues come from areas in which there is not direct competition from for-profits."
Determining when a nonprofit organization crosses the line and should become a for-profit business is a subject of debate among both nonprofit organizations and government agencies. The Internal Revenue Service establishes restrictions on how much money a nonprofit group can take in from businesses unrelated to its public service mission. But often conflicts occur long before a nonprofit company reaches the ceiling, particularly when an organization goes in head-to-head competition with private businesses.
Yet, the competition with for-profit rivals is a trend that bedevils nonprofit institutions across the country.
"In our world," said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, which is the testing company's biggest client and itself a nonprofit body, "when you go too far toward the business model, and E.T.S. has learned this the hard way, you begin to lose the kind of affinity and loyalty and sensitivity that comes from a public service operation. We are looking for a middle ground. How do we survive economically without losing our shirts or our values?"
 
The Long Fight
Feeling of Mission, Aura of Privilege
When the Educational Testing Service was started in 1947, its mission was clear. With World War II veterans swamping colleges and universities, the company was set up to develop and administer college entrance exams. The company's main rival today, ACT, is also a nonprofit organization, and there are many smaller commercial testing companies. But the testing service dominates college and graduate school admissions testing, delivering twice as many tests as ACT overall.
The company is best known for its flagship exam, the SAT, which it administers on behalf of the College Board, an organization of more than 3,000 schools and colleges. The testing service also administered 630,000 tests for graduate school admissions last year. About 180,000 teachers in 34 states took its certification exams, and 820,000 foreign students seeking admission to American schools demonstrated their English proficiency on its tests.
The service's for-profit subsidiary, the Chauncey Group, tested the skills of 1.5 million workers in 34 fields last year. An additional 1.2 million workers with native languages other than English submitted to its evaluation of their ability to communicate in English on the job in tests administered for their employers.
Critics have frequently said that the exams given by Educational Testing Service had a bias against minorities and women. The critics have also argued that too much emphasis is placed on standardized tests. But the creation of the Chauncey Group and other business moves by E.T.S. have revived a longstanding and less-publicized dispute.
"From the moment that E.T.S. opened for business, the for-profit publishers have been grumbling about it and asking why they get nonprofit status," said Nicholas Lemann, who is writing a book about meritocracy in America, which deals partly with the testing organization.
Nonprofit organizations usually exist to accomplish some charitable, humanitarian or educational purpose. To meet those public service goals, the organizations are in effect subsidized by taxpayers because they are exempt from paying some taxes.
E.T.S. qualified initially as a nonprofit group because its primary mission was educational: developing and administering tests to students on behalf of three nonprofit academic associations.
Under Federal tax regulations, a nonprofit group is exempt from corporate income taxes. But revenue earned from business activities that are not related to the organization's nonprofit purpose are subject to taxes.
Within the education world, the Educational Testing Service's nonprofit status also conveys a legitimacy not accorded commercial rivals.
Complaints from commercial competitors that E.T.S. had an unfair advantage grew so insistent in the late 1950's that the Internal Revenue Service conducted a three-year review of the organization's finances. In a 1962 letter, the tax agency agreed that the company was a legitimate nonprofit organization because its primary goal remained educational. To safeguard its status, E.T.S. later hired Mortimer Caplin, a former I.R.S. Commissioner, as one of its Washington lawyers.
The new round of criticism was touched off by the creation of the Chauncey Group and by the parent organization's own expanding sales of promotional material to teach students how to take its tests and to advise parents and students on the college admissions process.
"For years, E.T.S. scoffed at test preparation and now they are marketing their own line of products," said Andrew S. Rosen, the chief operating officer of Kaplan Educational Centers, a subsidiary of the Washington Post Company and a leading test preparation company. "I'm not sure why the taxpayer needs to subsidize another player in these industries."
 
The Change
Getting Bigger, Growing Aggressive
In its early decades, E.T.S. cultivated the atmosphere of a university. Debate was encouraged and job security was similar to the tenure enjoyed by college faculty members. But as the organization grew, the tenor became far more corporate.
The turning point came in 1993. Faced with the loss of a major Government contract, the organization laid off 250 people, roughly 8 percent of its staff of about 3,000, and cut benefits for those who remained. The steps were no harsher than those taken by many businesses, but the testing service's employees, accustomed to a more genteel workplace, were stunned.
"The atmosphere changed after that," said Robert Altman, who retired a year later as a vice president. "People were no longer able to feel secure. There had been a threat, and the threat was carried out."
At the time of the layoffs, the company was investing heavily to develop the next generation of tests, a key to future growth.
Software to replace paper-and-pencil tests with computerized versions has existed for many years. But E.T.S. held off because offering computerized tests meant offering testing centers with computers, which it did not have.
In 1993, the testing service signed an agreement with Sylvan, which specialized in tutoring young students at franchised centers, many of which have computers. The agreement made Sylvan the exclusive provider of computerized tests developed by the Educational Testing Service. The projected revenue allowed Sylvan to expand its computer centers. In exchange, Sylvan agreed not to do business on computerized tests with E.T.S. competitors, either for-profit or nonprofit. The deal gave the world's biggest testing service access to the largest network of computer-test centers.
Then, the nonprofit organization invested in Sylvan stock and Mrs. Cole joined Sylvan's board of directors.
With a computer network in place, the testing organization began in November 1993 to phase in a computer-based version of the Graduate Record Examinations, the standard test for admission to graduate schools. The next April, the licensing exam for nurses was switched completely to computer, bringing 200,000 customers a year to Sylvan centers.
The new business sent Sylvan's stock on a steady climb. E.T.S.'s initial investment of $1.5 million, which Mrs. Cole called a token, is now worth more than $16 million. Some present and former employees of the testing company said they regard the investment as a conflict, but Mrs. Cole said that the only complaint she had heard was concern that E.T.S. had become too dependent on Sylvan for its computer-based testing business.
In the eyes of some competitors, the arrangement was too successful. Last November, ACT filed suit in Federal District Court in Iowa City, contending that Sylvan was trying to create a monopoly and was working with the Chauncey Group to steal ACT customers.
In one instance, the suit contended, Chauncey and Sylvan sales representatives called on a professional organization that sponsored a licensing test administered by ACT and said that ACT had no future in computerized testing. The representatives also said that if the professional group wanted access to Sylvan's computers, the suit contended, the organization would have to switch to Chauncey to develop a new test because Sylvan would not work with ACT.
"These statements were made with the intention of diverting the test sponsor's test development business from ACT to Chauncey," the suit said, "and of inducing the test sponsor to contract with Sylvan rather than ACT for the provision of computer-based testing."
Robert A. Burgoyne, ACT's lawyer, said the company would seek damages of $100 million from Sylvan when the case goes to trial.
Sylvan has denied the allegations in court papers. Officials of E.T.S. and Chauncey declined to comment in detail because the records of the companies have been subpoenaed. But Mrs. Cole said Sylvan's actions were nothing more than an effort to protect its market.
 
The Future
Going Beyond Educational Testing
The Chauncey Group International was established as a profit-making subsidiary of E.T.S. on Jan. 1, 1996, to expand its parent's market share in developing and administering licensing and certification tests for professional organizations and exams for various Government entities.
Named after Henry Chauncey, the founder of the testing service, the organization started with about 100 employees and $20 million in assets, mostly in the form of existing test accounts, from its parent.
Nonprofit organizations create for-profit subsidiaries for a variety of business reasons. Sometimes the parent organization is generating too much income from businesses that are unrelated to its nonprofit purpose, jeopardizing its tax-exempt status. On other occasions, a nonprofit may set up a for-profit subsidiary to go after business unrelated to its central purpose.
"More often than not," said William Lehrfeld, a tax lawyer in Washington, "nonprofits will find ways in which they can reach into business opportunities using the aura or halo that may have developed from their ongoing nonprofit activities."
While the Educational Testing Service dominates admissions testing, the fast-growing marketplace for licensing and certification tests for private industry is more fragmented, with a large number of smaller companies competing for supremacy.
Chauncey has yet to show a profit, and officials there say it was set up to create a smaller, more responsive operation to handle the for-profit activities in which the parent had been engaged for many years. "We needed an operating environment that would enable us to serve our Government and business customers in a more flexible way," said Alice Irby, the president of Chauncey and a former E.T.S. executive.
One of the customers that Chauncey inherited from E.T.S. was the National Council of Architectural Registration Boards, an association of state agencies that licenses architects in the United States and Canada. Educational Testing Service had been the group's test consultant for 30 years and, beginning in 1990, it had worked on developing a computer-based test for architects.
When the test was unveiled last year, its computer simulations were praised, but some people were surprised by the cost, which doubled to $980 from $485.
Because computerized tests cost more to develop and administer, they are often much more expensive. A pilot version of a computerized SAT last year cost $75, roughly four times the amount of a paper test. But few increases have matched the fee for the architects' test.
Internal records from the architects' council show that the bulk of the fee goes to the Chauncey Group. The architects' council receives $427 of the $980, with the remaining $553 going to Chauncey for its expenses in administering the tests. The council pays Chauncey another $212 out of its $427 to cover development of new questions and administrative matters, bringing the total to $765 for each of the 3,000 or more tests expected to be administered each year. About 40 percent of Chauncey's revenue is paid to Sylvan for computer time in giving the tests, Chauncey officials said.
The high test cost angered Jessica Farrar, a Houston architect. Because she also happens to be a member of the Texas Legislature, Ms. Farrar mustered support for a state inquiry into the high fees.
"What we're finding is that they are pricing people out of their own profession," Ms. Farrar said. "A doctor in Texas pays $810, and a lawyer pays $275. Here are architects, who earn much less, paying more."

HEADLINE: NEW REPORTS SAY MINORITIES BENEFIT IN FISCAL RECOVERY

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Brightening economic fortunes are increasingly extending to racial and ethnic minorities and reaching farther down the economic ladder as the nation's recovery moves briskly through its sixth year, several reports released today indicate.
The reports -- income and poverty studies issued today by the Census Bureau and a report on home ownership released by Harvard University -- indicate that in the last three years, the economic prospects for nearly all households have risen and that the gains among minorities have in some cases reached unprecedented levels. 
 Seizing on the generally good news in today's reports of small increases in median income for American households, President Clinton took credit for the spreading prosperity and said it validated his economic policies. "After years and years of stagnant family incomes, today's report proves that America's middle class, no longer forgotten, is rising fast," he told reporters.
Bolstering this view, the Census Bureau reported that for the second year in a row, median household income increased in 1996, rising 1.2 percent, to $35,492. This was only the second time since 1989 -- just before the last recession -- that the median income did not fall or remain stagnant. The increase appeared to be based almost solely on income gains in the South.
Though minorities made strong gains, the increase in income across the board was relatively anemic, especially considering the healthy state of the economy. In fact, incomes for men with full-time jobs decreased by 0.9 percent last year.
Some experts attribute this to businesses' continuing to hold down wages and workers, fearful of their jobs, declining to aggressively address wage demands.
The study also noted that the median income for full-time working women was 74 percent of that for men last year, the smallest earnings gap ever recorded between the sexes by the Census Bureau. But the shrinking gap reflects more the decline of men's wages than an improvement of women's incomes. Recently, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the income gap between men and women had in fact widened. But the bureau study looked at all workers, including temporary workers. In contrast, the Census Bureau looked only at full-time year-round employees.
The Census Bureau reports also contained some gloomy news. While the growth in income for the richest 20 percent outpaced all other groups, the poorest 20 percent of the country's households had an income drop of 1.8 percent last year. And 500,000 more people, compared with the previous year, were living on incomes that were less than half the official poverty level in 1996.
The overall picture, however, showed improving fortunes for minorities almost across the board, evidence that economists say points to the benefits that a robust economy is extending to more groups of people.
In the last three years, virtually all groups -- non-Hispanic whites, blacks, Hispanics and Asian-Americans -- have seen their median incomes rise and their poverty rates drop. The Census Bureau reported that last year, 28.4 percent of black households were below the poverty line; that was the lowest proportion of blacks living in poverty since the Census Bureau began keeping tabs in 1955 and is undoubtedly the lowest black poverty rate in the country's history. A family of four making $16,036 in 1996 dollars is considered to be living at the poverty level.
Although the median income for blacks and Hispanics continued to trail that of non-Hispanic whites last year, black men working full time narrowed a gap to earn 80 percent of the income of non-Hispanic white men, the smallest income gap between these two groups in 30 years.
Median income is the exact midpoint in the income scale for any group. Half of the group's members earn less than the median and half earn more. The median is considered a more reliable measure than the mean, or average, income, which can be swayed by the gargantuan earnings of a relative few, giving a distorted view of a group's economic circumstances.
The Census Bureau's annual report was released on the same day as a Harvard study showing that economic gains by minorities helped fuel the country's residential real estate boom from 1993 through 1996.
Demographers had predicted that the housing construction surge would slow in the 1990's as the baby-boom generation settled into more or less permanent housing. Instead, the number of homeowners grew by 3.4 million households in the period studied, with minority homeowners making up 29 percent of the increase.
"The good economy is seeping down," said William Apgar, executive director of Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies. "Fair lending practices are starting to happen. People -- Realtors, lenders, home builders -- are beginning to see that there is a minority market that can afford reasonably good housing."
Some economists say blacks and other minorities are sharing more in the current recovery than they did in previous economic booms because on average, African-Americans tend to be better educated and possess more skills than in previous years. In addition, minorities are outpacing their gains from the 1980's because that period was marked by severe retrenchment in the manufacturing sector, where black workers tended to be concentrated.
But some found reasons to criticize the Administration.
"For a year of strong economic growth, this is quite a disappointing report," said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research and advocacy group. "Poverty failed to decline. Average income of the poorest fifth of families fell."
Today's Census Bureau reports underscore the economic progress that many minorities are making. In recent years, a number of measures of prosperity have pointed to improvements in the overall quality of life for blacks, still the country's biggest minority.
The last three years have shown growth in the median income for virtually every type of black family.
Hispanic households had a dramatic increase of 5.8 percent in median income -- the largest of any group -- which is a reversal of last year's decline of 5.1 percent.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
France Makes Oil Deal Despite U.S. Concerns
Delighted at a $2 billion contract signed between a French oil company and Iran, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France rejected an American law that claims the power to impose sanctions even on non-American companies investing more than $40 million in Iran or Libya. A1 

Scientists Find Disease Link
Scientists in Scotland say they have found "compelling evidence" that the "mad cow" disease responsible for the death of thousands of cattle in Britain is in no way distinct from a disease that has killed 14 people. Not only does their evidence suggest that bovine spongiform encephalopathy is a variant of Creutzfeld Jacob disease, but the new experiment suggested that a virus-like particle or co-factor is involved in the disease, unfortunately removing doubts about human susceptibility to infection from bovine products. A6
 
Diana Was Source in Biography
The main source for details of the Princess of Wales's unhappy marriage to Prince Charles and her troubled relations with the royal family as told in the 1992 book "Diana, Her True Story," was Diana herself, the author confirmed in the preface to a newly published edition. Diana denied she had been a source for the book when it was first published. A7
 
Mideast Talks Set to Resume
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced that Israel and the Palestinians have agreed to resume committee talks that broke down more than six months ago. The two sides agreed to meet on Oct. 6 to begin discussions on issues such as transit arrangements between Gaza and the West Bank. A6
 
15 Killed at Algerian School
Eight suspected Muslim militants attacked a village school in Algeria, shooting or slashing to death 11 female teachers as students watched. Four other people were also killed, witnesses said. The attackers, who were disguised in various uniforms, used the rallying cry of the Armed Islamic Group, which has been waging a campaign of killings aimed at destabilizing the Government. A5
 
30 Die in Chilean Asylum Fire
A fire at a Chilean home for mentally retarded children and adults killed 30 of its most handicapped residents when the flaming roof collapsed on their beds, officials said. Firefighters thought the blaze was sparked by an electrical problem. A8
 
2,700 Claims Sent to Swiss
More than 2,700 claims have been sent in by individuals who say they may be beneficiaries of Nazi-era Swiss bank accounts untouched since May 1945, the Swiss Bankers Association said. The names of almost 2,000 foreigners, including Holocaust victims linked to accounts opened in Switzerland before and during World War II, were released worldwide in July by the bankers' group in an effort to track down the rightful owners of the dormant accounts. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NATIONAL A14-27
 
10,000 Airline Workers Vote to Join Labor Union
Nearly 10,000 reservations takers, gate agents and ticket sellers at US Airways have voted to join the Communications Workers of America in the biggest union organizing election in the private sector in a decade, Federal labor officials said. The union won the support of workers by emphasizing that corporate profits have rebounded while employee pay and benefits have languished. A1
 
Recovery Reaches More in U.S.
Brightening economic fortunes are spreading to more Americans, extending increasingly to racial and ethnic minorities and reaching farther down the economic ladder as the nation's economic recovery moves briskly through its sixth year, a number of reports indicate. A1
 
Amendment Threatens Bill
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, proposed amending the main bipartisan campaign-finance legislation in Congress with a provision that Democrats immediately denounced as a ploy to kill the bill. The provision, which would prohibit unions from deducting dues or fees from the paychecks of union and nonunion workers for political activities without their permission, is strongly opposed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. A22
 
I.R.S. Proposal Criticized
Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy director, criticized a Congressional proposal to revamp oversight of the Internal Revenue Service, saying that the plan would create new problems rather than preventing incidents in which tax-collection agents harass taxpayers. A26
 
Experts Address Heroin Use
The Government brought together more than 500 drug experts from around the country to discuss the scope of the nation's heroin problem and how to deal with it. The two-day conference involves medical researchers and specialists in law enforcement, public policy and drug treatment and prevention. A27
 
Teamster Overseer Appointed
A Federal judge appointed a new overseer to decide whether Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, should be disqualified from a rerun election against James P. Hoffa. A26
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
School Condom Program Seen as Effective in Study
A study says that making condoms accessible to high school students through AIDS education programs does not increase the students' rates of sexual activity, but does increase condom use. The study compared the rates of condom use and sexual activity for thousands of high school students in New York City schools, which offer condoms, and students in Chicago, where H.I.V. and AIDS education is provided but condoms are not made available. A1
 
Ross to Switch Parties
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, whose career was left in jeopardy after Gov. Pataki barred her from running with him for re-election, said she will leave the Republican Party and become a Democrat. B1
 
Court to Hear Ellis Island Case
The Supreme Court said it would hear arguments on the dispute between New York and New Jersey over control of Ellis Island. B1

A New TV Ratings Alphabet
television networks are adding the labels D, L, S and V -- for suggestive dialogue, coarse language, sex and violence -- to the existing labels of TV-G, TV-PG, TV-14 and TV-MA. Many advocacy groups favor more detailed labels, but others say the system is bewildering. E1

Columns: Russell Baker.
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-24
 
Nurses Grow Into New Role
A growing number of nurses are taking charge of patients without the immediate supervision of doctors, a practice endorsed by more and more private insurers as well as Medicare and Medicaid. Perhaps not surprisingly, the medical establishment, and many doctors, vehemently oppose the idea. A1
 
Small Stocks Beat Index Funds
Mutual funds that invest in the stocks of smaller, faster growing companies have set the pace in the industry since the end of April, leaving behind index funds which track the biggest blue-chip companies. Overall, the third quarter will end with roughly four out of every five mutual funds that invest in American stocks having beaten the Standard & Poor's 500 index. D1
 
US Airways Faces Deadline
US Airways and its pilots negotiated feverishly in hope of reaching a new contract in time for the airline to meet a deadline today to confirm an order for as many as 400 jets from Airbus Industrie. D1
