HEADLINE: Two-Edged Sanctions Sword

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The issue of how to use economic sanctions as a weapon of foreign policy has bedeviled and divided the Clinton Administration during the last five years. But the case facing the White House now -- whether to punish companies with Government links in France, Russia and Malaysia for their $2 billion investment in Iran -- is filled with particularly agonizing choices for the White House.
There is no easy way, Administration officials conceded today, to enforce the anti-terrorism law that Mr. Clinton signed last year without alienating America's key allies, just at the moment he is trying to get their cooperation on a common policy toward Iran and other rogue states. Yet the failure to use the law, in its first test case, could make the White House look weak when its sanctions policy has been confused at best. 
 If Mr. Clinton imposes the toughest sanctions available -- a threat the State Department and the White House carefully avoided making today -- Mr. Clinton will re-open the battle with the European Union that began over American penalties against foreign companies that use formerly American property in Cuba.
But this time the repercussions will be far greater. In addition to the French, who are longtime adversaries on how to deal with Iran, the President would have to act against the two other major companies in the transaction. One of them, Gazprom, is the most powerful corporation in Russia, once headed by the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. He is still thought to be a major shareholder in the company.
The other company is Petronas, Malaysia's state-dominated energy enterprise. Only last week, Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, accused the United States and other great powers of using economic muscle to undercut his nation's currency and keep it from becoming a major economic competitor. Clearly, it would not ruin Mr. Mahathir's day to defy America's foreign policy goals in relation to Iran.
If, on the other hand, the President seeks the diplomatic way out, imposing light sanctions or none at all, he runs the risk of undercutting his own commitment to use all powers available to him to fight state-sponsored terrorism. His declarations about getting the world community together on the issue could ring hollow.
"It would send a message," said one of Mr. Clinton's advisers, who is pushing the Administration to take a tough line "that we will jaw-bone about terrorism, but we're not willing to go to the mat with our trading partners about it."
The State Department and its Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, Stuart E. Eizenstat, have spent much of the last year trying to deflect such choices by tamping down disputes over Washington's right to impose such sanctions. This spring, Mr. Eizenstat defused, at least temporarily, the argument with the European Union and Canada over invoking the Helms-Burton Act, which requires the United States to punish foreign companies that use what was once American property in Cuba.
The Europeans were on the verge of challenging the American law in front of the World Trade Organization, where many outside experts guess the United States might well lose. Under a deal brokered last spring, that case was deferred until at least Oct. 15 while the two sides try to work out a face-saving compromise, one that the Europeans say must include a way to keep the United States from extra-territorial applications of its law.
Cuba, however, was a case where big principles were at stake, not big money. In Iran, both principle and huge potential profits are in the mix, and that changes the politics considerably.
All three of the countries taking part in the deal with Iran see it as an opportunity to gain access to a huge undersea gas field without having to compete with American energy companies, which have all been barred from involvement since 1995, when President Clinton forced Conoco, Inc. to back away from a major oil deal with the Iranian Government.
Last year Congress passed the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act. The law provides the Secretary of State and the President with choices ranging from waiving all sanctions to imposing relatively minor penalties to barring the offending companies from trading with the United States.
Today, the State Department spokesman, James Rubin, and the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, gave no hint of what choice Mr. Clinton may make. A senior State Department official said "this could still take several weeks," because "if we are going to be in the position of issuing sanctions, we want to be sure of our facts," adding, "And it is not as if any of the signatories in this deal are likely to send us a copy of the contract."
To bridge the gap, the State Department will undoubtedly talk about how France and the United States are committed to a common goal: fighting terrorism. They simply have different strategic approaches, one arguing for economic isolation of Iran, the other for economic engagement. The American position is not aided by the appearance of inconsistency. In the cases of Mexico and China, it has argued that the best way to get a country to crack down on drug dealers, for example, or let up on dissidents, is to keep doing business there. In the cases of Cuba and Myanmar, formerly Burma, it has argued that America's economic power should be used to cut off investment until the offending government changes its behavior.
The French, at least, are clearly eager use this case to make the point that Washington is free to use its economic muscle to force its own companies to comply with American foreign policy, but that power cannot extend across its borders.
"Nobody accepts that the United States can pass a law on a global scale," Lionel Jospin, France's Prime Minister, said today. "If not, the world would be a different place, and we would no longer be the old independent nation that we are."

HEADLINE: Iraq and Iran Tempt World Energy Industry

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
On any evening in the last three years, a visitor to Baghdad, Iraq's capital, could spot senior officials of the French oil company, Total S.A., in the lounge of the plush Al-Rasheed Hotel where they have permanent suites.
Similarly, all around Teheran, French oil experts can be encountered in the luxurious restaurants of Shemiran, the northern suburb of the Iranian capital where the air is clearer and where oil companies of every nationality keep their executives in villas equipped with swimming pools. 
 "How can any major oil company in the world ignore Iran or Iraq?" asked Walid Khadduri, executive editor of the Cyprus-based Middle East Economic Survey, a prestigious energy newsletter, in a telephone interview tonight. "Iran has the second-largest gas reserves after Russia. Iraq is sitting atop the second largest oil reserves in the world after Saudi Arabia."
"Oil companies are in the business of exploring, finding, producing and buying oil and gas," Mr. Khadduri said, referring to the major national gas deal Total signed with Iran on Sunday. "It is their raison d'etre. From an oil company point of view, maintaining a relationship with these two giants is basic strategy, not to mention common sense."
France's $2 billion agreement with the National Iranian Oil Company to produce 2 billion cubic feet of natural gas from the South Pars field has been in the making for some years, oil industry officials said tonight, despite the United States' so-called "dual containment" strategy, which is intended to isolate the two countries and quash their main source of revenue: Selling oil and gas.
Indeed, the announcement of the huge deal has raised questions as to whether Washington's policy of economic sanctions to isolate countries like Iraq, Iran, Libya, Cuba and others has been effective beyond preventing American companies from tapping those countries' resources while competitors, mostly from Europe and Asia, help themselves.
Oil industry experts say even though the world, at the moment, is sufficiently supplied with oil, the demand curve in the future is rising, indicating that sooner, rather than later, a new global shortage is likely. This is especially so as large, churning economies like those of China and India continue to expand, implying greater consumption of electricity, new cars on the roads and higher standards of living with more home appliances consuming more energy. It is this knowledge that drives oil companies to forge ties with giants like Iran and Iraq.
Indeed, Total announced today that it was on the verge of signing an oil production agreement with Iraq to exploit the giant Nahr Umar oil field in the south, as soon as "the United Nations lifts the embargo" imposed on the country after it invaded Kuwait in 1990. At last count, Mr. Khadduri pointed out, "Sixty companies are negotiating oil deals with Iraq at the moment," all to be executed when the embargo is lifted.
Last year and this year, Russia and China signed deals to tap Iraqi oil fields, with few objections by the United States, presumably because both said they would respect the United Nations embargo. Russia will develop the West Qurna oil field, Iraq's largest oil pool. China will concentrate on the Ahdab field near Kut, also in oil-rich southern Iraq.
But signing a deal means that experts are working on the fields even if production does not physically begin. It also means investments flowing into the country in hard currency along with equipment and employment opportunities.
The principal lure of Iraq, experts point out, is that it possesses 110 billion barrels of proven oil reserves. That puts it right behind Saudi Arabia. Similarly, oil companies have been swarming all over Iran.
After the Clinton Administration forced the Conoco oil company to cancel a huge deal with Iran 3 years ago over developing the Sirri oil and gas field, Total took it over. Companies from Italy, Germany, Austria, Japan and other Asian countries are most active in Iran, driven by the recognition that its gas reserves are needed by many of its neighbors, including Turkey, Pakistan, India and eventually, Europe, which at the moment depends on Algerian, Russian, Norwegian and Dutch gas but is interested in diversifying its sources.
All of which leaves the American strategy of "dual containment" against Iraq and Iran -- in addition to the pressure exerted against Libya, another energy supplier -- appear to be increasingly ineffective.
As more countries, including allies of the United States, perceive economic sanctions as punishing them, it has become obvious in the last three years that American dictates have little resonance, particularly because they run counter to globalization of the world economy, a concept also promoted by Washington.
"The thing about this containment policy is that it is slipping everywhere," said Mehdi Verzi, senior oil analyst for Kleinwort Benson, the London investment concern, in an interview tonight. "You cannot ignore a country like Iran with 60 million people and three times the proven gas reserves of the United States itself," Mr. Verzi said. "The sheer economic logic of using Iran as a transit route by its neighbors to transport oil and gas is overcoming political obstacles caused by U.S. sanctions legislation," he added.
Oil industry officials interviewed tonight said there are probably as many oil companies negotiating with Iran now as there are talking with Iraq. One senior official in a major oil company who insisted on anonymity said companies talking with Iran "will not reveal themselves" in order not to provoke Washington. "But you can be sure they are talking and dealing," he asserted. Those dealing with Iraq, including Total, admit it, but say that they will only start producing once United Nations sanctions are lifted.

HEADLINE: The Place for the Aspiring Dot Com;
Internet Industry's Most Popular Address Is Manhattan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The stereotyped symbol of New York City's Internet industry is an ultracool, twenty-something cyberhead with a tattoo and a skateboard, plotting the overthrow of Microsoft from a fifth-floor walk-up on East 10th Street.
The reality looks more like Benjamin Colas. Mr. Colas, a 24-year-old advertising executive who favors open-neck white shirts and dark slacks ("casual but elegant," as he put it), helped create a new home page on the Internet's World Wide Web for Tide detergent. From his 13th-floor office at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in Manhattan, he plots the overthrow of Fab and Wisk. 
 For New York, selling soap in cyberspace may be only the beginning.
The city is emerging, communications experts say, as one of the national centers of the rapidly evolving Internet industry -- not because of what is new or on its way, but because of what is already here. A lot of the style of this new industry, dubbed Silicon Alley, may be new, but the muscle behind it is not. Established New York industries, especially advertising, publishing, fashion and design -- all based on communication and presentation -- are now leading much of the expansion of the new technologies, creating a potential for thousands of new jobs for the city into the next century.
Mr. Colas, for example, is the managing director of a new Saatchi & Saatchi subsidiary called Darwin Digital that was formed in July to help clients like Procter & Gamble, the Cincinnati-based company that makes Tide, exploit the Internet. Darwin's start-up staff of 6 has quadrupled to 25. Barnes & Noble has more than 100 employees in New York working specifically on the corporate Web site it launched this spring; almost all of them are editors and writers supplying things like book reviews, what in the jargon of the Web is called content. The jewelry store Van Cleef & Arpels, on the other hand, finds that one employee working part time on its Web site is sufficient. Small World Software, a Manhattan-based company that creates and runs corporate Web sites, has grown to 25 employees from 3 in three years.
"People ask us why we set up shop in New York," said Mark Jacobstein, a founder of Small World. "The answer, beyond the fact that we love living here and this is where the talent is, is that this is where the clients are."
A recent study by New York University said that New York has also charged ahead faster than any other city in the nation in embracing computer communications as a tool of business. The study found that at the beginning of the year, New York had more than 17,000 registered commercial and nonprofit Internet "domains," twice as many as its nearest rival, San Francisco, and 4.2 percent of the national total. San Francisco has the most addresses per capita, with New York second. Domains are essentially networks of Web pages and E-mail routing systems.
The study said that while New York shows few signs of supplanting the San Francisco Bay Area as the national center for technical innovation or programming, New York's potential niche nonetheless remains vast. Its publishing and design industries can take the lead as suppliers of content; its advertising industry, as a creator of commercial sales techniques.
"What it says is that this city has more to gain from the Web than other places," said Mitchell L. Moss, an author of the study and the director of the university's Taub Urban Research Center, which conducted it.
That a new industrial sector could grow up in one place, serving a disembodied cyberspace realm that glories in existing nowhere at all, is just one paradox posed by the Internet industry in New York. Another is that many of the jobs being generated by the marriage of computers and commerce have little or nothing to do with traditional computer work, like the development of hardware and software, and so are not being counted as such by economists or local and state governments.
Officials at the New York State Department of Labor said they cannot tell how many people work in the Internet content business because no industrial classification exists for them. The numbers of traditional computer and data processing workers in New York City has certainly grown, up more than 86 percent over the last five years, according to state figures, to about 28,000 at the end of last year. But that increase has also been fueled by hiring in other industries, especially securities firms, as Wall Street has become more computer-driven.
Mr. Jacobstein said the more important trend for the city is that many of the new jobs he sees being created do not involve the technical running of corporate Web sites, but rather keeping them stocked with new material. Corporations are increasingly realizing, he said, that Web sites and domains are not billboards that are created once and forgotten -- common in the earlier stages of the Web -- but continuing enterprises that need constant updating and links to the outside world, especially to advertising. That means, he said, the industry is increasingly requiring a whole nexus of talents and industries different from those it began with. Technology, it seems, is just the starting place.
Darwin Digital, the Saatchi & Saatchi unit, for example, has also helped Procter & Gamble launch a joint venture with Time Warner at the address Parenttime.com. The project merges the media company's child-care magazine division with an integrated advertising package supplied by Procter & Gamble -- all created and run from New York. The company also helped create a new network for children's games on the Internet. The sponsor, General Mills, the cereal company based in Minneapolis, came to New York to make it work.
There is little evidence that New York is becoming any kind of national center for computer operations, the technical side of the industry. With the global reach of telecommunications, an Internet domain registered in New York can be operated by computers -- called Web servers -- almost anywhere on the planet. Of the 10,500 domains that were running this summer in the 10 Manhattan ZIP codes with the highest domain concentrations, only 3,000 were being run by Web-server computers in Manhattan, according to Internet.org, an Internet business information company in Pittsburgh that worked with New York University on its study.
But the technical operation of a company's Web sites is also the one that generates the fewest new jobs, industry experts say. Many systems, once running, can more or less operate on autopilot unless there is a power failure, telecommunications breakdown or some other error.
Being ahead in a single snapshot moment is, of course, a fleeting thing in the exploding, evanescent world of computer-based communications. In many ways, telecommunications experts say, the New York University study was dated and to some degree obsolete from the moment of its completion. The number of new domains being registered nationally, which was running at about 10,000 a month last year, has surged to nearly 100,000 a month this year, according to Network Solutions Inc., which monitors and registers new domain names.
But New York also appears to be holding its own, at least for the moment. Between January and the end of May, the number of domains nationally more than doubled, from 418,089 to 1.13 million, according to figures from Internet.org. The number in New York increased, but not quite as fast, to 41,156. The city's share of the national total thus fell slightly, to 3.6 percent.
"I think it shows that to us that New York is the information capital," said Michael Bauer, the president of Internet.org. "While Silicon Valley is clearly the software capital, in New York, content is king."
